HEADLINE: Terror's Money Trail 

BYLINE:  By William F. Wechsler; William F. Wechsler was director for transnational threats at the National Security Council from 1996 to 1999.

DATELINE: WESTPORT, Conn. 

 BODY:
President Bush has just stepped up efforts against the international financial network that provides the lifeblood for Osama bin Laden and his Al Qaeda terrorist organization. He is setting up an interagency Foreign Terrorist Asset Tracking Center and has signed an executive order to cut off terrorists and their supporters from the United States economy. These are good first steps, but much more will have to be done.
 We should begin by recognizing what we're dealing with. It is wrong to think of Al Qaeda as being financed primarily by Mr. bin Laden. If there were a single source of financing, the problem would be much easier to solve. More important is Al Qaeda's global network of financial donors, Muslim charities, legal and illegal businesses, and underground money transfer businesses. 
 We should also recognize what can't be accomplished by targeting the financial network alone. Such actions will not, by themselves, strike a death blow to Al Qaeda. Here in the United States, we have been going after organized crime's financial network ever since we convicted Al Capone for tax evasion. But organized crime still exists. Nonetheless, by disrupting the criminal financial network, we will force Al Qaeda to take time and money to rebuild it -- and in the process help obstruct terrorist operations.
In the United States, we have strong anti-money-laundering laws and bank regulations. But virtually none of this exists where Al Qaeda raises and moves most of its money -- namely in predominantly Muslim countries where banking systems are underregulated and in the informal hawala banking system that is almost completely unregulated around the globe, including in this country. 
The administration should now make broader use of the International Emergency Economic Powers Act, the law cited by President Bush in his executive order. That law allows the federal government to threaten to cut off foreign governments and institutions from the American economy if they do not take action against the Al Qaeda financial network or cooperate in giving the United States information on terrorist financing. 
This strategy was adopted by the Clinton administration after the terrorist attacks on the American embassies in East Africa in 1998, when President Clinton signed similar executive orders against Al Qaeda and the Taliban government in Afghanistan. In some instances, it worked. The efforts helped ground the Afghan national airline, making it harder for Al Qaeda to move resources back and forth from Afghanistan. But over all, we had only limited success. In some cases, foreign governments lacked political will. In other cases, the governments had little ability to help because they had no system to combat money laundering or to audit fund-raising organizations. In the wake of the recent attacks and greater attention to charities that provide direct fund-raising links between Al Qaeda and societies in the Middle East, the Bush administration may be more effective in pressuring other governments. 
Clamping down on terrorists' finances will also require Congress to act. In addition to its powers under existing law, the federal government needs the ability to cut off rogue banks without having to prove publicly a direct connection to terrorists. Unfortunately, a bipartisan bill that would have allowed sanctions against countries and banks that operate as money-laundering havens was stopped last year by Senator Phil Gramm. That bill has been reintroduced this year and new hearings are scheduled for today. The legislation is more necessary now than ever. 
Congress also needs to make sure that we are fighting all forms of terrorist fund-raising at home by expanding anti-money-laundering regulations to cover securities brokers, casinos and the underground hawala system here at home.
Efforts to take down terrorist groups through military actions will probably take longer than we appreciate. Dismantling terrorism's financial network could take even more time -- which is good reason to start now.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE WHITE HOUSE; 
Bush Steps Up Appeal to Afghans To Rid Their Country of Taliban

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH BUMILLER and THOM SHANKER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 

 BODY:
President Bush came close to telling the Afghan people today to overthrow the Taliban government, encouraging them to rid Afghanistan of what he called "an incredibly repressive" administration. 
 Mr. Bush, answering questions at the White House, said the best way to bring those responsible for the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks to justice was "to ask for the cooperation of citizens within Afghanistan who may be tired of having the Taliban in place." 
 But an hour after Mr. Bush spoke, the White House press secretary, Ari Fleischer, interpreted the president's remarks as stopping short of a call for toppling a sovereign state. The planned military action in the region, Mr. Fleischer said, "is not designed to replace one regime with another regime." 
The administration, which has been critical of "nation building" missions for the United States military, appeared to be trying to walk a fine line between increasing pressure on the Taliban, who have given refuge to Osama bin Laden, the accused terrorist, and finding itself enmeshed in an eventual attempt to rebuild the ruined state of Afghanistan under a new government.
Washington has accused Mr. bin Laden and his Al Qaeda network of terrorists of being responsible for the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. Last week, the president said the Taliban had to "hand over the terrorists or they will share their fate."
Since the attacks, the administration has stepped up contacts with the Northern Alliance, a loose anti-Taliban coalition that controls 10 percent of Afghanistan. But any attempt to install the alliance in Kabul would be fiercely opposed by Pakistan, whose support is essential for United States military plans. Page B5. 
The president seemed mindful of that. While calling on Afghans to cooperate against the Taliban, he said he was not interested in creating a government to replace the Taliban should it fall as a result of American military strikes or internal unrest.
"We're not into nation building," he said. "We're focused on justice."
How it would be possible in practice for the United States to engage in military action that might lead to the downfall of a government without taking any interest in its successor was not immediately clear.
In his presidential campaign, Mr. Bush and his advisers dismissed the military and foreign policy goals of the Clinton administration as "nation building," which they characterized as a doomed effort to impose American values on countries unequipped to handle them.
Nevertheless, the question of what happens in Afghanistan if the Taliban falls or if military action drives millions of refugees toward the borders is urgent. But Mr. Bush made it clear today that he was not yet prepared to address that in detail.
His remarks echoed those of his national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice, who said on Sunday that the Afghans would be "better off" without the Taliban government.
American military and intelligence officers in the region are working with opposition groups to prepare military action, gather intelligence and pressure the Taliban.
Pentagon planners said today that one concern was that a huge refugee flow out of Afghanistan could undermine the shaky government of neighboring Pakistan, which Washington expects will play a crucial role in any direct action against the Taliban.
Pakistan's situation was among the themes of closed briefings for House and Senate members by Secretary of State Colin L. Powell and Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld this afternoon. Some members who attended said the administration was clearly grappling with the unintended consequences of the military options under consideration.
In a public briefing at the Pentagon, Mr. Rumsfeld picked up those themes and described an impoverished Afghanistan riven by political, military and ethnic rivalries that could undermine the Taliban from within. But he also noted America's responsibility to help ease the suffering of its civilians.
"There are many Afghan people who are being starved, who are fleeing for their lives," Mr. Rumsfeld said, "and it's just a terrible shame, and we have to do everything possible we can from a humanitarian standpoint to see that their lives are made better than they currently are by the Taliban government and by the circumstance they're living in." 
Not all Taliban members agree with its senior leadership's actions for "creating a hospitable environment for Al Qaeda," he said. Among the opposition, the Northern Alliance is engaged in an armed struggle to unseat the Taliban, the secretary said, and tribes in the south might be coaxed into cooperation.
Much of Mr. Rumsfeld's briefing was devoted to describing the complicated campaign against terrorism, a war without a formal opening or ending, and one that will not be without American casualties. The campaign against terrorists who threaten America "will not be an antiseptic war," Mr. Rumsfeld said.
The Pentagon has increased the number of warships and planes in easy striking distance of Afghanistan. But Mr. Rumsfeld's comments and those of other senior officials made it clear that the opening stage of the campaign was highly unlikely to be a decisive bombing or missile attack on Afghan targets or a major ground operation. The emphasis is coordinating strikes with other efforts to squeeze operations, especially with law enforcement to crack terrorist cells and with the drive on Mr. bin Laden's financial network.
The Pentagon also announced today the call-up of additional Reserve and National Guard troops, bringing to 14,000 the number mobilized since the attacks. Mr. Rumsfeld has been authorized to activate up to 50,000 guard and reserve troops.
Also today, Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi of Japan pledged his country's support in the fight against terrorism, in contrast to Japan's neutrality in the Persian Gulf war. The Japanese offered intelligence and logistical assistance to the United States, a step that lets Japan stay within the bounds of its postwar constitutional ban on collective self-defense. They also pledged $40 million in aid to Pakistan.
The White House announced that although Mr. Bush will attend the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation Leaders Meeting in Shanghai from Oct. 20 to Oct. 21, as planned, he will not visit Tokyo, Seoul and Beijing.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi of Japan, with President Bush in the Rose Garden, pledged his country's support in the fight on terrorism. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)(pg. B6)

HEADLINE: A Nation Challenged 

 BODY:

On the Diplomatic Front

BUSH APPEALS TO AFGHANS
President Bush came close to telling the Afghan people to overthrow the Taliban government, encouraging them to rid Afghanistan of what he called "an incredibly repressive" regime. But an hour after Mr. Bush spoke, the White House press secretary interpreted the president's remarks as stopping short of a call for toppling a sovereign state. A1

RIPPLES IN THE U.S. COALITION
Pakistan made clear it would oppose any plan to couple an American-led military thrust into Afghanistan with moves for a new government to replace the Taliban. B5

A VIEW FROM THE REBEL CAMP
The foreign minister of Afghanistan's rebel coalition says the United States should coordinate attacks with the rebel alliance. B4

SAUDI TIES WITH TALIBAN CUT
Saudi Arabia announced that it was severing diplomatic ties with the Taliban government of Afghanistan. B5

A PRICE FOR RUSSIAN SUPPORT
In an indication of the price Western nations may be ready to pay for Russian support against terrorism, Gerhard Schroder, the German chancellor, said the world should moderate its view of Moscow's actions in Chechnya. B6

A MISSION TO IRAN
Britain's foreign secretary, Jack Straw, met senior Iranian leaders as part of a flurry of diplomacy aimed at gaining cooperation and perhaps intelligence from Iran. B5

Fallout From the Attacks

A BAN ON ONE-PASSENGER CARS
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said that because of traffic jams that have spread for miles as a result of security checks, police would begin barring cars with only one occupant from entering Midtown and Lower Manhattan on weekday mornings. A1

NEW YORK JOB LOSS WILL BE STEEP
More than 100,000 people who have worked in New York City probably will find themselves unemployed, at least temporarily, as a result of the World Trade Center disaster, according to federal and state government estimates. B8

CHECKING WATER SUPPLIES
Cities and states are reassessing the safety of their drinking water, probing for weaknesses and shoring up defenses in what experts consider the unlikely event of a terrorist attack on water supplies. Yet experts say any threat to public water supplies remains largely remote. B7

The Investigation

WERE DIFFERENT ATTACKS PLANNED?
About 20 of the people arrested after the Sept. 11 attacks had obtained or tried to obtain special driver's licenses allowing them to transport explosives, poisons or other types of hazardous materials, federal officials said. The authorities are investigating whether these men may have been part of a terrorist plot. A1

SOME PEOPLE ARE RELEASED
Two weeks into the biggest manhunt in history, federal authorities have released several people. B3

A THREAT TO WORLD LEADERS
The president of Egypt and the deputy prime minister of Italy have both said that they were aware of a threat from Osama bin Laden's network of Islamic terrorists to kill President Bush and other leaders of the industrialized world when they met at a summit meeting in Genoa in July. B1

POSSIBLE LINK TO AL QAEDA
German investigators said that they believe there are links between two of the terrorists who carried out this month's attack on the United States and the Osama bin Laden organization, Al Qaeda. B2

TALIBAN SAID TO USE DRUG MONEY
The Taliban government in Afghanistan has earned tens of millions of dollars from the export of heroin and other narcotics since it proclaimed last year that it was putting an end to opium poppy cultivation, American officials say. B4

A CHARITY TAKES UMBRAGE
In ever needy Afghanistan, Al Rashid Trust is one of the biggest doers of good deeds. Among the destitute, this Islamic charity is considered a blessing, and so it was hardly surprising that the organization took umbrage at being included on President Bush's list of suspected Islamic terrorist groups and individuals whose assets should be frozen. B2

The Nation's Response

SKEPTICISM TOWARD ARMING PILOTS
The president of a pilots' union testified that his members should be allowed to take an FBI training course and be deputized as federal law enforcement officers, which would let them carry guns in the cockpit. But the idea drew skepticism from some other aviation experts and members of Congress. B7

PILOTS ON THE OFFENSIVE
After decades of training to respond passively to hijackers' demands, pilots and their employers are now adopting a more aggressive stance as potential soldiers in America's new war. B1

A MYSTERIOUS, ELITE UNIT
Unexplained disappearances of young men in communites near Fort Bragg leads to speculation that special forces units are being deployed. B1

A NEW NAME FOR MISSION
Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld renamed the war against terrorism "Operation Enduring Freedom." The original title, "Operation Infinite Justice," was scratched for upsetting Islamic sensibilities. B3

The Nation's Mood

SKITTISH SKIES
For air travelers and flight crews, there seems to be no such thing as an overreaction in the days since Sept. 11. B7

VISIONS FOR REBUILDING
Even as the grief continues over the destruction of the World Trade Center, proposals are coming in on what the site and the city around it should become. B1

EAGER ASSISTANCE FOR VICTIMS
Inside the Family Assistance Center at Pier 94, where bereaved relatives and surviving workers of the World Trade Center attacks are being urged to seek help, it is as though the welfare state had stumbled into paradise. B9

REPRIEVE FOR A SQUAD
The New York Fire Department decides against disbanding Squad 1 in Brooklyn, which lost 12 of its 27 firefighters in the Sept. 11 attack. B10

HEADLINE: THE NEW YORK PRIMARY: VOICES; 
A Shift in the Ritual, and Meaning, of Voting

BYLINE:  By MIRTA OJITO

 BODY:
Marjorie Severence, from Queens, voted in a primary election yesterday for the first time in her life. She is 67, and said it just felt urgent and relevant to vote now.
 But Monica Watson, 29, from Brooklyn, did not go to the polls, because to spend time electing a leader no longer seemed important to her. 
 David Stypmann, at 63, a lifelong Democrat from Manhattan, was surprised to find himself writing Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's name on the ballot. 
All over the city yesterday, from Forest Hills to Flatbush to SoHo, the decisions New Yorkers made to go to the polls, or not to go, and even whom to vote for, seemed to be fueled by perceptions, attitudes and opinions forged in the last 14 days, since the attack on the World Trade Center.
Voting became an act of defiance, a way of saying "this is still who we are," said Margaret Manos, a freelance editor in Battery Park City. Or it became a painful rite, a way to carry on while everything else, from personal security to economic stability, seemed so uncertain and remote.
"I still have a lot of questions about this election," said Robin Bergstrom, a lawyer who voted in Park Slope, Brooklyn, shortly before 8 a.m. "But it's important to me to look back at this moment and have the history books report that, despite what happened, New York had one of the biggest turnouts ever. If we've learned nothing else from the attacks, it's that we've taken our freedoms and our right to vote for granted for too long. They really matter."
John Camacho, a consultant on international joint ventures, said he had voted on Sept. 11, but that doing so again yesterday felt more meaningful.
"I have always voted," said Mr. Camacho, 36, "but it has a little bit more meaning now. It's more of a calling now, to continue on, to not let things change, to not panic or heed to the terror."
Even those who voted for the candidate they had chosen before Sept. 11 said that, in sticking to plans they had made before the attack, they were making a political choice not to allow outside events change their cherished views.
"I don't buy into nationalism or patriotism," said Nina Lavin, a jewelry designer who lives seven blocks north of the World Trade Center and saw the towers collapse from her windows. "But I do respect our Constitution and I'm not going to allow anyone to push the panic buttons for me and tell me the only man for the job is Rudy Giuliani."
Decisions did not come easy yesterday. Some people were anxious, confused and even angry that they were being asked to choose a new leader so soon after the destruction of the twin towers. 
"I came out early this morning, hoping that showing up would help me make up my mind about who to vote for," said Bonnie Boyle, a 42-year-old caterer, who intended to vote before going to work yesterday. "But I still can't decide. I'm just not ready."
Ms. Boyle, a Democrat who lives in the Kensington section of Brooklyn, said she planned to return to the polling place after work, once she has had time to scan news articles about each of the candidates.
"I have a lot of reading to do," she said. "I don't want to just vote for anyone. I want my vote to count." 
Still others found themselves making choices that they would never have thought possible two weeks ago. 
For almost 30 years, David Stypmann, who owns an antiques shop in SoHo, has voted for Democrats in New York City elections. He says he has little patience for Republican candidates and no tolerance for politically conservative people.
But on Monday, on the eve of the primary election, Mr. Stypmann happened to watch the "Late Show With David Letterman," which he says he never does.
The first guest that night was Mr. Giuliani, who talked about rebuilding and carrying on. It made Mr. Stypmann cry.
"He was so humble, so human," he said. "I've never been a fan of the man, but I was overwhelmed by his words."
Yesterday, Mr. Stypmann wrote Mr. Giuliani's name on his election ballot.
Anthony Rainey, 39, a graduate student of anthropology who lives in the West Village, was astonished that, for the first time ever, he voted for two people in the same election in the span of two weeks.
On Sept. 11, the day the primary election was supposed to take place, Mr. Rainey voted for Mark Green, a Democrat. When terrorists crashed two passenger planes into the trade center, Mr. Rainey's wife, a bond trader, lost scores of colleagues. Nothing has been the same since, he said.
So yesterday, wearing a red, white and blue ribbon on the lapel of his jacket, Mr. Rainey went to the polls to write in Mr. Giuliani's name.
"I've been struggling with this decision a lot today," Mr. Rainey said. "It's not something I take lightly and it is not a symbolic gesture. In times of war and crisis, laws ought to be changed for the benefit of the citizens."
Angry about all the talk of a third Giuliani term, Sandra Cergeant woke up early and cast her vote for Mr. Green. 
"It's not fair that he would even consider using this tragedy to seek another term," said Ms. Cergeant, 41, a paralegal from Canarsie. "I don't think he's done anything exceptional, besides what is already his job as mayor. He rose to the occasion. That's what leaders are supposed to do. Why should we be asked to change the law to suit one person? That's not democracy. He had his turn. Now it's time for someone new to rise."
For Liz Savage, 40, a waitress, the election has become an incomprehensible puzzle.
She is a New York native who has lived in Greenwich Village for 10 years, but she decided not to vote yesterday because she could not make up her mind. All of a sudden, the job of mayor became so crucial for the city that, she said, none of the candidates were qualified to take it on.
"Rather than make an uneducated guess, I decided not to vote," she said. "Guessing doesn't seem very fair in this particular election."
Jo Ann Morris, a 52-year-old retired manager who lives in the Bronx, said she could not understand people who did not vote in this election, which she considered pivotal for the city. She voted for Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx Borough president.
"We have to keep going," she said. "And I have to have my say."
But in a stark illustration of how torn voters were yesterday, Mrs. Morris said that her husband, a retired correction officer, chose not to vote. He had grown disenchanted with the candidates, she said, even though he had planned on casting his vote before the attack on the World Trade Center.
"He stayed home," she said. "No one on the list stood out."

CORRECTION-DATE: September 27, 2001

 CORRECTION:
Because of a production error, the opening page of The Metro Section yesterday, with an article about the mood of voters, omitted a full name in some copies for a 42-year-old Brooklyn caterer who was still researching her decision on Primary Day. She is Bonnie Boyle. 
The opening section of an article about the results of the Nassau County primary election was also omitted from some copies. It is available on the Web at www.nytimes.com/pages/nyregion /metrocampaigns.

HEADLINE: HUMAN NATURE; 
Fertile Soil For New Crop Of Farmers

BYLINE:  By ANNE RAVER

DATELINE: BURLINGTON, Vt. 

 BODY:
WHEN Will Raap came here 20 years ago, he was an urban planner looking for a city that hadn't forgotten its farms. Growing up in Fremont, Calif., he lived near fruit farms. "Now, it's all malled," he said. "There are no farms left."
 The first time Mr. Raap, 52, saw the Intervale, a fertile 700-acre flood plain here, it had become a dumping ground for junked cars and old washing machines. One lone farmer, Rena Calkins, then in her 80's, herded cows up the lane in her old pickup. 
 All that has changed. Leading the way through a patchwork of lush gardens early this month, Mr. Raap described how the Intervale got back in the business of producing food for this city of 40,000 -- living proof that crops can be raised without chemicals while reviving a way of life so rare it draws tourists.
Burlington is home to an economically and socially diverse community, which includes the University of Vermont and high-tech companies, as well as immigrants from Asia, Bosnia and Sudan, who arrived in the last decade. A third of the city's households have incomes of less than $25,000.
"For us, the Intervale is about food, energy and enterprise," Mr. Raap said. He noted that the United States is "consuming five or ten times our share of the world's resources," and said that sustainable agriculture -- community-based farming, which emphasizes recycling and de-emphasizes petrochemicals -- could go a long way toward teaching Americans to save resources.
At a harvest fair on Sept. 8, Mr. Raap savored fish and chips made with fresh-dug organic potatoes and fish raised in a greenhouse environment designed by John Todd, a biologist at the university. Mr. Todd has devised ways to use plants and biological organisms to clean waste and raise produce. His greenhouse at the Intervale raises warm-water fish and hydroponic tomatoes. With projects like this, "no one is going to become a millionaire," Mr. Raap said, "but it might all be sustainable." Along with City Hall, which provides land and other help, the Intervale runs an incubator farmers' program to train farmers, some of them raising Asian vegetables, and some distributing free food to the needy.
In the mid-1970's Mr. Raap spent time with E. F. Schumacher, the small-is-beautiful economist, and also lived at Findhorn, the alternative community in northern Scotland -- "a crazy quilt of musicians, artists and planners trying to build an ecological community with their own food and their own energy," Mr. Raap said. Findhorn, he noted, was "a response to the energy crisis and an early reaction to globalization." He met his wife, Lynette Navez, there. 
When the couple got to Burlington, they saw opportunity where others saw sludge being dumped on abandoned fields, a wood-burning power plant belching steam into the air and a deserted slaughterhouse. Bernie Sanders, a Brooklyn-born socialist, had just been elected mayor. Ben Cohen and Jerry Greenfield had set up their first ice cream shop across from City Hall. 
In 1983, Mr. Raap founded the Gardener's Supply mail-order company. Two years later, when the Burlington Electric Company put out a call for proposals for uses of its waste steam heat, he unsuccessfully proposed piping it into new greenhouses. He did succeed, however, in getting a community development grant for another idea: a compost operation on city-owned land, to turn yard and food waste, spent grain from breweries in the area and milk curds from Ben & Jerry's factories into black gold. 
The compost project took off, and so did Gardener's Supply, with sales last year of $45 million. In 1988, Mr. Raap began the Intervale Foundation, which is supported with about 10 percent of Gardener's Supply's profits. The foundation provides technical assistance and below-market rents on land and equipment and has helped about 20 farmers strike out on their own.
Ann-Elise Johnson, 24, a first-year farmer in the program, has 100 hens in a big pen she moves every week to a fresh section of her rented pasture. Last week, they were greedily pecking at a pile of over-ripe red and yellow tomatoes from Maggie's Tomato Patch, another farm in the Intervale. "If everyone starts to buy locally, we could start conserving energy and improve the local economy," she said.
The foundation also recycles profits from the compost operation, which yields 9,000 tons of compost a year and $60,000 for training new farmers. In a collaboration with Mr. Todd, farmers are also experimenting with things like growing mushrooms on spent grain and raising perch and bait fish on red worms raised on food waste. The foundation supplies about $700,000 worth of food, distributing 20,000 pounds a year to low-income families, said David Lane, the executive director.
And now it has plans for Eco-park, a $3 million complex resembling a crystal palace, to harness at last the power plant's waste steam, heating greenhouselike buildings on 300 acres of city-owned land. The city helped arrange a $1 million Economic Development Administration federal grant for construction, scheduled to begin in the spring. Eco-park will provide low-cost space to food-related businesses. In a closed loop, Vermont Soy could make tofu from organic soybeans grown at the Intervale, Mr. Lane said. The waste from the tofu production could be fed to red worms, which in turn could feed the fish.
Resource conservation is already a driving principle. Erik Wells, another beginning farmer, showed off lightweight portable hoop houses, which are used to raise chickens at the Intervale. "We get them to fresh pasture, where they can eat grubs and get fresh air and sunlight," he said. Before slaughter, the chickens also fertilize the fields.
On a gorgeous day in nearby Starksboro, Julie Rubaud and Eric Rozendaal, graduates of the incubator program, were talking about their new 108-acre farm. Mr. Rozendaal tossed a rutabaga from hand to hand as he recalled the drought that frizzled his carrot seedlings and the worries of getting his crew to pick fast enough. "When I'm out in this field in the summer, I wonder, Why do I want to do this?" he said. "But on a day like this, I start thinking about next year."

HEADLINE: STATE OF THE ART; 
Cellphones For a Song, Just in Case

BYLINE:  By David Pogue 

 BODY:
THE malls of America are a lot less crowded these days. But there's one fascinating exception: phone centers, which are doing a thriving business. 
 Many of the new customers are what cellphone companies call glovebox users -- people who have no intention of walking around downtown with a handset grafted to their temples but who simply want to keep a phone in the glove compartment for emergency use. In the new national mood of vulnerability, a lot of people are grasping for whatever straws of security they can find. 
 Not all of them are phone shopping in anticipation of another skyline-changing cataclysm, of course. But "just in case" and "be prepared" have more urgent meanings these days, even if the emergencies are the same ones that have always made cellphones attractive: car breakdowns, power failures in cordless-phone-only homes, orchestrating pickups of children. Nor is the cellphone useful only when it's your own emergency. When you're a witness to an accident or crime, the cellphone lets you fulfill your civic duty by calling for help. (On any cellphone, 911 calls are free and never use up monthly minutes.) 
For many cell-less Americans, the greatest impediment to signing up for a phone is the cost. Monthly cellphone fees average $45 and can run as high as $200. With a little digging, however, it's possible to uncover much more economical deals for the infrequent user.
Here, for example, is a pleasant loophole that may surprise you: Any cellphone that ever had service in the past, even a dusty, deactivated one, can still call 911. In other words, you can equip yourself with a genuine-emergency lifeline for next to nothing. All you have to do is get your hands on one of the 25 million retired cellphones rattling around in this country's junk drawers. (If you don't have access to such a drawer, at a friend's house or even your own, used cellphones are going for about $20 on eBay.)
But not every kind of emergency requires the attention of the fire, police and rescue squads. When you're lost on the way to a wedding, or you're running late, or Blockbuster doesn't have the movie your spouse sent you to pick up, the number you ache to dial may not be 911.
In these cases, you need a less limited emergency phone. The key to spending very little in this category is the prepaid cellphone. Under this arrangement, you pay for service by the minute, not by the month. You buy minutes in advance, usually in $25 to $100 chunks, either by calling a toll-free number with a credit card or by buying a refill card at a phone center or convenience store and plugging its code into your phone. Only in America do people ask, "Honey, can you run to the 7-Eleven and pick up a Slushee and some minutes?"
Once you own those minutes, you have 60 or 90 days to use them. At that point, any unused minutes expire, and your phone lies dormant until you buy another refill. There's one exception: if you buy a refill before your minutes die, they are reborn, joining the newly purchased minutes for another 60 or 90 days. (Apparently a cellphone just isn't a cellphone unless it's accompanied by rules so complicated you have to read them one syllable at a time.) 
Prepaid calling plans have a tarnished reputation, partly because you wind up paying much more per minute than you would on a monthly plan -- usually 15 to 35 cents, depending on how much you spend on each refill. Because no credit check or even ID check is involved, prepaid phones are also favorites of drug dealers and other seamy types. Nonetheless, they can be a terrific value for the glovebox user.
You can buy TracFone's phone-in-a-box, for example, for as little as $20 (after rebate) at almost any electronics or computer store, online or off. Then the fun begins.
If you care about keeping a single phone number for incoming calls, you must feed your TracFone a steady diet of refill cards, which you can buy every month or two ($8 to $100 per card, good for 10 to 300 minutes) or one $100 card per year (good for 100 minutes). A moment alone with a calculator will show those minutes to be staggeringly expensive -- up to 80 cents each. Note, too, that TracFone relies on the older analog cell network, meaning that you don't get caller ID, three-way calling or the other digital extras. (Digital TracFones are coming soon.) On the other hand, you have a working cellphone for as little as $96 a year -- putting you well ahead of the $240 annual bill, plus steep taxes, you'd pay for the least expensive traditional plan. (AT&T's prepaid phone service costs about the same -- four $25 refill cards can keep your phone in service for the whole year, which works out to a more reasonable 35 cents a minute.)
But you can save even more money. Both AT&T and TracFone give you a grace period (6 weeks and 16 weeks, respectively) after you've let your minutes expire without buying new ones, during which you still maintain your phone number. Only after that does AT&T or TracFone close your account. 
With a little effort, then, the emergency-use-only customer can play a very economical game. Buy a $20 TracFone, for example, and an $8 refill card. Wait out the four-month grace period before buying another $8 refill, which keeps you in the game for another four months. This routine involves monitoring the phone's display, which shows you how many minutes you have left and when you must buy another card to avoid having your account closed. But three cards can last the entire year. After buying the phone, you'll pay only $25 per year for a bona fide cellphone that's there when you need it. 
But the least expensive cellphone plan of all awaits those who don't care about maintaining the same phone number. Buy a TracFone or one of AT&T's Free2Go prepaid phones ($100, including a digital Nokia phone and $50 of minutes -- about two hours' worth). Don't buy any minutes, ever. Eventually, AT&T or TracFone will close your account and give away your old phone number, but that's no big deal. When an emergency arises, you can pull the phone out of the glove compartment, call AT&T or TracFone toll-free and buy some minutes on the spot, thus reactivating your account (albeit with a new phone number). Presto: you have the freedom to call anywhere in a pinch. And if that day never arrives, you haven't paid a nickel for cellphone service.
All that may sound like a lot of effort to save a few bucks, and the phone companies are understandably unenthusiastic about this scheme (while admitting that it's perfectly legal). But hey, time is money.
The final alternative is signing up for a traditional pay-by-the-month contract. Every carrier offers one rock-bottom, brutally restrictive $20-per-month program. For New Yorkers, the best $20 deal is VoiceStream's Northeast Neighborhood plan, which offers 60 weekday minutes and 500 weekend minutes for calls to 10 states, northern Virginia and Washington. 
Caveat caller: Before you sign up for any cellphone plan, confirm that the carrier serves your area. If you travel, ask how much you'll pay for roaming (using the phone outside your home region or outside the carrier's own network). Ask about long-distance calls, which, in the bottom-tier price plans, sometimes carry a steep surcharge. Also ask what happens if you ditch your carrier before a year is up (you usually get socked with a $150 to $200 fee).
Finally, note that many glovebox users find that having a cellphone for emergency use is like keeping a bowl of chocolates on the kitchen table "for guests." Sooner or later, you won't be able to resist dipping in. 
Fortunately, you're free to upgrade or downgrade your cellphone plan at any time, without charge. You can even convert a prepaid phone into one with a monthly contract, if it comes to that. So if you buy a phone for emergency use but wind up becoming addicted to its convenience, you wouldn't be the first. You're safe either way.

HEADLINE: Designers Look Beyond Debris 

BYLINE:  By JULIE V. IOVINE

 BODY:
ON Tuesday night, an impressive sampling of New York architectural talent streamed into the Great Hall at the Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art to share grief, locate friends and discuss how not to be left out of the rebuilding process in downtown Manhattan. For these architects, engineers and design professors, Sept. 11 was both a tragedy and a call to take a creative stand. 
 Some recounted fleeing office buildings near the World Trade Center that had caught fire or standing in the center's eerily quiet plaza watching falling debris. Others leaped ahead to new visions for the 16-acre plot now known as ground zero. 
 The gathering, co-sponsored by the Architectural League and the Cooper Union, attracted a near-capacity crowd of about 700 designers. While the World Trade Center was the main theme, the 21 official speakers did not limit themselves to a discussion of whether to focus on building a memorial or new skyscrapers. The entire process of building in New York must be challenged, they said. 
With politicians, developers and business leaders already considering ways to fill the void, most speakers made passionate bids to slow down and rethink all assumptions about reshaping the site.
"We do not dignify the dead nor fight the enemies of peace by denying that something has shifted, by rushing out to spend again, by fantasizing about 150-story towers that will take an additional hour to evacuate when the next disaster strikes," said Michael Sorkin, an architect and urban planner. There were some concrete suggestions. Diane Lewis, an architect and professor at the Cooper Union, proposed that the blasted site house an international institute against terrorism, possibly built with the rubble from the ruined towers. 
Another architect, Susana Torre, dismissed the idea of holding a design competition, as many expect, in favor of giving a commission outright to Frank Gehry to design a new "world arts center."
Several architects voiced concern that in the rush to rebuild, due process -- especially community reviews and zoning -- would be swept away. On the other hand, Ms. Lewis said, the rebuilding process could promote "a new sobriety" that would lead to a more egalitarian urbanism and an architectural sensibility devoid of brash image-making.
For now, any discussion about rebuilding is strictly speculative. And construction will have to wait for the removal of tons of debris from the site and surrounding blocks, a process that most estimates suggest will take about a year. In the meantime, New York's design institutions are developing their own ways to respond, interpret and offer salve in the aftermath of the attack.
The Municipal Art Society, in conjunction with City Lore, has commissioned Martha Cooper, a photographer, to capture images of the memorials and tributes that have flowered across the city, from the American flags sprouting on the statue of George Washington in Union Square to the candlelit testaments to the missing along the Promenade in Brooklyn Heights. The show of photographs will open at the society on Oct. 19.
A period of mourning should precede any consideration of new plans for the site, said officials of several design institutions. "The first order of the day is to memorialize and to do things that recognize the loss," said Frank Sanchis, executive director of the Municipal Art Society. "We feel things are moving too fast. We're put off and frightened by all the announcements of commissions and building the towers back up. It just hasn't sunk in."
The society does plan to support several memorial projects, including the so-called Towers of Light project by the architects Gustavo Bonevardi and John Bennett collaborating with the artists Paul Myoda and Julian LaVerdiere and the Creative Time arts organization, which will use light projections to recreate the twin towers as ghostly apparitions.
The Skyscraper Museum, whose gallery space at 110 Maiden Lane has been taken over by the emergency headquarters of the Small Businesses Administration, is assembling two exhibitions on the history of the construction of the World Trade Center. The first will open in the next few weeks in a vacant ground floor space at 1 Battery Park Plaza. Designed to be viewed primarily from the street, the exhibition features an 18-minute film of the towers being built. 
In February, the museum will open a second show, at the New- York Historical Society. A lecture series on the World Trade Center that the Skyscraper Museum was developing to celebrate its acquisition of the center's archives will not take place: the archives were destroyed.
Other design institutions are not altering their lineup of events but are considering subtle alterations and shifts of emphasis to shows already in the works. Some have taken on a grim relevance. At the Museum of Modern Art, Paola Antonelli, a design curator, was already at work for eight months on "Emergency," an exhibition of products, Ms. Antonelli said, designed to deal with crisis situations, from emergency room surgical instruments to firetrucks to safety instructions. "These are objects and graphic designs where there is absolutely no room for anything superfluous," Ms. Antonelli said, noting that there was as yet no date scheduled for the exhibition. "I want to show the public in some visceral way the importance of design in the real world," she said.
The Van Alen Institute, a nonprofit organization that promotes public architecture, plans to stage a show in December on how cities like Sarajevo, Oklahoma City, Berlin and Kobe, Japan, have rebuilt in the wake of both human-induced and natural disasters.
Recent events have rendered parts of some exhibitions obsolete. At the Cooper Hewitt National Design Museum, Donald Albrecht, a curator, is reconsidering some of the installations for a show on hotels that is scheduled to open in October 2002. A commission for Hani Rashid and Lise Anne Couture of Asymptote to design their vision of a hotel airbus will go ahead, but an artist's conceptual vision of a Japanese-style capsule hotel inserted into a scale model of an atomic bomb will not. "Some projects that seemed clever a few weeks ago now seem utterly inappropriate," Mr. Albrecht said. "People are going to become more sensitive to things that they perceive are irreverent or irrelevant."
Architects and designers interviewed over the last few days anticipate a new mood of seriousness and a fuller social consciousness in their work and others. The new sobriety had begun to surface even before Sept. 11 as a deteriorating economy caused projects to shrink and become more tightly focused. "There's an intensity to a 3,000-square-foot job where you have to clarify and hone your skills," said Alan Wanzenberg, an architect. "It's kind of great." Mr. Wanzenberg, whose partner Jed Johnson died in TWA Flight 800 off Long Island in 1996, said that he believed that in times of stress people looked for comfort in more formal, less abstract design solutions. "We may well start seeing people wanting more explicit, softer and more traditional images in design and art," Mr. Wanzenberg said.
Karim Rashid, an industrial designer in New York, was not so much changing his tack in response to recent events as finding new applications. David Shearer, owner of the design store Totem, noted that a coming line of Mr. Rashid's disposable cardboard furniture would be easy to transport in case of emergency. And a new line of clothes designed with Pia Myrvold of Cybercouture, a fashion designer, will be made with an electroluminescent material that will make it easy to locate people in the dark. "Design should take the new world into consideration," Mr. Shearer said. "It needs to be stronger, more straightforward and utilitarian, not just decorative."

HEADLINE: Art for Sale, but Will Anyone Be Buying?; 
In Attack Aftermath, Traditionally Lucrative Fall Season Faces Uncertainty

BYLINE:  By CAROL VOGEL

 BODY:
In the months leading up to the $500 million fall art season there's always uncertainty, but not since the Persian Gulf war has there been anything like this. In the wake of the terrorist attacks, collectors, dealers and auction house officials are coping with personal and financial losses. There have also been last-minute postponements of major shows and disruptions of shipping and travel plans.
 Every corner of the art world is in turmoil because of its close links to the economy and consumer confidence. But no one knows whether the market will freeze or investors with cash will see art and antiques as safe places to put their money. 
 Those who have been around the art world recall other difficult times: the recession of the early 1970's, when prices for every kind of collectible plummeted; the period after Black Monday in 1987, when, buoyed by the Japanese economy, prices of everything from diamonds to Impressionist paintings leaped to unimaginable heights; the gulf war, when distress sales dominated the market but nobody had an appetite for buying art. 
"This is a particularly tricky time -- we've never seen anything quite like it," said Christopher Burge, Christie's honorary chairman in America, a 31-year veteran of auction houses and the company's principal auctioneer. "This is a shock. We've seen hard times when tangibles like art became a safe haven because people were frightened of other markets, but we've also seen times when art buying froze. It's really too early to tell." 
Ordinarily, this is the season when the art world revs up again after the summer doldrums: galleries and museums buzz with people flocking to see new shows; auction house experts make their last pushes to get property to sell in their fall auctions. They also romance collectors with lunches and dinners that are private previews of the best of the coming sales.
But this year the fate of those November sales -- the multimillion-dollar Impressionist, modern and contemporary art auctions that attract dealers and collectors from all over the world -- is the subject of much speculation. Dealers are secretly betting there will be bargains. Sellers are hoping that the world will be a happier place by then and that people will feel like buying art.
The three major auction houses are fretting about the financial investments they made in artworks months ago. If the art market nosedives, Sotheby's and Christie's could be severely tested, but it is third-place Phillips, which has invested millions in guarantees to sellers, that has the most to lose.
Show organizers are also very vulnerable. With the Seventh Regiment Armory, at Park Avenue and 66th Street, restricted to military use, the organizers of the International Fine Art and Antique Dealers Show, Anna and Brian Haughton, went to Sotheby's and arranged to use the auction house's 10th floor next month. Most of the 72 dealers from here and abroad were so outraged that they pulled out of the show, saying that doing a fair at the York Avenue auction house would be "sleeping with the enemy." They also feared that the move from Park Avenue to York, from a ground floor space to the 10th floor, would significantly reduce traffic at the show. 
Last weekend in Chelsea, that densely packed swath of Lower Manhattan where contemporary art galleries are clustered cheek to jowl, the streets seemed as crowded as usual for a Saturday in September. But the atmosphere was different. Many people said that they were tired of watching the news, that they wanted to get out of the house. "There may be a lot of people about, but are they buying?" asked Henry Allsopp, a dealer at Dickinson Roundell, whose galleries are in New York and London. "I don't think so."
Michael and Susan Hort, TriBeca collectors, were methodically perusing all the new shows. "You're looking at all this beautiful art, but in the back of your mind you're thinking: 'What's the latest news? What's next?' " Mr. Hort said. "I don't think people feel like buying; there's just too much uncertainty. I don't know anybody who hasn't been financially affected by this. We were, big time."
Matthew Marks, a Chelsea dealer, said he decided to go ahead with his opening of shows by two young artists, Darren Almond and Hellen van Meene, last Friday. Although he admitted he was nervous, his two galleries were packed. "I had one client call me last week and say he wanted to buy something to cheer him up. But I also had one big sale canceled." 
Dealers for the most part say they are wary of approaching clients who don't come to them first. "I wouldn't dream of offering anything to my American clients because I think it would be crass," said Lowell Libson, a London dealer.
David Nash, a Madison Avenue dealer who ran Sotheby's Impressionist and modern art department for 20 years, remembers that during the gulf war some of his clients said they just didn't think it was right to be seen spending money in public. "But that changed," he said.
Donald Rubell, a Miami collector, says life has to go on. "I'm like one of those overeaters who can't stop," he said. "There's not a time when I don't feel like buying art."
Robert Mnuchin, who founded C&M Arts, a gallery on the Upper East Side, eight years ago after retiring as a partner of Goldman, Sachs, said he hadn't seen much traffic in his gallery since Sept. 11, and he wonders if this is a market correction or a slowdown. "You can't make predictions," he said. "Everything is on hold right now."
Sotheby's and Christie's moved their September sales of Asian art by a month, to Oct. 15. "People just couldn't get here," said William Ruprecht, chief executive of Sotheby's. Mr. Ruprecht also had to cancel several traveling exhibitions scheduled for last week because of cutbacks in airline schedules and security concerns.
"We physically couldn't get things there," he said. "We have a responsibility to protect the art we sell and to protect our people."
But officials at both Sotheby's and Christie's said they were planning to go ahead with future traveling exhibitions. As for October's schedule, which normally includes jewelry and furniture sales, Phillips is the only house that has postponed its jewelry sale until December.
Individual sellers are being cautious, too. The seasoned Los Angeles collector and dealer Irving Blum has postponed selling a 1960's sculpture by Donald Judd that was to have been included in Christie's November sale; it will now be sold in May. 
On the other hand, the television and theater producer Douglas S. Cramer intends to go ahead with a sale of 31 works of contemporary art by modern masters like Jasper Johns, Roy Lichtenstein and Ellsworth Kelly, worth between $15 million and $22 million, which Sotheby's plans to sell on Nov. 14.
"I would really be worried if this was art from the last five years," Mr. Cramer said. "But these are works from the 1950's, 60's, 70's and 80's. People have to do something with their money. In times of revolution and unrest, they tend to buy gold and collectibles." 
Mr. Cramer himself doesn't have much to be worried about. Sotheby's has given him a guarantee -- an undisclosed sum promised to the seller regardless of a sale's outcome.
Of the three auction houses, Phillips, which reinvented itself to compete with Sotheby's and Christie's, occupies the most precarious position. Its sale of more than $100 million worth of early 20th-century French and German paintings and sculptures from the estate of the Los Angeles collectors Nathan and Marion Smooke is a gamble, since Phillips has given the Smooke heirs a guarantee, believed by art experts to be around $180 million. If the market freezes and nobody buys art, it could mean more financial losses for the struggling auction house.
Phillips's parent company, LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton, has already posted losses in recent months. There are also reports from people close to Phillips that $8 million worth of contemporary art has been withdrawn from its contemporary art sale by sellers in recent days. But Simon de Pury, the company's chairman, said he had had some consignments since Sept. 11.
"I even had one seller who called to say he wanted some of the proceeds of his sale to go to a relief fund," Mr. de Pury said.
Christie's is trumpeting a sale whose entire proceeds will to charity. The Gaffe Collection, a sale of $40 million worth of modern masters on Nov. 6, may skyrocket in a way it might not have before Sept. 11. Not only is it first-rate material, but all the proceeds go to Unicef, the United Nations Children's Fund.
Sanford Smith, the Manhattan show organizer, is planning to donate one day's admission fees for each of his three shows in November to funds for the survivors of firefighters and police officers.
Mr. Smith's fairs are scheduled to take place at the Seventh Regiment Armory. Until he hears to the contrary, he said, he is going ahead as planned, his first show, the Print Fair, opening on Nov. 1.
"The income from the Park Avenue armory supports approximately 60 percent of the total state budget for all the armories," Mr. Smith said. "I can't see how they can afford to keep it shut. The city and state will lose more than $100 million a year in revenue spent by exhibitors and visitors who come to New York, as well as all the carpenters and teamsters who help make these fairs possible."
"And," he added, "that's not including another $10 million they will lose in sales tax."

GRAPHIC: Photo: With the big fall auction season coming up, the art world is wondering how the terrorist attacks and the resulting economic uncertainty will affect buyers. (Chris Maynard for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE JOB MARKET; 
For Students, Unexpected Doubts

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN D. GLATER 

 BODY:
When J. C. Gaither started business school last year, he knew that the job market might soften while he was working toward an M.B.A. But, he says, he had no idea just how much.
 "The severity is a shock to us all," said Mr. Gaither, 26, who will graduate in the spring from the Fox School of Business and Management at Temple University. 
 He is luckier than most; he was able to parlay his internship last summer into a job offer. Still, he worries that the offer could be rescinded. 
"There's no guarantee that it won't be taken off the table," Mr. Gaither said. "It's definitely not the same as it was maybe a year or two ago."
The economy was already turning against students who will enter the job market in the spring, but the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon -- let alone the prospect of a protracted war of uncertain dimensions -- has greatly increased the level of uncertainty on campuses. 
Many employers canceled interviews and information sessions at colleges in the weeks after the attacks, and not all have called to reschedule.
So students are having to face the fact that their postgraduation options are probably more limited than they have been for years. For most of them, it is the first time they have experienced a market that is not desperate to hire.
The principal problem confronting the consulting firms, the investment banks and the high-technology companies that until last year scooped up M.B.A. graduates is the high cost of carrying current employees as revenues fall because of cutbacks by clients. 
Many firms have already pushed back the start dates for last year's graduates and are not sure enough about business prospects to risk committing themselves to hire still more M.B.A.'s.
"We are seeing a lot of changes both in the overall employment market as well as some short-term changes" prompted by the attacks on Sept. 11, said Sheryle Dirks, director of the career management center at Fuqua School of Business at Duke University. In the short term, companies are waiting to see what happens to the economy, and in the long term, she said, "the market is softening."
In the last few weeks, Ms. Dirks said, several businesses canceled information sessions on campus and others rescheduled interviews to later in the year. Some businesses in industries, like airlines, that have been hit the hardest by recent events have canceled interviews outright, she said.
So far, business schools seem to have been affected a good deal more than law schools. 
For the most part, law firms -- with the possible exception of those in the San Francisco area that were already hard hit by the slowdown in the technology sector -- have been quick to emphasize that hiring will continue, although at a slower pace. Partners at several firms say that they are hiring fewer summer interns, for example.
Susan M. Guindi, assistant dean for career services at the University of Michigan Law School, said, "We have not had a single cancellation." Even Thacher Proffitt & Wood and Sidley Austin Brown & Wood, whose law offices were in the World Trade Center, "are still planning on coming, bless their hearts," she said.
For business students, who are finding less or none of the expected wining and dining, the uncertainty is unsettling.
"It's a shock to the system," said Betsy Leichtfuss, a second-year student at the Cox School of Business at Southern Methodist University in Dallas. Ms. Leichtfuss says as a result, she is taking a more organized and hands-on approach to her job search. She has prepared a binder with copies of the cover letters she has written, for example, to keep track of the jobs she is pursuing, and she is putting a lot of effort into networking.
"That's what's really going to help a lot of people this year, rather than what people are used to," Ms. Leichtfuss said. In years past, employers, desperate to hire business graduates, came to campuses to woo them; now, she said, she knows she has to "find out whom I know that knows someone that knows someone" in order to find the right job.
Ms. Dirks, the career adviser at Fuqua, is encouraging students to contact alumni to gain an advantage in their job searches. She is also actively marketing the college's graduates, something that was not necessary in recent years. "We're more externally focused," she said.
For first-year students looking for summer internships, the canceled information sessions are a serious problem since they are an important way for employers to provide information about themselves. 
At the Olin School of Business at Washington University in St. Louis, a career fair scheduled for late November has been moved to early March, said Gregory J. Hutchings, associate dean for career services. Many big companies have prohibited nonessential travel by employees, he said, and attending career fairs does not usually qualify.
As a result, students must do more research on their own, Mr. Hutchings said. "The students, like everyone else, are trying to figure out how to deal with this."
One way some students are dealing is by considering jobs in places they had not thought about seriously. For example, Mr. Gaither, the Fox student, said that many classmates were looking beyond management consulting and investment banking to established companies, like the auto companies, or are looking in parts of the country other than San Francisco, New York or other hitherto highly desirable cities.
"A lot of us are calling companies that maybe have not historically recruited here," said Thomas M. Day, 29, a second-year student at Fuqua. Students at his college and elsewhere are also trying to interview with more companies, he said, to ensure that they get at least one offer.
By this time last year, Mr. Day said, students were weighing multiple offers. This year, he said, "there's a good chance that at the end of the recruiting season, you could end up with nothing."
Among the difficulties is the uncertainty over how to approach companies with offices in or near the terrorist attacks, Mr. Day added. "It will be harder to call firms in New York and network" with them, he said. Career planning advisers on campuses have told students to hold off on calling prospective employers while everyone copes with the aftereffects of disaster.
That advice sits well with many students, however anxious they may be about their future. The attacks have reduced the importance of the job search in everyone's mind, Mr. Day said. "It puts the whole job thing into perspective."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Thomas Day at Duke University said many students were hoping to get at least one offer for a summer job. (M.J. Sharp for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Essay; 
All Is Not Changed

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
Legend has it that when Lord Cornwallis formally surrendered to General Washington at Yorktown, ending the Revolutionary War, the redcoated band played "The World Turned Upside Down."
 The same song is being played today in the aftermath of the September massacre. Life will never be the same, we are told with dreary unanimity. From now on, everything will be different. We have to learn to live with dread. 
 No more sense of security in skyscrapers or airplanes; no more carefree days cheering at the Super Bowl; no more driving on a bridge or through a tunnel without a frisson of fear that the truck ahead may be driven by a suicidal maniac. Confidence in our personal safety is supposedly a thing of the past. 
The notion that "everything has changed" ripples outward: this loss of our sense of security about our very lives spreads to worry about our livelihoods. As the fallout from fear curtails travel, will I lose my job near the airport or making beds at the resort? Will the ebb of consumer confidence depress the stock market and plunge us into deep recession and snatch away the security of my retirement funds? Do I dare start a new enterprise in this climate, or even bring a new baby into this vale of fears?
Now for a message from the poet Milton: "Hence, loathed Melancholy!" True, we have a right to be outraged at the death of our 7,000, murdered only for the sin of being free and happily productive Americans. And we have an obligation to support their families in their bereavement and to wipe out the state sponsors of their killers. 
We have no cause, however, to wallow in what is becoming a fashionable dread, and no reason to assume the doom of our personal security and national prosperity.
This debilitating dread is abetted by the belated warnings from agencies that failed to protect us. A chagrined Justice Department and C.I.A. -- which neglected to use present authority to work closely with immigration and customs officials -- now cover up past misfeasance with demands for more intrusive police powers to eavesdrop on and detain suspects. 
On top of a panicky rush to eliminate rights, too many of us are afflicted with a "nameless, unreasoning and unjustified terror," in F.D.R.'s words, of seeming to be complacent about the terrorist threat. This catch-up alarmism contributes to the "terrorist mastermind" theory that focuses on Osama bin Laden as the central villain. It is simpler and less controversial than exposing the far greater nuclear and bio-war threat based in states using terrorists as their launch pads. 
Suicide hijackers and bombers do not pose what is coolly called an existential threat to -- that is, a danger to the very existence of -- the United States. We lose 7,000 lives on our highways every two months. Terror-sponsoring states use these human missiles to implant that debilitating dread in individual American minds, thereby causing us to curtail our freedoms and to implore our leaders to appease the terrorists. 
That is not going to happen. The blow to our body politic of Sept. 11 is not a knockout blow. We will brace ourselves for other murders already probably set in train, until we force the nations supporting terrorists to turn their agents over. Every new offense creates its fierce counteroffensive, and we are not going to let their new weapon change our lives permanently. 
Airliners will be hijacker-proofed and private pilots deeply vetted. New York's ground zero will be rebuilt and Washington's Pentagon repaired. Our coming deficit will stimulate the economy, and the smart money on Wall Street will gobble up shares months before the upturn. The Redskins will not make it to the Super Bowl but two other teams will. 
And we'll shake off that dread. Americans will return to our future's normalcy (no, President Warren G. Harding didn't coin the word), which will be no more or less safe than the present. Our children's world will be rightside up.
I believe that especially on this somber Day of Atonement, as Jews ask God to seal their names in a symbolic book. It is not a book of fear or lamentation. In an ageless affirmation of hope, we call it the Book of Life.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE ECONOMY; 
I.M.F. Sees World Growth At Its Weakest In a Decade

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 

 BODY:
The global economy is likely to grow at its weakest rate since the early 1990's, though it may narrowly avert a recession this year, the International Monetary Fund said today.
 The I.M.F.'s latest World Economic Outlook, which measures the cumulative growth rate of the world's economies, forecast 2001 growth of 2.6 percent, just above the level of 2.5 percent that the fund classifies as a technical recession for the global economy. 
 The forecast was adjusted to reflect growth in Europe that was weaker than expected, a worsening recession in Japan and a recovery slower than anticipated in the United States. But it did not factor in the effect of the Sept. 11 attacks on the United States. Fund officials acknowledged that the attacks would have at least some effect on growth this year. 
Kenneth Rogoff, the organization's chief economist, told reporters that he could not predict how the incidents would affect growth. But he said that the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon were having "a negative effect on activity now in many regions of the globe" through weakened consumer confidence.
Mr. Rogoff said he still expected a relatively strong recovery in the United States and abroad next year, with the fund projecting 3.5 percent global growth. But he warned that the attacks might well cause that figure to be lowered in coming weeks.
The lending agency has struggled to put a positive face on economic prospects even though most private economists argue that both the United States and the world economy will have recessions this year and have significantly weaker growth in 2002 than most once foresaw.
Some say the world this year will post its most anemic growth since the early 1980's. In addition, the unusually robust global growth last year may make the deceleration feel like the most wrenching since the oil shocks of the mid-1970's.
World output has not actually shrunk in any given year since the 1930's. But many developing economies are considered to be in recession when their growth rate falls into the low single digits because they need relatively rapid expansion to relieve poverty and accommodate bigger work forces.
Mr. Rogoff said he remained relatively optimistic because central banks had taken aggressive steps to stimulate growth. He said that productivity gains from spreading technology could also help economies recover quickly from the downturn.
But the world's leading economy, the United States, almost certainly faces a full recession this year, Mr. Rogoff said.
"I think it's a done deal," said Mr. Rogoff, a Harvard professor who became the fund's chief economist this year. Many private economists agree that United States output will probably shrink in the third and fourth quarters before recovering next year.
Later in a news conference, Mr. Rogoff said he wanted to withdraw his remark about United States growth, which sounded gloomier than the White House has in recent days.
"I have to withdraw my remark 'done deal' simply because we know that growth is going to be lower for the United States, but we simply have no idea of exactly how much lower," he said.

HEADLINE: THE NEW YORK PRIMARY: NEWS ANALYSIS; 
Ferrer's Choice: Appeal to Pride, Or Embrace All

BYLINE:  By ADAM NAGOURNEY

 BODY:
Fernando Ferrer won a spot in a Democratic runoff in large part, Democrats said yesterday, because he rallied black and Latino voters with his promise to represent the "other New York," and by embodying the hope of electing the city's first Puerto Rican mayor.
 But as Mr. Ferrer prepares for an Oct. 11 runoff with Mark Green -- in a city whose political demographics are shifting quickly, as evidenced by the fact that nearly half of the Democratic voters on Tuesday were Hispanic or black -- he faces two choices about how to proceed. His task is already being complicated by Mr. Green, who pointedly called for unity yesterday and declared that mayoral candidates should run "an interracial and interborough and interethnic campaign." 
 The more conventional approach would be for Mr. Ferrer to find a way to broaden his appeal, so that he can move beyond the coalition of black and Latino voters that catapulted him to first place in Tuesday's primary. He received 35 percent of the total vote, compared with 31 percent for Mr. Green, according to unofficial and incomplete returns compiled by The Associated Press. 
By any measure, it was a racially lopsided outcome. Mr. Ferrer won 52 percent of the black vote and 72 percent of the Hispanic vote, but only 7 percent of the white vote, according to a survey of voters leaving the polls. In a sign of the challenge facing Mr. Ferrer, white Democrats in the survey who voted for one of the two losing Democrats, Alan G. Hevesi and Peter F. Vallone, overwhelmingly named Mr. Green as their choice in a Ferrer-Green race. 
The second approach is to do what Mr. Ferrer -- in contrast to some of the elected officials supporting him -- has seemed uncomfortable trying to do: make a direct appeal to ethnic pride, and explicitly trying to build an electoral foundation of black and Latino voters.
Roberto Ramirez, the Bronx Democratic leader, has long argued that as soon as Mr. Ferrer established himself as a viable candidate for mayor -- and he surely passed that threshold on Tuesday night -- the city's rapidly expanding Hispanic vote would turn out behind him.
That would be combined with black voters, brought to Mr. Ferrer by the support of figures like the Rev. Al Sharpton, who are pushing for a coalition of black and Latino voters, as well as white liberals drawn by Mr. Ferrer's views. 
In this kind of charged atmosphere, those voters might be more likely to go to the trouble of voting in a runoff, some of Mr. Ferrer's advisers argued yesterday, than Democrats backing the more conventional candidacy of Mr. Green. The risk, though, is that such an appeal, fairly or not, can be portrayed as excluding whites.
Mr. Ferrer's first steps yesterday were in the direction of trying to appeal to white Democrats. He headed out to Queens to collect the endorsement of Mr. Vallone, the moderate Democrat. He prepared to put on the air an advertisement featuring his endorsement by Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the retired senator, also a moderate Democrat.
He moved away from talking about "the other New York," though he made a point of emphasizing that while rebuilding New York after the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center was his first priority, he had not abandoned the argument he made from the start of the campaign, that the city had neglected too many New Yorkers during the years of prosperity. 
Still, as Mr. Ferrer's advisers considered his situation yesterday, they said he was inclined, if possible, to try to blend aspects of the two approaches as he faces his contest with Mr. Green.
"He needs to do both," Mr. Sharpton said. "He needs to get more turnout in the progressive white and African-American and Latino community. And he needs to get more white votes."
David Axelrod, his chief campaign consultant, disputed the suggestion that Mr. Ferrer's appeal to white voters could not expand, noting the endorsement he won yesterday from Mr. Vallone.
"I don't think you can assume that we don't have the ability to grow among white voters, exponentially," he said, adding, "I don't think people see him as a divisive figure. I don't think people see him as a threatening figure."
That Mr. Ferrer is in this position -- Mr. Green's advisers described it as a predicament, while Mr. Ferrer's supporters argued that he was now primed to sweep Mr. Green out of public life -- is a reflection of how strikingly the political dynamics of New York have changed. 
As Primary Day approached, aides to Mr. Ferrer's opponents predicted that the Hispanic vote would make up 15 to 18 percent of the turn-out. It was actually 23 percent of the total, according to surveys of voters leaving the polls. By contrast, in 1989, the last time such a survey for a Democratic mayoral primary in New York was conducted, Hispanics made up 8 percent of the electorate.
This year, white voters made up about 50 percent of the electorate. In that 1989 election, it was about 61 percent. Black voters that year made up 29 percent of the electorate, but that number was undoubtedly increased by the fact that David N. Dinkins was running to become New York's first black mayor. This time, it was 24 percent.
Interestingly, given the mostly fitful attempts by New York politicians to create a black-Latino coalition, Mr. Ferrer drew almost the same percentage of black votes in this race, or 52 percent, as Mr. Dinkins drew from Hispanic voters in 1989, when he drew 54 percent of what was then a much smaller segment.
But Mr. Ferrer has seemed to struggle trying to rally Latino and black voters to his candidacy without opening himself up to criticism. By contrast, even Mr. Ferrer's supporters said Mr. Dinkins was more graceful in 1989 in trying to put together a black-Latino coalition to appeal to a multiethnic city, which he called a "gorgeous mosaic."
In using the phrase "the other New York," Mr. Ferrer has said that that was simply a description for New Yorkers who did not benefit from the economic prosperity of Mr. Giuliani's term. But his advisers acknowledge that the phrase has had resonance among black and Latino voters, accounting in part for his strong performance among those voters, an argument made by some of Mr. Green's supporters.
Similarly, Mr. Ferrer has avoided explicit racial overtures in this campaign, other than Spanish-language appeals to Hispanic voters, which were a variation on the kind of ethnic appeals that have been the bread and butter of urban politics for a century.
"The vote might be polarized, but Freddy is not a polarizing figure," said Prof. Douglas Muzzio of the School of Public Affairs at Baruch College. "Freddy is a real moderate, nondemagogic, inclusionary guy."
At the same time, though some of Mr. Ferrer's supporters, like Representative Charles E. Rangel, the Harlem Democrat, have framed Mr. Ferrer's appeal in more ethnic terms. After initially saying he was likely to stay neutral in the mayoral primary, Mr. Rangel switched to Mr. Ferrer because he saw a potential of building a black-Latino coalition.
But Mr. Sharpton said that any attempt by Mr. Green's supporters to portray Mr. Ferrer as running a racially based campaign would become increasingly difficult. 
"Vallone helps him," Mr. Sharpton said. "The fact that we can build an inclusive government helps him. And the fact that we have not been offensive helps him.
"I think the bogeyman thing backfired. He not only made the primary. He outpolled Mark!"
