HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE INSURERS; 
Insurers Ask Help to Survive Future Losses

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 

 BODY:
Insurance executives told Congress today that they had plenty of money to pay for about $40 billion of losses from the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11. But they said they urgently needed help to provide coverage for possible future violence.
 In testimony before the House Committee on Financial Services, some of the leading insurers argued that since terrorism had the potential for enormous repeated financial blows, the government should take responsibility for paying the most expensive claims. They said they were not seeking a bailout, similar to the $15 billion relief package that the airlines received last week, but assistance in confronting an immeasurable financial abyss. 
 "There's no way to price for this," said Ronald E. Ferguson, the chairman of General Re, one of the country's largest insurers and a unit of Berkshire Hathaway, in an interview after the hearing. "There's no way you can expose your capital and your shareholders to what amounts to almost infinite risk."
Dean R. O'Hare, the chief executive of the Chubb Corporation, another big insurer, told lawmakers that something had to be done quickly. "We have a crisis brewing as we speak," he said.
Negotiations are under way for renewal of much of the nation's commercial insurance, he said. No insurer, he said, is prepared to take on all the risk of any huge corporation; and so far, none of the reinsurance companies that usually share the risk with retail or primary insurers are willing to provide terrorism coverage.
Unless a solution is found quickly, he said, American corporations will have no coverage for terrorism and, in the event of an attack, will have to pay for their own losses. That would bankrupt some companies and disrupt the national economy.
Representative Christopher Shays, a Republican from Connecticut, responded with skepticism. Was the question of insurers' providing coverage, he asked, a matter of "can't or won't?" 
Mr. O'Hare responded, "There's no way on earth a single company could offer hundreds of millions of coverage on its own."
Lawmakers generally responded sympathetically to the insurers, praising them for their decision to ignore war provisions in much of their coverage that might have enabled them to refuse to pay claims in the recent attacks. But they made it clear they were not eager to draw the government into the insurance business and take on commitments for untold billions.
"I would be extremely reluctant to accept any plan that puts the taxpayer on the hook for insurable losses," said Representative Richard H. Baker, a Republican from Louisiana. Particularly, he added, "when there is no federal office that exercises any real jurisdiction over solvency and business practices of the industry."
Insurance is regulated state by state without industrywide federal oversight.
In the short term, some help could come from the Securities and Exchange Commission. Harvey L. Pitt, the chairman of the S.E.C., told legislators that the agency was considering easing regulations to allow the airline and insurance industries to raise capital more quickly. He also said he might ask Congress to extend a waiver on certain trading regulations that has permitted companies and executives to help prop up the price of their shares. With the waiver, publicly traded companies can buy their own shares without the normal restrictions on volume and timing.
As a model for government action, the insurers cited a plan developed in London in the early 1990's in response to Irish Republican Army attacks in which private insurers paid the first $150,000 or so for terrorist damage. Then a pool of money created by contributions from insurers and the government paid claims. When those funds were exhausted -- which the insurers said had never happened in London -- the government would pay.
No previous terrorist attacks anywhere have come close to the ones in New York and Washington in casualties -- more than 6,000 people are missing and presumed dead -- and financial losses.
Until those attacks, terrorism coverage was included along with other commercial coverage in the United States, at no extra charge, under the assumption that the chance of its ever being used was remote.
Kathleen Sebelius, the president of the National Association of Insurance Commissioners, the organization of state insurance regulators, encouraged the lawmakers to consider giving the industry financial backing. But she cautioned against any "new mechanism that would discourage private market capital."
The nation's insurers have tried for several years to get the government to take on the highest costs in natural catastrophes like hurricanes and earthquakes. But today, Mr. Ferguson said he felt the government had a greater obligation to help out with terrorism. "After all," he said, "the basic duty of the government is to defend its citizens."
The insurers and members of Congress said they expected furious negotiations on the issue over the next few days. "This is an issue for today, tomorrow and the next day," Mr. Ferguson said, "not next year."
But Mr. Shays said he did not expect Congress to decide as quickly on the insurance issue as it did on the bailout of the airlines, which was accomplished in a few days.
"I have confidence that this is going to be legislation that is going to be thoroughly debated," Mr. Shays said, "and is not just going to go through."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A Customs agent views the damage to the Customs office in the wreckage of the World Trade Center. Insurance executives asked Congress yesterday for assistance in paying claims on such damage. (Reuters)(pg. C4)

HEADLINE: THE NEW YORK PRIMARY: NASSAU COUNTY; 
After Democratic Victory, Suozzi Turns to Republicans

BYLINE:  By ELISSA GOOTMAN

DATELINE: LEVITTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 26 

 BODY:
A day after he won the Democratic primary for Nassau County executive, Thomas R. Suozzi returned to the campaign trail today, preparing for a race that many believe will be less challenging than the one he faced Tuesday. 
 In a primary that drew 24 percent of Nassau's registered Democrats, about double what was expected, Mr. Suozzi, the four-term mayor of Glen Cove, soundly defeated Thomas P. DiNapoli, an assemblyman from Thomaston, by a margin of about 8 percentage points. 
 November's general election represents the Democrats' best chance in decades to seize the county executive office. That is because the county, one of New York's wealthiest, reached the brink of bankruptcy under years of firm Republican rule that was characterized by well-documented patronage, a highly paid police force, rampant borrowing and lavish spending on budget items like park maintenance. 
The county's fiscal crisis led Thomas S. Gulotta, the Republican county executive since 1987, to decide not to seek re-election this year, clearing the way for the man whom Mr. Suozzi will face in November: Bruce R. Bent, a multimillionaire financier running on the message that he is a scrupulous money manager and a political outsider. 
Mr. Bent said today that he would continue to put forward that message, arguing that Mr. Suozzi, the son and nephew of former Glen Cove mayors, is as much a political insider as Mr. DiNapoli. 
"They're both career politicians, which is specifically what I'm running against," Mr. Bent said in a telephone interview. "What I assumed and what our polls have been showing all along is that the people are fed up with politicians." 
Mr. Bent, 64, said he believed that the World Trade Center attack and the prospect of war would compound residents' economic concerns, enhancing the appeal of his own financial expertise and the need to break from politics as usual. 
"They're nervous, and they want somebody who they feel has got the experience to, as they say, move the ball along," he said. 
But within the Democratic Party, Mr. DiNapoli's supporters are wondering what effect the Sept. 11 attack, and the postponement of the primary that was planned for that day, played in Mr. Suozzi's victory. 
For one, some have attributed the high voter turnout to a surge in patriotism. Nassau was close enough to the attack to feel its impact, but distant enough to have its homes and polling stations remain intact. 
And all along, Mr. Suozzi pushed for high voter turnout, while Mr. DiNapoli targeted a narrower segment of prime Democratic voters.
Others suggested that the sense of helplessness following the collapse worked in Mr. Suozzi's favor politically, increasing the importance of his charisma and vigor. 
"This is a guy who looks like he could will a building to stand," said Lisanne G. Altmann, a Democratic legislator from Great Neck who supported Mr. DiNapoli. "I just think people must have gravitated toward his energy." 
Ms. Altmann said she believed that Mr. DiNapoli's supporters, including party leaders, would be quick to recover from their surprise and rally around Mr. Suozzi. 
Meanwhile, other party insiders speculated that one step toward restoring Democratic unity could involve Larry Aaronson, chairman of the Nassau Democratic County Committee, stepping down in favor of Jay S. Jacobs, Mr. Suozzi's campaign chairman. 
Mr. Jacobs said it was too soon to say whether he might replace Mr. Aaronson.
Mr. Aaronson did not return a telephone call seeking comment. 
Mr. Suozzi said he would work to unite his party and to attract Republican voters disillusioned with theirs. 
And while stopping short of a no-new-taxes vow, he said he did not believe that higher taxes were critical to restoring the county's financial health. If elected, he said, he will try to focus on cutting waste, citing as an example the Police Department's use of uniformed officers in jobs that civilians could fill. 
Mr. Suozzi held his first post-primary news conference outside a strip mall in Levittown, a Republican mainstay and the home of that party's chairman, Joseph N. Mondello. 
Flanked by television cameras, Mr. Suozzi returned to hand-shaking, greeting the people he found exercising at the Bally Total Fitness club. He came upon his ideal prospective voter when he saw Jim Georgoudes, a Republican who was exercising on a seated leg press, a towel draped around his neck. 
"I'm a Republican, I'm from Levittown -- but I like you, Tom," Mr. Georgoudes said. 
Mr. Georgoudes said he could not recall the name of his own party's candidate, but he could not help but recall Mr. Suozzi's. 
"I like what he stands for," he said. "And he called me about 25 times."

HEADLINE: OPEC Holds Informal Talks; Decision on Output Likely Today 

BYLINE:  By NEELA BANERJEE 

DATELINE: VIENNA, Sept. 26 

 BODY:
Ministers from the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries ended informal talks today without announcing a decision on daily production levels, but delegates at the meetings said the group planned to leave output unchanged.
 OPEC, a 10-member cartel that produces 40 percent of the world's oil, is expected to render its official decision on Thursday. 
 It has been widely expected to leave production levels unchanged, despite a decrease in the commodity price of oil this week. The cartel is waiting for its earlier reduction in output, of one million a barrels a day effective Sept. 1, to take hold. It requires about 40 days to feel the effect of such a supply cutback as the oil makes its way from the Persian Gulf region to American refineries and finally to drivers and households. 
OPEC faces stiff international pressure to keep oil prices low. Members are aware, analysts say, that any production cuts to prop up prices would be considered insensitive in the wake of the attacks in the United States and the toll they have taken on the global economy. 
Crude oil for November delivery rose 57 cents today, or 2.6 percent, to $22.38 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange, rebounding from a two-year low on Tuesday. Traders said they thought that the price already reflected the economic slowdown and the weaker demand expected after the attacks on Sept. 11.
Oil prices have dropped more than 20 percent since the attacks. Phil Flynn, vice president and senior market analyst at Alaron Trading in Chicago, told Bloomberg News that "the market has been pricing in recession fears for the past seven days."
In London today, Brent crude oil for November settlement rose 62 cents, or 2.7 percent, to $23 a barrel on the International Petroleum Exchange, after falling as low as $20.70 intraday.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: CHARITY; 
For Many, the Good Times Have Ended

BYLINE:  By AARON DONOVAN 

 BODY:
When Dmitry Beznosov thinks about his life before the World Trade Center was destroyed, he recalls an exciting job as a limousine driver -- and wishes he still had it.
 "I really enjoyed working this job," he said. "Even though it might seem like I wasn't making that much money." 
 With tips included, Mr. Beznosov made about $400 a week driving throughout New York City, most often to and from the airports. "I drove a lot of nice people," he recalled. 
Those people included Jennifer Lopez, Jean-Claude Van Damme, James Woods and members of 'N Sync. "The girls were running after the car -- that was pretty crazy," he said.
But the good times for Mr. Beznosov ended on Sept. 11. The company he worked for was a mile north of the trade center along Washington Street, and most of its cars were covered with debris from the collapsed towers. Much of its business came from companies in the trade center or elsewhere in the financial district, and in the days that followed the attack, the company reduced its fleet from 15 cars to 3, Mr. Beznosov said.
Mr. Beznosov tried going back to work, but found there was nothing to do. He used to go out on three or four trips a day. One day last week, he waited by his car all day, but the dispatcher never called. "Nobody wants to drive in a limousine in a situation like this," he said.
His boss told him not to expect to return to work any time soon. "Maybe it's going to get better in a few months," Mr. Beznosov said, "but I don't think so."
So Mr. Beznosov, 24, applied for unemployment assistance and food stamps. But he worried about how he would pay the rent. An officer at the unemployment office in Jamaica, Queens, that was set up specifically to help those who lost their jobs because of the trade center attack, suggested that he call the Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service, one of the 10 local charities supported by The New York Times 9/11 Neediest Fund. The agency paid a month's rent, $406, for his one-bedroom apartment in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn.
Mr. Beznosov is not alone in facing difficult times ahead. According to government estimates, more than 100,000 city workers are likely to be at least temporarily unemployed. Many of those people are turning to charities like the Brooklyn Bureau for help. "Some of the people were either self-employed or they were independent contractors or they worked for small companies that were decimated or temporarily closed," said Donna A. Santarsiero, executive director of the agency.
Ms. Santarsiero said that her agency has always received many requests for help paying rent, but the trade center disaster has made a common New York problem more prevalent. When people come in for help with immediate expenses, the Brooklyn Bureau also tries to help them find work.
Despite being unemployed, Mr. Beznosov, who came to New York from the Soviet Union when he was 10, said he was still happy to be in America. But he is not fully content.
Melanie Fallon of the Brooklyn Bureau listened to Mr. Beznosov tell his story on Tuesday. "Like most of the people we've been seeing, Dmitry is really anxious to get back to work," she said. 
"Yeah," Mr. Beznosov said. "Really anxious."

HEADLINE: Poverty Rate Falls Sharply Among Hispanics, Study Shows 

BYLINE:  By NINA BERNSTEIN

 BODY:
Even as the gap in poverty rates between whites and blacks narrowed nationally in 2000, it failed to change in New York City, according to a new analysis of Census Bureau data by an advocacy group for the poor.
 In contrast, the poverty rate declined steeply among Hispanic New Yorkers, who began the boom years of the mid-90's as the poorest group, and by 2000 had the same average poverty rate as non-Hispanic blacks. 
 The analysis, based on figures from house-to-house surveys by the Census Bureau, is to be released today by the advocacy group, the Community Service Society of New York, which has been tracking city poverty rates for decades. Using two-year averaging, the society found that New York's overall poverty rate declined in 1999-2000 to 19.9 percent, a level not seen since before the recession that began in 1990. The city's rate mirrored the national decline to 11.3 percent. 
The economist who analyzed the data for the society, Mark K. Levitan, said there were many possible explanations for the trends that emerged from the numbers, which were based on a small sample.
"It seems clear that Hispanics were able to take advantage of the city's expanding job market in ways that were not open to non-Hispanic blacks," Mr. Levitan said. "Casually walking down the street and taking a look at who is busing the tables, who is making the beds, who's minding the children -- we've had this rapid expansion of low-wage service work, and it appears that it's mainly Hispanics who are filling those jobs."
But another explanation, suggested by Andrew A. Beveridge, a professor of sociology at Queens College, is that the rising immigration of Hispanics with greater skills, education and money has changed the Hispanic population of New York. 
Using two-year averaging to compensate for a small sample size, Mr. Levitan found that the poverty rate for Hispanics was now at 28.9 percent in the city, statistically indistinguishable from the 26.5 percent poverty rate among non-Hispanic blacks, but much higher than the 9.2 percent poverty rate among non-Hispanic whites.
Mr. Levitan and Professor Beveridge both stressed that the official poverty line is too low to be a realistic benchmark of well-being in a city as expensive to live in as New York. An annual income below $17,603 qualifies a family of four as impoverished; for one person, the poverty line is $8,794. 
For those who took advantage of the expanding service economy, Mr. Levitan said, "a lot of those jobs might get people over measured poverty, or they might be working more than one job." 
Some people, he said, will contend that "these are jobs blacks will not take, that blacks think are below them." There may be some truth to that, he said, because people born in this country and immigrants from poor countries have different expectations about what constitutes an acceptable standard of living. 
But Mr. Levitan said that more important was "statistical discrimination."
"With so many people coming off the welfare rolls and so many people coming from abroad, even though the city economy was generating very high employment growth, for employers it was still a buyer's market," he said. "Employers will hire employees that they think will work long, hard hours for low pay, and who fits the image? The immigrant with a Spanish accent."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE RETAILERS; 
Red, White and Blue Christmas

BYLINE:  By LESLIE KAUFMAN and CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

 BODY:
Earlier this year, as Saks Fifth Avenue was starting to plan its ad campaign for Christmas 2001, it chose to highlight a piece of jewelry: a white-gold-and-diamond bracelet shaped like the Manhattan skyline, including the World Trade Center's twin towers. 
 After terrorist attacks leveled the towers on Sept. 11, Saks realized that it had to change course swiftly. The company removed photos of the bracelet from the cover of a glossy 12-page magazine insert and from the Christmas catalog that will be arriving at customers' homes in November. 
 Like Saks, retailers are grappling to find the right mix of commerce and sensitivity in the weeks after the attacks. The quest is as precarious as it is urgent because the fourth quarter, which begins next week, can generate as much as half their profits for the year. 
Even before the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, consumer confidence was down and merchants were preparing for the toughest holiday season in a decade. The assaults have thrown new questions into the planning and created an atmosphere in which what to sell and how to sell it have become highly charged issues. 
It is still fairly early in the season, and the national mood could metamorphose in any number of ways in the weeks from now to Thanksgiving, when the heavy buying really begins. Indeed, some merchants far from New York, including several of the largest mass market retailers, seem to be making fewer changes, at least for now. But many more say circumstances are forcing them to make at least preliminary alterations for the holidays, examining merchandise to make sure it upsets no one and thinking, at least, about changes that the times may demand.
Mall owners are already saying that patriotism will be a big theme. "Santa is going to look a lot like Uncle Sam this year," predicted Mark Rivers, a spokesman for the Mill Corporation, which operates 12 malls, including one only 15 miles from the Pentagon.
Across the nation, browsers are likely to hear standards like Eartha Kitt's "Santa Baby," but also military bands playing Christmas carols and patriotic tunes. Stars and stripes will be ubiquitous. Trees will be draped in red-white-and-blue bunting, not just silver tinsel.
Still, this will mostly be a season of omission, of products that will not be advertised, parties that will not happen. Lord & Taylor, a unit of Federated Department Stores, will still open its Christmas windows, but this year there will be no opening fete. "We're doing it with very little fanfare," said Lavelle Olexa, a company spokeswoman. 
Saks has indefinitely shelved the Live a Little tag line for its print ads. "We are trying hard not to offend anyone," said Sheri Wilson-Gray, chief marketing officer for Saks Fifth Avenue Enterprises. "We have a lot more to lose by seeming to be insensitive then we have to gain by selling any particular product."
Some retailers are reassessing their merchandise. Until a couple of weeks ago, a hand-held electronic game called Pox looked as if it was on its way to becoming the new hot toy. The game, made by Hasbro, is billed as a "game of alien creation and universal destruction" and involves players zapping each other with wireless signals that control or contain "pox" infections. 
Then there is Project Gotham Racing, a game developed by Microsoft for its new Xbox game console. Players speed in cars through the canyons of Manhattan, trying to avert disaster, while the twin towers and other New York points of interest loom in the background. 
Both are being played down by toy sellers these days. "In the toy business, you have to do what you can about predicting the hot products, but you also have to deal with product delays, or a dark horse, or a change in the national mood," said Jeanne Mayer, a spokeswoman for Toysrus.com, the online arm of Toys "R" Us, the country's largest toy retailer. 
Americans are being encouraged to shop, both as an act of patriotism and to help them get on with their lives after the attacks. But it is not clear that they are doing so. Moody's Investors Service said yesterday that credit card use declined significantly in the days after the terror attacks. 
For many people, shopping and celebrating seem inappropriate at a time when families are grieving and flags only recently stopped flying at half-staff.
"There is generally a sense of survivor guilt, that even if you didn't have anyone directly lost in this catastrophe, you have guilt about having lived through this," said Sylvia Welsh, a psychologist at the New York University Psychoanalytic Institute in Manhattan. "The perspective right now is that the self-indulgence of the last decade is at fault. The degree to which that is going on will affect the holiday season. It doesn't bode well for retailers." 
Holiday window displays are hastily being reviewed in light of the new national mood. At Barneys, long known for its unusual and topical holiday displays in its windows on Madison Avenue, this year's theme was planned six months ago, and "fortunately, we had gone in a very traditional, sweet direction," said Simon Doonan, the store's creative director. 
The windows will be witty, he added, but in a kinder way than in the past. Instead of the live models who were parked there last December, playing out a "Survivor" theme, the windows this year will feature Santa Claus and an assortment of elves. One elf will be based on Elvis Presley, another on Dostoyevsky, a third on Elton John. The theme will be Christmas, not American resilience. 
"It's going to be our version of a groovy grotto, Santa's groovy grotto," Mr. Doonan said. "The irony that usually pervades our Christmas windows is now inappropriate. There is going to be wry humor, but nothing sardonic." 
At Wal-Mart Stores, a spokesman said patriotic themes would pervade whatever displays Wal-Mart put together for the holidays. "You can be sure that the overriding theme in the stores will be patriotic," said the spokesman, Tom Williams. "There will be flags. The stores will have the Christmas theme, but it will be very clear that the country is aware of itself and aware of what's at stake. We're in the U.S. of A." 
Target Stores plans no changes in its advertising for the holidays, a spokeswoman said. "But certainly we have looked at the merchandise and tried to make sure that everything from the merchandise to the commercials to the print ads is sensitive and appropriate," said the spokeswoman, Carolyn Brookter. 
So far, Target, a 1,000-store chain, has not canceled any orders from its suppliers, but executives are maintaining a watchful attitude about holiday shopping. "Everybody is wondering about what will be happening then," she said. 
Before Christmas, of course, comes Thanksgiving, and some retailers are expecting that holiday to resonate more than usual this year. Williams-Sonoma, which starts its holiday offerings with turkey roasting pans at Thanksgiving and addresses December with an array of housewares, linens and luxury food products, has made no adjustments to its catalog since the attacks, a spokeswoman said. But the company does plan to position itself as a kind of helping hand to those preparing Thanksgiving and subsequent celebrations this year. 
"We have really expanded our offerings in the food category, with things like squash puree and focaccia stuffing and other items that make it easier for people to prepare a Thanksgiving," said the spokeswoman, Tracy Brown. "I think Thanksgiving is going to be particularly important to everybody affected by what happened on Sept. 11."

CORRECTION-DATE: September 29, 2001

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Thursday about retailers that are altering their marketing plans in the wake of the terrorist attacks misstated the ownership of Lord & Taylor, which said it would still open its Christmas windows, but without a celebration. It is part of May Department Stores, not Federated.

HEADLINE: Schools Closed by Disaster Are Losing Some Children 

BYLINE:  By ABBY GOODNOUGH

 BODY:
The idea of sending her daughters to unfamiliar, severely crowded schools while their Battery Park City neighborhood recovered from the World Trade Center attack was too much for Suzanne Schiffman. So she fled New York City last week and signed the girls up for school in the Hamptons, where their summer home has become a semipermanent refuge from the chaos of Lower Manhattan.
 "The public school they were attending in Battery Park City was pretty exclusive and the ones they'd have to transfer to, I would never send them there," said Ms. Schiffman, whose sixth grader is now attending a private school in East Hampton for $10,000 a year and whose second grader is at the public elementary school in Southampton. "It's easier living out here, they're happy and I know they're getting good schooling." 
 The decision by Ms. Schiffman and at least three dozen other parents to pull their children out of schools temporarily closed by the attack is but one sign of the extreme disruption, confusion and anger flowing through the communities closest to the disaster site. In the latest jolt, one of the shuttered schools, Public School 234 in TriBeCa, may move its 600 students a second time because its temporary site, P.S. 41 in the West Village, is unacceptably crowded. The new site is a Roman Catholic school, St. Bernard, which closed in June.
The close-knit communities of parents, teachers and administrators at P.S. 234 and six other schools closed by the attack have mostly done their stoic best to provide normality and sound instruction for the roughly 9,000 children who had barely settled into their classrooms when they were displaced on Sept. 11. But there are daily yelps of frustration and fear from parents, some of whom are displaced from their homes and taking drastic measures.
Anna Switzer, the principal of P.S. 234, said that up to 40 students had enrolled elsewhere since the attack. Ellen Foote, the principal of Intermediate School 89 in Battery Park City, which Ms. Schiffman's older daughter attended before the attack, said that four students had not come back, but added that more might leave if their families could not return to their apartments. The principal of P.S. 89 declined to comment, but a spokesman for Manhattan's District 2 said the school's attendance had hovered around 75 percent.
Ms. Switzer, for one, remained hopeful yesterday that most of the lost students would return once P.S. 234, one of the city's top-rated schools, gets back on the corner of Greenwich and Chambers Streets. 
A quick survey of schools in the Hamptons yesterday found that more than a dozen students from Lower Manhattan had transferred to the Ross School in East Hampton and the Hampton Day School in Bridgehampton, both private schools, and to several public schools. Elka Rifkin, the acting head of school at Hampton Day, said her school alone had accepted six elementary school students and four preschool students so far. Tuition for elementary school students is $12,000 to $14,000 a year, she said.
At Marshall Elementary School in East Hampton, Tom Lamorgese, the principal, said that two students from Lower Manhattan had enrolled last week. One student's family is displaced from its home indefinitely, he said, and the other's parents are simply "a little too nervous" to send their child to school in Manhattan right now.
Back in New York, Board of Education officials were lobbying the Office of Emergency Management yesterday to speed up the reopening of the shuttered schools. The city has already returned Stuyvesant High School to the board's control, and board officials said yesterday that its 3,000 students would return by Oct. 9. Another school, P.S. 150 in TriBeCa, is also on the fast track for reopening, the officials said.
The future was less clear for P.S. 234, which is being used by the Red Cross, and P.S. and I.S. 89, whose shared building has been commandeered by the Office of Emergency Management. Anthony Shorris, the deputy chancellor for management and policy, said yesterday that the board would definitely get the buildings back and begin cleaning them in October. He said the board was waiting on whether to transfer P.S. 234 students to the St. Bernard building until it knew more about when they could return to TriBeCa.
Two other schools, the High School for Leadership and Public Service and the High School of Economics and Finance, both on Trinity Place, are even closer to ground zero and will be closed longer.
Despite the trying circumstances, many parents at P.S. 89 and P.S. 234 were fiercely defending and praising their schools yesterday. Andrew Giangola, a TriBeCa resident, initially planned to home-school his daughter Gaby after the attacks occurred, but decided it was more important for her to be with her teachers and friends. He said he was "just completely taken" by the enthusiasm at P.S. 234.
"Our neighborhood is resilient, everyone is standing tall and we are trying to do the same," he said. "Gaby's in first grade, so if the disruption is only for a few weeks, I doubt this is going to affect her SAT scores."

HEADLINE: Terrorists Are Sought in Latin Smugglers' Haven 

BYLINE:  By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: CIUDAD DEL ESTE, Paraguay, Sept. 25 

 BODY:
For decades, this seedy border town has struggled with its reputation as the contraband capital of South America. But now the so-called Triple Frontier suddenly confronts a much bigger problem: 40 F.B.I. agents and police officers from three other countries are scouring the area for evidence that the region has become a haven for Islamic terrorists.
 "This is the very last thing that we needed here," lamented Faoud Fakih, a department store owner and prominent member of the Arab community here. "Business is already bad, and now we are going to be stained by an even more disastrous kind of propaganda?" 
 Argentina, Brazil and Paraguay meet here. Their porous common border has been a fluid and often-ignored barrier until now. Since the World Trade Center attacks, however, the Paraguayan police have been rounding up Arab immigrants who they say may have "links to militant groups" here that manufacture false passports and offer refuge and financing to terrorist networks.
Paraguay's former consul in Miami, Alejandro Weiss, is now under arrest, accused of having sold more than 300 passports, visas and cargo shipment authorizations at up to $8,000 apiece until he was fired this spring. At least 16 of those passports, the authorities say, ended up in the hands of suspect Lebanese, Syrian and Egyptian citizens who intended to melt into the fast-growing Arab community here.
Leaders of that community dismiss the entire effort as a witch hunt.
"There are people here who don't like the policy of the United States," said Ali Muhammad Hassan, the president of the local Islamic Society. "But that doesn't make them terrorists. You keep hearing people say things like that, and you get sick of it."
All told, an estimated 12,000 people of Arab descent, most of them members of Lebanese immigrant families, live in the Triple Frontier region. Many own or work in stores here in Paraguay, but choose to live on the Brazilian side of the border in Foz do Iguacu, which has an an Arabic school and social club, supermarkets that sell Muslim food products and four Arabic-language cable television channels. It also has a gleaming mosque on Palestine Street.
Among those who went undetected while he lived here was El Said Hassan Mokhles, an Egyptian who is now in jail in Uruguay, awaiting a court ruling on an extradition request by the Egyptian government. Arrested with a fake Malaysian passport as he was leaving Brazil early in 1999, Mr. Mokhles is wanted in Egypt on charges that he took part in a terrorist operation that killed 58 foreign tourists at Luxor in 1997.
What drew Arab businessmen here is the same thing that continues to attract people from China, Korea, India and Latin America: a chance to make a lot of money with little or no government interference. The annual turnover here is estimated at more than $12 billion, which would make the economy of Ciudad del Este larger than that of the rest of Paraguay.
Of course, nearly all of the Mont Blanc pens, Rolex watches, and other products sold here are fakes or pirates, imported from Asia or assembled in workshops on the edge of town. 
Thanks to Ciudad del Este, Paraguay has both a higher per capita consumption of whiskey than Scotland and a record consumption of cigarettes. These are often smuggled, or to use the favored local euphemism, "re-exported," to Argentina and Brazil.
"This is one of the world's great centers of lawlessness," said a Brazilian Federal Police official in Foz do Iguacu, just a 10-minute walk across the Friendship Bridge over the Parana River. "Every criminal activity that you can possibly think of flourishes here, from drug and arms trafficking to money laundering, counterfeiting, carjacking, contraband and prostitution."
On Monday, for instance, the Brazilian police seized more than 12 tons of marijuana hidden under a shipment of coal in a truck that had just crossed the border here.
It was a record haul, but the case has been overshadowed by the investigation into possible links between groups here and the attacks on the World Trade Center, with rumors that even Mossad, the Israeli intelligence agency, is involved.
The Argentine government was the first to step up surveillance activities in the area, acting after bombing attacks in Buenos Aires on the Israeli Embassy and a Jewish community center killed 115 people in the mid-1990's. Those attacks have been attributed to Hezbollah, with the Argentine authorities suggesting they were planned and organized at least in part here.
In 1997, the Argentine minister of the interior, Carlos Corach, described the Triple Frontier region as "a sanctuary" for crime and terrorism. Then as now, the government was accused of playing politics to cover up its inability to find the real perpetrators of the attacks.
"That response was orchestrated by the government of Carlos Menem, and he has no credibility whatsoever," said Mr. Fakih, the department store owner, referring to the former Argentine president who is now under house arrest in connection with illegal sales of arms to Croatia and Ecuador. 
But the Brazilian authorities tell much the same story, insisting that they have evidence that members of the Arab community here have financed Hezbollah.
If terrorists are really hiding out here, it should be easy for them to go unnoticed. More than nine million tourists visit the Triple Frontier area each year, to see the mighty Iguassu Falls, gamble at casinos or shop in the hundreds of shops that line both sides of the Parana River, which forms the border of the three countries.
"It's an anthill here, with all kinds of people coming from all over the world," said a Brazilian Federal Police official. "Every day we have more than 20,000 people crossing that bridge, and you can't stop and inspect them all."
The Brazilian police say they are also investigating the activities of Muhammad Kassem Jomaa, the mayor of Chui, a town just across the border from the Uruguayan customs post where Mr. Mokhles, the jailed Egyptian, was caught. Mr. Jomaa has acknowledged visiting Mr. Mokhle in jail, but the Brazilian authorities appear most concerned about his former wife's claim that he is a Lebanese and not a Brazilian citizen, which would make him ineligible for the office he holds.
As for Mr. Mokhles, his wife and three children still live here on charity supplied by sympathizers, according to Mr. Hassan. But the same Arab community leaders who complain of persecution here belittle the significance of the case against Mr. Mokhles anytime it is brought up.
"If someone has a problem with his government, is this our responsibility as a community?" asked Taleb Jomaa, imam of the the mosque the family attends in Foz do Iguacu. "This is an open city and I am not a police inspector, so if someone comes here and has had some problems, so what?"

(Agence France-Presse); (Reuters) Map of Paraguay highlights Cuidad del Este: F.B.I. agents are part of the hunt for terrorists in Cuidad del Este.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE GUARDIANS; 
Demand Up for Security Services

BYLINE:  By RALPH BLUMENTHAL and BARRY MEIER 

 BODY:
As the airlines and tourism industries reel from the fallout of the terrorist attacks, companies that offer security and protection say they are being overwhelmed with demands for their services from businesses, public agencies, colleges and cultural institutions.
 Those requests, the companies say, include stepped-up building security, background checks and screening of job applicants, evacuation plans for overseas employees and even the development of protection plans against chemical and biological attacks. 
 The demand has become so strong that many security companies said they had been forced to turn away new customers, and some businesses and institutions have spent fruitless hours seeking additional security staff.
"People are emotionally scarred by what happened, and employers are willing to do everything necessary to give the employees a feeling of safety," said Michael Stapleton, president of a New York-based company that bears his name and provides bomb-sniffing dogs. 
In New York, an executive of a performing arts organization said his office made 62 calls last week in an effort to find two retired or off-duty police officers to help at an event, a shortage he had never faced before. "Everyone wants them now in every building," the executive said, referring to security guards. 
Before the attacks on Sept. 11, the financial outlook of the $100 billion security industry was flat, said William Daly, a spokesman for Control Risks Group, a security consultant. All that has changed, and some security companies said they were getting requests for types of services that they had never received before. 
Terry Lenzner, the chairman of the Investigative Group International, a consulting firm based in Washington, said he received a call earlier this week from the president of a venture capital firm in New York City who wanted to protect his employees from a possible biological or chemical attack.
"He wanted to know whether they should buy gas masks," said Mr. Lenzner, who added that his firm was evaluating the request.
Security firms say that many businesses want to increase building security with more employee and visitor screening, including high-technology face- and fingerprint-recognition systems. Companies also want improved fire safety plans and protection for mailrooms and loading docks.
Mr. Stapleton, who heads the company that provides bomb-sniffing dogs, said that before Sept. 11, companies only wanted dogs when they received bomb threats. But now some Wall Street firms want dogs to routinely patrol the lobbies or guard the loading docks.
Security companies said businesses were also hiring them to do more-thorough background investigations of employees. And those requests are not limited to the private sector. Michael H. Boyle, a director of forensic and litigation services in the Miami office of KPMG, a consulting firm, said it had recently been contacted by local and county governments in Florida trying to find ways to improve background checks on employees.
Much of the increased demand is coming from companies in New York and Washington or those with overseas operations. Mr. Daly said Control Risks had been asked to develop evacuation plans for companies with overseas offices in the event of a protracted war.
Jules Kroll, chairman of Kroll Inc., a consulting firm in New York, said it had been hired by companies to assess how well their plants and buildings would withstand explosions or chemical attacks.
The turnabout in the security industry has meant that it is hiring employees when many companies battered by a weak economy and the terrorist attacks are cutting back.
Ira A. Lipman, chairman of Guardsmark Inc., a company based in Memphis that provides security services, said it had received a surge of phone calls from job-seekers including retired military officers. He and other industry officials said they were hiring retired agents from the Federal Bureau of Investigation and other law enforcement agencies.
Security industry executives said the biggest immediate demand was not for trained investigators but for building guards. But security experts said that new guards could not be hired overnight, especially in places like New York, which has some of the nation's strongest rules mandating background checks and training.
"That process can't be speeded," said Jack Donohue, a regional director for Securitas, which owns the Pinkerton Security Services and Burns International.
Many industry experts said they expected some of the new security measures would remain in place even after the demand for added services died down.
"A lot of things that we are doing now are more commonplace in European and Middle Eastern countries," said Mr. Boyle, the KPMG executive. "But while they adopted these kind of measures through a transitional period we are trying to accelerate them in a week."

HEADLINE: After Tragedy, Publicists Are Hyper About Hype 

BYLINE:  By GLENN COLLINS

 BODY:
The World Trade Center tragedy may not have blighted the public relations industry entirely, but it certainly has given the business of ballyhoo a bad name.
 Happy-face press releases go unread. Enthusiastic e-mail messages are unanswered. Since Sept. 11, editors, reporters and news producers "haven't been interested in writing stories that have nothing to do with the crisis," said Jack Bergen, president of the Council of Public Relations Firms, the industry's New York-based trade group. 
 New York City's $792 million public relations industry, the most prodigious conflation of communications representatives and spin managers on the planet, had already been reeling during a miserable year, thanks to a sinking economy.
For the industry, following a boom year, "it's like a freight train hitting a brick wall," Mr. Bergen said. The year 2000 was the greatest year ever for flackery, hoopla and hyperbole -- some $4.2 billion in estimated billings nationally, the highest ever -- and in New York City, the industry grew 24 percent, according to the council. Now Mr. Bergen worries that industry revenues could be down 5 to 10 percent for 2001.
Since the attack, journalists "are defining news differently," said Fern Berman, a food-industry publicist who watched the World Trade Center horror unfold from her 12th-floor office on 21st Street near Fifth Avenue. "I am heartbroken," she added, "and I understand that right now, journalists don't need to hear about things that are not important."
In New York City, Mr. Bergen said, many public relations people "are having a difficult time focusing on their work, because they've seen a tragedy in which their friends have been killed, and many have been pulled out of buildings during bomb scares. Some say the work is unimportant."
Many are rethinking their techniques, as the industry tries to figure out ways to be useful. On the day of the disaster, Howard J. Rubenstein assembled the 200 employees of his eponymous Manhattan firm and told them "that they are more relevant today than ever," he said. "And I told them not to take advantage of the tragedy for any client, to not do anything inappropriate."
But those who did not have his counsel have been branded tasteless and, worse, have been ridiculed. Some news releases have been collected in journalistic rogues' galleries, and sent by e-mail throughout the news trade.
Although the public relations business has long been comfortable with crisis management, "there is almost a new political correctness we have to worry about," Mr. Bergen said. "This is a crisis in which the old rules don't always apply."
Dan Klores Communications in Manhattan brought in grief counselors and had prayer sessions for its 120 employees, several of whom lost friends and relatives in the disaster. Mr. Klores said he lost one account, United Airlines, but has picked up a few new ones.
Other companies found a purpose from the first moments of the tragedy. Diaz-Schloss Communications, which has represented the parent company of Windows on the World, Night Sky LLC, since 1996, "fielded hundreds of calls round the clock from all over the world," said Karen Schloss, a co-owner.
"The disaster didn't make us question what we do," she said. "It reaffirmed what we do."
Mr. Bergen has advised public relations firms to instruct companies "how to express to their community how they feel about this," he said. "We suggest that they can donate to appropriate charities, and take out newspaper and magazine ads. The companies want to do it in a way that does not look opportunistic."
More and more non-trade center articles are creeping back into newspapers, newsmagazines and television news broadcasts. "We'll return to a more normal environment for public relations," said Mr. Rubenstein, "but in a way this has scarred all of our psyches. We will never forget these horrifying images."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: AID TO BUSINESS; 
Airline Bailout Encourages Other Industries to Lobby for Government Assistance

BYLINE:  By LESLIE WAYNE 

 BODY:
The $15 billion airline bailout approved overwhelmingly by Congress has lobbyists for other industries lining up now to make the case that their clients, too, need federal aid. 
 The insurance industry wants the government to help cover future terrorism-related losses. Travel agents want $4 billion. Pilots, restaurant workers and other groups want extra government money to provide shelter from the economic impact of the terror attacks. Big corporations are calling for huge tax cuts. 
 For corporate America, the spigots in Washington appear tantalizingly open: $40 billion in emergency money, the airline rescue package and a variety of other economic stimulus measures that Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, has suggested could amount to another $40 billion to $60 billion. With numbers this large, and with the economy already in a slump, business is casting a keen eye on what Washington can deliver.
"As soon as there was an announcement of an aid package, people started coming out of the woodwork," said James Albertine, president of the American League of Lobbyists, a trade group. "There are a lot of industries that will be looking at the pot of gold. The federal government is spending more and, obviously, there will be some winners. There's lots of opportunities and it cuts across all industries. It's pretty much open season."
Not so fast, caution some lawmakers. Fiscal conservatives, who expressed concerns about the $15 billion airline deal, are not enthusiastic about further tapping the Treasury for other bailouts. And House and Senate Republican leaders are reluctant to hand out more money for fear of creating a stampede. While Republicans want to help business with an overall stimulus package, which could include more tax cuts, and Democrats want to offer laid-off workers extended unemployment benefits, members of both parties are wary of the lobbying brigades.
The range of industries asking for help runs the business spectrum: Amtrak, hotels, restaurants, manufacturers, oil and gas, the steel industry and consumer products. They are calling for tax cuts, direct aid and support for new types of security-related activities.
Part of the reason the airlines scored so big -- aside from their dire straits -- was the platoons of high-powered lobbyists who scrambled to get the measure passed with lightening speed. Among them was Linda Hall Daschle, wife of Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Senate majority leader. Mrs. Daschle helped develop the lobbying strategy for American Airlines. "She is an aviation expert and she was extremely helpful to guide our company," said Al Becker, an American Airlines spokesman. Lobbyists for Continental Airlines included Rebecca Cox, wife of Representative Christopher Cox, a California Republican.
Their success last week is being cited as a model for others to follow -- if they can. But the corporate lobbyists know they could risk a backlash in Congress and among the general public if they appear as through they are trying to capitalize on a national tragedy.
"When Congress is looking at war and when you've got a lot of families grieving," said Kenneth E. Feltman, a lobbyist and former president of the lobbying league, "it isn't very becoming to go hat in hand."
Yet, in subtle ways and at the highest levels of government, that is what many lobbyists are doing. 
In line behind the airlines is the insurance industry. At a White House meeting last week with President Bush and more than a dozen insurance executives and lobbyists, the industry presented a new plan. Called Pool Re, it is a reinsurance pool, modeled after similar ones in Europe, that makes the federal government the insurer of last resort in acts of terrorism, lifting the burden of excessive payments from the industry. 
"We want the federal government to act as a backstop," said Julie Rochman, a senior vice president of the American Insurance Association. "It's not a bailout. It is not direct funding. We are not an industry lined up with our hand out."
Other industries are more clear that they want a handout. In testimony before a Congressional committee, Paul Ruden, senior vice president of the American Society of Travel Agents, painted a bleak picture of an industry about to be wiped out by a sudden downturn in travel. He is asking for $4 billion in grants and no-interest loans, and for protection against reductions in airline ticket commissions.
"There are a lot of industries being impacted by this; we are not alone," Mr. Ruden said. "But we have special problems, and if we are not helped, it could slow down the economic recovery."
John P. Connors, executive vice president of the American Hotel and Lodging Association, has been meeting with Congressional and administration officials to explain the problems facing hotels and to get support for immediate changes in the tax code. Among the changes he is seeking are increases in the deductibility of business meals, entertainment and spousal travel; a reduction in corporate tax rates; and financial help in installing new security systems.
To Mr. Connors, these items are not handouts. "We want to be responsible corporate citizens," he said. "We are not asking for corporate welfare."
Restaurant owners are haunted by the vision of a closed Ronald Reagan National Airport in Washington, with idled restaurants and absent customers. The National Restaurant Association is collecting data from restaurants around the country about how the national crisis is affecting them. 
In general, the industry continues pursuing its main legislative agenda, tax breaks for restaurants. Fearful of coming on too strong, Lee Culpepper, the government affairs director for the restaurant group, said he had spent the last two weeks trying to get information on the restaurant downturn to Congress rather than proposing legislation.
"I think lobbyists need to be very sensitive to running to Capitol Hill and asking for relief," Mr. Culpepper said. "I think we would be much better received if we provide information on the impact."
The steel industry says a military crisis means that the domestic steel industry needs further protections -- even though steel has become an increasingly small component in military products. And Amtrak, the passenger rail service, is asking for $3.2 billion in emergency money because of the increased use of trains, especially in the Northeast corridor.
Companies in many troubled industries will be joining with the A.F.L.-C.I.O. to endorse payments for laid-off workers. "It will not be inexpensive," said William Samuel, the labor federation's legislative director. "But given that we've already committed $40 billion to this effort, there are clearly resources to cover it."

HEADLINE: Scrambling to Survive, at a Small Chelsea Caterer 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH P. FRIED

 BODY:
The New England chicken potpie and the shrimp pasta salad were about to be loaded into the delivery vans at Jason's Catering -- regular buffet lunches en route to the World Trade Center for 300 employees of two companies that were the small catering firm's linchpin clients.
 But that was on the morning of Sept. 11, and so, of course, the lunches were never dispatched. The two companies accounted for 25 percent of the corporate catering firm's orders. Wholesale cancellations of business meetings and parties by other clients in Manhattan have the previously prospering Jason's, in the West 20's in Manhattan, reeling from a total business plunge of up to 75 percent, its owners say. 
 "We are hemorrhaging cash," one of the owners, Gary Lyons, said this week.
Throughout New York City, hundreds of small businesses, from travel agencies to livery taxi companies and messenger services, have suffered severe blows since the trade center attack. 
Some are in general fields, like travel and tourism, and others, like Jason's, did a major part of their business with companies that were in the trade center or close to it. 
It will probably be months before the attack's long-term effect on the city's small enterprises can be assessed, as many of the severely weakened companies succeed and others fail in the struggle to regain their footings. 
But Jason's offers a microcosm of this struggle and of the fears of workers at small businesses hit hard by the disaster. A nine-year-old company with 30 employees, Jason's had been built with a great deal of effort, said its second owner, John Jason. 
From a ground-floor kitchen that sends cooking aromas into the intersection of 11th Avenue and 28th Street in an industrial slice of Chelsea, the company catered thousands of meals a day for Midtown and downtown clients, like Sony, Ralph Lauren and Morgan Stanley Dean Witter.
Its steadiest, most reliable income, Mr. Lyons said, came from two accounts. One was Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, an investment firm on the 88th and 89th floors of 2 World Trade Center, which ordered a daily lunch for more than 100 employees. The other firm, Baseline Financial Services, an information technology company on the 77th and 78th floors of the same tower, had ordered a buffet lunch for 200 employees three days a week. 
Keefe, Bruyette has reported that a third of its employees at the trade center are missing. On Monday, nearly two weeks after the attack, a Keefe representative called on Jason's to begin supplying breakfast and lunch for 20 employees at one of the sites where the investment firm had temporarily relocated, Mr. Jason said.
He expressed confidence that this meant that Keefe, Bruyette would resume its high volume of business once it was again at a single location. 
So far there has not been any indication of what will become of the business with Baseline, he said.
As Mr. Jason, a tall, muscular 39-year-old, spoke about his efforts to resuscitate his business by drumming up new clients and seeking more jobs from existing ones, he suddenly choked up and fought back tears. 
"This is not about accounts receivable," he said. "I knew so many people in those buildings."
Unlike many catering operations, Jason's is not part of a restaurant or food shop and thus has no other income to offset catering losses. Mr. Lyons declined to provide overall revenue figures before Sept. 11 but said that despite the downturn in the economy, "We were having a good year, as strong or slightly stronger than last year." 
He said that "at least 80 percent" of the meals his company was to have catered since the attack and in coming weeks had been canceled, at a probable loss of about $100,000, which is in addition to the long-term losses involving the two main accounts.
No employees have been laid off, Mr. Jason said, and he expressed determination that none would have to be. "I truly believe we will rebuild this company," he said.
Nearby, looking up from bowls of pasta and platters of grilled chicken that he was routing for delivery, Glen James, 30, an employee from Brooklyn with a young daughter and a wife who works part time, made clear that he was rooting for his bosses.
"I've got to pay my rent," he said. "That doesn't stop."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
SKECHERS EXPECTING WEAK RESULTS AS SHOE COSTS RISE

BYLINE:  Reuters 

 BODY:
 The shoe company Skechers USA Inc. said yesterday that it expected third-quarter profit to fall sharply below analysts' estimates because of high costs and a weakening economy. The company, which designs and markets so-called lifestyle athletic shoes, cut its full-year earnings outlook in July and said yesterday that costs rose in July and August when sales exceeded its expectations, but it was unable to cut spending in September when sales slowed. Skechers, based in Manhattan Beach, Calif., said its third-quarter earnings will be "in line with or slightly lower than" the 40 cents a share it reported for the third quarter of 2000, compared with the analysts' average estimate of 51 cents compiled by the research firm Thomson Financial/First Call.

HEADLINE: National Briefing Washington: City Regains Control Of Finances 

BYLINE:  AP 

 BODY:
 Five years after it was formed to help steer Washington back from economic collapse, a presidentially appointed panel ceded control of District of Columbia government back to local officials. 
"The fiscal situation is just light years better," said the economist Alice M. Rivlin, the outgoing chairwoman of the panel, the District of Columbia Financial Responsibility and Management Assistance Authority. She was presiding over the authority's final meeting. The five-member panel was imposed by a Republican-controlled Congress in 1995, just months after Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr., who had spent six months in jail for a 1990 drug conviction, won a fourth term.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Lobbyists Line Up to Make Their Case for Federal Aid
The $15 billion airline bailout approved overwhelmingly by Congress has lobbyists for other industries lining up to make the case that their clients, too, need federal aid.
 For corporate America, the spigots in Washington appear tantalizingly open -- with $40 billion in emergency money, the airline rescue package and other economic stimulus measures that could amount to an additional $40 billion to $60 billion. Page B6. 

Many Ways to Lift Flagging Economy
If the administration and Congress decide the flagging economy needs an additional kick after the terrorist attacks, they have a long menu of policy choices available. B6.

Starwood Hotel Chief Plans Ahead
Barry Sternlicht, chairman of Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide, encouraged any assistance and cleanup his chains could provide immediately after the Sept. 11 attacks. But much of his focus was on long-term issues like offering displaced companies space and rallying fellow hoteliers to push for their own piece of the federal pie. C6.

How to Disrupt Terrorist Finances
Disrupting the finances of Osama bin Laden's terrorist network and others will require a global crackdown, including an end to laws in countries that allow secret bank accounts, the Senate Banking Committee was told. B6.

Washington's Moves Faulted
The lack of a strong voice from Washington on the economy has contributed substantially to the sense in America that the economic center is not holding and is feeding the recessionary fires. Jeff Madrick: Economic Scene. C2.

Three Major Gauges Give Up Gains
Stocks gave up gains and headed lower. The Dow Jones industrials fell 92.58 points, or 1.1 percent, to 8,567.39. The Nasdaq composite index fell 37.60 points, or 2.5 percent, to 1,464.04. And the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 5.23 points, or 0.5 percent, to 1,007.04. C8.

Delta and Sky Chefs Announce Cuts
Delta Air Lines became the latest airline to announce cuts and reduce flights -- up to 13,000 jobs worldwide and a 15 percent reduction in its schedule -- because of a plunge in demand. Also, LSG Sky Chefs said it would lay off 4,800 of its 16,000 employees. C6.

Uncertainty Increases on Campuses
The economy was already turning against students who will enter the job market in the spring, but the attacks have greatly increased the level of uncertainty on campuses. C4.

Coke-P.& G. Venture Called Off
Coca-Cola and Procter & Gamble called off plans for a joint venture that they had announced in February. The partnership would have combined Coca-Cola's Minute Maid business and P.& G.'s Sunny Delight drink and Pringles Chips brands. Analysts have been predicting the deal's demise for months. Shares of Coca-Cola fell $1.11, to $46.89. P.& G. rose 13 cents, to $71.13. C12.

$2.9 Billion Deal for Power Concern
Reliant Resources has agreed to acquire Orion Power Holdings, an electric power generator, for $2.9 billion in cash, executives said. C7.

$100 Million Bid for Gehl Rejected
A $100 million bid by Harold C. Simmons, the billionaire corporate raider, for Gehl, a small equipment maker, lost out. C2.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place; 
What's Eating Those Giant Media Stocks?

BYLINE:  By SETH SCHIESEL 

 BODY:
The stocks of almost all major media companies have fallen since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. But some are down more than others, and one -- Vivendi Universal -- has even risen.
 Why have different media companies fared differently, and why is the outlook for some of them shakier than for others? 
 It all depends on their relative exposure to the economic uncertainties in the aftermath of Sept. 11 -- especially the implications for tourism and the United States advertising markets. And so far, investors generally seem to have factored those relative risks into the companies' share prices. 
The media company that appears to be most exposed on the advertising and tourism fronts, Walt Disney, has experienced a 26 percent drop in its stock price since the attacks. Shares of Vivendi, which draws only small parts of its revenue from theme parks and advertising, are up 3 percent.
In between are the recent stock performances of the media giants whose exposure to advertising and tourism falls between the Disney and Vivendi extremes. Shares of Viacom have fallen 14.4 percent; the News Corporation, 22.4 percent; and AOL Time Warner, 6.3 percent.
Based on estimates and the companies' own reports, Disney has the most revenue pegged to advertising and tourism -- about 56 percent. The next is Viacom at 47 percent; the News Corporation, slightly more than 32 percent; AOL Time Warner, 23 percent; and Vivendi, only about 4 percent. 
(Two other media giants are not included here: Bertelsmann, which is privately held, and Sony, the bulk of whose revenue comes from consumer electronics.)
The revenue percentages, of course, are not a perfect guide to the newly changed media landscape. There are other forces particular to each company, like the fact that members of the Bass family of Texas sold more than 6 percent of Disney's outstanding shares last week to help cover their own big losses in other stocks. 
And the media companies most at risk now, of course, are the same ones that appear poised to benefit the most whenever the advertising market finally improves and if consumers become more willing to travel. 
But it is telling that on Sept. 17 alone, the first day markets were open after the terrorist attacks and before the Bass move, shares of the five big companies were already moving in ways that reflected their relative exposures to advertising and tourism: Disney stock dropped the most, followed by the News Corporation, Viacom, AOL and Vivendi.
While the United States advertising market had been in the doldrums all year because of the dot-com collapse and the overall slowing of the economy, the Sept. 11 attacks largely dashed hopes for a quick recovery. Overseas advertising markets also appear to have suffered this year, but analysts say the terrorist attacks are less likely to play a direct role in determining their course. So only domestic advertising has been included in these risk calculations. 
As for the impact of the attacks on tourism, consider Disney, which drew nearly a third of its revenue -- and almost half of its operating income -- from its theme parks and resorts operation in its most recent fiscal quarter. 
Some of Disney's park revenue is generated overseas, and the company has said that its foreign parks have had no drop in visitors since Sept. 11. But as the early news photographs showed nearly deserted Main Streets at Disney's parks in California and Florida, investors were badly alarmed, even though the company says that attendance is now rebounding.
While the downturn in tourism has been severe, it may not last as long as the poor advertising environment, depending on whether there are any more major attacks. Compared with the falloff in travel, the stagnation in advertising is a result of a broader, more complex set of economic factors.
If tourism returns to normal more quickly than advertising does, Viacom and the News Corporation could be in more trouble than Disney. Viacom generates slightly more than 45 percent of its revenue from United States advertising, while the News Corporation derives about a third. For Disney and AOL Time Warner, the figure is slightly less than a quarter of revenue. And for Vivendi it is less than 1 percent. 
Even at the other companies where stocks have fallen, there may be pockets of strength. Disney's family-oriented films could be more popular than ever. And Viacom's Blockbuster unit, for instance, may see an uptick in video rentals and sales as people stay home. Much the same could potentially be said of Disney's family-oriented videos.
Through yesterday's close of trading, the one disparity between revenue at risk and the movement of share prices involved the News Corporation and Viacom. While the News Corporation's price declined only slightly more than Viacom's on Sept. 17, since then News Corporation shares have fallen much farther, even though Viacom has more revenue pegged to advertising and tourism. What's more, Viacom warned last week that its financial results this year would be below previous forecasts.
But more than bad news, uncertainty is detested by investors. The News Corporation and its chairman, Rupert Murdoch, have given investors little guidance since the attacks. In contrast, Viacom's top executives, Sumner M. Redstone and Mel Karmazin, have been holding conversations with big investors, analysts say.
Riding above the turmoil, for now, is Vivendi, which is based in Paris and is the only one of the five media companies whose shares have risen since Sept. 10. It does have a theme park business, including the Universal parks in Florida and California, but that unit contributes only about 3.4 percent of revenue. 
More important, only about 4 percent of Vivendi's overall revenue is generated by advertising, and that figure is set to decline as the company sells off European magazines.
And Vivendi has almost no direct presence in the United States television business. Long term, that remains a big weakness for the company. In the current environment, however, it can look like a strength.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE AIRLINES; 
Delta Announces Job Cuts and Reductions in Service

BYLINE:  By SHERRI DAY 

 BODY:
In the latest blow to the ailing airline industry, which has lost billions of dollars because of the terrorist attacks, Delta Air Lines said yesterday that it would cut up to 13,000 jobs worldwide and reduce its flight schedule by 15 percent because of a plunge in the demand for air travel.
 Delta, the nation's third-largest airline, is the latest carrier to cut its work force to maintain its financial viability. Last week, 12,000 job cuts were announced by Continental Airlines; 11,000 by US Airways; 20,000 by the AMR Corporation, the parent company of American Airlines and Trans World Airlines; and 20,000 by UAL, the parent company of United. Among the major carriers, only Southwest Airlines has not announced job cuts. 
 Airline analysts said that with Delta's announcement, the total number of job losses in the aviation industry exceeded 100,000. That figure includes job cuts by airline-related companies like Boeing, which plans to cut up to 30,000 jobs, and the airline caterer LSG Sky Chefs, which said yesterday that it would lay off 4,800 of its 16,000 employees.
If airline travel continues to slump, airlines could lose as much as $11 billion in international revenue this year, the International Air Transport Association said.
The airline industry lost hundreds of millions of dollars when the government grounded all flights and sealed off domestic airports for two days after the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11. The attacks also made many people afraid to fly. On Friday, Congress voted to give the industry $5 billion in emergency aid and $10 billion in loan guarantees.
But Leo F. Mullin, Delta's chairman and chief executive, said yesterday that the $5 billion bailout, of which Delta will receive about $650 million, would cover the company's losses only for this month. Company officials estimate that Delta will post revenue losses of $2 billion through Dec. 31. The number of people aboard the company's flights has decreased by at least 30 percent since the attacks.
For example, on the Delta shuttle flights from Boston to New York yesterday, only 200 passengers were on board, Mr. Mullin said. Before the attacks, the shuttle flights carried about 3,000 people a day.
"Prior to Sept. 11, any discussion that questioned our airline's capacity for financial survival would have been unthinkable," Mr. Mullin said. "The operational and financial outlook for airlines has changed precipitously and drastic measures are required if we are to avoid becoming the first economic casualty of the war."
The job cuts, Mr. Mullin said, are needed to stem the company's losses. 
Mr. Mullin also said he would forgo his salary for the rest of the year. The chief executives of two other airlines, Donald J. Carty of American and Gordon Bethune of Continental, have also decided to give up their salaries for the remainder of the year.
Delta, based in Atlanta, has given its affected employees, who range from baggage handlers to pilots, six options regarding their dismissals including early retirement, voluntary severance, and one-, two-, three- and five-year voluntary leave packages. Some workers will also be put on furlough, a move that makes it impossible to know immediately which parts of the country will register the most job cuts, said Cindi Kurczewski, a company spokeswoman.
The majority of Delta's flight reductions, which are to begin on Nov. 1, are in Orlando, Fla., where the carrier will fly 38 percent fewer flights because of a decline in leisure travel. In New York, Delta will decrease flights by 36 percent, with the greatest reduction at Kennedy International Airport. That is in part because several international flights will be suspended until March.
Shares of Delta rose 34 cents, to $24.86.
Airline analysts said that Delta's announcement, which was made at a news conference yesterday, would likely serve as a precursor to revenue warnings from other airline companies.
"We will see a couple of carriers have to seek consolidation," said Kevin C. Murphy, an analyst at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. "This has really broken the back of the industry."
