HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE ALLIANCE; 
MILITARY CALLED JUST ONE ELEMENT IN WAR ON TERROR

BYLINE:  By JAMES DAO with PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Sept. 26 

 BODY:
Facing some skepticism from NATO allies over going to war to eradicate terrorism, the Bush administration said today that military operations would not be the "primary piece" of its campaign.
 At a meeting of NATO defense ministers that offered the administration a first opportunity to convey detailed plans to the alliance, some European states pressed for, but did not get, a detailed showing of evidence that would justify any attack on Osama bin Laden's Al Qaeda network in Afghanistan. 
 Rudolf Scharping, the German defense minister, said he had expected Paul D. Wolfowitz, the deputy defense secretary, to arrive with a "white paper" spelling out the evidence connecting terrorist acts to Al Qaeda.
But administration officials are still debating how much information to make public since much of it rests on secret communications intercepts. The allies had been led to expect more by Secretary of State Colin L. Powell's statement last Sunday that the government would "put before the world, the American people, a persuasive case." Page B4. 
After the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, NATO invoked for the first time an article of its founding treaty that says an attack on one member will be considered an attack on all. A sustained alliance military campaign against terrorism seemed possible, but today Mr. Wolfowitz said: "If we need collective action, we will ask for it. We don't anticipate that for the moment." 
Before the NATO meeting, a senior Pentagon official told reporters that the United States would ask the alliance for logistical, intelligence and other support, but "the military piece is not the primary piece." 
Some American military planners expressed private frustration today about the unattractive array of military options in war-torn Afghanistan, where destitute refugees were reported to be in flight toward the sealed borders of Iran and Pakistan. 
As a result, the Bush administration was being forced to broaden the scope of its planning for a possible humanitarian disaster while also lowering somewhat expectations for a major military campaign, officials said. Expectations had been raised by a steady buildup of American troops and aircraft in the Persian Gulf and elsewhere.
"The people of Afghanistan are already beginning to suffer the humanitarian consequences from this -- just in anticipation of events," a senior Pentagon official said, referring to possible military strikes against Mr. bin Laden's network.
Russia has helped decisively in preparations for any military action in Afghanistan and today it was rewarded. The United States, in a clear shift, stated for the first time that the Al Qaeda network played a role in inciting the bloody rebellion in the Russian territory of Chechnya, where the Russian Army has been accused of using indiscriminate force against civilians and committing numerous human rights abuses in putting down the revolt. 
Mr. Wolfowitz provided an overview of the administration's case against Mr. bin Laden, but did not go into detail, officials said. 
In public remarks, Mr. Wolfowitz said the "evidence is there for the whole world to see."
"Many of the people in this room watched it live on television," he said, referring the images of aircraft crashing into the World Trade Center. "There is no question that the Al Qaeda organization has been convicted in courts of law for acts of terrorism, including the bombing of our embassies in East Africa." 
The desire of some ministers for more evidence caused tension, but in the end there was at least public backing from the allies for the administration's antiterror campaign.
Still, as Mr. Wolfowitz explained that the United States would seek different kinds of help from NATO states, some worried that the American approach could lead to a wider war. "Most people in Europe would like to see that only the ones who are found guilty are hunted down and penalized," one NATO official said.
The NATO secretary general, Lord Robertson, questioned whether it was even necessary for "an ally to produce evidence." 
Even as administration officials voiced confidence that Mr. bin Laden was guilty, they seemed less sure that he could be brought to justice simply by military strikes.
"The diplomatic instrument with the intelligence instrument with the military instrument," a senior administration official said, "are much more effective than any one of them individually." It is important to understand, the official emphasized, "that if we take military action, one of the major objectives of that action will be to get more information; there is nothing more important in this war than information." 
Administration officials said today that they were urgently trying to marshal food aid for the Afghan people.Just a week ago, White House officials were opposed to efforts to send more aid, saying it would fall into the hands of Taliban fighters.
The International Monetary Fund today approved a $135 million loan installment for Pakistan in a sign that economic policy was being used to shore up critical allies. 
The shift in the administration's Russia policy was first announced at the White House, when Mr. Bush's spokesman, Ari Fleischer, delivered a strong expression of gratitude and support to the Russian president, Vladimir V. Putin, for aligning Russia with the United States against terrorism. In doing so, another senior Bush administration official said, "We know that Al Qaeda has exploited the war in Chechnya, may have even helped to provoke it." 
These remarks showed how much importance the Bush administration attached to Mr. Putin's identification with the Western cause. Russia agreed to open air corridors and played a decisive role in persuading Central Asian states to open bases for military and relief operations on Afghanistan's northern flank.
Mr. Fleischer's remarks were a sharp reversal of Mr. Bush's tone on Chechnya. During the presidential campaign, Mr. Bush said that international financing for Russia should be cut off because of Mr. Putin's crackdown in Chechnya. "This guy, Putin, who is now the temporary president, has come to power as a result of Chechnya," Mr. Bush said in a television interview in February 2000. Mr. Putin dealt with Chechnya in a way "that's not acceptable to peaceful nations," he said. 
At a meeting with Muslim leaders today, Mr. Bush stopped short of Mr. Fleischer's comments, saying that Mr. Putin should "deal with the Chechnya minority in his country with respect" for human rights. 
"I would hope that the Russian president while dealing with the Al Qaeda organization also respects minority rights within his country."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE MONEY TRAIL; 
Pressing for Rules to Follow Terrorists' Cash

BYLINE:  By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 

 BODY:
Disrupting the finances of Osama bin Laden's terrorist network and others will require a global crackdown, including an end to laws in tax haven countries that allow secret bank accounts, the Senate Banking Committee was told today.
 The ease with which Al Qaeda, the terrorist network of Mr. bin Laden, has moved money around the world has drawn close scrutiny here as the nation searches for ways to fight an enemy that is not a state, but a network of radicals operating in perhaps 35 countries. 
 Americans, as well as residents of France and some other countries, have long lived with rules requiring banks to keep detailed records that are available to law enforcers, experts on money laundering and terrorism said. These experts urged that these rules be adopted by every country. Countries that refuse to comply should be shut out of global financial markets, current and former federal law enforcement and diplomatic experts testified. 
Most industrial countries have adopted bank disclosure rules, and even the Swiss, with a reputation for confidentiality, have come to cooperate with financial investigations of terrorism, drug dealing and looting of governments. But about three dozen tiny countries and much of the Middle East remain closed to investigators of financial crimes.
Tiny island nations like Nauru allow foreigners to create shell banks and businesses into which the trail of tens of billions of dollars abruptly ends because financial records are officially secret. Perhaps 2 percent of the global economy represents laundered money, the committee was told. The experts said that disclosure rules not only must apply to every country, they must extend beyond banks to stock brokerage firms, casinos, check-cashing services and informal money-transfer businesses.
The witnesses also called for closing loopholes that let the known assets of terrorists, drug dealers and tax cheats slip away even when they are on deposit in American banks. One loophole in American law shields the accounts of foreign banks at American banks, known as correspondent bank accounts, even when the money in them can be clearly identified as belonging to a specific terrorist or criminal.
An early sign of whether the financial front of the new war on terrorism is succeeding will be whether the prices charged by money launderers rise, said Jimmy Gurule, Treasury under secretary for enforcement. 
He said the administration was also moving up by six months, to Dec. 31, the deadline for domestic nonbank financial services businesses to register with the government. The registration is required under a 1993 measure to combat money laundering, a law that has not been fully carried out because of disputes over administrative rules.
Without nearly uniform worldwide rules on keeping financial records and making them available to investigators, the battle against money laundering that finances terrorism cannot succeed, said Jonathan Winer, a Washington lawyer who led the State Department's law enforcement efforts from 1994 to 1999.
"Cutting off terrorist finance is like cutting the heads of the hydra," Mr. Winer said. "Every time we chop off one head, more will grow back in place. To survive we must kill the entire beast and that means more than a single bin Laden or any part of his related terrorist finance networks."
Much of the hearing focused on concerns by Senator Phil Gramm, the Texas Republican and ranking committee member, who said that last year he killed a similar money laundering bill. The bill passed a House committee with one dissenting vote, but came under fire from Representatives Dick Armey, Tom DeLay and Ron Paul, all Texas Republicans.
Senator Gramm expressed concerns about violation of the due process rights of banks and their customers whose funds are frozen or seized because of suspected terrorist activities. 
Senator Gramm asked whether "a guy named Bobby Ben Loden from Iraan, Texas, has a right to come forward and say 'My name is Loden and I'm from Texas and you have made a mistake here.' "

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths; 
CIAFARDINI, CHRISTOPHER

 BODY:
 CIAFARDINI-Christopher. Died Tuesday, September 11, 2001 in the tragic destruction of the World Trade Center in New York City. He was 30 years old and a Vice President, Financial Analyst at Fred Alger Management, Inc. He joined Fred Alger Management, located on the 93rd floor of World Trade Center Tower North, in March of this year. Born May 8, 1971, Christopher leaves behind a loving family and many close friends and admiring co-workers. He is survived by his father, Edward, of East Norwich, New York; his mother, Maggie, of New York City; and an older brother, Dominic, also of New York City. Christopher also leaves behind loving grandparents, and numerous aunts, uncles and cousins. "Christopher was a quiet, deliberate man who had strong opinions and high ideals," Dominic recalls of his brother. "He had a passion for Wall Street, and was so happy to be working high in the sky for Fred Alger Management." Prior to Fred Alger Management, Christopher worked at Merrill-Lynch, Morgan Stanley, Gruntal, and CitiGroup. Christopher attended Oyster Bay High School on Long Island, NY. He graduated with distinction from the University of Colorado at Boulder in 1993, receiving a Bachelor of Arts degree in Economics. At Boulder, Christopher was a member of Phi Beta Kappa, the Golden Key National Honor Society, and Omicron Delta Epsilon International Honor Society in Economics. Christopher also attended the Johnson Graduate School of Management at Cornell University, where he received a Master of Business Administration in May 1999. 
Because of his dedication to his educational pursuits, Christopher was awarded a Johnson School merit-based scholarship. He greatly enjoyed his experience there and sought to continue his connection to the university after graduation by joining the Cornell Club in New York City. To honor his affection for Cornell and the Johnson School his family has established a scholarship in his memory. The family requests that in lieu of flowers and other expressions of condolence, contributions be made to: The Christopher Ciafardini Scholarship, care of SC Johnson Graduate School of Management, Cornell University, 221 Sage Hall, Ithaca, NY 14853. A Memorial Mass will be held for Christopher on Friday, October 5, at 10:30 AM at St. Thomas More's Church, 65 East 89 St. (between Madison Ave. and Park Ave.), in New York City.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene; 
In responding to terrorism, the administration is falling short on the economic front.

BYLINE:  By Jeff Madrick; Jeff Madrick is the editor of Challenge Magazine and a collection of essays, "Unconventional Wisdom: Alternative Perspectives on the New Economy." He teaches at Cooper Union and the New School. E-mail: challenge@mesharpe.com.

 BODY:
DIPLOMATIC and military efforts may rightly take precedence, but the White House has provided minimal economic leadership since the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. What action has been taken, notably the aid to airlines, has been more a reaction to a clear-cut emergency than part of a coordinated plan.
 The lack of a strong public voice on the economy has contributed substantially to the sense in America that the economic center is not holding and is itself feeding the recessionary fires. President Bush's first speech on the economy was inexplicably relegated to a radio address last Saturday, 11 days after the attack. 
 Consider what the president might have said two or three days after the attacks. He could have stood before the nation and said -- to list a few possibilities -- that he would keep the mails running on time, get FedEx and U.P.S. back in the air, be certain there was enough telephone capacity to handle the rising load and put the federal government in charge of airport security.
He could have gone further. He could have asked for a patriotic gesture from big business. He could have suggested that it wait three or four weeks before laying off any worker to give him time to start the economy moving. Letting go 100,000 workers almost immediately, as the airline and aerospace industries did, was hardly an act of patriotism. Granted, the airlines are in trouble, but so is America. The growing prospect of losing a job has sent a shiver down the spine of many Americans. The support package to the airlines should have included a provision about the retention of as many jobs as possible. Working people have to be placed on the agenda again.
The mere presence of a strong president aware of the risks and potential economic pain would have provided serious comfort to the nation, much as Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's constant presence did in New York City. But instead we got platitudes about how the terrorists would not break America's spirit, and no substance.
There is every reason to believe that the economy has not been centrally damaged in any way. But what is important to understand is that recessionary behavior can feed on itself. If left unattended, unemployment can rise and profits fall much more than necessary. It is more than a little surprising that Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, has urged lawmakers to wait a while to see how bad conditions really are. That is like letting the patient bleed to see if the wound will heal itself. Maybe it will, but the bleeding itself will usually make matters worse.
The main concern, which Mr. Greenspan and others know well, is that the attacks came when there were many imbalances in the economy. Consumers are heavily indebted, savings rates are low, the dollar is high, the trade deficit is enormous, capital spending has dried up and, by historical standards, stocks are still overvalued. And a serious recession was almost certainly under way before Sept. 11. If dispirited consumers on average now begin saving just one percentage point more, they will reduce the nation's gross domestic product by roughly $100 billion. And they may save two or three percentage points more. 
The priority, even conservative economists now agree, is to pump money into the economy temporarily. Congress and the administration are preparing stimulus packages. The president has agreed to about $50 billion in emergency expenditures so far, but even if the new packages come to $100 billion, it is likely to be too little. A minimum of $200 billion to $300 billion of stimulus the next two years is probably needed. Some economists, like James K. Galbraith of the University of Texas and Wynne Godley of the Jerome Levy Institute at Bard College, say significantly more is required. 
What should the president do?
First, he should speak frankly. He should stop superfluous cheerleading, which the public mistrusts, and tell us precisely what he will do to maintain prosperity. In the economic arena, this administration has no equivalent of the steady public voice of Secretary of State Colin L. Powell. It is up to the president.
Second, tax cuts should take second place to public spending. But if there is no political way to avoid them, the tax cuts should be designed to be spent quickly, which means they should be directed toward middle-income and poorer workers. Cutting payroll taxes is the best alternative.
Third, new public spending should be aimed at those hurt most in a recession. Most important, the coverage of unemployment insurance, which has been radically reduced since the 1980's, should be expanded. Benefit payments should also be accelerated. These expenditures will rise in recession but fall when the economy recovers.
Some economists also sensibly advocate raising the amount of money available for revenue sharing with the states, which are cutting back spending on public services as a slowing economy reduces their tax revenues.
But, also, the best new social programs should now be put in place. These include health care programs as well as public investment in infrastructure, new railroad systems, education, and day care, all of which will strengthen the economy in the future. This may indeed mean permanently higher expenditures, but the nation has too long neglected its public investment under the guise of good economics, which the failures of the airline security system make all too clear.
Finally, the nation will spend on its military, its security and perhaps to support more ailing industries, like travel and insurance. Rebuilding Lower Manhattan will provide long-term economic benefits and pay for itself. But the greater danger is that we will exaggerate these needs when health care and specific areas of public investment have been so long neglected.
Mr. Godley makes one further important point. Stimulus to the American economy, without similar stimulus overseas, could send the nation's imports way up without a commensurate rise in exports. If the trade deficit soars, it will put pressure on an already overvalued dollar to fall rapidly, stimulating inflation and higher interest rates. Mr. Godley urges a coordinated stimulus package among developed nations.
This administration seems trapped in a noninterventionist ideology that had become the order of the day. But it is a new day. And if the action is swift enough, unnecessary pain can be avoided.

HEADLINE: NYC; 
Life Goes On, And Exits Must Be Made

BYLINE:  By CLYDE HABERMAN

 BODY:
MAYBE our universe didn't turn upside down as thoroughly as we had thought. That was one of the more surprising conclusions to be drawn yesterday from the New York City primary.
 Ever since our terror-induced nightmare began on Sept. 11, we have heard incessantly how nothing will be as it was before. The New York that we once knew was gone, we were told. Our cultural institutions may be in peril. The movies will have to search for new themes. Fashions will be different. No one will want to read the gossip columns. 
 Why, we may never smile again, or so suggested some sages who solemnly declared that the World Trade Center catastrophe had ushered in, as one put it, "the end of the age of irony."
Somehow, a New York that suffers terminally from irony deficiency anemia is a bit hard to imagine. A brief glimpse of Jay Leno telling an Osama bin Laden joke on the tube early yesterday suggests that not all of us have lost the American talent for laughing our way through horror.
Now we have the election results to suggest quite strongly that, even in our grief, life does go on. Not the same as before, of course. How could it? But New Yorkers' concerns, and their expectations of their local leaders, are in many respects what they were all along.
For starters, the voter turnout on Tuesday seems to have been about 26 percent. That is hardly great, but for New York it's not half bad. The pre-Tuesday conventional wisdom was that our souls were so crushed that it would be a minor miracle if more than 34 people showed up to vote. New Yorkers proved a lot more durable.
Conventional wisdom, foolishly accepted by this corner of the newspaper, also had it that Fernando Ferrer would lose ground, for who would want to hear now about this being a divided city? Who would vote for someone promising to be the antithesis of the wildly popular Rudolph W. Giuliani?
Many people, as it turned out. Mr. Ferrer, the Bronx borough president, finished first in the Democratic mayoral primary, ahead of the favored public advocate, Mark Green.
Nor have New Yorkers' top priorities been radically altered by the terrorists, especially among Democratic voters, still dominant in this city. Consider a survey done by Edison Media Research of Somerville, N.J., which interviewed people as they left polling stations.
They were asked to name their most important issue. The largest group of Democrats, 30 percent, said education, which was also No. 1 in most polls before Sept. 11. In second place was the economy, cited by 21 percent. "Preventing future terrorist attacks" came in third, with 16 percent.
As for qualities sought in a mayoral candidate, the largest group, 37 percent, wanted someone who "understands the city and its problems." A mere 3 percent emphasized that this person should be "strong in a crisis" (a trait also mentioned by only 8 percent of the Republicans surveyed).
THE focus that was there before is the focus today," said Julie Weprin of Blum & Weprin Associates, New York pollsters. "It doesn't minimize the jolt that we received. But the issues that concerned us before still do."
William B. Eimicke, a political science professor at Columbia University, said that the Edison poll results underscored New Yorkers' resilience. "We're saddened," Professor Eimicke said. "But I think the attitude has been, 'We're going to go on with our lives.' "
No one, he added, has embodied the chin-up spirit better than Mr. Giuliani. That is why the professor is not alone in wondering if the mayor is doing that spirit or himself much good by looking now for a way around the term-limits law that will force him out of office on Dec. 31.
Mr. Giuliani said yesterday that New York was emerging from the immediate crisis. As the weeks roll on, assuming no more terrorist attacks, the sense of crisis will inevitably recede. And life being what it is, many New Yorkers are bound to focus less on the gallant mayor of recent weeks and more on aspects of his personality that fail to inspire.
Baseball, Mr. Giuliani's beloved sport, provides a useful lesson, even if it involves the Boston Red Sox and not his cherished New York Yankees. In 1960, the great Ted Williams of the Red Sox was about to retire. As that season neared an end, he hit a home run. That was it, Williams said, with a grand flourish. He made it his last time at bat.
As the mayor surely senses, there can be no more graceful way to leave the field than having just hit a home run.

HEADLINE: State Seeks to Play a Role In the Reconstruction Effort 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA

 BODY:
Officials in Albany and Washington say that the effort to rebuild after the destruction of the World Trade Center will be controlled primarily by the state and federal governments, not the city, although they concede that as yet, they have little idea what that effort would look like or how it would be managed.
 In the two weeks since the attack, much attention has been focused on the city's recovery efforts. The only specific step toward rebuilding came from Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and City Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone, who have said they will create a reconstruction commission, and Mr. Giuliani's name has often been mentioned to head that panel. But state and federal officials say there is little that a city-only effort can accomplish. 
 "It is not realistic," said Senator Joseph L. Bruno, a Republican and the Senate majority leader. "The city will do whatever they feel is appropriate, but they're going to have to deal with the state. The state is going to have to have prime responsibility."
"The city can't do what's needed on its own," said Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, a Democrat. "I think there has to be a global redevelopment authority that goes well beyond just the jurisdiction of the city."
State officials in particular are determined that they will lead what could become the largest public works project of its time, and they tick off a long list of reasons. The trade center site is owned by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which is controlled by the governors of the two states; much of the nearby damaged property belongs to two state agencies, the Battery Park City Authority and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority; and much of the promised federal aid is likely to be funneled through Albany.
They also note that the city needs permission from the Legislature and Gov. George E. Pataki to take major financial steps like selling billions of dollars in bonds or imposing or cutting taxes. In the first days after the attack, Mr. Vallone and Mr. Giuliani turned to Albany for a $2.5 billion increase in the city's borrowing authority, which the state granted. The state also has broad power to alter city laws, over objections from City Hall.
But the federal government is likely to provide most of the money to help businesses and individuals recover economically -- it has committed $20 billion, compared to $500 million from the state -- and it might become a major contributor to the reconstruction of the trade center site itself. Under those circumstances, members of Congress warned, it is hard to imagine that they would not also have a direct role in deciding how the money is spent.
"Obviously, if there are federal dollars involved, then we will have a voice," said Senator Charles E. Schumer. "To make this work, you have to have the federal, state and city governments on board."
Mr. Pataki deflected questions about whether the state would take the lead role in reconstruction. "We've had a tremendous relationship at all three levels, federal, state and city," he said. "And as we go forward with reconstruction, we should have all three elements, federal, state and city, pulling together, working together, in a cooperative teamwork, and I'm confident that'll happen."
The governor's top aides were more direct. "Look, others are going to be involved," one said. "It's going to take Washington and it's going to take City Hall. But this is going to be mostly our job." New Jersey, as a partner in the Port Authority, is likely to have a role as well, he said.
Mr. Bruno and some advisers to the governor predicted that Mr. Pataki, both in his official role and as New York's main liaison to the Bush administration, will inevitably play the central role.
Several members of Congress and the state Legislature said that a possible mechanism for rebuilding is a city, state and federal commission that would decide how to dole out money, and perhaps even what to build. Some said they expected Mr. Pataki to push the Port Authority to take the lead role in reconstruction, which would bypass the Legislature -- a contention the governor's aides would not confirm or deny.
State officials have been full of praise for Mr. Giuliani's handling of the rescue and cleanup efforts, and Mr. Schumer lauded both the mayor and the governor. All sides are loathe to be seen as turning a tragedy into a power struggle, but all appear, to one degree or another, to expect one. "This is going to be a fight," said a member of Congress from New York City. "If we're lucky, it'll be a quiet one and a quick one."
On Monday, Mr. Silver took 70 Assembly members on a tour of the site, which lies in his district, and Mr. Bruno has since taken 20 senators there. Both said they wanted to prepare their colleagues for the enormity of the task to which they will be asked to devote billions of dollars. "No picture, no television picture, can give them the extent of it and impress upon them what it is they're a part of," Mr. Silver said.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 28, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about the New York State role in the effort to rebuild after the attack on the World Trade Center misstated the number of state senators whom Joseph L. Bruno, the majority leader, took on a tour of the site. It was 55, not 20.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE ECONOMY; 
Many Stimulus Options Weighed

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 

 BODY:
If the Bush administration and Congress decide that the flagging economy needs an additional kick in the aftermath of the terrorist attacks, they have a long menu of policy choices available.
 The White House and the leaders of the two parties in Congress have made clear that they do not want to rush into a decision and would like to see some hard data on the state of the economy after Sept. 11 before moving ahead. 
 But with unemployment rising, the stock market falling and a number of high-profile industries struggling, the political pressure on Washington to do something is strong and increasing. And as the pressure mounts, the partisan and policy debate is intensifying over the pros and cons of the specific options on the table. 
In Congress, the two parties are starting to clash over what kind of tax cuts would best deliver immediate help to the economy.
Congress is also beginning to look at all kinds of ideas for spending huge new sums of money, from rebuilding in New York to construction of new highways and rail lines. A lengthening list of industries is seeking special help. 
Then there are the growing ranks of the unemployed, who are likely to receive some help, perhaps in the form of an extension of the time they can collect unemployment benefits. And members of both parties have thrown out additional ideas like increasing the minimum wage and promoting free trade.
The fight over specific measures is unfolding against the backdrop of a broader debate about how much the nation can afford to invest in new tax cuts and spending now without creating a long-term budget problem that would in turn harm the economy again. There are camps within both parties concerned about a fiscally irresponsible free-for-all.
The sharpest debate is likely to be over further tax cuts. 
The most widely considered idea is to provide individuals with an immediate and sizable tax reduction, probably through a rebate much like the ones sent out this summer as the first big component of the tax cut signed into law by President Bush in June.
But Democrats said any such rebate should cover not just people who earn enough money to pay federal income taxes -- the group that received rebates this summer -- but also the 34 million low-income households who do not pay income taxes but do pay the payroll taxes that finance Social Security and Medicare.
In addition to having been passed over by the last rebate, low-income people are more likely than wealthier people to spend any windfall they receive -- and prompting people to spend more is the whole point of the exercise.
"The tax cut that makes the most sense to me is a rebate that includes the people who pay the payroll but not income tax," said Robert Greenstein, executive director of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a liberal research group. 
Republicans, however, are continuing to balk at a tax cut that would be paid for out of general income tax revenue and go to people who do not pay income tax. Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, said he would "rather just give flat rebate checks" to income tax payers, especially since lower-income people will benefit in coming years from a variety of increased tax credits included in Mr. Bush's tax cut.
Many conservatives continue to press for a reduction in the tax on capital gains. Their argument is that such a cut would make investment more attractive by increasing the rate of return, thereby putting upward pressure on stock prices and reversing a sharp drop off this year in investment by businesses in new factories, computers and other equipment.
The proposal has been losing steam, in part because even economists who support reducing or eliminating the capital gains tax -- including Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman -- say such a move would not have much immediate effect on the economy. Democrats say it would also disproportionately benefit the relative handful of people who own large amounts of stock at a huge cost to the budget.
Kevin A. Hassett, an economist at the American Enterprise Institute, a conservative research organization, said a better approach to short-term stimulus would be to cut corporate income tax rates.
"If you think capital markets are in a wait-and-see mode, then the best policy imaginable is to do something that gets cash to corporations," Mr. Hassett said. 
Cutting corporate income tax rates has become the administration's leading proposal, and it is also being pushed heavily by large businesses.
"Some form of corporate tax reduction is just going to improve the earnings, the cash flow, the ability of corporate America to compete in a global economy," said John T. Dillon, the chief executive of International Paper.
But Democrats said reducing corporate rates would be prohibitively expensive and would not necessarily lead to the intended outcome of higher stock prices and increased investment by businesses in new equipment.
There are already indications that Congress will spend relatively freely, both to help the overall economy as well as to address specific issues. There are proposals circulating to increase spending on railroads as an alternative to air travel, to increase airport security, to build schools and highways and to funnel more money into weapons and other military technology.
After years in which budget politics made it hard for Democrats to push big spending packages through Congress, liberals are seizing this opportunity to press for some of their priorities. The Economic Policy Institute, a liberal research organization, today proposed $100 billion of new spending over the next year as part of a two-year, $300 billion stimulus package.
Economists said higher levels of government spending did give the economy a boost. But the degree of that boost depends in part on where the money goes and how quickly it gets from the government's books into the real economy. And if a spending spree led to budget deficits, it could push up long-term interest rates, offsetting all or much of the positive impact of the spending.
One spending proposal that seems likely to pass is an expansion or extension of the unemployment insurance program. The Senate is considering a bill that would extend, by a year, the current 26-week limit on benefits.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE ADVOCATES; 
Much of the Policy Criticism Aimed at U.S. Turns Muted

BYLINE:  By ANDREW POLLACK 

 BODY:
Early in September, Oxfam, the British humanitarian organization, was circulating a petition calling on the United States to "put health before wealth" by supporting relaxation of international patent policies that Oxfam says make vital medicines too expensive for developing countries. 
 But immediately after the terrorist attacks at the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, the petition was removed from Oxfam's Web site. When it returned last week, the cartoon drawing of Uncle Sam had been replaced with a picture of a bottle of pills, and the language singling out the United States had been muted. The group also canceled a news conference at which it had planned to denounce the United States for its patent stance. 
 "It was not appropriate given the kind of national trauma that was occurring here," said Severina Rivera, a senior policy adviser at Oxfam America in Washington. 
Since the terrorist attacks, many other advocacy groups have been canceling planned actions as well, or have toned down oratory that could be perceived as insensitive or even unpatriotic. 
The Sierra Club has removed the "W Watch" column from its Web site because it could be perceived as critical of President Bush. It has also stopped its phone solicitations and pulled advertising from the air. The A.F.L.-C.I.O., the Mobilization for Global Justice and many other groups canceled plans to protest at the annual meetings of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund. The bank and fund later canceled their meetings, which were scheduled for the end of this month in Washington. 
Friends of the Earth let the one-year anniversary of its discovery of unauthorized genetically modified corn in the food supply pass without even a news release. "No one's interested in gene-altered corn right now," said Mark Helm, a spokesman for the organization. 
Even if activists are broadcasting their messages, few people seem to be listening. "What we find is a blackout on coverage and attention to activism," said Asia Russell, a member of Act Up Philadelphia, which has been campaigning to have lower priced drugs available to treat AIDS in Africa. 
Some groups fear that if they are perceived as unpatriotic it will hurt them in the long run. "We strongly need to avoid any perceptions that we are being disrespectful to President Bush," Allen Mattison, director for media relations at the Sierra Club, wrote in an internal memorandum. "Now is the time for rallying together as a nation; the public will judge very harshly any groups whom they view as violating this need for unity."
But several activists say they are concerned that the self-restraint, especially as expressed in the Sierra Club memorandum, has gone too far. 
"This self-censorship is dangerous in itself," said Kristin Dawkins, director of the globalism program at the Institute for Agriculture and Trade Policy in Minneapolis, which is critical of the influence of multinational corporations on agriculture. "It allows some of the very, very dangerous policies that the Bush administration is pursuing this very minute to go forward unchecked." 
Environmental groups say they are concerned that some proponents of opening the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to oil drilling are pushing their cause using the prospect of energy disruptions from a possible war. Some human rights groups, while dropping their usual causes, are starting campaigns to oppose any rush toward war and steps that they perceive would erode domestic civil liberties in the name of counterterrorism. 
Ms. Rivera of Oxfam, a lawyer who normally deals with trade issues, has shifted abruptly to analyzing international laws regarding military responses. "We have a position urging military restraint," she said. 
The International Action Center in New York had been planning a march in Washington on Saturday against the International Monetary Fund and World Bank. But with the financial meetings canceled, the group says it will now have an antiwar demonstration in Washington the same day, said Teresa Gutierrez, a national co-director. 
She dismissed concerns that such demonstrations would be unpopular. "We went to the vigils at Union Square with some caution and sensitivity and found there was no problem in handing out antiwar fliers," she said. 
Some groups are continuing with their campaigns. The Organic Consumers Association went ahead last week with planned leafleting outside Starbucks outlets to protest the use of genetically modified ingredients and to promote the sale of coffee grown by people earning what the association said was a decent wage. 
Ronnie Cummins, national director of the association, said about 20 of 300 volunteers nationwide postponed distributing the leaflets. 
Mr. Cummins said he received one irate e-mail message "from somebody who said it was a shame and why didn't we move to Afghanistan." But he added that his volunteers said that Wall Street resumed business "and so did our criticism of corporate behavior."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: AIRLINE SECURITY; 
Bush Shows Reluctance To Approve Guns for Pilots

BYLINE:  By MATTHEW L. WALD and ELISABETH BUMILLER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 

 BODY:
Indicating that he thought there were better options to increase flight security than arming pilots, President Bush said today that he would introduce "confidence-boosting" measures on Thursday to try to convince frightened Americans that it is safe to fly.
 "There may be better ways to do it than that," Mr. Bush said in response to questions at the White House about allowing pilots to carry guns in the cockpit. "But I'm open to any suggestion." 
 Administration officials said that the president was in favor of strengthening cockpit doors and that that would be among the security enhancements he would announce in a speech to airline employees at O'Hare International Airport in Chicago.
The officials said the president would also propose an increase in armed sky marshals on planes, although they would not give specific numbers. They also said that Mr. Bush would call for the federal government to assume responsibility for training and screening airport workers, but that he was opposed to making the workers federal employees.
The measures were among the first practical responses of the White House to fears about airline security since the Sept. 11 attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. At the end of last week, many airlines were flying at only 30 percent capacity, and the industry is facing thousands of layoffs.
"One of my concerns is that this terrible accident has said to many Americans, convinced many Americans to stay at home," Mr. Bush said. "And one of the keys to economic recovery is going to be the vitality of the airline industry."
Mr. Bush was to fly on Air Force One, but his transportation secretary, Norman Y. Mineta, was to fly on a commercial airline.
Mr. Bush did not say why he was apparently against allowing pilots to carry guns in the cockpit, which has been proposed by the largest pilots' union and is under consideration on Capitol Hill. Pilots have said they are worried that many pilots lack firearms training, that firing a gun at 35,000 feet could damage equipment and cause a catastrophic accident, and that hijackers could grab the guns.
Today aviation officials said they were still trying to work out the details of how to strengthen doors, a step they said could help thwart hijackings but create other safety problems.
"From the outside, it might look like we're dilly-dallying," one official said. "But we keep running into longstanding technical issues."
The president's proposal for airport screening may not satisfy all parties. Officials said today that Mr. Bush would call for having the screening continue to be done by contractors, although they would work for the government, not the airlines.
The new approach would give the government more control over training, performance standards, wages and benefits. It would also increase the likelihood that the required criminal background checks were carried out and would make it more practical to require other background checks. But it would fall short of what some lawmakers have called for, which is to have the work done by government employees. 
Government officials said that the precise program Mr. Bush would call for was still in flux, but that it was likely to include longer-term initiatives, like redesigning some airplanes so the pilots could have access to restrooms and food without going into the aircraft cabin. 
Mr. Bush's proposal was also said to include having a law enforcement officer at each of the 700 passenger screening points. But administration officials would not discuss how many sky marshals there are now on planes or how many there might be in the future.
Senator Richard J. Durbin, Democrat of Illinois, who will be accompanying President Bush to O'Hare, said he believed the administration was also considering a plan to place surveillance cameras in airplanes to allow pilots and possibly personnel on the ground to monitor the passenger cabin.
"We live in a world where there are video cameras at A.T.M. machines on every corner in America and we do not put them in airplanes," he said.
The door issue is complicated because sealing the cockpit from the cabin can cause safety problems. In case of explosive decompression on a Boeing 767, a one-pound per square inch difference between the pressure in the cockpit and the cabin would put 6,000 pounds of pressure on the cockpit floor, which might rupture and damage cables needed to fly the plane, Boeing said.

HEADLINE: Democrats Have Trouble Finding 2002 Candidates 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 

 BODY:
Top Democratic officials say the terrorist attacks have severely hampered their recruitment efforts, particularly for candidates for the Senate, and have upended their entire political game plan for the midterm elections next year.
 Beyond Capitol Hill, the aftershocks of the attacks are being felt around the country at all political levels, by Democrats and Republicans alike. The political terrain has shifted so sharply that candidates are reluctant to take on incumbents -- and in some instances incumbents are deciding to stay put rather than retire or seek higher office. 
 Just today, John Ballou, a Republican legislator in Kansas, said he would not run for the United States House, saying, "I believe it is important for all elected federal and state officials to be united." 
The new dynamic is causing the most consternation for Democrats, who are trying to hang on to -- if not build on -- their precarious one-seat advantage in the Senate. In the past week or so alone, three Democrats who had been viewed as the most formidable prospects in their states, and were expected to challenge incumbent senators, decided not to run: Dan Glickman, the former agriculture secretary, in Kansas; Lt. Gen. Claudia Kennedy, retired, in Virginia; and Gov. John Kitzhaber in Oregon.
To make matters more discouraging for Democrats, Senator Fred Thompson, a Tennessee Republican who is popular in his state, said he had decided not to retire next year because of the terrorist attacks. "Now is not the time for me to leave," Mr. Thompson said. 
In Florida, the Republican governor, Jeb Bush, faces a challenge from Janet Reno, the former attorney general, but has one less potent Democratic challenger. Pete Peterson, a former congressman and ambassador to Vietnam, dropped out, citing the national crisis. (Mr. Peterson met today with Mr. Bush, apparently to discuss the prospect that the governor would appoint him to a job battling terrorism.)
Representative Ron Kind, Democrat of Wisconsin, recently said that he would remain in the House and not run for governor. "On Sept. 11, our ship of state took a hit," Mr. Kind said, and that "requires that all hands be on deck."
Among Republicans, Senator Craig Thomas of Wyoming decided against running for the open seat for governor in his state, also citing the attacks.
Some prospective challengers explained that it was ticklish for them to stump about domestic issues in a time of crisis or to even solicit people for donations when they would rather give money to help victims' families. They also speculated that voters may feel more comfortable turning to leaders who are already in power.
Democrats are particularly unsettled because before the attacks, polls showed the country was more in tune with their issue agenda of Social Security, health care and education. Now the party's talking points are obsolete because the single-minded focus is on war, protecting Americans and the economy.
"On Labor Day, we had them exactly where we wanted them to be," said James M. Jordan, executive director of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee. "We were talking Social Security. It was nirvana. But the entire national issue agenda has radically changed."
Speaking of his new difficulty in recruiting candidates, Mr. Jordan said of the Democrats: "They feel that they've simply lost control of the agenda and their fates. It's certainly got to be discouraging for any challenger to work extremely hard for 13 or 14 months to find out on Election Day that he or she never really had a chance due to the national environment."
People's decisions about running for office are often quite personal and complicated, and it could be that some are using the attacks as an excuse to retreat from a contest that looked too daunting even before the attacks.
But party officials said they were convinced, at least in the case of Mr. Glickman and General Kennedy, that they were poised to run.
Mr. Glickman, a former House member who decided not to challenge Senator Pat Roberts, said in an interview that the attacks "sealed it for me."
"I don't think we should just emasculate politics," he said. "But to run a very, very difficult uphill race during a time of great national conflict would mean you can't run the kind of race you need to run."
Nicole Harburger, the top strategist for General Kennedy, who had planned to take on Senator John W. Warner in Virginia, said the attacks would have made fund-raising problematic. 
"For a candidate who is new to politics, you don't have your home team of contributors to call upon in this difficult time," Ms. Harburger said. "The plane hit where her former office was. She's lost a ton of her colleagues. The idea of having to grind away on the phone when she has a stake in this feels tough."
Taking care not to sound cavalier about the attacks, Democrats said they were confident that the issue agenda would eventually turn back in their favor.
"I fear that our issues may not" carry much weigh in the campaign, said Art Torres, chairman of the California Democratic Party. "But that doesn't stop me from trying" to raise them.
Mr. Jordan said bad economic news could shift the agenda to his party's favor. "It's going to be a hard truth for Republicans that they are sailing straight into the teeth of the Bush recession," he said. "At some point, the domestic agenda is going to re-emerge and it tilts very sharply in favor of Democrats."
Mitch Bainwol, executive director of the National Republican Senatorial Committee, was careful not to gloat in what, at first blush, is an improved positioning for his candidates. 
"It's just a different mix of issues, a different challenge, a different role and a different mood in this city," Mr. Bainwol said. "What this ultimately means is really hard to crystal ball."

HEADLINE: Agriculture Secretary Says Wartime Budget Leaves $171 Billion Farm Bill in Doubt 

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH BECKER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 

 BODY:
Agriculture Secretary Ann M. Veneman said today that the Bush administration was uncertain whether there was enough money to finance the $171 billion House farm bill, raising the possibility that farm subsidies might be the first major program to feel the pinch of the new wartime budget.
 "The budget is uncertain," Ms. Veneman said at a hearing of the Senate Agriculture Committee. "I can't tell you where the budget is going to go with regard to anything." 
 A report on long-term farm policy unveiled by Ms. Veneman last week made clear that, regardless of budget factors, the administration did not intend to support continued rising subsidies for farmers, which it said distorted the farm economy. Today, she promised farmers that the administration would not leave them without a safety net.
The ranking senators on the committee were less circumspect in their criticism of the House farm bill, which is scheduled for a full vote next week.
Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana, the senior Republican on the committee, said it was irresponsible to even consider such a bill, which he said spent too much money on big grain and cotton farmers, undermined the American trade position and spent too much money in a time of war.
"It is inconceivable that the farm bill is going to be on the floor next week in the middle of a war," Mr. Lugar said, and he ridiculed the argument that $20 billion a year in grain and cotton subsidies was necessary for the war effort.
"I'm tired of everyone saying an army marches on its stomach to imply that we need a farm bill to feed our troops," Mr. Lugar said. "We've got food coming out our ears."
The battle was joined immediately by Representative Larry Combest, a Texas Republican who is chairman of the House Agriculture Committee, who said he would move ahead with his bill despite the criticism from the Senate and the administration.
"If the Senate has the desire to be seen as slowing this process, then it is certainly possible they simply do not intend to act," Mr. Combest said. "I do not intend for the House to neglect its duties to the American farmer."
At stake is a subsidy system structured to reward the biggest farmers, who receive 84 percent of federal cash payments even though they represent less than one-fourth of the country's two million farmers.
Mr. Combest's measure would increase subsidies and add new ones, an approach rejected by the administration in its new farm policy.
This week Senator Tom Harkin, the Iowa Democrat who heads the committee, joined Mr. Lugar in releasing the committee's new farm bill objectives, many of which were similar to the administration's ideas.
They said they wanted "a significant change from past policies" and advocated federal help for smaller farmers through conservation programs, new rural aid programs and greater promotion of trade.
Senator Kent Conrad, Democrat of North Dakota, who heads the Senate Budget Committee, pleaded with Secretary Veneman to tell him how much money would be available for a farm bill. Mr. Conrad said the farm economy was in trouble and warned that if money was not available "there will be a race to the auctioneer" by desperate farmers selling off their land and equipment.
"I've never seen such a sense of despair among farmers," he said.
Ms. Veneman said the Office of Management and Budget would decide how much money was available, and she promised that the administration would issue its response to the House farm bill before it was debated. 
She also said that while prices remained flat, there was good news for American agriculture. Farm income will be at an all-time high of $61 billion this year, she said, and farmland has risen in value by 21 percent.
In her report, released last week, Ms. Veneman said price supports encouraged overproduction, which keeps prices low and pushes up land rents. She said today that to reach the farmers who most needed help because of low crop prices, she would keep a safety net, but not one made up entirely of subsidies.
"What we have said is that we need to talk about more than the farm support program but the whole rural economy," Ms. Veneman said.
With the current farm bill not set to expire for another year, the senators said they have time to write their farm bill. 
Among the objectives they set out was the protection of farmers "actively involved in farming and ranching," which could affect many absentee landowners and corporations. The senators also called for greater diversity in farming and money to create jobs in rural America.
Senator Blanche Lincoln, Democrat of Arkansas, who receives subsidies through a family trust, said she feared that tampering with subsidies would encourage the growth of corporate farms.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE INVESTIGATION; 
Nine Arrested as Licenses For Trucking Are Studied

BYLINE:  By DON VAN NATTA Jr. and NEIL A. LEWIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 

 BODY:
As part of a Justice Department investigation prompted by concerns about a possible new terrorism threat, nine people were arrested today on charges of fraudulently obtaining commercial driver's licenses in Pennsylvania to allow them to transport hazardous materials, including explosives, fuels and poisons. 
 Law enforcement officials said they did not know whether the nine men, at least eight of them arrested in Michigan, Missouri and Washington State, had any connection to the hijacking of the passenger jets that attacked the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. The arrests followed by a day a warning from the Federal Bureau of Investigation to officials in New York and other cities about the threat of truck bombs and the possible use of trucks in a terrorist chemical attack. 
 Attorney General John Ashcroft said on Tuesday that the bureau had developed intelligence information indicating "a potential for additional terrorist incidents" on the nation's highways and that some truck drivers who had sought hazardous-material licenses might have ties to the airline hijackers. 
Today the bureau and state transportation officials across the country began reviewing the 2.5 million truck drivers holding licenses allowing them to haul hazardous chemicals and fuels.
Court documents outline a criminal operation in which as many as 30 people in the last several years have paid to fraudulently obtain commercial driver's licenses to carry hazardous materials. 
The nine arrested today were among a group of 20 who fraudulently obtained the special licenses in Pennsylvania from July 1999 to January 2000, law enforcement officials said tonight. Three of the nine were arrested in Washington State, four in Detroit, and one in Kansas City, Mo. The site of the ninth arrest was not available.
Court records said a driver's license examiner for the Pittsburgh office of the Pennsylvania Department of Transportation had provided the permits to people who did not take required tests or who had suspended licenses. The examiner was not identified in the court papers.
The examiner, the authorities said, worked with a middleman identified in court records as Abdul Mohamman, nicknamed Ben. One of the permits was bought for a man whose driver's license had been suspended for driving under the influence of alcohol, the court papers said.
The authorities quoted the examiner as saying that he had issued the special licenses "at Ben's instruction without conducting the required tests" and that Ben had paid him $50 to $100 a license "by placing the money in brand-new bills" under his desk calendar.
The intensified scrutiny of hazardous-material licenses came as federal prosecutors increased the pressure on a Virginia man whose name and phone number were found in a car registered to one of the hijackers of the jet that slammed into the Pentagon. That man, Mohamed Abdi, 44, a naturalized citizen from Somalia, was ordered jailed without bond today by a federal magistrate judge who said Mr. Abdi might otherwise flee the United States.
Mr. Abdi, who lives in Alexandria, Va., was arrested on charges that he had forged his landlord's name on rent subsidy checks. Ordinarily that kind of charge would have meant his release on little bail, if any.
But a federal prosecutor described Mr. Abdi as "an essential witness" in the terrorism investigation who "may be more," and in ordering him held today, the magistrate judge, Welton Curtis Sewell, said at a hearing: "The circumstances of this particular case are so extreme and so unusual. If this court released this defendant, there would be a risk of flight."
Federal prosecutors would not say whether they suspected that Mr. Abdi was an accomplice of the hijackers. 
When Mr. Abdi was arrested on Saturday, an F.B.I. agent said in court today, he had in his pocket a torn newspaper clipping of an article about Ahmed Ressam, an Algerian convicted of conspiring to bomb Los Angeles International Airport in a millennium terrorism plot. Mr. Ressam testified earlier this year that he had spent six months training at terrorist camps in Afghanistan.
Mr. Abdi is just one of 352 people who have been arrested or detained in the investigation springing from the attacks of Sept. 11 An additional 392 people are being sought for questioning.
At a separate hearing today, Magistrate Judge Sewell granted prosecutors' request that Herbert Villalobos be detained without bond. Mr. Villalobos was seized in Arlington, Va., on Monday and charged with helping one of the hijackers, Abdulaziz Alomari, obtain a fraudulent Virginia photo identification card. 
As the inquiry proceeded, Senator John Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts, said investigators had learned that Osama bin Laden's finances were seriously hurt when regulators shut down the Bank of Credit and Commerce International 10 years ago. The bank was closed amid a vast scandal, having been connected to fraud, theft, secret weapons deals, money laundering and terrorist financing.
Mr. bin Laden had accounts at B.C.C.I., but investigators did not know it then, Mr. Kerry said today. "We have learned since from law enforcement and intelligence that when we shut it down, we dealt him a very serious economic blow because of the size of those accounts and his dependency on that flow," Mr. Kerry said, speaking at a Senate hearing on money laundering legislation.
Investigators are now trying to trace the money behind Mr. bin Laden's network, Al Qaeda, and Mr. Kerry and other lawmakers have called for tough new money laundering statutes.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The false Canadian passport used by Ahmed Ressam when he lived in Canada and attempted to enter the United States. (Associated Press) Chart: "The Investigation So Far"In a widening investigation into a possible terrorist plot, nine more people were arrested yesterday on charges of fraudulently obtaining licenses to transport hazardous material. And two others were ordered jailed on suspicion that they had information about the plot to commandeer the airplanes that crashed into the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. The Chief Suspect YESTERDAY: Though the Bush administration has promised to make public its case against Osama bin Laden and his organization, Al Qaeda, officials said the information had not been released because of internal wrangling over declassifying material that might inadvertently expose intelligence-gathering methods or sources. The Hijackers Investigators trying to retrace the steps of 19 hijackers have checked immigration records and questioned, among others, instructors at flight schools where they paid for training. Officials say the hijackers appeared to have exploited legal loopholes and lapses by the immigration authorities to get into the country and remain here. In Custody More than 350 people have been taken into custody, many for immigration violations, and nearly 400 others are being sought for questioning. A leading source of information about people linked to terrorist cells, federal investigators say, is Ahmed Ressam, an Algerian-born man awaiting sentencing near Seattle for conspiring to set off a bomb during the millennium celebration last year. But Mr. Ressam did not recognize any of the 19 suspected hijackers. YESTERDAY: Nine people were arrested in Missouri, Michigan and Washington State on charges of fraudulently obtaining licenses to transport hazardous materials. Mohamed Abdi of Alexandria, Va., whose name and telephone number were found in a car registered to a suspected hijacker, was ordered jailed without bond. Herbert Villalobos, charged with helping a suspected hijacker obtain a fraudulent photo-identification card in Virginia, was ordered held without bond. Investigators believe that the hijackers presented such cards at the boarding gate.

HEADLINE: World Business Briefing Europe: Switzerland: Bank Expects Profit Fall 

BYLINE:  By Elizabeth Olson (NYT) 

 BODY:
 Switzerland's second-largest bank, the Credit Suisse Group, said its third-quarter profit would drop substantially below last quarter because of the drop in the markets after the attacks on Sept. 11. 
The aftermath will "exacerbate the already difficult economic and market conditions experienced by all our businesses," particularly Credit Suisse First Boston, the bank said. The group's second-quarter net income declined 23 percent. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

GRAPHIC: Graph tracks the daily closing price of Credit Suisse Group shares for the week.

HEADLINE: Leadership for a Wounded City 

BYLINE:  By John Mollenkopf; John Mollenkopf, director of the Center for Urban Research at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York, is co-author of "Place Matters: Metropolitics for the Twenty-First Century."

 BODY:
Before Sept. 11, New York City voters were thinking about choosing the leaders of an almost wholly new government to take office on Jan. 1. They were looking for candidates who would sustain the successes of Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's administration, like reducing the crime rate and welfare rolls, while tackling issues it did not successfully address, like school performance and affordable housing. They wanted a new mayor to listen more carefully to those who felt excluded from City Hall. With signs of an economic downturn, many voters also hoped our new leaders would be able to negotiate hard choices fairly and get more out of city government.
 The destruction of the World Trade Center, the loss of more than 6,000 New Yorkers and the shattering of the city's confidence dramatically changed this landscape. 
 Quite understandably, New Yorkers have rallied behind Mayor Giuliani, who has done a superb job of taking charge and working closely with emergency personnel, all the while assuaging anxiety and urging tolerance. It is natural that many New Yorkers would want him to continue to lead us through this crisis. It is also natural, if not entirely rational, that the mayor and his inner circle would want to continue to be in charge.
The last two weeks have apparently led many New Yorkers to feel that the Democrats emerging from Tuesday's primary, Public Advocate Mark Green and Bronx Borough President Fernando Ferrer, and the Republican nominee, the businessman Michael Bloomberg, do not have Mayor Giuliani's stature. But these nominees have not had the chance to be tested by, and be shown equal to, the challenges faced by Mr. Giuliani.
Such comparisons, one hopes, will be transitory as we shift from crisis mode to rebuilding the city. As we make this shift, Mr. Giuliani's strengths, like his bond with the emergency services, will become less relevant -- and qualities that had been in doubt, like whether he is sufficiently inclusive or whether he can strengthen communities, will become more important. If Mr. Giuliani seeks to use his current standing in public opinion to overturn the political process, he will tarnish himself and create the disunity he so wishes to avoid.
This election cycle already promised, mainly because of term limits, a remarkable turnover in our civic leadership, opening the way to a more diverse and representative group of elected officials with fresh ideas. Now the voters will need to judge those seeking election on Nov. 6 not by how well they would have handled the sad tasks of the last two weeks, but how they will face the even larger challenges of healing the city's wounds, reviving its confidence and managing its physical and social restoration.
An immediate task will be to organize the process for deciding how to rebuild our city. The struggle over this has already begun in government offices and corporate boardrooms, and the questions raised will confront the victors in November. Who should participate? Who will be the primary beneficiaries? Should we focus on restoring the financial services industry in lower Manhattan or address broader questions, like the relationship of the Manhattan central business districts to downtown Brooklyn, Atlantic Terminal, Queens West and Jersey City? Can this be an opportunity to create a more integrated regional economy, one with better mass transit? And how can we ensure that the massive investment we are about to undertake will lift the economic chances of all New Yorkers, not just investment professionals?
As we evaluate the candidates in the Democratic runoff and general elections, we must ask who can best rise above competing interests, make sure the decision-making process is inclusive and lead us to solutions based on consensus. This will require tremendous political skills as well as vision and drive. On Tuesday, voters disproved predictions that turnout would be minimal. In the next six weeks, New Yorkers will have a chance to show just how serious and democratic we can be about deliberating our future.

HEADLINE: Merrill's Asset Management Chief Will Leave 

BYLINE:  By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Jeffrey M. Peek, who ran the asset management division at Merrill Lynch and who was passed over for the firm's presidency in July, is leaving, Merrill said yesterday.
 Robert C. Doll, the firm's global chief investment officer, was named to succeed Mr. Peek as president of Merrill Lynch Investment Managers, which at the end of the second quarter had $533 billion under management. 
 Mr. Peek, 54, joined Merrill Lynch in 1983 as a managing director in the investment banking division.
He had been a main rival of E. Stanley O'Neal's for the job of president and chief operating officer of Merrill. When Mr. O'Neal was named to those positions in July, it was widely assumed that Mr. Peek would eventually move on.
"It is a pretty safe assumption" Mr. Peek is leaving because he lost out to Mr. O'Neal, said Guy Moszkowski, an analyst at Salomon Smith Barney. "It's a shame he feels compelled to leave, because he is a very talented, capable guy."
Mr. Peek did not return a telephone call seeking comment.
In a joint statement, Mr. O'Neal and David H. Komansky, Merrill's chairman and chief executive, noted Mr. Peek's "many important contributions to the firm."
"Most recently, he was instrumental in transforming Merrill Lynch into one of the world's leading asset managers for both institutional and retail clients," the statement said.
Though Mr. Peek is highly regarded within the firm, Mr. Moszkowski said, Merrill Lynch is well equipped to survive his departure.
"Like most large firms, Merrill has a pretty deep bench of talent," he said.
Mr. Doll, 47, joined Merrill Lynch in June 1999 as the asset management division's chief investment officer for equities after spending a dozen years at OppenheimerFunds Inc. He was named co-head of Merrill Lynch Investment Managers America in November 1999. Earlier this year he became the unit's global chief investment officer. He will continue to serve in that role, Merrill said, and will join the firm's executive management committee.
Under a new management structure, Merrill said, Mr. Doll will report to Michael Marks, the 59-year- old executive chairman of Europe, the Middle East and Africa region. Mr. Marks, who is based in London, will become chairman of Merrill Lynch Investment Managers.
In a telephone interview, Mr. Doll said his immediate goals were "to take the best of what we have and keep it happening."
Mr. Doll said the stock market's dismal performance in the wake of the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon might not be over. But, he added, prices look appealing.
"The low for the economy and the markets will be lower and later than originally believed" before the attacks, he said.
"On an absolute basis, the market still looks expensive," he added. "But relative to cash and bonds it looks more attractive than it has in years."
What is required now, Mr. Doll said, is a "confidence builder."
"Do we need certainty? No. Right now, we need less uncertainty."
