HEADLINE: ART REVIEW; 
Bruegel the Elder Explains It All for You

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL KIMMELMAN 

 BODY:
WE could all do worse right now than to lose ourselves for a while in the Met's show of drawings and prints by Bruegel, who knew a thing or two about vice and virtue.
 Bruegel lived in rough and crazy times, but beauty, his work reminds us, makes comforting order out of almost everything it comes into contact with. So whether he was drawing vanity or sloth or demons with nasty spiked maces or peasants harvesting corn under a high sun or a man slipping on the ice of a frozen moat in a crowd of happy skaters, he delivered the same lapidary message. The world is anarchic and cruel and can drive all of us to despair sometimes. But good art is a realm unto itself, with its own rules and rationale, and thankfully we can escape into it from time to time when we need to regain our senses. 
 We know next to nothing about the great Pieter Bruegel the Elder, not even when or where he was born. We know that he worked in Antwerp and Brussels and died in 1569, leaving two young sons, Jan and Pieter the Younger, who followed in his footsteps, making paintings and drawings sometimes confused with his. 
It's probably a relief that we don't know too much about him. Against the narcissism of our fin-de-siecle milieu, the dim figure of the elder Bruegel comes as a small and fortuitous counterpoint. Scant knowledge about him means, among other things, that he does not bear the burden of needing a meaningful and anecdote-filled life to justify attention. There is only his art to consider, or only the small, exquisite fraction of it that survives, to which generations of eager and tendentious historians have tried in vain to attach biographical significance.
They have theorized about his feelings regarding Spanish rule in the Netherlands and regarding the Inquisition, but nobody really has an idea where Bruegel stood. His work can be bleak and full of horror about the costs of war and persecution, but it stands apart from, which is to say above, contemporary specifics, benefiting from art's metaphoric flexibility and basic irrelevance. Longevity is the compensation for this kind of irrelevance, great art not losing its topicality as do the political and religious wars, plagues and other calamities in the midst of which the art is often made.
It's obvious that Bruegel learned from Bosch, whose strange influence runs throughout his amazing drawings and prints of the seven deadly vices. And we also know that he went to Italy, where he saw Italian art, meaning Michelangelo and Titian, although just how much he picked up from them is another thing scholars don't agree about.
The work in the show looks Italian-derived in some cases, Netherlandish in others. It looks old and modern. It seems like the end of one tradition and the start of another. The drawings are loose or microscopically detailed, partly depending on whether or not he designed them for engravers to make into prints. They are so varied that it's no surprise scholars wrangle over attributions.
One of the fine early landscapes is a precise view of the old marine customs house next to the church of Santa Maria in Turri on the Tiber in Rome, bobbing masted boats in the foreground; squat buildings rise heavily on the river's far bank in a shimmering light, a marvel of graphic economy, austere architecture and subtle atmospherics.
The drawing is from the same trip that must have taken Bruegel through the Alps, which he drew, too, with a mix of poetic license and topographical fidelity where it came to rocky outcroppings, craggy paths and needle peaks. Attitudes toward mountains were beginning to shift in Europe, a sign of the medieval world slowly yielding to the modern one. Luther's idea was that mountains were God's retribution for man's fall, an outcome of the flood before which the earth had been perfectly flat. But this view was starting to give way to the notion of sublime vistas. Bruegel's landscape drawings, part fantasy, part faithful, seem on the cusp of history.
Some of the landscapes in the show are also peaceable scenes of anglers and cows, of travelers looking at valleys, and of winding rivers and gingerbread towns nestled behind fortress walls. Bruegel loved the variety of unfolding information that comes from close, patient observation, and in a work like "Wooded Landscape With Mills" he leads the eye diagonally from the big, twisted tree in the foreground past thatched houses and a tiny water mill in the distance to an opening somewhere even farther away, the background barely big enough for him to register with his pen, a vertiginous effect akin to looking through the wrong end of a telescope.
Elsewhere, he adopts a God's-eye view, surveying broad panoramas with divine equanimity, although some of the really spectacular landscapes are not by Bruegel: the exhibition and its catalog devote much space to works formerly attributed to him, possibly by him, prints based on works he did or in his style. Some drawings are credited to Jacob Savery, Roelandt Savery and to someone called the Master of the Small Landscapes. A famous and elaborate Alpine scene, once considered a Bruegel, is now said to be by the anonymous Master of the Mountain Landscapes. The prints are by professional engravers.
This all makes for a connoisseur's paradise. At a time like now it is heartening to see how civilization goes on in the form of art historians obsessing about such minutiae. That said, the show will be a little confusing and diffuse to some people. And it would be nice one of these days to read an exhibition catalog, written not just for experts, that somewhere explains in plain, heartfelt words why anybody should care about the art in the first place.
You don't need any help, though, to appreciate the virtues of the vices, or Everyman as a greedy, nearsighted merchant, or some of the nimbler drawings like "The Beekeepers," an image of lumbering, faceless figures in woven masks and bulky clothes. One of the men is in a pose cribbed from Michelangelo's Sistine ceiling. They lug baskets around a big mandrake plant while a boy hides in a tree. Scholars have disagreed about whether the picture is an allegory of Protestants and Catholics; its impact is, if anything, greater because of its mystery.
"Summer" is not mysterious but, combined with Bruegel's fantastical scenes and with drawings like "The Beekeepers," it conveys a near-Shakespearean complexity of human understanding. A funny, rollicking image of peasant labor, its slightly above-it-all tone recapitulates Bruegel's attitude toward everyday life as amusing but also grotesque and absurd. His "Big Fish Eat Little Fish" is another example: the world is foolish and full of bizarre people, so all you can do is laugh.
The most memorable drawing, "The Painter and the Connoisseur," is not difficult to decipher: a long-suffering artist is with a slack-jawed patron, who squints through spectacles while grasping his purse, a quintessential image of the misunderstood genius getting the last laugh. The message is blunt, but the technique is a blend of delicacy and carelessness, suggesting Bruegel may have done the drawing for himself or a friend. Its excellence derives from the directness of delivery.
From it, you wouldn't say Bruegel was a compassionate artist, never mind his beloved pictures of peasants and ice skaters. Instead, his dark-humored viewpoint seems strangely moving and modern. Solace, he implies, comes only from the integrity of the artist's effort, not a bad lesson today.
"About suffering they were never wrong, the old masters," Auden wrote apropos of a Bruegel painting. He was right. Or about pleasure, he might have added.
"Pieter Bruegel the Elder: Drawings and Prints," organized by Nadine M. Orenstein and Manfred Sellink, is on view through Dec. 2 at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710.

HEADLINE: First Requiems, Then Resolve 

BYLINE:  By ALLAN KOZINN 

 BODY:
WHEN Gordon J. Davis, the president of Lincoln Center, convened the directors of the center's resident performing groups on Sept. 12, the day after the attack on the World Trade Center, the shock of the disaster was fresh, and life in New York was virtually frozen. But Mr. Davis believed that it was important to meet, partly to decide what to do next, and partly to make sure that all of the arts center's constituent organizations were fully informed about plans for everything from memorial concerts being planned to heightened security on the plaza and in the halls and backstage areas. 
 Lincoln Center had been evacuated immediately after the attack. Planning, fund-raising and administrative work came to a halt, box offices were closed and rehearsals were canceled. So were opening-night fund-raising galas at the New York City Opera on the night of the attack and at the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center the next night. Similar events at other Lincoln Center organizations were scrapped as well, and the first five concerts of the Rachmaninoff retrospective that was to have opened Lincoln Center's Great Performers series were also canceled when it became clear that the performers, from England and Russia, could not get to New York. 
 At the Lincoln Center meeting, Mr. Davis and his colleagues agreed that it was time to get back to work, if not quite back to business as usual. Other organizations have approached their seasons with a similar resolve. And although several say that they are likely to face substantial financial losses because of the disaster, executives at large and small concert halls in New York agree that the structure of musical life in the city -- seasonal rather than year-round, and with an audience that is mostly local rather than dependent on tourism -- has shielded them from the devastating drop in ticket sales on Broadway.
"There have been some difficult decisions," Mr. Davis said of his discussions with colleagues at Lincoln Center. "Probably the hardest call was at the New York City Opera, which had planned to resume its performances with 'The Magic Flute' on Friday. But on Thursday, when the president announced that Friday would be a day of mourning, we scheduled a vigil on the plaza, and City Opera had to decide whether to cancel its performance, which it did. They could have gone on -- it wasn't that the plaza was going to be so crowded that people couldn't get into the State Theater. But going on didn't seem to fit the tenor of the moment."

'A Sense of Shock'
City Opera also lost several rehearsals, said Paul Kellogg, the company's general and artistic director, and when the rehearsals resumed, the singers were still traumatized. 
"This is a deeply professional company," Mr. Kellogg said, "but there was a sense of shock that left people so affected that the will to proceed was momentarily shaken. People got over that, and realized that we have something here that's useful to do, and they got right into it again." 
The New York Philharmonic had different reasons to fret. Although the orchestra's season was not scheduled to open until Sept. 20, the Philharmonic had just completed a European tour, and on Sept. 11, the players were at the Frankfurt Airport in Germany waiting to come home when all flights were canceled. The nearest hotels that could accommodate the more than 100 musicians were in Stuttgart, more than two hours away. 
By the time the players returned to New York, on Sept. 15, the start of the season had been transformed. Anne-Sophie Mutter, the German violinist, who was to have played the Beethoven Violin Concerto on opening night, had decided not to travel. And in any case, Kurt Masur, the orchestra's music director, and Zarin Mehta, its executive director, had decided to replace the opening night Franck and Beethoven program with a memorial performance of the Brahms German Requiem, with the proceeds -- about $300,000 -- to be donated to a World Trade Center relief fund. 
"Putting this memorial together was so straightforward and easy," Mr. Mehta said. "The orchestra immediately said, 'Of course, we have to do it.' The first two singers I asked, Thomas Hampson and Heidi Grant Murphy, said yes, and when I talked to Kurt Masur about what to play, there was maybe three seconds of discussion. By Saturday, the choir already had its first rehearsal. And then, getting 'Live From Lincoln Center' and the whole PBS network together to broadcast a 90-minute program -- it all fell into place. I've experienced a surge of friendship and cooperation, and I hope we can continue to be nice to each other for a long time." 
Smaller organizations were affected as well. On the day of the attack, Merkin Concert Hall was about to open its Tuesday matinee series with an early afternoon performance by Concertante, a young chamber orchestra. "I was on my way downstairs, and I saw people huddled around the radio," said Vickie Margulies, the director of concert programs at the hall, "but I didn't know what was going on. 
"Meanwhile, the musicians were arriving with their instruments. Some had been watching what was happening on TV and were stunned, and as it became apparent how serious this was, we were all very shaky. But we had to decide what to do. I think, for a while, the musicians felt they could go on, and one of the things we discussed was the healing power of music. But it was just too shattering and too close, so we decided to postpone."
Several more performances were canceled at Merkin that week and the next, including two sold-out installments of the New York Guitar Festival, which were to have been broadcast live on WNYC-FM (93.9). But that was the least of Merkin's problems -- or WNYC's. The radio station, which broadcasts from the Municipal Building on Centre Street and which sent its signal out through the World Trade Center, was knocked off the air for a few days, and access to its studios was restricted. At Merkin, all telephone service was knocked out the day of the attack, and it has not yet been restored. (Its box office is using a cellphone: 917-579-3269.) 
City Opera and the 92nd Street Y have similar communications problems, if less severe. Both have lost their long-distance telephone service and their e-mail. At the Miller Theater at Columbia University, electronic communications were working, but a large mailing of season brochures, sent out just before the attack, was delayed, as were advertisements in some publications. And touring complications caused the immediate cancellation of three of the hall's new-music concerts, two by the Klangforum Wien, from Austria, on Tuesday and Wednesday, and one by the Intergalactic Contemporary Ensemble on Nov. 9. Otherwise, the hall's season, which begins tonight, has been unaffected. 
Schedules that were interrupted quickly got back under way. At Merkin, concerts resumed on Sept. 16, when the Western Wind, a vocal sextet, gave a concert of music for the Jewish New Year. The group had planned the concert as a benefit for its next recording project, and tickets cost up to $200. "But we decided instead to donate the money we raised to the Red Cross," said William Zukof, the sextet's countertenor. "There was no disagreement in the group about that." 
Having canceled its first two scheduled performances, City Opera raised its curtain on Sept. 15 with a new production of "The Flying Dutchman" that was to have opened the season on the night of the attack. There have been no further cancellations, and the company is planning to restore the lost performance of "The Flying Dutchman" to the schedule on Oct. 8 as a benefit for rescue workers and victims' families. 
The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center transformed its canceled gala into a free concert last Tuesday and solicited donations for Engine Company No. 40 and Ladder Company No. 30, the firehouse near Lincoln Center, which lost 11 firefighters at the World Trade Center. And Merkin Concert Hall, Lincoln Center and the Miller Theater all quickly set out to reschedule their canceled concerts and sought ways to commemorate those lost. 
"The spirit is alive, and people are making their statement by going on," said Ms. Margulies of Merkin Concert Hall. "In terms of human loss, this has been simply disastrous, and talking to musicians, the first thing on their minds is how to reach out. In terms of economics, this will have an effect we don't know the entirety of. There are many imponderables, and it's hard to do business without phones. We have no idea how many people are trying to reach us." 
Perhaps the most immediate financial effect of the disaster on the classical music business has been felt at the box office. 
"The box office is really suffering," was Mr. Kellogg's blunt assessment of ticket sales at City Opera. "On Monday, Sept. 10, our box office sales were twice what they were on that date last year. And our advance sales had been very good. But it stopped. Now, our day-to-day ticket sales at the box office, through Ticketmaster and the Internet, are 37 percent of what they were." 
Mr. Kellogg said that once the company opened, much of the audience returned and that the houses for the two new productions that have opened -- "The Flying Dutchman" and "The Mikado" -- have looked reasonably full.

A Drop at the Box Office
Aftershocks of the attack have been registered at the Metropolitan Opera box office as well. Before Sept. 11, the Met had sold 57 percent of its tickets for the season, roughly equivalent to sales at the same time last year. "Then, Sept. 11 happened, the tragedy," said Joseph Volpe, the Met's general manager. "Last year, in the 10 days starting on Sept. 11, we sold $2.4 million in tickets, or 2.8 percent of our total capacity. This year, in those 10 days, we sold $700,000, which is about seven-tenths of a percent of our capacity." 
Mr. Volpe pointed out, though, that the Met sold out an extra performance, the preview of opening night, presented as a benefit for the victims of the World Trade Center disaster, on Sept. 22. That concert also attracted some 3,000 listeners to the Lincoln Center plaza, where it was broadcast on a huge television screen, and it raised $2.5 million. 
Robert J. Harth, the new executive director of Carnegie Hall, arrived in New York from his last position, at the Aspen Music Festival and School in Colorado, on Sept. 8 and has been dealing with little but loss since then. Herman Sandler, a donor to several orchestras and musical programs, and a member of the Carnegie board, was among those missing at the World Trade Center. And the death on Sept. 22 of the violinist Isaac Stern -- Carnegie's president and an important presence at the hall ever since he led the fight to save it from destruction in 1960 -- is likely to be traumatic for Carnegie. 
Because of construction on its new Zankel Hall, Carnegie had planned to open later than usual this year. Although the first concert in the hall is a performance by the Orpheus Chamber Orchestra tomorrow, and Carnegie has just scheduled a Concert for Remembrance, with James Levine, Yo-Yo Ma and Leontyne Price on Sunday, the official opening of the season is a Berlin Philharmonic concert on Wednesday. No performances have been canceled, and none of the scheduled performers have decided not to travel. But like everyone else, Mr. Harth acknowledged a decline in ticket sales. 
"Our box office only opened for single ticket sales on Sept. 10," he said. "Clearly, our tickets are not being sold with the alacrity we're used to. But we are seeing sales pick up, as everything in the city is. It's too early to say that things are back to normal, but it's moving in that direction. Of course, our opening concerts, with the Berlin Philharmonic, are very well sold. But most of those sales took place prior to Sept. 11, by subscription." 
The major musical organizations in New York have been somewhat insulated from the aftermath of the attack, because they sell a significant percentage of their tickets by subscription. Subscription series are announced between January and March, and because people who are inclined to purchase them also tend to want to ensure the best seats, the core audience for the season is in place well before the end of the summer. Preseason subscription sales typically count for between 55 and 65 percent of an organization's tickets. 
Two other factors have helped the musical world. One is the seasonal nature of musical life. There is a heavy concert calendar from late September through mid-May, and a summer festival season from June through August. But on Sept. 11, opening night was anywhere from a week to five weeks away for musical organizations as diverse as the New York Philharmonic, the Met, Carnegie Hall, the Brooklyn Academy of Music, the 92nd Street Y and the Miller Theater. 
And many organizations say that unlike Broadway, which thrives on tourism, classical music plays mostly to a local audience. That said, the definitions of "local" and "visiting" are relative: City Opera estimates that 19 percent of its audience comes from outside New York City, but how much of that 19 percent can be ascribed to tourism is less clear. Mr. Davis, of Lincoln Center, said that as much as 70 percent of the subscription audience for Great Performers comes from New York City (all five boroughs), with another 15 to 20 percent from New Jersey, suggesting that tourism may account for as little as 10 percent of the total audience. 
Carnegie Hall has no figures on tourism, and representatives for smaller halls, from the Kitchen to the 92nd Street Y and Merkin Concert Hall, all guess that their ticket buyers are mostly New Yorkers. And Mr. Mehta, of the New York Philharmonic, was reluctant to guess what tourism contributed to the orchestra's ticket sales. 
"If we sell 65 percent by subscription, and we sell 85 percent of our tickets to a particular concert," Mr. Mehta said, "then obviously 20 percent is in single ticket sales. Whether the people who bought those tickets came from Manhattan or Milwaukee, we don't know." 
Mr. Mehta and his colleagues may have an chance to find out, however. City Opera and the Met have noted an inclination among ticket holders to exchange their September and October tickets for tickets to performances later in the season, and both say the requests are coming mainly from people outside New York. At the Met, this has been particularly true of tickets sold on the Internet. Although such sales accounted for only about 4 percent of the Met's capacity last season, Mr. Volpe said that 43 percent of those sales were in the New York, New Jersey and Connecticut region, 26 percent were from elsewhere in the United States and 31 percent were from outside the United States. 
"What's happening," Mr. Volpe said, "is that we're getting a lot of cancellations and requests for refunds on the Internet from people who have to travel distances. The highest number of these requests, for some reason, come from Florida. Germany is second, and Japan is third. Tourism will bounce back at some point, but it's going to be a while. So I can't say what the overall effect will be." 
City Opera does not offer refunds, but it does allow exchanges for performances later in the season, or even in future seasons. Generally, the exchange policy has been offered only to subscribers, but because of the disaster, City Opera has been extending it to all ticket holders. And Mr. Kellogg has found the response distressing. 
"People who are leery about coming back to New York are exchanging their tickets for later in the season," he said. "All those exchanges affect our ultimate box-office income, because we are exchanging people into seats that would otherwise be available for sale." 
One thing no one is able or inclined to do, at the moment, is to estimate the full financial impact of the disaster. The added security measures virtually all diminish profits. Lincoln Center has increased its uniformed security guards. And bomb-sniffing dogs have been used at Avery Fisher Hall, although Mr. Davis said that this was a precaution, not a response to a specific threat. Lincoln Center and Carnegie Hall will be instituting occasional bag and briefcase checks, and are encouraging concertgoers to arrive a few minutes earlier than usual. 
There are also not-so-incidental incidentals to be considered. Having its players marooned in Europe, for example, meant that the New York Philharmonic was liable for four days of hotels and daily expenses for more than 100 people, at a cost that Mr. Mehta said he had not yet calculated. 
"At this point," Mr. Kellogg said, "I'm just covering my eyes and trying to move forward. You just have to proceed, and measure the fallout later. It will be significant, and we're aware of it. We're steeling ourselves to hear the news when we've had the time and distance to compile it."

CORRECTION-DATE: October 2, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article in Weekend on Friday about the terrorist attacks' impact on New York's classical music institutions misstated the Carnegie Hall connection of Herman Sandler, a donor to several arts organizations, who is listed as missing at the World Trade Center. He was not a member of the Carnegie Hall board; his wife, Suki Sandler, is.

HEADLINE: Car Rental Companies Preparing for a Slump 

BYLINE:  By CHERYL JENSEN 

 BODY:
FEWER people are flying, and more are expected to be driving. Still, that is not good news for the $19.5 billion rental-car industry, since more than two-thirds of its business is done at airports.
 "Our feeling is that car rental companies will probably lose about 50 to 60 percent of their business in the next three to six months, especially at airports, due to the decline in business travel," said Sherb Brown, publisher of Auto Rental News, a trade magazine based in Torrance, Calif. 
 "We're expecting this to be pretty devastating to the car rental industry -- just as devastating as it will be to the airline industry," Mr. Brown said. "Some of the major companies are planning on decreasing their fleets by 50 to 60 percent immediately." 
Several rental companies said business improved this week, though rentals were still far below the levels before Sept. 11. At Hertz, the market leader, which does 90 percent of its business at airports, rentals fell by half in the week after the terrorist attacks, said Richard Broome, vice president for corporate affairs. But this week, Mr. Broome said, "we have been seeing a modest improvement, although we are nowhere near where we were before Sept. 11, by any stretch of the imagination."
Industry officials said they expected that fear of flying and the inconvenience posed by new security measures were likely to prompt more people to drive to business meetings, often in rental cars. A survey of 60 corporate travel managers for Fortune 500 companies, conducted by the National Business Travel Association last week, found that 65 percent were planning to recommend the use of rental cars for short trips.
Many of these customers will not be traveling through airports, though, and will be looking to rent in places that are more convenient to their homes and offices.
Budget Rent a Car, which already did a relatively high proportion of its business away from airports, is moving more of its fleet to those locations, a spokeswoman, Jennifer Sullivan, said.
Mr. Brown and industry officials said they did not think the increase in business driving would offset the loss of airport business. "We're expecting maybe a 5 to 10 percent increase in local markets," which are offices outside airports, Mr. Brown said. "That won't offset a 50 to 60 percent decline in the airport markets."
Even before the terrorist attacks, the industry had been struggling as business travel declined in a slowing economy. Business was off 5 to 7 percent before Sept. 11, said Michael Taylor, director of travel services at the Westport, Conn., offices of J. D. Power & Associates.
"When Pam Am Flight 103 blew up over Lockerbie, Scotland, it took about 9 months for the airline industry to recover," Mr. Taylor said. "This is probably going to take longer, because it happened on American soil and is so much more dramatic."
What will all this mean to the business and vacation traveler? In the short term, plenty of cars will be available at airports, and rates at those locations are unlikely to rise, Mr. Brown said. They may even fall.
There may be slight price increases at outlets away from airports, "because that's where we're expecting some additional rentals," Mr. Brown said. 
It may be difficult to find cars at a few locations because rental companies had a surge in one-way rentals right after the bombings, as stranded air travelers rented cars to get home. Mr. Brown said there might be slightly more demand for minivans and sport utilities because families may want to drive, instead of fly, on vacations. "But nobody is expecting anything dramatic," he added.

HEADLINE: TV WEEKEND; 
Viewing New York's Past But Seeing the Present

BYLINE:  By Caryn James 

 BODY:
In 1945 a plane crashed into the Empire State Building. As told in "New York: An Illustrated History," the companion book to Ric Burns's colossal PBS series, a B-25 Army bomber lost its way in the fog, then flew into the building and burned. Fourteen people died, but the building stood so firm that tenants returned two days later. 
 Because it came a few weeks before the end of World War II, "For New Yorkers the nightmarish accident was a reminder of just how lucky their city had been," Mr. Burns and his co-author, James Sanders, write. "Overseas, virtually every other major world capital had been humbled or destroyed," but New York "had emerged from the world's greatest conflict virtually unscathed, richer than ever, its great walls of stone and steel untouched by the horrors of war." 
 Like the book, the concluding episodes of the series, "New York: A Documentary Film," are loaded with details that resonate differently now that New York is no longer so lucky or untouched. It is fair to wonder if these chapters should have been postponed. After the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center, it is impossible to see them the way they were intended, as a history of the city from 1929 through the 1990's. (They are Episodes 6 and 7, picking up where the previous 10 hours, shown in 1999, left off.) 
Now their very first words vibrate with unintended meaning. Over a close-up of lights on a black, rainy street, an ominous voice warns, "The contemporary city is profoundly menaced." Philip Bosco is reading what the architectural historian Siegfried Giedion called the evil potential of the automobile; he feared in the 1930's and 40's that machines were becoming more important than people. But with the events of Sept. 11 still so fresh, the film becomes a catalog of accidental significance and observations that have become touchingly out-of-date.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani says here that during the Depression and World War II, Fiorello La Guardia was exactly the leader the city needed to get through those dark years. "He was the mayor of New York City during the most difficult time ever to be mayor of New York City," says the man who can now claim that role.
Every distant view of the skyline leads a viewer to search for the World Trade Center, which at times appears as a central image. The towers loom against a bright blue sky while speeded-up film propels clouds toward them and a voice says, "The world is in chaos." (In the Burns style, we find out whose words are being read only after the speaker is finished; this comment is from the secretary of the 1939 World's Fair.) 
Like the World Trade Center itself, the series now carries a symbolic weight it never had before. As several commentators have noted, the twin towers were not beloved buildings and are understandably not even mentioned in the film, but you don't need a New Yorker's perspective to feel how they haunt it.
While the program is constantly touching raw nerves, though, it is also timely in a more precise way than anyone could have imagined. As it happens, these episodes are not about New York's glory days, but about its plummet to the depths during the Depression and again during the financial crisis of the 70's, which brought the city social unrest, near-bankruptcy and the enmity of the rest of the country. The theme of these episodes, now intensified, had always been there: this is a story of resilience, a lucid reminder of how often New York City has rebuilt itself.
The films were not altered, except to replace the final credits (there is now a glimpse of construction workers raising the World Trade Center) and to add a title card explaining that the documentary was produced before the tragedy, adding: "For nearly 400 years, the people of New York have faced adversity and prevailed. This film is dedicated to them."
Taken on their own, these episodes are better than the sometimes plodding ones that preceded them. They are more focused, and at four and a half hours less of an endurance test. Stylistically they match, though, with period film and photographs, off-screen actors reading contemporary accounts, and on-screen commentators. These include the lively historian Mike Wallace, the biographer Robert A. Caro (whose subject, Robert Moses, is the film's most crucial figure) and Ray Suarez, familiar as a reporter for "The NewsHour With Jim Lehrer," but also an astute, no-nonsense observer of the city's history. Yet accidental meanings come to bear on the style, too. The narrator's prose, read by David Ogden Stiers, is as purple as ever, but today such a flaw seems trivial next to the series' reassuring insights about the city's hard times. Brian Keane's music, which had always seemed lovely though sentimental, takes on a mournful cast.
Episode 6, "The City of Tomorrow," focuses on the Depression and the war years, showing long lines for food and Hoovervilles in Central Park. Federal aid was siphoned off by Tammany Hall and the corrupt mayor, Jimmy Walker.
The reform-minded La Guardia held the city together for three terms, but it was Moses who planned and shaped it for nearly 50 years. He channeled money onto gargantuan road-building projects like the Triborough Bridge, though he never drove a car; he connected parts of the city while remaining troublingly disconnected from its life. He is heard here saying, "Cities are created by and for traffic," and his projects callously displaced entire neighborhoods.
In the 40's New York had everything, Mr. Suarez says near the start of Episode 7, "The City and The World." He adds, "New York sort of looked down on the rest of America from Olympus, and the seeds of its downfall might have been in that." After the war, manufacturing moved out, the middle class left for the suburbs, and the city's economic base was destroyed.
A sharp attitude emerges from this episode, creating a picture of urban blight brought about by federal programs that were wrongheaded or ineptly executed or both. High-rise housing projects were created, but they were inhospitable slabs of stone. By the 70's the South Bronx was a burned-out shell and a national symbol of urban decline. The low point came in 1975, when President Gerald Ford refused to guarantee loans to save New York from bankruptcy, and a now classic Daily News headline read: "Ford to City: Drop Dead." (He later changed his mind, fearing the ripple effects if New York defaulted.) This may not be the best time to hear it, but it is good to be reminded that New York was not always perfect; take it as a sign of normalcy.
More meaningfully at the moment, the film charts how fast the city returned to glory after its steep decline. The demolition of the old Penn Station (seen in black-and-white film, which must only hint at the architectural gem it was) in 1963 led to the creation of the Landmarks Preservation Commission. And Moses finally went too far when he tried to cut a great swath of highway through downtown neighborhoods, from the Lower East Side through what is now SoHo to Greenwich Village, and was thwarted by community resistance.
More piercing and more bracing than they would have been before, these final episodes also have an eloquence that is now enhanced. We see the ocean liners Queen Mary and Queen Elizabeth coming to New York after World War II, their decks crammed with hundreds of soldiers returning home. "That may have been the greatest time in New York," the historian David McCullough says. 
As the ships head toward land, the Statue of Liberty comes into view but -- then as now -- no World Trade Center rises nearby. The filmmakers could not have known how poignant their words would come to seem. When the ships entered the bay, the narrator says, "A gigantic cheer went up at the sight of the ravishing skyline of New York, which had never seemed more precious or more filled with promise for the future."

NEW YORK

HEADLINE: Asia Casts a Wary Eye to the West 

BYLINE:  By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Sept. 27 

 BODY:
Mark Lettenbichler expected a flood of canceled bookings in the days after the terrorist attacks on New York and Washington. What worries Mr. Lettenbichler, the general manager of the Ritz-Carlton Hotel here, is that his guests have not yet returned.
 "At least with the Asian crisis, you knew where the bottom was," Mr. Lettenbichler said. "The disturbing thing here is you don't know what to expect. We know we're going to see a decline, but for how long?" 
 From luxury hotels to computer manufacturers to shipping agents, Asian companies are battening the hatches for a much-deeper-than-expected economic downturn. The Asian tempest of 1997-98was largely rooted in home-grown excesses, but this time, people here feel swept by events out of their control.
Mr. Lettenbichler recalled that hotels here and elsewhere were half empty during the Asian financial crisis. He worries that a deep recession in the United States could bring back those days. In this age of global linkage, he said, Asia's distance from the West will provide little insulation.
Like the United States, most Asian countries were well into a slowdown before the attacks. Much of the weakness in Asia was because of weak demand for Asian exports in the United States and, to a lesser extent, Japan.
That trend has now been amplified: economists are rapidly reducing their forecasts for consumer demand and growth in both countries. Salomon Smith Barney said in a new report that it expected the United States economy to contract 0.2 percent in the fourth quarter, while Japan's will shrink 1.5 percent.
As Americans and Japanese curtail their purchases of laptop computers, video games and designer clothing, their austerity is reverberating through the export-dependent Asian Tiger economies.
On Wednesday, Singapore reported a record 21 percent decline in industrial production in August, and South Korea is expected to follow with a double-digit drop of its own. Taiwan, with the technology sector as its linchpin, is rewriting its record books, suffering its worst recession in half a century. Unemployment is expected to exceed 5 percent, extraordinarily high for Taiwan.
"The slowdown in the tech sector has had a very adverse effect on our economy," said Taiwan's finance minister, Yen Ching-chang, in a recent interview. "If this tragedy affects the U.S. economy, Taiwan will not be exempt."
Nearly 40 percent of Taiwan's exports go to the United States or Japan. Mr. Yen is cautiously optimistic about the American economy, saying it was big enough to absorb the shock of the attacks. But he said that Asian countries could no longer depend on Japan to be a locomotive for the region, despite its size.
"After the financial crisis, no one can be sure when Japan will recover," said Mr. Yen, who conferred with other finance ministers at a recent meeting of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum in Suzhou, China.
Not all Asian countries are affected the same way by a simultaneous downturn in the United States and Japan. Hong Kong's exports, while vulnerable to global weakness, are cushioned somewhat by its role as a middleman for the rest of China, packaging and reshipping goods to and from the mainland.
The weakening value of the United States dollar, a significant problem for countries like Japan whose exports lose competitiveness as a result, poses little or no threat to Hong Kong because its currency is linked to the dollar at a fixed rate; the same is true for China and for Malaysia.
Hong Kong will also benefit from the Federal Reserve's lower interest rates because its monetary policy is tied to that of the United States. Lower rates will be a relief to the territory's debt-burdened property developers.
A sharp rise in oil prices, a possible result of military action, would have a similarly uneven effect. Importers like South Korea and the Philippines would be badly hit, while producers like Indonesia and Malaysia would benefit.
What sets this downturn apart is its potential effect on China, Asia's most populous country. It came through the regional crisis with scarcely a scratch, mostly because China is less dependent on exports than its neighbors. But many analysts say it will not weather this one without damage.
Yiping Huang, a China economist at Salomon Smith Barney, said global weakness would diminish the country's exports enough to slow its overall growth. Mr. Huang has lowered his forecast for China's economic growth to 7.6 percent a year in 2001 and 2002, down from 7.8 percent this year and 8.2 percent next year.
Those numbers still put China far ahead of other Asian countries, many of them in recession or teetering on the brink. And when China's membership in the World Trade Organization is made official, analysts expect a stampede of foreign companies eager to enter China.
The trouble for China is that 11 percent of its foreign direct investment comes from the United States. Many experts say that American investors will steer clear of China and other emerging markets in the aftermath of the attacks.
"Everyone in China is expecting a very buoyant year in foreign direct investment," said Henry Lee, the managing director of Hendale Asset Management in Hong Kong. "But I think the first reaction of Americans will be to hold their own fort, before investing outside the U.S." 
That could spell trouble for Southeast Asian countries as well; they have already suffered a marked decline in foreign investment since the crisis of 1997-98. Most vulnerable are countries with large and potentially restive Muslim populations, like Malaysia, and Indonesia.
"President Bush's recent remarks may heighten the risk of Muslim insurgencies in some Asian countries," said Donald Hanna, the head of Asian economic analysis at Salomon Smith Barney in Hong Kong.
Few people say this downturn will prove to be as devastating as the Asian crisis, which wiped out years of development and redrew the region's economic and political map. Some, like Marc Faber, the money manager, even argue that investors should seize the opportunity to buy Asian stocks cheaply.
But most agree that Asia can forget any dreams of returning to robust health in 2002. "This disaster was televised worldwide and traumatized people around the world," said Ian K. Perkin, chief economist at the Hong Kong General Chamber of Commerce. "Are they going to feel like spending at Christmas?"

HEADLINE: Mexico Hopes to Lure Travelers With Its Close-to-Home Status 

BYLINE:  By GRAHAM GORI 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 27 

 BODY:
As in much of the world, the economic outlook in Mexico has darkened in the weeks since the terrorist attacks in New York and Washington, and analysts say the economy will grow only 0.5 percent in 2001, far off its 2000 pace of 6.9 percent.
 But one sector that is at the center of the trouble elsewhere may be a bright spot for Mexico. Officials say tourism here may not decline much and may regain losses because Americans who are nervous about security in air travel will want to visit places that are familiar, safe and close to home, and Mexico fills the bill. 
 "Flying is a concern, and longer flights are a larger concern," said John McCarthy, director of Mexico's National Trust for Tourism Development, emphasizing that flights to Mexico are only slightly longer than domestic flights for most Americans.
The Ministry of Tourism, which calculates that tourism accounts for one-tenth of the Mexican economy and that 85 percent of its 20 million annual visitors come from the United States, has asked for a $40 million increase in its adverising budget to reinforce the perception that Mexico is a safe place to visit.
Officials also say Mexico will weather the storm better than other nations because of its emphasis on time-share tourism, in which guests buy a part-ownership of a place to stay and the right to use it for certain weeks each year. Mexico has more time-share properties than any country except the United States.
"These are people who will be demanding tickets, and creating the necessary critical mass to bring some life back to these towns," Mr. McCarthy said.
In Cancun, where nearly the whole population of 600,000 depends directly or indirectly on tourism, one-sixth of the guest rooms are time-shares. In Puerto Vallarta and in the Los Cabos region, the proportion is nearly 40 percent.
Hotel occupancy is running 10 percent below normal this month, officials said, but they hope to see near-normal traffic by December.

HEADLINE: America's Economic Cloud Extends Across Europe 

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Sept. 27 

 BODY:
BASF, the German chemical conglomerate, had already warned investors last month that profits would be down this year. Today, assessing the fallout of the terrorist attacks on New York and Washington, the message was far more pessimistic.
 "The sensitive balance of the global financial and economic markets has been disturbed and must be re-established," Jurgen Strube, BASF's chief executive, said in a carefully worded statement. It was obvious, he said, that an economic recovery would not occur this year and that a recovery would occur next year only if political leaders made the right decisions. 
 European corporations and consumers have been badly unnerved by the events of the last two weeks. The European economy had already slowed considerably in the last several months, and the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11 extinguished hopes here that the United States would bounce back and pull the rest of the world along with it. 
Now, executives like Mr. Strube see two possible futures to prepare for. In the happier example, world leaders work together and manage to stabilize the world economy. In the grim one, consumer confidence continues to plunge, oil prices are volatile and recovery comes very late or not at all next year.
"Both scenarios are equally realistic," Mr. Strube said.
In France, Insee, the economic research institute, reported today that business confidence in September dropped to its lowest level since 1996 -- and four-fifths of the survey responses came in before the attacks, so the mood may now be even bleaker.
The prime minister of France, Lionel Jospin, went so far as to declare consumer spending tantamount to a civic duty. "The battle against terrorism is not merely an issue for the judges, the intelligence agencies and the nations," Mr. Jospin said in an interview published today in the French newspaper Ouest-France. "Let us together show economic patriotism."
In the two weeks since the attacks, European corporations have been racing to revise their plans and prepare for a more prolonged slowdown. LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton, the world's biggest luxury goods group, said just after the attacks that its earnings would be down; similar warnings have since come from Gucci, the Italian fashion designer; Escada, the German producer and retailer of sports and casual clothing; and Leica, the German camera maker.
Most of those warnings stem from fears about slowing sales in the United States. But European consumers are likely to cut back sharply as well, especially if the slowing economy causes unemployment to rise. 
Economists have once again revised downward their forecasts for growth in the 12 nations adopting the euro currency. A few months ago, many expected growth of 2 percent this year and 2.5 percent or more in 2002; now most expect 1.5 percent or so this year and next.
The spreading gloom has already affected economic policy. European finance ministers, meeting last week in Belgium, made it clear that many countries would fall short of their goals for deficit reduction this year.
The European Central Bank's policy board decided at its meeting in Frankfurt today not to follow the emergency half-point cut in interest rates approved after the attacks with any additional reduction. But many economists are convinced that more rate cuts are to come.
Today's warning by BASF provided addition evidence that the fallout from the terrorist attacks is reaching heavy industry as well as consumer spending. BASF and other chemical companies had already been contending with slumping demand and prices, prompting BASF to shed 2,800 workers. Plans for another 1,200 layoffs were announced last month. But BASF said then that it could still increase profit by 10 percent a year.
Today, the company said the attacks made that goal unrealistic.
German machine manufacturers and carmakers are also under pressure. Germany's association of machine tool manufacturers said today that production would fall 2 percent next year as a result of weak global demand. Heidelberger Druckmaschinen, the world's largest maker of printing presses, warned this week that its sales would come in lower this year than last. 
Throughout Europe, many companies had based their optimism on the conviction that the American economy would bounce back quickly. 
Escada, the producer and retailer of high-priced casual wear, generates more than 24 percent of its sales in the United States and is still planning to build a store in New York City. But the chief executive, Wolfgang Ley, said this week that Escada's sales in America fell by half immediately after the attack and were still off by 25 percent. 
"We cannot yet say whether that is a trend," Mr. Ley said on Wednesday, as he discussed the company's third-quarter results. But, he said, the company has already started to search for ways to cut costs and will probably not meet its goal of increasing sales by 10 percent this year. 
Big clouds hang over Germany's luxury car companies as well, especially Porsche, which receives nearly half its profits from the United States.
The big question is whether European consumers will cut back their spending as well. The Dutch government reported this week that consumer confidence, measured just after the terror attacks, had dropped 9 percent from the month before -- the first evidence that the attacks had rattled consumers on this side of the Atlantic.
It is too soon to know if the effects are broad and lasting. Pinault-Printemps-Redoute, the big French luxury goods company, said this week that its Paris stores had experienced only a brief drop in sales after Sept. 11.
"From what we can tell, I would say the near-term impact is, if anything, less that we had been expecting," said Simon Irwin, a retailing analyst at BNP Paribas. The real effect will depend, he said, on whether unemployment begins to rise, as it has in America.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Big Companies' Shares Rally on Hopes They Offer Safety

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL BRICK 

 BODY:
Stocks of large companies rose yesterday in an afternoon rally, as investors sought relatively safe places to place their money through an increasingly cloudy economic downturn.
 Money managers turned to companies that they thought were less likely to suffer in a recession, and they also bought Treasury securities, pushing those prices higher as well. 
 Investors generally disregarded the day's economic reports, which they found either unsurprising or virtually meaningless after the attacks against the United States. Instead, they mostly expressed confusion about what the United States might do with its military, about what might be done to the country and about how it all would play out in dollars and cents. 
"How long will people have their hands in their pockets?" asked Stephen J. Massocca, president of Pacific Growth Equities, an investment bank in San Francisco. "How long will people stay off airplanes?"
After being solidly down until midafternoon, the Dow Jones industrial average turned around and rose 114.03 points, or 1.33 percent, to close at 8,681.42. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 11.57 points, or 1.15 percent, to 1,018.61.
The Nasdaq composite index slipped 3.33 points, or 0.23 percent, to 1,460.71, although it recovered from steeper losses.
Still, analysts had doubts that the blue-chip rally reflected any broad turnabout in the stock market. "There's not going to be any instant gratification," said David Henwood, chief investment officer for Raymond James & Associates. "There's really nothing to sustain it."
The rally seemed to involve preprogrammed trading touched off by stock prices reaching certain low levels, said Brett Gallagher, vice president of Julius Baer Investment Management. Rallies caused by investors covering short sales, or bets that prices will fall, more typically begin in small-capitalization stocks, he said. By the middle of the day, the stock market "looked oversold on a technical basis," he said.
In contrast, prices of Treasury securities moved higher throughout the day, pulling down their yields, which move in the opposite direction. The government issued new two-year notes on Wednesday, a move that in other circumstances might cause prices to fall and yields to rise, but demand was hefty. The yield on the two-year note dropped to 2.76 percent yesterday, its lowest point in decades, from 2.79 percent on Wednesday.
The yield on the benchmark 10-year Treasury note fell to 4.55 percent from 4.63 percent, while the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond dropped to 5.43 percent from 5.50 percent. 
Shares of drug makers, which are considered somewhat resistant to the effects of an economic slowdown, were rising all day. Merck gained $2.86, to $66.21, while Pfizer rose $1.20, to $39.75. Later in the day, prices began to rise for other large-capitalization companies, including the so-called cyclicals that had fallen sharply recently. The rally in the Dow was helped by gains by Exxon Mobil, up $2.41, to $38.42; Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, up $2.93, to $96.31, and General Motors, up $1.06, to $41.16.
Tobacco companies showed strength yesterday. Philip Morris rose $2.14, to $49, helping to lift the Dow. RJR Tobacco Holdings rose $2.73, to $58.
Weighing on the Dow, however, was I.B.M., which fell $1.30, to $90; the company was the subject of a few negative reports from influential analysts this week.
Semiconductor stocks continued to be among the weaker sectors. National Semiconductor lost $2.23, to $20.63, while Applied Materials dropped $1.26, to $27.87. The Philadelphia Stock Exchange's semiconductor index fell 8.63 points, or 2.33 percent, to 362.00, after plunging 7.9 percent on Wednesday.
Sonus Networks was the day's biggest loser, dropping $3.52, or 55 percent, to $2.88. The company, which makes telephone network equipment, forecast losses for the third quarter and the full year because of weak demand for its products.
The latest economic reports appeared to have little effect on the stock market. The government reported yesterday that sales of new single-family homes rose 0.6 percent in August, to an annual rate of 898,000, and orders for durable goods dropped 0.3 percent in August. But many investors seemed to feel that after August ended, everything that had happened during that month only mattered for 10 days.
The government also reported that the number of initial claims filed for unemployment insurance jobless claims rose by 58,000, to 450,000, for the week ended Sept. 22 -- the highest level in about nine years. "I don't think that caught anyone by surprise," Mr. Massocca said.
Market analysts often express the utmost certainty about their own opinions, if not about stocks. In contrast, William Tedford, a vice president of Stephen Capital Management, said that soon after the attacks, he accepted that the Dow would fall about 10 percent.
"It could be much worse than that," he said. "I just don't know yet."

HEADLINE: The Economic Stimulus We Need 

BYLINE:  By Alan S. Blinder; Alan S. Blinder is a professor of economics at Princeton and former vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.

DATELINE: PRINCETON, N.J. 

 BODY:
It is time to get past the debate over whether or not the United States economy needs a fiscal stimulus and get on to the questions of how large and what kind. While history offers no real parallels to the terrorism of Sept. 11, it is all but certain that the American economy entered a recession on that day -- if not before. Prior to the attacks, only the mighty consumer was keeping the economy above water. And while the official data will be mum for some time, consumer spending probably fell off a cliff on Sept. 11. The longer we wait, the more likely it is that the terrorists will score a victory over our economy. 
 Three principles should guide the debate over the stimulus. First, we must act quickly. No policy action can match the speed of the likely drop in consumer spending -- in that sense, we are already behind the curve. So we must find policies that can sail through Congress quickly. Second, we must remember that rapid actions do not guarantee quick effects. For example, the Federal Reserve has already cut interest rates and will probably do so again on Oct. 2. But those rate cuts will not affect spending for many months to come. An effective stimulus must lead to new spending promptly. Third, the stimulus program must not damage the long-run prospects for federal budget surpluses, lest long-term interest rates rise and choke off spending. 
 These three principles eliminate many of the ideas that have been bandied about in Washington. And they lead me to recommend the following policy, which is nonpartisan, fast-acting and temporary: Let Congress offer to reimburse the tax receipts lost by any state that agrees to cut its sales taxes over the next 12 months (up to some limit). Since almost every state levies a sales tax, this plan should be well received by both Republican and Democratic governors and legislatures throughout the country. 
A sales tax cut aims its medicine squarely at boosting consumer spending, which is the highest priority right now. Since most sales taxes are regressive, reducing them would benefit low-income families, many of whom live from paycheck to paycheck. Such people are likely to spend their gains quite promptly. But everyone who purchases taxable items would receive a tax cut.
Since the proposed sales tax cut would be temporary, it would not damage the long-run budget outlook. As Alan Greenspan and many others have observed, fears that the surplus is disappearing have kept long-term interest rates too high for months. A stimulus program must not exacerbate those fears.
The effectiveness of many types of tax cuts -- like income tax cuts -- is undermined by making them temporary, because most people base their spending decisions on more than this year's income. But the situation is just the reverse for a sales tax cut. The impact of a lower sales tax is actually enhanced by making it explicitly temporary, because doing so creates clear incentives (albeit small ones) to buy now rather than later.
Finally, we could strengthen the stimulus by offering special tax rebate assistance to New York City, which, as the chief victim of the horrors of Sept. 11, is suffering a sharp economic downturn.
A temporary sales tax cut would be politically attractive, economically effective and administratively simple to boot. The American economy is going to experience a recession, almost certainly. But if we act quickly and decisively, it can be a short one.

HEADLINE: Into an Unknowable Future 

BYLINE:  By Tom Brokaw; Tom Brokaw, author of "The Greatest Generation," is managing editor of NBC Nightly News.

 BODY:
Every great turn of history's wheel takes us in a new direction, but the destination is not easily discernible because the lessons of history are not fixed and immutable.
 The terrorist attacks on Sept. 11 seem to have been every bit as jarring to most Americans as the Japanese attacks on Pearl Harbor were for another generation. But Pearl Harbor led us into a great war and out of a great depression. This new war on terrorism will be fought less conventionally, and it could lead us into a deep recession. 
 Nonetheless, the two events are bound by a common reaction of, first, shock, then patriotism, national unity and a determination to fight back. But as we learned so painfully in Vietnam and the Russians learned in Afghanistan, military superpowers can be brought to their knees by enemies who have geography and zeal on their side, whatever their number. The lessons of David and Goliath are as fresh today as they were in biblical times.
On the home front, the success of the United States in World War II was due in large part to the common commitment of civilians as well as of those who were in the armed services. Factory workers stopped producing cars and started producing war planes and tanks; women went without stockings; children went without toys; families learned to ration sugar and meat.
In this new fight, the American economy will take a hit, but it is coming down from a very high high. We've been living on a rich diet, and though that may now change, many of the sacrifices are more likely to be inconveniences.
An equally important measurement will be the effect on our political and popular culture. Will gratuitous violence in movies and the cheap and titillating confrontation of talk shows give way to a longing for more serious themes? Will the surge of bipartisan spirit endure, washing away the pettiness that devalues public life and alienates voters?
When John F. Kennedy was assassinated, I was a young reporter working in Omaha. I was a true child of the 50's, innocent and conventional in my ambitions. I remember thinking then: "This doesn't happen here. This will change us." But I could not have anticipated the cataclysmic change that followed, from Vietnam, through social upheaval, to Watergate. Almost 40 years later I feel as uncertain as I did then, knowing only that change is coming again in forms we cannot foresee.

HEADLINE: With War in the Air, Home's but a Dream; 
Mexican Migrants, Fearing Impenetrable Border, Are Staying Put

BYLINE:  By CHARLIE LeDUFF

DATELINE: HOLBROOK, N.Y., Sept. 27 

 BODY:
The Mexicans here are holding their fingers into the winds of war. If they are gauging it correctly, this year's Christmas is shaping up to be a lonely and indigent one.
 Normally, the migrant men who work illegally on Long Island's East End would be making travel plans. The summer construction and landscaping jobs are drying up, and the holidays are approaching. This is the time they begin drifting back to Mexico with money orders in their wallets and chocolates for their women. 
 But the ambushes on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon on Sept. 11 have changed all that. Word from the southern frontier is that there is now an almost impenetrable wall of federal agents on both sides of the border guarding against terrorists determined to sneak into the United States. 
In this atmosphere of high anxiety, illegal workers say they believe that if they go home now, they have little chance of returning later.
To make matters worse, the Mexicans say, if the attacks have socked the American economy, then they have pummeled the already anemic Mexican job market.
"It's like living in purgatory," said Lorenzo Castillo, 53, a former tenant farmer from central Mexico who walked the desert for two days last spring to make his way to Farmingville, a small Long Island town about an hour and a half's drive east of Manhattan where illegal immigration has sparked crackling tensions. Farmingville is still a place where a man can make $10 an hour raking another man's leaves.
"I want to go home," Mr. Castillo said. "But I can't go home. I haven't made enough money. And if I go, will they arrest me? Or if I come back, will they arrest me then? I can't take the chance. I'm staying here for the winter."
In fact, only 3 of the 15 men who sleep and eat in a small, well-kept house here said they would risk the return home. Eduardo Cervantes arrived in April after being robbed in the desert. The work has run out and he has saved enough money, he said. Besides, he has not met a Mexican woman since he moved to the suburbs. Javier Santillan wants to see his wife. Mario Huerta is a new father who has yet to lay eyes upon his child. 
They will take the chance, they said. The others will wait.
This appears to be the trend nationwide, said an official with the United States Border Patrol, who offered his expertise on the condition that he not be named. 
"We're counting less footprints on the dirt roads around the border and we're apprehending fewer people," the official said. "My gut feeling is no one is moving anywhere. The Mexican economy is in the dumps and there is a feeling of insecurity among those men."
Mexico's president, Vicente Fox, came to the United States less than a month ago, lobbying Congress and the American people for the legalization of some of the 3.5 million Mexicans working here unlawfully. 
But with the terrorist attacks, the Mexican workers who had hoped for an immigration amnesty just three weeks ago now say they believe that the discussion is dead.
"The border is going to be tougher than I've ever seen it," said Lalo Cervantes, 38, who has drifted around the United States for 18 years making his living. "But closing it down is the correct thing to do at a time like this. The Mexicans here are just going to have to do what they have to do." 
Miguel Escobar, the Mexican consul in Douglas, Ariz., said the lines at the legitimate crossing points into the United States are long and the checks are exhaustive as a consequence of the attacks. 
Moreover, Mr. Escobar said, the Mexican government has added agents along the border in an effort to close the porous points where illegal immigrants routinely cross. Agents now rummage through the guest houses where people wait to be walked across the border by guides for a $1,000 fee.
"We have more people at the federal, state and local levels working the border, and it is paying off," Mr. Escobar said. "For example, 13 men from Yemen were apprehended last Saturday in Agua Prieta, just across from Douglas." 
None of the men in the Long Island house has any desire to spend the holidays in an immigration detention cell. 
But, while there was work at the beginning of the construction season for anyone who wanted to stand on the street corners and battle for it, on any given day now, a quarter of these migrant workers stand idle. 
"Things just aren't as abundant as they were," Lalo Cervantes said. "But this won't discourage the men. We have too many ties to this country now."
In the aftermath of the attacks, some of these men drove to Manhattan to help in rescue efforts. They carried buckets on their backs and distributed food in the shelters. And in the front of the Mexicans' house here is a sign torn apart by the wind. It reads: "America We Are With You."

CORRECTION-DATE: September 29, 2001

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article in The Metro Section yesterday about Mexican migrant workers described their lonely and indigent lives on the East End of Long Island and their fear that antiterrorism measures would result in border shutdowns and strand them in this country. The article was illustrated with a photograph of a man in a house shared by 15 Mexicans. He wore a sombrero emblazoned with a Spanish vulgarism. The choice of picture evoked an ethnic stereotype, and the publication of the vulgarism violated The Times's standards. The picture should not have appeared.

HEADLINE: Number of Uninsured Drops for 2nd Year 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 

 BODY:
The number of Americans without health insurance declined last year for the second year in a row, after rising steadily for more than a decade, the Census Bureau said today.
 The bureau found a significant increase in the number of people with coverage provided by employers, and it reported a substantial increase in the number of children with insurance. 
 Over all, the number of people without health insurance declined by 551,000, to 38.7 million last year, from 39.3 million in 1999, the bureau said. The proportion of people without coverage declined to 14 percent, from 14.3 percent. 
Several economists and health policy experts said the declines were unlikely to continue this year. Tens of thousands of people have been laid off, the economy has weakened, and the cost of health care and health insurance has shot up.
Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, said: "With the economic downturn, we need to be worried that more Americans will become uninsured. We know that when people lose their jobs, they are likely to lose their health insurance as well."
The number of people with employer-sponsored coverage rose more than 3 million last year, to 177 million, as employers competed for workers in a tight labor market by offering health benefits to employees and their dependents. The number of uninsured children dropped 693,000, to 8.5 million.
"The main driving force for children, as for adults, was the increase in employer-sponsored insurance coverage," said Charles T. Nelson, a statistician at the Census Bureau.
Congress has been considering proposals to expand coverage and even earmarked money for the purpose earlier this year. Democrats tend to favor expanding Medicaid and other public programs. Republicans and some Democrats support new tax breaks to encourage the purchase of private insurance. But Congress has set such proposals aside at least temporarily while it responds to the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, and the budget surplus has declined.
From 1998 to 1999, the number of the uninsured fell by 1.7 million.
Genevieve M. Kenney, an economist at the Urban Institute here, said: "The decline in the number of uninsured last year was encouraging, but the pace of change was slower than in 1999. It worries me that one in five poor children is still uninsured."
The number of poor people without health insurance declined by 825,000 last year, to 9.2 million, from 10 million in 1999. Still, 29.5 percent of the poor had no health insurance of any kind last year, the bureau said. The number of poor children without insurance declined by 248,000, to 2.5 million, from 2.75 million in 1999.
The bureau said that the number of people in government health insurance programs rose slightly, by 355,000, to 66.9 million last year.
John F. Holahan, director of health policy research at the Urban Institute, said it appeared that the number of children on Medicaid had declined, while the number in the Children's Health Insurance Program, which serves families with slightly higher incomes, had increased.
Kate Sullivan, director of health care policy at the United States Chamber of Commerce, said the increase in employer-sponsored coverage reflected the fact that employers, especially small businesses, had been trying to lure workers by offering health benefits.
"But," Ms. Sullivan said, "we now have very different economic conditions. Employers are experiencing the highest premium increases in a decade."
Thus, Ms. Sullivan said: "I expect to see an increase in the number of uninsured in 2001 because people have been losing their jobs. An unemployed worker cannot easily afford coverage. The average cost for a family health plan is just over $7,000 a year."
With revenues growing less than projected, many states are experiencing budget pressures, and some have considered trimming Medicaid. Matt D. Salo, director of health legislation at the National Governors' Association, said: "Medicaid accounts for 20 percent of state budgets and is growing at double-digit rates. That's unsustainable."
The proportion of Hispanic people without insurance, 32 percent, remains higher than that of other groups. About 18.5 percent of blacks and 9.7 percent of non-Hispanic whites were uninsured last year. Coverage increased for those two groups, but not for Hispanics.
Leighton C. Ku, a health policy expert at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, said: "A large proportion of Latinos are noncitizen immigrants. Because of that, they are less likely to have Medicaid and job-based health insurance."
To compare states, the Census Bureau suggested using three-year averages of data from 1998 to 2000. By this measure, the proportion of people without health insurance ranged from a high of 22.6 percent in New Mexico and 22.2 percent in Texas to a low of 6.9 percent Rhode Island and 8.2 percent in Minnesota and Iowa.
The proportion of people without coverage was slightly above the national average in New York, (15.3 percent), but was below the national average in Connecticut (9.5 percent) and New Jersey (12.9 percent). 
The Census Bureau said it had made technical changes that tended to reduce the number of people listed as uninsured, so the figures for 1999 and 2000 are not directly comparable with those for earlier years. In conducting interviews, the bureau said, it now asks follow-up questions to help people recall whether they have insurance.

HEADLINE: Moratorium by Nasdaq on Listing Rules 

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The Nasdaq stock market has temporarily suspended certain trading requirements to help companies remain listed and to ease the economic turmoil in the wake of the attacks on Sept. 11. 
 Nasdaq, which lists more than 4,300 companies, said yesterday that the moratorium would be in effect until Jan. 2. 
 The move exempts companies from meeting minimum stock price and public float requirements -- the number of shares available for public trading. 
"It gives those companies that were on the cusp of delisting a chance to weather the uncertain times a little more," a Nasdaq spokesman, Michael DeMeo, said. 
Nasdaq, part of the National Association of Securities Dealers, would not disclose the number of companies that face delisting. 
A company's shares must trade above a minimum price, usually $1, to stay listed on the Nasdaq market. The minimum value of a public float varies.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: JAKARTA; 
U.S. Lets Employees Leave As Indonesia Protests Mount

BYLINE:  By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 27 

 BODY:
With hundreds of protesters burning American flags outside its gates and with fringe groups threatening to kill Americans, the United States Embassy told most of its staff today that they could leave the country if they chose.
 While the government has expressed guarded support for the United States in its new battle against terrorism, militant Islamic groups have been staging demonstrations in several cities and vowing to take revenge if the United States attacks any Muslim nation. 
 These groups represent a small minority in this mostly Muslim country of 210 million, where the practice of Islam is largely tolerant and moderate. But they have made their presence felt in recent years with bombings, vandalism and threats. 
Last week, President Megawati Sukarnoputri affirmed in a meeting with President Bush in Washington that Indonesia joins America in opposing terrorist attacks, though she stopped short of pledging support for retaliation. "We share this moment of grief with you," she said.
At home, small demonstrations had already begun, almost daily, outside the fortified American Embassy, set far back from the street behind a high iron fence near government buildings in central Jakarta.
Such demonstrations are not uncommon -- protests erupted, for instance, over international aid to East Timor when it broke from Indonesia in 1999. There was a similiar but smaller wave of protests and threats in 1991 when the United States led an international force in attacking Iraq.
With emotions running high here, some leading religious and political figures have joined the vilification of the United States. Vice President Hamzah Haz suggested last week that the terror attacks could help America "cleanse its sins." The former president, Abdurrahman Wahid, said America itself is a "terrorist nation."
With the verbal attacks swirling, Ambassador Robert S. Gelbard criticized Indonesia's security forces today for not moving against militants who have openly threatened to attack the embassy and kill Americans, including himself. "They have not been prepared to act," he said, "to warn or to arrest people who break the law when there are threats against the lives of Americans."
On Wednesday, the State Department warned Americans to stay away from Indonesia, saying the attacks in the United States had raised security concerns here significantly. In an earlier statement, it said, "Extremist elements may be planning to target United States interests in Indonesia."
Mr. Gelbard said last week that Osama bin Laden, who is Washington's prime suspect in this month's attacks, could also be tied to threats that caused the closure of the embassy here for several days last fall.
The embassy statement today said, "The Department of State has authorized the voluntary departure of all United States government personnel in non-emergency positions and family members in Indonesia."
Many Americans who live here have been rattled by the threats and some diplomats and their dependents were already preparing today to leave. Extra police have been posted outside the embassy, which can only be entered, like a space capsule, through a series of secure locked chambers.
The rally at the embassy today was the biggest so far, with raised fists and chants of "Go to hell, America" and "The United States government supports terrorism." There were cheers when an effigy of President Bush was set on fire.
This is a time of broad discontent in Indonesia, which has suffered over the past four years from political chaos and economic collapse. Angry demonstrations and violent outbursts have become a common response to problems of all sorts.
The rallies outside the embassy provide a forum for expressing broader grievances against America, said Al Chaidar, an expert on Islamic groups at the University of Indonesia.
Indonesia's prickly form of nationalism sharpens its resentment of America's wealth and power and of the influence it wields here through multinational organizations like the International Monetary Fund.
In addition, America's perceived solidarity with Israel has continued to arouse anger here as in many other predominantly Muslim nations.
"We call on the Indonesian government to sever all ties -- diplomatic and economic -- with America and its allies," said Muhammad Ismail Yusanto, an organizer of today's rally at the embassy. "To close their embassies, expel their diplomats and take over their companies and assets."
It seemed an unrealistic plan for the world's fourth most populous nation, but the threats of violence that surround it gave the words a sharper edge.
