HEADLINE: For Nicaragua's Atlantic Indians, Autonomy Means Neglect 

BYLINE:  By DAVID GONZALEZ 

DATELINE: ALAMIKAMBA, Nicaragua 

 BODY:
For generations, the Miskito Indians nestled in the remote jungles along the Atlantic Coast have been cut off from the rest of the country by distance, culture and even the weather.
 Other parts of Nicaragua have been parched from drought in 2001, but unrelenting rains swelled the Prinzapolka River here, turning it into a murky mess. Latrines flooded, and agricultural chemicals washed down its banks. When the rains subsided, the rice and corn fields became a feast for insects. 
 As difficult as the weather has been, so too have been the lives of those living in one of the most isolated -- and forgotten -- parts of Central America. Some villages are reachable just by canoe on a four-day journey. Public assistance is barely present, even though the region covers almost half of the country. Limited self-rule was granted in 1987 as part of a truce with rebels who had taken up arms against the Sandinista government.
Autonomy was supposed to give residents a say not only in how they were governed, but also control over abundant natural resources. Instead, it has resulted in neglect, with most people barely surviving on farming and fishing. Aid groups are increasingly worried about the licenses that the national government has recently issued to logging companies. 
Underscoring the neglect, the Inter-American Court of Human Rights has ruled that the Nicaraguan government had repeatedly violated the human rights of the Mayagana Indian community, according to its lawyers.
The court, part of the Organization of American States, is widely expected to announce its ruling publicly on Friday, Sept. 28, in Washington. But the lawyers say that in a near-unanimous decision, the court faulted Nicaraguan officials for ignoring the traditions and property rights of the Mayaganas when it granted the logging concessions. Nicaragua's protection of the Atlantic Coast residents has been "illusory," a summary of the decision said.
With little official attention charitable groups and relief agencies are the sole sources of assistance. The floods have left thousands of villagers dependent on donated food, and even that will run out in October, when heavier rains may arrive. 
"Then the matter becomes complicated," said Charles Grigsby, project director for Oxfam in Nicaragua. "We need to build wells and latrines. People want to plant their fields. But all you can do now is clear them." 
Rains and floods are not new to the villagers, whose houses line the river. Many said they knew that they should live further inland but did not have the resources to relocate and rebuild. 
On a recent visit, a few trees poked out from the river at Dos Amigos, a village an hour and a half from Alamikamba by motorboat. A thick puttylike mud was everywhere, from the riverbank to under the stilt houses and beyond, to the marshlands. A few chickens and hairy gray piglets scampered about, while a calf was tied to a post under one house. 
"A lot of animals died when the river swelled up," a farmer, Fidel Gomez, said. "The clothes that people had hanging outside their houses were lost when the current took them away. People were left very poor in this zone." 
Before the donated food arrived, many residents got by with bananas. Some ate a datelike fruit called ujon that is usually fed to pigs and that the residents said made the children ill and left mothers unable to nurse their infants. 
Mateo Rosales's wife, Eusebia, is too weak to nurse their 18-month-old in the one-room shack that they share with eight other people. Although they have been able to supplement their meager banana diet with corn and soy meal, they are not so sure about the fields that used to provide them rice, corn and other roots and grains. 
"I want to plant again, but I can't with these floods now," Mr. Rosales said as a steady rain sent knee-high streams of water creeping toward the houses. "We planted what seeds we had and lost them with the first floods. And without a harvest, we cannot get new seeds."
Without rice, people have had to depend on donated corn. But even that has been a mixed blessing, because the youngest children are not used to eating it and have become sick with diarrhea, residents said. 
Orlando Jacobo, who is in charge of providing health information for the village, said children suffered allergies, respiratory infections, rashes and colds. "We do not even have a pill to give them," Mr. Jacobo said. "I am the health leader for this zone, but we do not have medicine. I am only the health leader in name."
Carla Hernandez, a community health specialist with Christian Medical Action, a relief group in the region, said a three-month supply of medicine from donors had yet to arrive. Worried about mosquitoes, which thrive in stagnant water, she had already given out antimalaria drugs.
She said her group, as well as a team from the Health Ministry had not been able to assess the extent of the problems from the floods. "The city governments are just being formed now," Ms. Hernandez said. "The government does not exist here. There is only one clinic in Alamikamba with one nurse."
The Dos Amigos school had been turned into a warehouse, as residents gathered for emergency food. The village leader, Felipe Rivera, thanked the United Nations representatives who had arranged the shipment. That was about as close as he would get to an official body. 
"The government gives us nothing," Mr. Rivera said, as he pondered the difference between autonomy and abandonment. "The government is my papa, but he does not come to visit."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Corn from U.N. and U.S. aid programs arriving in Alamikamba, Nicaragua. Floods have left thousands dependent on donated food. (Alex Quesada/Matrix) Map of Nicaragua highlighting Alamikamba: The jungles near Alamikamba are isolated by distance and culture.

HEADLINE: Layoffs Push Jobless Claims to 9-Year High 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 

 BODY:
The number of workers seeking unemployment benefits surged to the highest level in nine years as people dismissed after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks began to file claims for state aid.
 Job losses "will probably get worse before they get better," said Nicholas Perna, a private economist at Perna Associates in Ridgefield, Conn. That is likely to push unemployment above its current 4.9 percent rate, analysts said. 
 First-time jobless claims rose by 58,000, to 450,000, in the week ended Saturday, the Labor Department said. That was the largest gain and the highest level since the week ended July 25, 1992, when a company-wide shutdown of General Motors plants led to an increase of 69,000 claims filed.
A more complete joblessness picture will emerge in comin weeks as the government receives updated state reports, a Labor Department spokeswoman said. For instance, New Yorkers have filed about 75,000 claims since the attacks, and only 11,000 have showed in the national statistics so far, the department said.
Companies have announced plans to eliminate more than 100,000 jobs since Sept. 11. The attacks also caused manufacturers to shut down plants because increased security measures delayed shipments of needed parts, and that will mean a decrease in factory orders in coming months. In August, orders for durable goods fell 0.3 percent, led by weaker demand for aircraft, computers and automobiles, the Commerce Department said. The drop followed a revised 1.1 percent decrease in July that was larger than previously reported.
The attacks most likely pushed the economy into its first recession in a decade, analysts said. The economy probably shrank 0.5 percent on an annual basis in the third quarter and will contract 1 percent in the fourth, economists said. They now see a recovery starting in the first quarter of 2002, with growth reaching a 3 percent rate by the third quarter of that year.
The Commerce Department, in a separate report, said new-home sales rose in August to a level that still suggested the housing market was weakening before the attacks.
Sales increased 0.6 percent, to an annual rate of 898,000 houses, from a July pace of 893,000 that was weaker than first reported, the government said. Analysts had projected sales at a 925,000-unit pace.
On jobless claims, analysts had forecast that they would rise by 48,000 from the 387,000 initially reported for the week before last.
"Layoffs are mushrooming and spreading," said Sung Won Sohn, chief economist at Wells Fargo & Company in Minneapolis. "This will probably kick the jobless rate to above 5 percent shortly, and clearly the risks of a recession have increased."
The four-week moving average of new jobless claims, a less volatile measure of unemployment, rose to 422,000 last week from 410,250 the week before. So far this year, initial claims have averaged 388,000, up from last year's weekly average of 303,000 as the slowing economy pushed up the unemployment rate to 4.9 percent in August.

HEADLINE: AT&T Looks To Baby Bells For a Buyer 

BYLINE:  By SIMON ROMERO 

 BODY:
AT&T, the stumbling communications company once known as the mighty Ma Bell, is seeking to sell its telephone operations to one of its Baby Bell offspring. 
 AT&T has approached at least three of the nation's largest local telephone companies -- Verizon Communications, SBC Communications and BellSouth -- about buying its consumer and business telephone operations, people close to the companies said. 
 The three local phone companies were once part of AT&T, before the government-enforced breakup of the Bell System in 1984. In terms of annual revenue, SBC and Verizon are now both bigger than AT&T's telephone business, which topped $45 billion last year but is expected to decline this year.
Consumers might feel little impact from an AT&T deal, because it would not include AT&T's cable television business, the nation's largest, which AT&T plans to spin off or sell. And residential long-distance service is a business that all the Bell companies are planning to offer anyway -- but only as they win regulators' approval state by state. Acquiring AT&T would do nothing to speed that regulatory timetable. 
Each of the Bells is interested in AT&T primarily for its business customers and its national and international network, the world's largest communications system. Analysts say AT&T's telephone business could fetch $30 billion or more.
For AT&T, the effort to sell its telephone operations, which include the largest consumer long-distance company, is yet another sign of the way a groping business strategy and a protracted long-distance price war have left the company a battered shell of its former self. 
In the last two financial quarters, AT&T has lost nearly $2 billion, largely a result of a sharp decrease in revenue from long-distance operations and the decline in value of Internet-related investments. The company is also saddled with almost $40 billion of debt. 
"AT&T is a rapidly depreciating asset," said Scott Cleland, a financial analyst who is chief executive of Precursor Research in Washington. "AT&T is throwing out lifelines wherever they can."
After spending some $100 billion buying cable television systems in the late 1990's in a strategy of combining cable, telephone service and Internet access into a single household service, the company chairman, C. Michael Armstrong, reversed course a year ago. In October, he announced a plan to break AT&T into three companies: a wireless carrier, a cable television company and a telephone company. 
The wireless spinoff has been completed. But the cable proposal was interrupted in July by an unsolicited $44.5 billion takeover offer for the cable business that came from Comcast. The companies have not negotiated since then, but they are close to signing a confidentiality agreement that would allow them to talk, people close to the matter said. But AT&T is also having discussions with other suitors.
Now comes word that instead of making its telephone business a stand-alone operation, AT&T is looking for a rescue by one of the Bell companies. 
Officials from AT&T and the Bell companies it has contacted declined to comment on the talks yesterday. People close to the talks said it would want to label any possible deal a "merger of equals," not only out of pride but for tax advantages. 
But analysts said it was clear that AT&T was seeking to sell its business and consumer assets to the highest bidder. People close to the company said that AT&T had also held discussions with at least one big overseas communications company, although they declined to identify the company. 
AT&T's discussions with BellSouth were reported yesterday on the Web site of Business Week magazine.
A deal between AT&T and a Bell company would raise regulatory issues, although perhaps not the hard opposition AT&T encountered in 1997 when it discussed a merger with one of the same companies, SBC. 
At the time, Reed E. Hundt, the Clinton administration's chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, said such a combination was "unthinkable." It was the derailing of that deal that eventually resulted in AT&T's cable television strategy. 
William E. Kennard, the Democrat who succeeded Mr. Hundt at the F.C.C., said yesterday, "If this is a step to putting the Bell System back together again, it would reverse more than 20 years of promoting competition."
But the current F.C.C., under the chairmanship of Michael K. Powell, a Bush appointee, is seen as much less likely to resist big communications mergers. Mr. Powell declined to comment yesterday. 
For a deal to pass regulatory muster, any Bell company would probably be forced to sell AT&T long-distance properties in states where it had not yet received federal approval to provide long-distance service. 
Verizon, based in New York, has local telephone operations in 31 states and is allowed to offer long-distance in Connecticut, Massachusetts, New York and Pennsylvania. 
SBC, based in San Antonio, has local operations in 13 states and has won long-distance approval in Texas. 
BellSouth, which is based in Atlanta and operates local phone companies in nine Southeastern states, has not been allowed to enter the long-distance business.
Another concern facing regulators is competition on the local level, where companies other than the Bells have no more than 10 percent of the market, according to the F.C.C. In fact, AT&T is one of the largest competitors with the Bells in this area, making co-ownership of local properties an important issue in any possible deal.
Regulators would be likely to require the resulting entity to sell AT&T's local telephone properties in the region in which it operates. But the companies formed by a merger could put this issue to their advantage by suggesting they would strengthen AT&T's local phone properties in the regions dominated by other Bells, thus increasing competition.
"It's a matter of structuring the deal to allow it to pass muster," said Bob Atkinson, a former F.C.C. official who is now director of policy research at the Columbia Institute for Tele-Information. 
Since the federally approved breakup of AT&T that spun off the original seven Baby Bell companies as local telephone providers, the Bells have emerged as the largest and best-financed communications concerns, consolidating into the four current companies. 
The fourth is Qwest Communications, based in Denver. Executives who described the AT&T discussions yesterday said they did not know if the company had talked to Qwest. 
In the last year, the telecommunications industry has been thrown into turmoil, as the dot-com collapse sent tremors through the economy. Companies that had expected the Internet boom to result in rapidly expanding demand for communications capacity were among the hardest hit when the weakening economy squelched that demand. 
The decline in value of large concerns that compete with AT&T, like WorldCom, which owns the long-distance company MCI, and Sprint, another large long-distance company, have led to speculation that they, too, might become takeover targets. 
Yet it is AT&T's decline that has perhaps attracted the most attention. The likely main attractions of AT&T's assets -- excluding its cable television properties -- are the data and voice communications services AT&T provides to large businesses. Business communications services is a $165 billion market, in which AT&T is the largest player, with a $35 billion share. 
An example of these services are the circuits and high-speed data transmission lines that AT&T leases to large companies that need to transmit information efficiently throughout the United States and sometimes around the world.
But the value of nearly all telecommunications properties has mostly declined in recent months, as the industry seeks to cope with the bankruptcies of numerous start-up companies that created a glut of network capacity.
The uncertainties make the value of a deal involving AT&T and a Bell company difficult to estimate. Analysts' estimates of the value of AT&T's long-distance and local telephone operations range from $20 billion to $50 billion, although most seem to fall at $30 billion to $35 billion.
"At these prices it comes down to who has the least hassle in getting a deal done," said Kevin Calabrese, an analyst at Argus Research.

HEADLINE: Financial Magic Looked Good, but Left Companies Weak 

BYLINE:  By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
SUDDENLY, balance sheets matter.
 For the last decade, as the American economy prospered, corporate America focused almost exclusively on earnings. Even as profits soared, however, many companies were borrowing more and more. 
 Why the debt? You might think that companies would have sought to take advantage of high stock valuations by selling shares and building up cash reserves. But few did. As a whole, corporate America bought more stock than it sold during the final years of the economic boom. 
Buying back stock seemed like such a good idea. Companies could issue millions of options to their executives, and then buy back stock to avoid diluting earnings. Many borrowed money at relatively low interest rates and bought back more shares than they issued. That tactic raised earnings per share and persuaded investors that companies were growing when their revenues and overall profits were not. Wall Street loved it.
"One of the hazards of the boom in equities is that it made companies feel they were worth more than might have been supported by fundamentals," said John Lonski, the chief economist of Moody's. "So they felt more confident about borrowing." 
And borrow they did. By the second quarter of this year, corporate America had debts amounting to a record 28 percent of assets, noted Paul Kasriel, the chief economist of Northern Trust.
Some called such numbers irrelevant. Interest rates were low, so debt-payment burdens did not seem excessive. Debt levels were compared with the high market value of companies' shares, and called reasonable. Earnings looked good, especially after companies massaged them to create pro-forma reports that left out some expenses. Investors who doubted those numbers looked instead to operating cash flow. Neither the earnings nor the cash flow table reflected the cost of share buybacks, and neither showed what would happen if sales, and share values, fell sharply.
Even now, earnings statements will present the best possible picture. The accounting rule makers have rushed out generous guidelines about how to treat losses after the terrorist attack. The rules are so flexible that some losses that would have been realized in any case will now be classified as extraordinary. Some companies will be able to report pro-forma profits that are better than they would have been without the attack. Analysts will say companies exceeded expectations, and thus presumably did well, even as they report large (extraordinary) losses. 
It remains to be seen whether those numbers will reassure share buyers. But creditors will watch the balance sheet, where all losses, whether or not they are called extraordinary, look the same. Some companies may report good pro-forma earnings even as they file for bankruptcy.
Much of the commentary on the stock market since the attack has focused on which industries will be hurt the most by the recession and falling consumer confidence. But attention is gradually turning to the question of which companies have the strongest balance sheets, and thus will be best able to survive. This week's stock market recovery has been concentrated in higher quality companies.
As investors flee the junk-bond market, borrowing costs are up sharply for low-rated companies that can still borrow money. Many cannot.
Companies that go broke will blame the recession for their woes. But their complacent financial strategies during the boom will bear part of the responsibility.

HEADLINE: OPEC, Deep in Uncertainty, Leaves Oil Output Steady 

BYLINE:  By NEELA BANERJEE 

DATELINE: VIENNA, Sept. 27 

 BODY:
Facing great uncertainty about the full economic impact of the attacks on the United States, and any retaliation that may come, the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries decided today to hold to its current production level of 23.2 million barrels a day.
 Despite a drop in oil prices this week, OPEC's decision to stay put was widely expected. If it had cut production to prop up prices, which it has already done three times this year as global demand slackened, it would have risked appearing insensitive to the spreading economic pain from the attacks two weeks ago. 
 Yet OPEC, which produces about 40 percent of the world's oil, appeared to leave open the option of cutting back production before its next meeting in November if prices continue to tumble. The group's president, Chakib Khelil of Algeria, said OPEC remained convinced that commodity oil prices "around $25 a barrel" were sustainable. In trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange today, the price of crude oil rose 36 cents, to $22.74 a barrel. Oil prices have fallen more than 18 percent since Sept. 10. 
Analysts note that OPEC has a means to decrease production by 500,000 barrels a day without a formal meeting if prices fall below a certain range. But it may not be as quick to reduce output as in the past.
"OPEC is not operating on its own timetable," said Raad Alkadiri, an OPEC specialist with the Petroleum Finance Company, a Washington consulting firm. "The clock they are looking at is Washington's -- and when Washington will go ahead with retaliation, what it will involve and how the world economy reacts to it. The situation isn't just murky for them, it's opaque."
Before Sept. 11, OPEC members had the luxury of gradually coming to terms with a slowing global economy and the decreased demand for oil. But the attacks raise questions that have left OPEC nations shaken.
Crude oil use in the United States alone fell by 930,000 barrels a day, or about 6 percent, after the attacks, as planes stood on tarmacs and the broader economy stalled, according to the Energy Information Administration, the analysis arm of the Energy Department. The question is whether that slide continues, and if so, for how long. 
"The impact of the disaster upon the international oil industry will be profound," Mr. Khelil said in opening remarks today at the OPEC meeting. 
The United States energy secretary, Spencer Abraham, welcomed OPEC's restraint. He said in Washington that the decision indicated the organization's understanding "that we need to have a strong and growing economy worldwide."
OPEC's only option for stabilizing prices now, analysts said, is to stop the informal overproduction that is rampant within the group. When oil prices were climbing most of last year, OPEC nations did not produce beyond their official quotas because nearly all lacked the extra capacity at the wellhead to do so.
But as the quotas were reduced and prices declined, some members stayed at a higher pace of production, especially in the last few months, to cash in on the still relatively high price of $25 or so a barrel. Analysts estimate that OPEC is overproducing by 700,000 to 1.3 million barrels a day.
On Sept. 1, a production decrease of one million barrels a day, ordered earlier in the summer, went into effect. Oil traders will be watching if that reduction is adhered to.
"A lot of the problem has been overproduction," said Thomas P. Bentz, senior energy analyst with BNP Paribas. "If they did adhere to quota levels -- and that's a big if -- it will take a substantial amount of crude off the market."
OPEC has no way of enforcing adherence, and analysts said that some countries, like Algeria and Qatar, have often gone their own way despite warnings. But OPEC has been stunned by the fall in oil prices this week, which might scare members into line. OPEC countries do not disclose actual production figures. But oil traders closely follow, tanker by tanker, how much oil is being shipped, and that information should have a great effect on prices. 
"OPEC lacks credibility right now," Mr. Bentz said, "so the initial reaction from the market is, 'We'll see.' Until there is clear information about production, the price will probably bounce around between $21 and $24 a barrel."
The organization has also turned to major producing nations outside its ranks, asking that they, too, pledge not to increase output. At today's meeting, representatives from eight non-OPEC exporters, including Russia, Mexico and Angola, said they would support the group.
But analysts said they considered the gesture mostly symbolic. Most of those countries lack the spare capacity to increase production, and Russia, which has steadily increased exports over the last year, may do so if it sees the chance, analysts said. 
Perhaps the harshest matter that OPEC has been forced to face, and much earlier than it wanted to, is that $25 for a barrel of oil may not be sustainable indefinitely. Despite Mr. Khelil's statement, some members said they could live with lower prices. 
The Iranian oil minister, Bijan Zanganeh, told the Reuters news agency, "Now I am comfortable with $22 because the OPEC basket price is about $20, and $22 is better than $20 for us." The "basket" to which he referred is the average of seven crude oil benchmark prices that the organization tracks. 
Indeed, early in 1999, when steeply falling oil prices approached $10 a barrel, OPEC would have been delighted at an $18 price, Mr. Alkadiri and other analysts said. "OPEC members aren't facing economic disaster because of these prices, he said. "They have to tighten their belts a bit."
If oil prices fall below $20 a barrel, that could eventually help lift the global economy out of its slump. Even before Sept. 11, high oil prices were thought to have been a major brake on economic growth.
"If oil ends up at $17 a barrel, is that necessarily bad?" said Leonidas P. Drollas, chief economist for the Center for Global Energy Studies, a research firm in London. "It's good for the U.S. consumer, and it is bound to help the economy."

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY 

 BODY:
 INTERNATIONAL A3-12

During a Yearlong Intifada, Fear Has Gripped Mideast
Among the facts upon which Israelis and Palestinians disagree is what day the intifada began. Palestinians say Sept. 28, 2000, when Ariel Sharon, now the Israeli prime minister, visited a site sacred to Muslims; Israelis tend to say the day before or the day after. But people on both sides describe similar effects of the events since: fear and desperation. A3

Shooting Rampage in Swiss Hall
A 57-year-old gunman stormed into a crowded regional legislature in Zug, killing 14 people and detonating a hand grenade before shooting himself dead. It was the bloodiest episode in the normally tranquil country's recent criminal history and prompted talk of tightening Switzerland's relaxed security. A6

HEADLINE: Guard Is Up for Stadium Security Officials Across the Country 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WONG

 BODY:
The football stadium sits across the Hudson River from the smoking debris of the World Trade Center. There will be more people with guns and uniforms there this weekend than at some minimum security prisons. They will look in bags and look over cars and scrutinize the tickets of tens of thousands of fans standing in long, long lines.
 But officials at Giants Stadium, which plays host to a Giants game Sunday afternoon and a Jets game Monday night, want those same fans to keep this bit of advice in mind: sit back, relax and enjoy the game. 
 Across the country, sports fans are trickling back into stadiums after a brief respite prompted by the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11. Those responsible for stadium safety are trying to walk a fine line between ensuring tight security and not ruining the fun. That middle ground will become only harder to tread during a fall season of high-attendance football games and baseball playoffs, and as the United States edges closer to military action in Afghanistan. 
"Our mandate here is what it always is, and that's to provide a safe, clean, effectively run facility for games or events to be staged in," said John Samerjan, a spokesman for the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, which runs Giants Stadium and the other athletic facilities at the Meadowlands in East Rutherford, N.J. "In terms of the atmosphere of the game itself, I think once the first pitch has been thrown or the kickoff has come, it is what it is. It's a baseball game or a football game, and I think fans' enjoyment of that will be the same as it has been at any other time."
But Samerjan acknowledged that "there will be some delays, and we're just trying to appeal to the fans' common sense here."
Many security experts say that sports arenas are logical targets for terrorists. Stadiums are gathering places for tens of thousands of people. And sports events often have a highly symbolic patriotic value.
"At least potentially, stadiums have an attractiveness to the terrorists because of the large gathering of a crowd, and it appears that the terrorists we're dealing with are intent on doing as much harm as they possibly can," said Jeff Schlanger, the chief operating officer of security services at Kroll Associates, a risk assessment company. "That's a potentially attractive target to a terrorist bent on wrecking as much havoc as one can."
John Woodward, a senior policy analyst at the RAND Corporation in Santa Monica, Calif., said that "stadiums and sports arenas in America, especially in light of the attacks, are legitimate terrorist targets," and that "those in charge of security in sports arenas and stadiums probably realize that very well."
Security experts say that, depending on intelligence gathered about the level of threat, new measures can include searching bags, using bomb-sniffing dogs and installing facial recognition technology, which was used at the Super Bowl last year. The Federal Aviation Administration has even declared no-fly zones within a mile of major stadiums and up to an altitude of 3,000 feet.
More security guards will be assigned to Giants Stadium. The Giants' home opener against the New Orleans Saints is expected to draw about 80,000 fans, as is the Jets' game on Monday night against the San Francisco 49ers. The events of Sept. 11, Samerjan said, "dictate that we increase our security presence, and our patrons would want us to do that."
The Meadowlands uses in-house security guards and the New Jersey State Police to staff events, although Samerjan declined to disclose their exact numbers.
When the attacks took place, he said, the company pulled out guidelines it had used during previous times of heightened security, instances that included the Persian Gulf war, a 1995 visit by Pope John Paul II and the 1994 World Cup. In addition to a ban on backpacks, coolers and large bags, stadium workers are required to wear identification badges at all times. Drivers are forbidden to park beneath ramps at the complex, which includes a racetrack and Continental Arena, home of the Devils and Nets.
Samerjan said tailgating would not be curbed because it "takes place at a considerable distance from the building itself." But stadium officials around the country are reviewing their policies on such practices. Bobby Goldwater, who oversees the 55,000-seat R.F.K. Stadium in Washington, said "that's something we're studying."
"There's a balance that has to be struck here, and I think every sports and entertainment venue will be searching for the right balance," he said. "I think there will be a challenge, and certainly a goal."
In Pasadena, Calif., a police officer said security officials overseeing the Rose Bowl, which plays host to college football games during the season and will play host to the national title game on Jan. 3, were reviewing their usual plans.
"As our situation nationally emerges, I would expect that planning and reviewing process to continue," the officer, Commander Mary Schander of the Pasadena Police Department, said.
But officials are keeping in mind that "the majority of people who want to go to an event want to go into the stadium and have a good time as expeditiously as possible," she said.
Along with Giants Stadium, the Rose Bowl played host to many of the games during the 1994 World Cup, and the heightened security measures for that event provided a useful template, Schander said. The measures included establishing inner and outer perimeters for the 90,000-seat stadium, searching all incoming packages and installing a surveillance camera system.
In 1942, a month after the bombing of Pearl Harbor, the Rose Bowl game was held in Durham, N.C., as a precaution.
At the Staples Center in Los Angeles, security guards are waving handheld metal detectors, known as wands, over the bodies of fans coming to the 20,000-seat arena, Michael Roth, an arena spokesman, said. Although many stadium officials said they had no immediate plans to use metal detectors, guards at the Staples Center used wands for Madonna concerts in the days after the attacks. Staples Center officials are now preparing for what they expect to be their two largest sports events of the next month: the Los Angeles Kings' home opener on Oct. 4 and the Los Angeles Lakers' home opener on Oct. 30.
As baseball teams look ahead to postseason play, stadium officials will be keeping in place security measures drawn up by Major League Baseball after Sept. 11. Coolers and large bags are prohibited and unauthorized cars parked within 100 feet of an arena are being towed. 
But baseball stadium officials are also tailoring security measures to their particular stadiums. At Pacific Bell Park in San Francisco, the number of security officers was increased by 10 percent for the first game after the attacks. Delivery trucks going to Wrigley Field in Chicago can only come in through the north entrance, and employees who park near the stadium have their ID's scrutinized more carefully.
At Safeco Field in Seattle, officials are still allowing large bags, but only after inspection, and "we're doing the same thing right now that we would do during any playoff game, except for the World Series," Paul Schieck, the director of stadium security, said.
Like the Super Bowl, the World Series will have security coordinated by league officials and federal, state and city law enforcement officials.
But the biggest test for sports security in the next year will undoubtedly come at the 2002 Winter Olympics in Salt Lake City. Previous Olympics have been plagued by acts of terrorism, starting with the 1972 Games in Munich, where 11 Israelis were killed. In 1996, a bomb went off in Atlanta, killing a person and injuring 111.
Security in Salt Lake City will be overseen by a newly created state agency, the Utah Olympic Public Safety Command. On the federal level, it will be overseen by the Secret Service, the F.B.I. and the Federal Emergency Management Agency. Since Sept. 11, officials from the agencies have been meeting around the clock to review plans, Mitt Romney, president of the Salt Lake Organizing Committee, said.
"I'm sure there will be some changes made," he said, "and we have been assured that whatever resources needed to secure the Games will be made available."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
In this new campaign, the words of the advertisers are written on the subway walls.

BYLINE:  By Andrew Zipern 

 BODY:
SUBWAY passengers in Atlanta who looked through the dark windows of their moving train yesterday saw glowing full-motion ads for Dasani, the bottled water from the Coca-Cola Company. The start of the unusual advertising campaign, originally scheduled for Sept. 11, the day of the terrorist attacks, was a quiet event, but it may herald a new age in outdoor advertising.
 City transit systems are emblazoning the dirt and graffiti-covered walls of subway tunnels with illuminated signs that, when seen from a speeding train, appear to be animated. The effect, similar to that of a flip book, is not unlike watching a 30-second television commercial. 
 "As you pass by at high speed, you see a full-fledged motion picture," said Matthew Gross, president of Submedia, the outdoor advertising company based in New York, which has installed 1,000 feet of light boxes between the Dunwoody and Sandy Springs stations on the North Line in Atlanta. "We use a series of compressed images and are able to get an extremely high frame rate -- about 200 to 300 frames per second."
An offbeat and fast-growing phenomenon, "in-tunnel" systems began appearing this summer in Europe. Adidas and Coca-Cola, the first to experiment with them, bought space in the subways of Budapest and Athens through MotionPoster, a small company in Oxfordshire, England. MotionPoster has recently announced contracts to install systems in Frankfurt and Munich and in Seoul, South Korea.
Many of the world's mass-transit systems are considering similar proposals. Interest remains high even after the attacks on Sept. 11. "We really have not had any letup in interest from advertisers," Mr. Gross said. "No matter what happens, companies are still looking for a way to differentiate themselves."
In August, Submedia signed a contract with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to install a system on the PATH commuter rail line in Manhattan. (Mr. Gross said that in the wake of the attacks, no firm date has been set.) Sidetrack Technologies, in Winnipeg, Manitoba, is setting up tunnel ads in the subway in Kuala Lumpur and has plans to bring at least two more systems to North America next year. All three companies are meeting with transit officials.
"Advertisers are using every opportunity they can find to communicate their marketing messages, to fight the clutter of advertising that surrounds us," Sid Holt, editor in chief of Adweek magazine, said in an e-mail interview. "And outside of prison, I can't think of a more captive audience than subway riders."
If in-tunnel media companies have anything in common, it is the belief that marketers must delve into previously unexplored territory to get consumers' attention.
Mr. Gross said advertisers could expect to pay $35,000 to $250,000 a month for in-tunnel media, depending on location and passenger traffic. The cost of Dasani's three-month run in Atlanta, he said, "is on the lower half of that scale."
Coca-Cola's subway ad is made up of saturated color images of cascading water. "It's a neat way to communicate in a targeted, closed environment," said Kellam Graitcer, Dasani's brand manager at Coca-Cola. Phactory Productions Inc., a New York design firm, created the ad.
"When you've got a brand new medium, people don't have anything that's been designed specifically for it," said Rob Walker, president of Sidetrack Technologies. "We can put images on both sides of the train so that the images can interact through the train."
Still, some wonder how effective such ephemeral imagery can be. Diane Cimine, executive vice president for marketing at the Outdoor Advertising Association of America, who has never seen the ads, said in-tunnel promotion sounds "wild and fun" but wonders whether "there's going to be a limitation on the communicability of these mediums."
Even if the market is relatively small, some critics say the idea will inevitably backfire, particularly given the new skittishness of subway riders. "There have been so-called breakthroughs like this for years -- like ads at the bottom of golf holes or in public toilets," said Kalle Lasn, the editor of Adbusters, a magazine published by the Media Foundation in Vancouver, British Columbia, that satirizes consumerism.
"The real story, the way I see it," Ms. Lasn said, "is that we are at the beginning of a huge backlash against the encroachment of our mental environment." 
Some point out that the technology is similar to one used by marketers in Ray Bradbury's dystopian vision "Fahrenheit 451."
MotionPoster maintains that there have been no negative comments in Europe. "None at all," said Michael Pelham, chairman of MotionPoster. "The passenger reaction is absolutely fascinating."
The ads "don't block any beautiful views of city architecture or mountains," Mr. Gross said. "This isn't a pristine environment. This is an industrial environment. It's just dark outside the window." 
He also points out that advertising revenues help the cities. "This is providing revenue to the subway system. It's actually directly helping the communities where these signs will be in place."
The economics of deals vary by city, but few transit authorities have the luxury of turning a blind eye to the potential revenue. Atlanta's in-tunnel advertisements are projected to bring the city several million dollars over the next few years. 
"I think people will ride the train just to see the ad," said Tony Griffin, marketing business manager of the Metropolitan Atlanta Rapid Transit Authority. "Obviously if this thing is a success, we want to look at it as a way of expanding."

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs; 
Talk Later

BYLINE:  By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
The day after the World Trade Center bombings an Egyptian TV show called and asked me to explain the impact on Americans. I scanned my brain for an analogy and finally said: Imagine how Egyptians would feel if three suicide bombers rammed airplanes into the Pyramids, with thousands of people inside. The World Trade towers were our Pyramids, built with glass and steel rather than stones, but Pyramids to American enterprise and free markets, and someone has destroyed them. 
 I'm still not sure the world fully appreciates what this has meant to Americans. We are not fighting for Kosovo, and we are not fighting for Bosnia, Somalia or Kuwait. We are fighting for our country. And Americans will fight for their country and they will die for their country. 
 The big question is how we fight this war to deliver to Americans what they want -- which is not revenge, but justice and security. It requires a new attitude toward the battle and new strategy on the battlefield.
What attitude? We need to be really focused, really serious, and just a little bit crazy. I don't mean we should indiscriminately kill people, especially innocent Afghans. I mean that the terrorists and their supporters need to know that from here forward we will do whatever it takes to defend our way of life -- and then some. From here forward, it's the bad guys who need to be afraid every waking moment. The more frightened our enemies are today, the fewer we will have to fight tomorrow. 
As for the new strategy, if our first priority is to destroy the Osama bin Laden network in Afghanistan, then we need to understand that it takes a home-grown network to destroy a home-grown network. Let me put it another way: If Osama bin Laden were hiding in the jungles of Colombia instead of Afghanistan, whose help would we enlist to find him? U.S. Army Special Forces? The Colombian Army? I don't think so.
Actually, we would enlist the drug cartels. They have the three attributes we need: They know how to operate as a covert network and how to root out a competing network, such as Mr. bin Laden's. They can be bought and know how to buy others. And they understand that when we say we want someone "dead or alive" we mean "dead or dead."
The Cali cartel doesn't operate in Afghanistan. But the Russian mafia sure does, as do various Afghan factions, drug rings and Pakistani secret agents. They all have their local, home-grown networks, and it is through such networks that the Afghan part of this war on terrorism will be fought. "The best news I've heard all week was that Vladimir Putin is serious about joining the coalition," said Moises Naim, editor of the journal Foreign Policy. "This sort of character can really help now."
Moises is right. Something tells me Mr. Putin, the Russian president and former K.G.B. spymaster, has the phone number of the guy in the Russian mafia who knows the guy in the Afghan cartels who knows the guy who knows the guy who knows where Mr. bin Laden is hiding. It is going to be that kind of war: an above-ground army you fight with tanks and generals, an underground network you fight with moles and exterminators. 
In fighting this kind of war the president and his advisers would do themselves a huge favor by not talking so much. They are already starting to contradict themselves and get tied up in knots. Be like the terrorists: Let your actions speak. It is much more unnerving to the enemy.
For everything there is a season. There will be a season later on for talking. There will be a season for dealing with other states that have supported terrorism. And there will be a season for promoting Arab-Israeli peace or economic development. But right now -- right now is the season of hunting down people who want to destroy our country. War alone may not solve this problem, but neither will social work. And one thing a focused, covert war will do is create a level of deterrence that has not existed up to now. Every state has to know that after Sept. 11, harboring anti-U.S. terrorists will be lethal. 
To drive that point home, though, people have to see that we are focused, serious and ready to use whatever tactics will make the terrorists feel bad, not make us feel good. As the Lebanese militia leader Bashir Gemayel once said about the Middle East -- before he himself was assassinated -- "This is not Norway here, and it is not Denmark."

HEADLINE: Japan Is Hoping Weaker Yen Revives Growth 

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The yen dropped to a one-month low against the euro and a two-week low against the dollar yesterday as the Bank of Japan sold its currency for the sixth day since Sept. 17 in an effort to steer the economy away from a recession.
 Meanwhile, the government said today that the unemployment rate remained at a record 5 percent in August and that household spending fell 1.3 percent in August, seasonally adjusted, from July. 
 Japan's currency weakened yesterday to 119.59 a dollar from 117.85 on Wednesday. It fell as much as 1.9 percent, to 120 a dollar, the lowest since Sept. 11. The decline rounded out a five-day losing streak, the longest this year. The yen sank for a fourth day against the euro, to 109.87 yen from 108.74. It traded earlier at 110.21 yen a euro, the lowest level since Aug. 23. 
Japanese policy makers want a weaker currency to bolster exporters' earnings and revive growth in Japan, the No. 2 economy in the world. A lower yen makes exports more attractive, which would help companies handle a three-year drop in domestic retail sales.
"They're not fooling around -- they really want to ensure a weaker yen," said Mark Thome, vice president for foreign exchange at Fortis USA Financial Markets. The yen may slide to 122 yen a dollar in coming weeks, he said.
The dollar strengthened to 91.76 cents a euro from 92.33 on Wednesday. The dollar has lost 1.8 percent against an indexed average of the yen, euro, Swiss franc, British pound, Canadian dollar and Swedish krona since the attacks on Sept. 11, raising concern the United States economy may slow further.
The yen extended early losses yesterday on speculation that the Federal Reserve Bank of New York sold yen on the Bank of Japan's behalf, said Vincent Palazzolo, chief trader at Sumitomo Mitsui Banking. Peter Bakstansky, a spokesman for the New York Fed, declined to comment on possible sales. The European Central Bank said it bought euros and sold yen for a third day this week.
Dustin Reid, a currency strategist at UBS Warburg in Stamford, Conn., said, "The Japanese authorities are upping the ante, and they're getting smarter with their intervention" by using other central banks to operate in various time zones and intervening while the direction of trading is already in their favor.
Mr. Thome at Fortis USA said there had been speculation that the Fed sold yen close to the 119.50 yen-a-dollar level. "The Bank of Japan should be successful," and the yen may slide toward 121 or 122 a dollar, he said.
Other than selling yen, Japanese officials "have no other policy options" to revive their economy, said Stefan Schilbe, an economist at HSBC Trinkaus in Dusseldorf.
Benchmark interest rates in Japan are already near zero, and government spending is constrained by debt amounting to about 130 percent of gross domestic product.
Japan has been stepping up yen sales as the end of its fiscal half-year approaches this Sunday. Japanese companies often buy yen to repatriate funds at such times, traders said.

HEADLINE: MOVIE GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. The ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on
Page 12.

Now Playing

"GLITTER," starring Mariah Carey. Directed by Vondie Curtis Hall (PG-13, 145 minutes). This film wants to be a heart-tugging tale of a rags-to-pop-royalty climb made poignant by love and loss. But "Glitter," with Ms. Carey as a talented performer who goes from backup singer to troubled star, is mostly dross, an unintentionally hilarious compendium of time-tested cinematic cliches that illustrate the chasm between hopeful imitation and successful duplication (Lawrence Van Gelder).

"THE GLASS HOUSE," starring Leelee Sobieski, Diane Lane, Stellan Skarsgard, Trevor Morgan and Bruce Dern. Directed by Daniel Sackheim (PG-13, 101 minutes). After their parents are killed in a car accident, Ruby Baker (Ms. Sobieski) and her brother are sent to live with the Glasses, a pair of dysfunctional creeps who also turn out, to no one's surprise but the children's, to be diabolical criminals. The movie might have succeeded as a minor entry in the thriller subgenre that includes "Single White Female" and "The Hand That Rocks the Cradle," but it takes more than a spooky score and horror-movie editing tricks to generate suspense. Mr. Skarsgard, who plays Terry Glass, is so cold and repellent from the start that it's impossible to imagine that anyone would trust him with a pet goldfish, let alone two innocent (and, of course, once it comes to outwitting him, absurdly resourceful) children (A. O. Scott).

"HARDBALL," starring Keanu Reeves, Diane Lane and John Hawkes. Directed by Brian Robbins (PG-13, 110 minutes). Daniel Coyle's nonfiction book about a children's baseball team from Chicago has been adapted into a mawkish, cutesy tearjerker. Mr. Reeves, as self-conscious as ever, is its reluctant coach, a down-and-out gambler who redeems himself (and pays off his debts) by leading these latter-day Bad News Bears to victory. The star is forced to deliver inspirational sound bites like the movie's meaningless tag line, "The most important thing in life is showing up" (Stephen Holden).

"LIAM," starring Ian Hart, Claire Hackett, Anne Reid and Anthony Borrows. Directed by Stephen Frears (R, 90 minutes). Like many other movies that revisit the turmoil and deprivation of the past century from the perspective of a child, Mr. Frears's new film, about a young boy in 1930's Liverpool, England, walks the delicate boundary between politically inflected realism and costumed sentimentality. At its best, "Liam" explores the effects of unemployment and poverty on Liam's working-class Catholic family with an impressionistic, detached lyricism that captures a boy's puzzlement and curiosity without being too cute about it. But the anecdotal treatment of the family's life gradually and inexorably turns melodramatic, and the violent conclusion seems not to grow out of the lives of the characters, but to be clumsily imposed on them (Scott).

"THE MUSKETEER," starring Catherine Deneuve, Mena Suvari, Stephen Rea, Tim Roth and Justin Chambers. Directed by Peter Hyams (PG-13, 106 minutes). This hopelessly confused and poorly written adaptation of "The Three Musketeers" tries to blend traditional costume adventure with MTV-ready attitude and Hong Kong-style duels. The nervous jump-cut editing chops the action sequences into visual coleslaw, and Mr. Chambers's lead character, D'Artagnan, mumbles like a dazed lobotomy patient. Ms. Deneuve and Mr. Rea, in small roles, pretend they're in another, more coherent movie, but it doesn't help (Holden).

* "OUR LADY OF THE ASSASSINS," starring German Jaramillo, Anderson Ballesteros and Juan David Restropo. Directed by Barbet Schroeder (R, 100 minutes; in Spanish, with English subtitles). One description for the ambience of this devastating portrait (filmed in high-definition video) of the corrupt Colombian city of Medellin might be documentary hallucination. With a screenplay adapted by Fernando Vallejo from his novel "La Virgen de los Sicarios," the film gazes into the soul of a burned-out homosexual writer who returns to Medellin (his hometown) after 30 years and finds it transformed into a circle of hell plagued by rampant, casual slaughter. He falls successively in love with two nihilistic street boys, both killers (Holden).

"ROCK STAR," starring Mark Wahlberg, Jennifer Aniston and Jason Flemyng. Directed by Stephen Herek (R, 142 minutes). Based on the true story of a heavy-metal fan who replaced the lead singer in the band he worshiped, this sloppy, charming melange of "This Is Spinal Tap" and "Almost Famous" looks back nostalgically at the big-haired, leather-and-spandex pop metal of the mid-1980's. Mr. Wahlberg, playing a Pittsburgh head banger who unexpectedly lives out his fantasy of sex, drugs and rock 'n' roll, captures both the naivete and the passion of obsessive fandom. Though the story of his transformation from regular guy to metal god and back again is predictable and unconvincing, the movie is full of well-observed details and authentically awful music. It both celebrates and, with gentle knowingness, ridicules the noisy, raucous world of big arena shows, endless touring and androgynous machismo that was 80's metal (Scott).

"TWO CAN PLAY THAT GAME," starring Vivica A. Fox, Morris Chestnut and Anthony Anderson (R, 90 minutes). Written and directed by Mark Brown. In this formulaic, featherweight romantic comedy, Ms. Fox, playing Shante, a young, supersuccessful advertising executive, dispenses tough-minded, good-humored advice on how to keep a man in line. Her resourcefulness is tested when her own man, a lawyer named Keith (Mr. Chestnut), threatens to stray. The two principals are appealing enough, but what little comic spark the film has comes from Mr. Anderson as a colleague of Keith's who becomes his counselor in love and war (Scott).

Film Series

OSCAR WILDE FILM SERIES. In conjunction with its major exhibition "Oscar Wilde: A Life in Six Acts," continuing through Jan. 13, the Morgan Library is presenting an eight-part film series that begins today and illuminates the multifaceted Wilde's life and work. The opening attraction, at 4 p.m., is "The Browning Version" (1951), directed by Anthony Asquith and starring Michael Redgrave as a middle-aged boarding school headmaster with an unfaithful wife. Redgrave's performance won him a prize for best actor at Cannes. At 6:30 p.m., the series continues with another Asquith film, "The Importance of Being Earnest" (1952), based on the classic Wilde comedy and again starring Redgrave. Coming up are "Maurice," "Salome's Last Dance," "The Picture of Dorian Gray," "An Ideal Husband," "The Trials of Oscar Wilde" and "Lady Windermere's Fan." Admission to the Wilde series at the Morgan, 29 East 36th Street, Manhattan, on Fridays through Oct. 19, is free with the regular requested contribution: $8; $6 for students and 65+; under 12, free with an adult. Tickets are available at the admission desk on the day of the show. Information: (212) 590-0333 (Van Gelder).

HEADLINE: Aid for a Terrorized Economy 

 BODY:
With the nation almost surely cast into recession by the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, leaders in Congress and the White House have been looking for ways to stimulate the economy. They have already pledged $40 billion to reconstruction and counterterrorism. To further spur consumption and investment, Washington should focus on the households and growing businesses that need extra cash most. Any stimulus should be temporary and designed to preserve the government's long-term fiscal health. 
 Top Republicans' initial proposals were dated and irresponsible. Lawrence Lindsey, the president's economic policy adviser, made lowering the corporate income tax rate the centerpiece of the administration's proposals, to the delight of big business lobbies. Representative Bill Thomas, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, suggested a cut in tax rates for capital gains, an idea that fortunately seems to be losing steam. These dead horses from the Republicans' stable of long-term fiscal policy themes were to be reincarnated as measures to stimulate the economy now. 
 Yet neither of these proposals would give the economy much of a short-term boost, and they might cost the government hundreds of billions of dollars in lost revenues over the coming decade. A cut in corporate income tax rates would just let owners of companies keep more of their profits. It would not necessarily change their investment or employment decisions in the short term, or ever. Reducing the capital gains tax might provide an incentive to save when the economy recovers, but in the short term it would lead to mass selling in a faltering stock market. In both cases, the tax cut would mainly benefit the wealthiest Americans -- those least likely to use it for new consumption.
As Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, and Robert Rubin, the former treasury secretary, pointed out in testimony before the Senate Finance Committee on Tuesday, the best remedies would be temporary, and encourage spending or investment. A temporary cut in payroll taxes would give extra money for consumption to all working Americans, even those with earnings too low to pay income taxes. Temporary tax credits for new investment would help companies to grow, potentially creating jobs to offset the numerous layoffs expected to result from the attacks.
To protect the government's bottom line, any new tax relief should be offset by rollbacks of President Bush's mammoth, 10-year package of tax cuts. Controlling the level of public debt would take upward pressure off long-term interest rates, an essential step toward promoting recovery.
The more regressive elements of the president's tax-cut package should be the first to go. Repealing the phase-out of the estate tax would be one good place to start. Restoring the top income tax rate to 39.6 percent, a move that could yield up to $100 billion over 10 years, is another. Top-bracket taxpayers would still benefit from rate reductions in the lower brackets.
A cyclical recovery to normal economic growth should arrive within a year or two. The current focus should be on measures that offer temporary, rapid and broad-based improvements in welfare.

HEADLINE: U.S. Will Help States With Unemployment Insurance 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 

 BODY:
Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill said today that the federal government would help states shore up their unemployment insurance programs to cope with the surge in layoffs after the terrorist attacks and might also extend benefits to jobless workers for a longer period.
 Mr. O'Neill spoke a few hours after the Labor Department reported that new claims for unemployment benefits rose last week to their highest level in more than nine years. The increase, to 450,000 from 392,000 the week before, was among the clearest indicators of how the aftershocks from the attacks are rippling through the economy. 
 Mr. O'Neill said the Bush administration continued to review a wide variety of options for helping the economy, including tax cuts that would be directed at individuals and businesses. But he said the debate within the administration was shifting from whether the government should pass an economic stimulus package to what types of actions it should take and that President Bush was likely to settle on a specific package soon.
"There's going to be something," Mr. O'Neill said in an interview. "It's obvious that some things need to be done. For example, we need to make sure the state unemployment trust funds have enough funds."
Mr. O'Neill singled out New York State, saying he was "not yet satisfied they have enough funds."
Beyond making sure that states do not run out of money to pay unemployment compensation, Mr. O'Neill said, "we're looking at the duration of benefits." He did not offer any details. Unemployment insurance is generally limited to 26 weeks.
Mr. O'Neill said Mr. Bush had directed his advisers at a meeting on Wednesday to develop detailed projections on what effects stimulus packages of different sizes and composition would have on the economy and job losses. 
Mr. O'Neill said that whatever the administration proposed now might have to be revisited later as the situation changes. He said there was already some thought being given to providing more aid to the airline industry, which was given $5 billion in cash assistance and $10 billion in loan guarantees last week to avert the threat of immediate bankruptcies.
"This is going to be a long and enduring thing," Mr. O'Neill said. "We may need to come back and look at it again. In the case of the airlines, the direct infusion of cash for liquidity, that's fine, but it may very well be that something else is required."
Mr. O'Neill said helping the airline industry was important because many of the economy's problems were related to the sharp decline in air travel, a problem Mr. Bush sought to address today by announcing new security proposals. 
But Mr. O'Neill said it was also important to address the ways in which the psychological aftershocks from the attacks are damping all kinds of economic activity. And he said Mr. Bush believed that making the economy strong was a critical element in sustaining the campaign against terrorism.
The president has "a strong feeling that a stronger economy makes everything else easier," Mr. O'Neill said. 
The administration and the leaders of the two parties in Congress are hoping to agree on a bipartisan stimulus plan within the next week or two, Congressional aides said today. The White House and Congress have been waiting for more data about the economy's course before moving ahead, but today's report on unemployment claims plus other new figures increased the likelihood that the country is near or in a recession.
The Congressional Budget Office reported today that the federal budget surplus for the year that ends Sunday will be about $121 billion, $32 billion below its estimate of just a month ago. The budget office said the decline stemmed largely from weakness in the economy both before and after the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11.
Lawrence B. Lindsey, Mr. Bush's chief economic adviser, said the White House was still early in the process of settling on specific proposals and did not want to be hasty in developing a plan, especially with the economic outlook still in flux. He declined to identify any specific steps the administration would push for in the stimulus package.
"We've got a pretty good grasp on the fact that action is necessary," Mr. Lindsey said in an interview. "But we don't have a sense yet of all the ramifications."
On Capitol Hill, both parties are floating proposals to help the economy. Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, said today that he would like to see as much as $31 billion in immediate spending increases, including $8 billion to expand the unemployment insurance program and as much as $20 billion to help people who have been laid off keep their health insurance.
With layoffs mounting, pressure is increasing on the administration and Congress to provide help for the unemployed. Congress is already considering a plan that would extend unemployment compensation by up to a year from the current limit of 26 weeks.
In New York State, new claims for unemployment benefits have risen from 12,423 in the seven days ended Sept. 6 to 15,500 in the week ended Sept. 13 to 22,200 in the week ended Sept. 20.
Robert Lillpopp, a spokesman for the New York State Department of Labor, said 10,800 of the new claims in the last two weeks were related to the terrorist attacks. 
Unemployment insurance is financed by a tax on employers, and New York currently has about $1 billion in its fund, Mr. Lillpopp said. He said that amount would be adequate in normal times, but that it was possible the state might need more money if job losses continue to surge.
"We're currently exploring our options with the U.S. Department of Labor," he said. "But at this point we haven't asked for any specific amount of funds."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: REAGAN NATIONAL AIRPORT; 
U.S. Marshals May Be Key To Reopening Of an Airport

BYLINE:  By LIZETTE ALVAREZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 

 BODY:
As pressure builds to reopen Ronald Reagan National Airport, the only airport still out of service, Transportation Secretary Norman Y. Mineta said today that he would back a plan to place federal marshals on every flight using the airport as a requirement to reopen it.
 The decision to close the airport, in suburban Virginia, either temporarily or indefinitely, has battered the area's economy, prompted thousands of layoffs and angered just about every lawmaker on Capitol Hill, most of whom regularly use Reagan National to get home. And while President Bush visited O'Hare International Airport in Chicago today to encourage fearful passengers to fly, many here in Washington wondered why the message did not apply to them and their local airport. 
 They are quick to point out that none of the commandeered jets left from or were scheduled to arrive at Reagan National Airport and that two other airports -- Dulles International and Baltimore-Washington International -- are also within minutes, by air, of Washington. Both are operating without unique restrictions. 
"On the one hand he's telling people to fly, but on the other hand security people are telling him he can't open National Airport because it's not safe," said Representative James P. Moran, a Virginia Democrat whose district is home to the airport. "By the same token, he's saying we need to get back to normalcy and stimulate the economy, and we've closed down an airport that has so far resulted in the loss of 10,000 jobs."
Reagan National, which is across the Potomac River from Washington, was ordered closed, either indefinitely or temporarily, by the National Security Council because it is three miles from the White House.
Today, Mr. Mineta said he would be willing to place armed guards on all flights leaving from or coming to National Airport, if that is what it takes to get it running again. But he was the first to acknowledge that the decision was not his to make.
"I believe it should be reopened," he told Reuters today before he boarded a commercial flight from the Baltimore-Washington airport to join Mr. Bush in Chicago. "We are working on it, but it is in the hands of the National Security Council and the U.S. Secret Service."
Senator Jon Kyl, an Arizona Republican on the Intelligence Committee, agreed that placing armed guards on every flight was a logical step. "It seems to me that National ought to reopen," Mr. Kyl said, noting that increasing security is a "real imposition." But he added, "Why aren't people complaining? Because they can see a real effect."
After more than two weeks of limbo, lawmakers, local officials and the governors of Maryland and Virginia are getting restless. The administration has said little about what it intends to do, only that Mr. Bush is aware of the "harmful impact" the airport's closing is having on the economy, as the White House press secretary, Ari Fleischer, said on Wednesday. But, he added, security concerns remain.
The airport was recently remodeled and generates $5 billion a year in revenue. It normally employs 10,000 workers, but 4,000 of them have now applied for unemployment. US Airways, which operates a New York to Washington shuttle and maintains a hub at Reagan National, has cut 11,000 jobs overall. But the reverberations are being felt in other sectors of the local economy as well, including Washington-area hotels, restaurants, cab drivers and rental car companies.
On Capitol Hill, Mr. Moran, with the backing of a large number of House members, intends to introduce legislation next week to reopen the airport if an administration decision is not imminent. He said he hoped that would increase pressure on the White House. Several lawmakers will be going to the White House next week to discuss the situation.
"National Airport is a symbol of our nation's ability to move freely across this country," said Representative James L. Oberstar, the senior Democrat on the House Transportation Committee. "It if remains closed, the terrorists have won."
In general, lawmakers and local officials agree that security must be significaly heightened at the aiport, more so than at other structures, and they and a number of consultants have offered recommendations. They include placing armed guards on every flight, paying special attention to airports where connecting flights to National are made and expanding the regional airspace security program.
Pilots, for example, would have to identify themselves 20 minutes before landing at the airport, as opposed to just a few minutes. They could also use special codes to verify their identities.
"With those kinds of measures -- costly, time-consuming, disruptive, intrusive -- I think there will be enough confidence in security to allow the reopening of National," Mr. Oberstar said.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: MEXICO; 
Fox Pledges Full Support For the U.S.

BYLINE:  By GINGER THOMPSON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 27 

 BODY:
Abandoning Mexico's history of neutrality in times of violent conflict, President Vicente Fox said today in an interview that Mexico pledged "unconditional support" to the United States in its war against terrorism.
 "We will act in solidarity with all of the nations of the world who have taken on this campaign, particularly the United States," Mr. Fox said. "We understand clearly that we are friends, neighbors and partners. And we are not going to run and hide when our neighbor needs us." 
 The remarks, to a small group of foreign journalists, were aimed at responding to critics who had said Mr. Fox's support for the United States seemed ambiguous and bound by conditions. 
Foreign Minister Jorge G. Castaneda said before Congress on Wednesday that at least 19 Mexicans had been killed in the attack on the World Trade Center, that Mexico's economy would suffer and that Mexico could just as easily be attacked by terrorists unless their organizations were destroyed.
"Even before the second tower fell," Mr. Fox said, "I declared before Mexico and the press how sad and painful the events were for us."
Although Mexico's stand may have more moral than practical significance to the United States, Mr. Fox's statements were his boldest challenge yet to Mexico's constitutional commitment to noninterventionist foreign policies and to finding peaceful solutions to conflict.
His position has fueled anti-American sentiment that political experts say has not only divided Congress, but also Mr. Fox's cabinet.
A few days before the terrorist attacks, Mr. Fox was in Washington as the first state visitor of the Bush administration. At the time, President Bush announced that the United States had no more important relationship than with Mexico.
But the attacks and Mr. Bush's declarations against terrorism have unleashed a resurgence of bad feelings toward the United States that threatens to undermine Mexico's new high-profile status.
Mr. Castaneda, the architect of Mr. Fox's campaign to make Mexico a more active influence in the world, has been scolded in Congress as a traitor. Some legislators called for his resignation.
Carlos Fuentes, the writer who is a former ambassador, said, "We are partners to the United States, but in no way should we be 'yes men' to the United States." He used a derogatory word that also translates as "subjects."
Another renowned author and historian, Enrique Krauze, responded: "Historic disputes do not justify a lack of moral solidarity. I believe President Fox should make a clear gesture of sympathy for the American people."
The government is sharing intelligence every day on Islamic immigrants who have been detained, the president said, adding that border security had been tightened.
"Of course," he added, "there will be voices of dissent. But that doesn't change anything, because we are expressing the voice of Mexican men and women. We do it because we know how they feel and think. And because of that, our path is clear."
