PERSON: A. Joseph Debe 

HEADLINE: A. Joseph Debe, 73, Creator Of Unusual Stock Derivative 

BYLINE:  By ALEX BERENSON 

 BODY:
A. Joseph Debe, who had worked for more than two decades to create a stock derivative that became popular in the late 1980's, died at his home in Garden City, N.Y., on Sunday. He was 73.
 The cause was lung cancer, his daughter Gina O'Sullivan said. 
 Born in Italy on Nov. 16, 1927, Mr. Debe came to the United States in 1934. He spent his childhood in Maine before moving to New York, where he attended Astoria High School. He served in the Navy as a pharmacist's mate for three years, then returned to New York, where he studied economics at City College.
After a number of jobs in the securities industry, Mr. Debe became manager of the $160 million Surveyor mutual fund in 1971. Five years later, he founded the Americus Shareholder Service Corporation to work full time on a plan he had conceived in the late 1960's to create a kind of stock derivative that would help both conservative and aggressive investors.
Shareholders profit from stocks either by cash dividend payments or by the capital gains that result when a stock's price rises. Risk-averse investors prefer the security of dividends, while more aggressive investors like the potential profits that result from big price increases.
Mr. Debe realized he could split a single share into its dividend and capital gains components, creating two separate investments out of one stock. To do so, he formed trusts that issued two securities, the "Prime" and the "Score," on individual stocks like Philip Morris and Merck. The Prime's returns came mainly from dividends, while those of the Scores were generated solely by gains in the underlying stock -- although if the stock did not rise, the Score unit was worthless. Both securities lasted five years from the day a trust was created, and both could be traded on the American Stock Exchange.
Mr. Debe worked for more than a decade before winning approval from the Internal Revenue Service for a full-scale introduction of the new securities. "He worked on it for a long time," said Barbara Mehringer, his assistant of 30 years. "He was a very patient, very persevering person, and determined."
When Primes and Scores were introduced in 1987, they proved extremely popular, accounting on some days for more than 10 percent of the trading volume of the exchange. But after Americus had issued 27 of the trusts, the I.R.S. dealt Mr. Debe a heavy blow, ruling that the trusts would be subject to unfavorable tax treatment. The ruling effectively meant that Americus could not create more trusts.
The ruling left Mr. Debe very disappointed, Ms. Mehringer said. But he did not give up, working until his death on other ways to recreate his idea.
In addition to his daughter Gina, Mr. Debe is survived by three other daughters, Dawn Crociani, Karen Cosme and Joanne Hibner; two sons, Joseph and Peter; and 16 grandchildren.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS AND BONDS; 
Stocks End The Week On an Uptick

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL BRICK 

 BODY:
A strong week eased the pain for investors only slightly as the stock market ended its worst quarter since the crash of 1987. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average rose 166.14 points, or 1.9 percent, yesterday, ending a week of recovery in which the index gained 7.4 percent for its best week since 1984. 
 But that gain erased less than half the loss recorded by the stock market in the previous week, when trading resumed after the World Trade Center attacks. The third quarter ended with the Dow down 15.8 percent, its worst showing since it lost a quarter of its value in the last three months of 1987. 
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 15 percent for the quarter, also the biggest drop since 1987. The Nasdaq composite fell 30.65 percent, slightly ahead of its dismal performance in the fourth quarter of 2000, when it skidded 32.7 percent.
As the third quarter began, investors were hoping for a quick end to the economic slowdown, and stocks had managed decent gains in the second quarter despite a long list of earnings warnings. But as the quarter progressed, it became clear that the economy was weakening further. And then came Sept. 11.
"Three months ago, the market was discounting some kind of slowdown," said Peter I. Cardillo, the chief strategist for Westfalia Investments. "The end of the quarter turned into a fiasco of a totally different nature, and that is the unknown."
Before the terrorist attacks, investors were uneasy. Aware that corporate profits might not improve soon, they were focusing on consumers, whose spending seemed to be steadying the economy even as companies halted capital spending. The Federal Reserve had already reduced interest rates six times, for a total of 2.25 percentage points, encouraging consumers to refinance their mortgages at lower rates and putting more money in their pockets.
But the corporate outlook continued to worsen as company projection after company projection disappointed investors. By August, the prospect of an overall recession, not just in the manufacturing sector, had crept into the minds of once-optimistic investors. Consumer confidence and retailers' reports reinforced the idea that the last support of the economy was slipping.
From the end of June through Sept. 10, the Dow fell 8.5 percent and the Nasdaq composite index fell 21.5 percent. Then came the attacks. Consumers retreated even further in their spending habits, and recession seemed unavoidable.
When trading resumed on Monday, Sept. 17, stocks plunged even though the Federal Reserve cut rates another half a point. The Dow fell 14.3 percent, its steepest one-week slide since the Great Depression.
Yesterday, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 166.14 points, to close at 8,847.21. Though bad, its decline of 15.8 percent for the quarter pales against its drop at the end of 1987. After Black Monday in October of that year, the Dow ended the quarter down 25.3 percent. 
On the final day of the quarter, all the major indexes rose. The Nasdaq gained 38.09 points, or 2.6 percent, to 1,498.80. It had a gain of 5.31 percent for the week. The S.& P. 500-stock index rose 22.33 points, or 2.2 percent, to 1,040.94. Its weekly gain was 7.78 percent.
Some of the week's move seemed to reflect a belief that last week's decline had simply been overdone in panic. Investors concluded that some shares were beginning to look like bargains. They eased back into the market, despite the uncertainty about the economy and further military action.
Owen Fitzpatrick, managing director of Deutsche Bank Private Bank, tentatively called the week of declines an overreaction.
Robert D. Hormats, vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International, said that investors were somewhat encouraged by the interest rate reductions and the government's plan to stimulate the economy by spending, like the bailout of the airline industry and the immediate relief efforts. "The market is now beginning to look down the road and say to itself, those two measures will lead to recovery some time next year," he said.
The short-term picture looks sharply worse, however. Corporations have only begun to assess the damage to their finances from the attacks and the abrupt economic shock. They have issued 152 profit warnings since Sept. 11, according to Thomson Financial/First Call, for a total of 573 warnings on the quarter. The record, says the research firm, was 655 in the first quarter.
Stock analysts are just beginning to sort out the financial impact. Three months ago, they predicted that the companies of the S.& P. 500 would produce $13.82 a share in operating profits in the third quarter, and they have since lowered their forecast to $10.42. In all, analysts now expect profits to decline 19.4 percent from a year ago, far more than the 6.2 percent drop projected as the quarter began.
The industries with the worst performing stocks for the quarter were the automakers, semiconductor companies and airlines.
Even though the government announced a large cash infusion for the airline industry, its ability to recover to profitability is much in doubt, with traffic off sharply and many costs rising. American Airlines, a unit of AMR, and United Airlines, a unit of UAL, each fell from above $30 a share to below $20 during the quarter. The worst performers on the New York Stock Exchange included the U S Airways Group and America West Holdings, both of which fell more than 80 percent. 
Oil and gas drilling companies and entertainment companies also suffered.
The few bright spots included electronic military gear, metal and glass container makers and gold producers. 
Of course when stocks fall, investors look for havens. Bond prices, which had been stubbornly low, began to rise because of heightened demand. The yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell on the two-year note to its lowest level in decades.

HEADLINE: At Home Files for Bankruptcy; Will Sella Unit 

BYLINE:  By MATT RICHTEL 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 28 

 BODY:
The At Home Corporation, a once-mighty Internet portal turned high-speed access provider, filed for bankruptcy protection today, a victim of shrinking online advertising revenue and the collapse of the dot-com bubble. 
 The company, which does business as Excite@Home, said that it intended to sell its broadband business to AT&T, which now owns a 23 percent stake and a controlling interest in Excite@Home, for $307 million, pending court approval. The broadband business serves about 3.7 million customers nationwide and would continue to operate during the bankruptcy process, the company said. 
 The bankruptcy comes as little surprise, given that investors have put increasing, and public, pressure on the company, which is based in Redwood City, Calif. Still, it represents a downfall of a company that was one of the marquee brand names of the highflying dot-com era; for many months, it was among the top three most visited Internet portals.
Excite@Home officials could not be reached for comment about the bankruptcy. In a statement, Patti Hart, Excite@Home's chief executive, said the Chapter 11 filing would let the company "protect the value of the broadband business for the benefit of the company's financial stakeholders" 
She said the plan also "will help reassure our customers that service will continue uninterrupted through the restructuring process."
It is unclear what will happen to the service when, and if, a deal is completed and approved to sell the broadband assets to AT&T.
In recent weeks, however, several big-name cable providers, including AT&T Broadband and Cox Communications, that offer customers the Excite@Home broadband service, said they intended to continue service uninterrupted should Excite@Home declare bankruptcy.
In April, Ms. Hart was hired by Excite@Home and charged with finding a way to make the business work with dwindling cash reserves and a fading advertising market.
She later said that while she expected a challenge, she discovered that the situation was dissipating much more quickly than she anticipated.
The company announced in June that it had raised at least $100 million in additional emergency financing. But in July, it announced that its quarterly losses were $346.3 million and that it required additional financing. Just the opposite happened: some investors began asking for their money back.
In August, Ernst & Young, the company's independent auditors, concluded in a report that it had "substantial doubt" about Excite@Home's long-term viability. Shortly thereafter, creditors who had lent Excite the $100 million two months earlier demanded half of the money back immediately, asserting that they had not been fully apprised of the seriousness of the company's financial straits. 
Excite@Home said it had retained Houlihan Lokey Howard & Zukin Capital to help in continuing the bidding process for its assets. It will consider other bidders besides AT&T for its broadband service. The company said it had "sufficient cash on hand" to finance its operations during the bankruptcy process.
At least one industry analyst has said that Excite@Home suffered not merely because of the advertising market but because officials bet that the cable access business would grow much more quickly than it had.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE WORKERS; 
Northwest and American To Pay Severance Benefits

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
American Airlines and Northwest Airlines, facing the anger of their employees, have dropped plans to deny severance benefits to thousands of workers that they plan to lay off in their post-Sept. 11 slump.
 The two airlines originally invoked an emergency clause in their union contracts in refusing to pay severance benefits. After their labor unions protested that other airlines were making such payments -- and threatened to lobby Congress to deny bailout funds to any airline that failed to -- American and Northwest changed course. 
 Northwest said it would provide one week to six weeks' pay to laid-off workers, while American did not spell out how much assistance it would offer. 
"This is something we have wanted to do but weren't sure we would be able to provide, given our changing circumstances and the devastating impact of the terrorist attacks on our industry and our company," Donald J. Carty, American's chief executive, said in a written statement. American's change of heart was first reported yesterday in The Los Angeles Times.
The airline industry has plunged into crisis since the terrorist attacks. Passenger loads have dropped 50 percent, and airlines have maneuvered to cut costs sharply, announcing plans to eliminate nearly 100,000 jobs. 
But airline and union officials said yesterday that the number of layoffs would be considerably less than 100,000, largely because thousands of employees were taking voluntary furloughs. In addition, encouraged by some new incentives, more than 1,000 airline workers are expected to take early retirement, while hundreds of pilots plan to go temporarily into the Air National Guard or the Air Force Reserve, further reducing the need for layoffs.
Northwest Airlines originally announced that it would lay off 2,800 flight attendants, but because of a furlough program negotiated with the union, 2,500 Northwest attendants chose to take voluntary furloughs. With such furloughs, most of them five months long, Northwest's flight attendants will receive unemployment insurance payments, while retaining their health benefits and travel privileges. 
Union officials acknowledged that fear of flying was a factor in some flight attendants' decisions to accept a voluntary furlough.
"A lot of them were scared," said one union official who insisted on anonymity. But many airline officials said that at most several dozen flight attendants had resigned outright because they were afraid to fly after the hijacking of the planes.
The wave of airline job cuts has increased pressure on Congress to provide extended unemployment insurance to airline workers who lose their jobs and to have the federal government reimburse them for 18 months of health insurance coverage. Union officials and Democratic lawmakers voiced confidence yesterday that Congress would take up such measures next week, attaching them to White House-backed legislation to enhance airport security. 
Last week, Congress approved $5 billion in cash assistance and $10 billion in loan guarantees for the airlines. "We should also be helping the thousands of airline employees and their families who are hurting," Senator Tom Daschle, Democrat of South Dakota, the majority leader, said yesterday.
Ari Fleischer, the White House spokesman, said yesterday that the Bush administration opposed tying help for airline workers to the security package. Instead, he said, it should be considered as part of an economic stimulus package.
Union officials remained dissatisfied yesterday with the severance benefits being offered by American and Northwest.
"It's substantially less than what the contract offers," said Robert De Pace, the chairman of the machinists' union at Northwest. "But every little bit helps."
Last week, Northwest announced that it would eliminate 10,000 positions, but in recent days Northwest management said that voluntary leaves and attrition would reduce the layoff total to no more than 6,500 workers. 
"I have to acknowledge that the company has gone out of its way to work with this union to reduce the number of involuntary layoffs," said Danny Campbell, president of the Teamsters union local that represents Northwest's flight attendants.
Continental Airlines said that it would need to make 1,000 fewer layoffs than the 12,000 it initially announced, because that many workers had agreed to take one-year leaves of absence.
Airline executives have sought to share some of the pain by taking pay cuts, and yesterday the top officials of United Airlines and US Airways said they would join top officials at American, Delta and Continental in forgoing pay for the rest of the year.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
American and Northwest To Pay Severance Benefits
American Airlines and Northwest Airlines, facing the anger of their employees, have dropped plans to deny severance benefits to thousands of workers that they plan to lay off in their post-Sept. 11 slump.
 The airlines had invoked an emergency clause in their union contracts in refusing to pay severance benefits. After the unions protested and threatened to ask Congress to deny bailout funds to any airline that failed to pay severance, they changed course. Page C3. 

Huge Losses for Airport Retailers
Retail businesses at the nation's airports, which have expanded greatly in the last few years, are experiencing huge losses because of the decline in travel. C3.

United Airlines will cut the total number of passengers it can fly by six percentage points more than it had previously indicated. C3.

Growth in Second Quarter
Gross domestic product expanded at a 0.3 percent annual rate from April through June, government figures showed, revised from an earlier estimate of 0.2 percent. Second-quarter growth was the weakest since G.D.P. contracted in the first quarter of 1993. Separately, the University of Michigan's index of consumer sentiment fell to 81.8, the weakest since November 1993, from 91.5 in August. C2.

AT&T and Comcast Sign Agreement
AT&T and Comcast signed a confidentiality agreement that could pave the way for negotiations on Comcast's $37 billion offer to acquire AT&T Broadband. Final details were not immediately known, but in a statement, Comcast said it was restricted from holding certain discussions with third parties relating to AT&T Broadband without AT&T's approval. C4.

Bank of New York Profit Shortfall
The Bank of New York, which had many offices, including its headquarters, in Lower Manhattan, said the Sept. 11 attack would cost it $125 million, or 17 cents a share, in the third quarter. Still, it expects to get most of that back from its insurance policies. C3.

Japanese Banks Have Record Losses
With the first half of Japan's fiscal year ending on Sunday, financial institutions are recording major losses. The finance minister, Heizo Takenaka, said the losses show the banks are finally coming to terms with their problems, and he gave no sign that the government was considering a bailout. "This indicates they are writing off their nonperforming loans -- in a sense this is a good sign," he said. C2.

Daunting Lines Form at Airports
More rigorous screening procedures and an increase in business and leisure travelers have produced daunting lines at airports around the country in the last two days. Much of the delays were caused when the Federal Aviation Administration ordered more thorough examination of laptop computers and other carry-on luggage. A1.

South Korean Production Climbs
South Korea's industrial production unexpectedly rose 4.5 percent in August from July, after four months of declines. Sales of cars produced by Hyundai Motor were one reason for the upturn. Analysts had expected a drop of at least 0.5 percent in production. C2.

Hawaii's Lifeblood Slows to a Trickle
Never have the prospects for Hawaii's tourism-dependent economy plunged as low -- or as quickly -- as in the days since Sept. 11. The famed beaches are mostly deserted. Most hotels are less than half full. Restaurants open late and close early, if they open at all. Taxis and tour buses are empty. Entertainers have canceled shows. About the only busy place, it seems, is the unemployment office. B1.

On Intifada's Anniversary, A Surge of Deadly Violence
Three Palestinians were killed and 80 others were wounded, most of them by bullets, after Israeli troops opened fire on Palestinians demonstrating, throwing stones and, at times, shooting on the first anniversary of their renewed intifada, or uprising. The fighting came despite a 10-day-old truce between Palestinians and Israeli forces, which remained officially in effect. A5

More Charges for Milosevic
A second indictment was issued against Slobodan Milosevic, the former Yugoslav president who is awaiting trial at The Hague on charges of war crimes in Kosovo. The additional chargesof war crimes in Croatia considerably broaden the case against him, tribunal officials said. A3

China Frees American
China has released Wu Jianmin, a freelance journalist who is a Chinese-born American citizen, after detaining him for almost six months on charges of spying for Taiwan, a United States Embassy official said. Mr. Wu is one of a handful of American citizens and permanent residents detained earlier this year by China's security forces. A4

Italian Conflict of Interest
Parliamentary leaders from Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi's coalition decided to appoint the members of a watchdog group that will monitor the actions of the news media outlets and other companies he owns, in order to address possible conflicts of interest.The watchdog group will then report back to Parliament, a plan criticized by the political opposition as further proof of the problem. A5

Swaziland's New AIDS Policy
The king of the tiny, AIDS-afflicted African country has told the country's young women that they are to stop having sex for the next five years, and wherever they go, Swazi girls now will be expected to wear a bundle of bright traditional tassels, signifying celibacy. Breaking the ban could cost each offender a cow, the country's true currency. A5

Spending Deal Reached For Defense and Education
The White House and Congressional leaders of both parties have agreed to provide the full increase President Bush had sought for defense spending before the terrorist attacks and to allocate more money to education, officials said. The deal would push spending for the coming fiscal year $25 billion above what Mr. Bush had originally requested. A6

Early Results on Drug Law
Defendants sentenced under California's Proposition 36, a three-month-old law that mandates treatment instead of prison for first- and second-time offenders who use or possess drugs, have had far more serious addictions than anyone expected, and many of them did not finish their treatment. Yet supporters say the basic goal -- to offer treatment rather than incarceration -- is being met and the prison population has dropped. A6

New ID's for Border Crossing
The immigration service has yet to install machines to read identification cards that will be required starting Monday for Mexicans routinely entering the United States. The agency said it does not have the money to buy the machines. A7

R.O.T.C.'s Renewed Purpose
The war on terrorism has given R.O.T.C. recruiters fresh material for their pitches and cadets a visible expression of respect. "Before, no one paid attention to us," said one cadet, Cesar Feliciano. "Now I get the waves and the high-five's and the 'we're with you's.' " A7

HEADLINE: Beliefs; 
Amid Islam's complexity, scholars are challenged to influence change without compromising.

BYLINE:  By Peter Steinfels 

 BODY:
Authentic Islam, the world has been told repeatedly in recent days, condemns terrorism, rejects violence against innocent civilians and advocates peace. The message has come from many of the highest Muslim religious authorities, from American Muslim organizations, from the pope, from the president and from many others. 
 Obviously, the message is welcome. It accurately reflects the view of millions of Muslims appalled by the carnage of Sept. 11, and especially of Muslims who have crossed oceans to begin new lives with their families in the United States. It counters stereotypes and forestalls vengeful and senseless attacks against Muslims. 
 But without in any way questioning the value or sincerity of these statements, many people want to know whether these condemnations, voiced to non-Muslim audiences at a moment of crisis, are consistently and systematically communicated to primarily Muslim populations.
And well beyond the denunciation of atrocities, there is a further question. Are there significant networks of Muslim scholars and intellectuals striving to articulate a genuinely Islamic vision that would embrace individual freedom, political democracy, pluralism, equal rights for minorities and women and other values that have emerged as the better part of modern civilization?
The question is important because it is an illusion to think that there is simply an authentic Islam and then a fringe group of inauthentic Muslims. What is authentic or inauthentic in Islam is contested, as it is in Christianity, Judaism and most other religious traditions. 
It takes only the slightest knowledge to recognize how incredibly diverse and complex Islam is, and if Osama bin Laden's network is only a tiny group at the end of a spectrum, at many other points on that spectrum there are Muslims closer to his worldview than to the West's. 
If that is going to change, the change must almost certainly come from within Islam itself. Westernized secular intellectuals remain significant in the Muslim world, but it is not too much to say that their day passed several decades ago. Sacralization, not secularization, is the wave of the future. 
That future is largely in the hands of religious thinkers. "The scholars are the heirs of the prophets," Muhammad is held to have declared. 
Unfortunately, the official class of religious teachers in many parts of the Muslim world has long appeared intellectually calcified and co-opted by governments. That opened the way for a new breed of religious intellectuals, in many cases the anti-Western, antiliberal theorists or ideologues of militant movements. 
Of course, their successes did not rest on intellectual efforts alone but also on the festering resentments in the Muslim world over centuries of economic and cultural decline, colonization, material inequities, local corruption and despotism, the seemingly intractable conflict between Israelis and Palestinians and all the other factors that serious thinking about combating terrorism must eventually confront. 
Meanwhile, are there counterparts to those extremist ideologues? Are there Muslim thinkers and scholars immersed in their faith, sensitive to the frustrations and resentments of the Muslim world, and yet appreciative of Western liberties not as an affront but as a stimulus to re-examine the riches of Islam and determine what can and cannot be affirmed with full religious integrity? 
Some individual Muslim thinkers come to mind immediately, not only academics but also two political leaders recently removed from power: Anwar Ibrahim, the deputy prime minister of Malaysia, jailed on politically inspired grounds in 1998, and Abdurrahman Wahid, the liberal leader of a large traditionalist movement in Indonesia whose personal eccentricities led to his removal from that nation's presidency.
But beyond such prominent figures, is there anything resembling a network or movement of such people who, without agreeing on everything, know one another, share the same podiums, write for similar journals -- and can get a hearing in the heartlands of Islam? 
"My immediate answer is yes, absolutely," said Azza Karam, one of a half-dozen scholars of Islam or Islamic politics who were asked that question this week. The others, in varying degrees, agreed. 
But Dr. Karam, director of the Women's Program at Religions for Peace, was swift to outline the obstacles such thinkers face. Attacked as compromisers by both militant Islamists and "secularists who don't wish to have anything to do with religious language," bridge-building religious thinkers are also discredited, she said, by governments that affirm some version of moderate Islamic principles but go on practicing the usual manipulations of power. 
Concretely, who might be seen as part of a network of Muslim thinkers engaged in dialogue with liberal values? Asked to name some representative individuals, these half-dozen experts offered lists that varied a good deal. Some reached further into the ranks of moderate Islamists whose attitudes toward the West, democracy and giving Islamic law a dominant role in Muslim societies others would find questionable. Some bristled at names that others mentioned, a reminder that creating circles of intellectuals is often more delicate than brain surgery. 
Azizah Yahia al-Hibri, professor of law at the University of Richmond, was the most concrete, pointing to a double issue of the Journal of Law and Religion that she has edited. Scheduled for publication next week, it has more than 600 pages of articles and reviews meant "to further Islamic thought and dialogue in the U.S. and around the world." 
Professor al-Hibri insisted that her experiences lecturing in Islamic countries on topics like democracy and the role of women -- and meeting with legislators and mullahs -- showed that advocacy of change could get a hearing if it was "honestly related" to the Koran and the hadith, the sayings of Muhammad. 
What can be done to encourage a network of Muslim thinkers -- without compromising them? American Muslim organizations might play an important role, as might private foundations and academic centers. 
An enterprise like this, although it cannot be directly part of a struggle against terrorism, is surely not irrelevant to the outcome.

HEADLINE: World Business Briefing Americas: Brazil: Growth Forecast Lowered 

BYLINE:  By Jennifer L. Rich (NYT) 

 BODY:
 Reflecting higher local interest rates and a worsening global economic picture after terrorist attacks on the United States, Brazil's central bank lowered the country's economic growth forecast to 2 percent from 2.8 percent for 2001. 
Fears of a recession were reduced, however, after the government revised the second-quarter gross domestic product up to 1.82 percent from a previously announced growth rate of 0.79 percent. Analysts say that lower economic growth will help keep a lid on inflation, which is already expected to exceed the central bank's goal of 6 percent this year. The government forecasts inflation of 6.5 percent. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

HEADLINE: Sales of New Municipal Bonds Up 37% 

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Municipal bond issuance rose 37 percent in the third quarter, as falling interest rates encouraged states, cities and other governments to refinance, Thomson Financial Securities Data said yesterday.
 Sales of new municipal bonds rose to $191 billion in the quarter from $139 billion a year earlier, Thomson Financial said. 
Bonds sold to pay off debt that carried higher interest rates more than doubled, to $62 billion. 
 Interest rates tumbled in the last 12 months as the economy slowed and the Federal Reserve reduced short-term rates eight times. Yields on the benchmark 10-year Treasury note sank 1.2 percentage points.
Municipal bonds issued for refinancing accounted for 32 percent of the total in the quarter, up from 18 percent a year earlier. The figures excluded short-term securities and private placements. 
The Sept. 11 terrorist attacks may have limited sales during the last two weeks. Municipalities are still likely to sell a record $300 billion of bonds this year, said Curt Hagfeldt, head of municipal bond underwriting, sales and trading at Banc of America Securities in San Francisco.
Yields on tax-exempt municipal bonds have fallen up to two percentage points from a year ago, but Mr. Hagfeldt said returns are still attractive compared with Treasury securities.
Municipal bond mutual funds grew to $299.7 billion in August, a rise of 2.5 percent from July, fed by the largest increase in investment since 1994, according to the Investment Company Institute, the fund industry's trade group.

HEADLINE: Scholars Divided on Giuliani Bid 

BYLINE:  By EMILY EAKIN

 BODY:
Politicians have responded in different ways to an adoring public. Julius Caesar declined attempts by his constituents to have him wear a crown, explaining, "Non rex sum sed Caesar" -- "I am not a king but Caesar." (Though in the end, his closest advisers got him out of office by stabbing him.) And George Washington refused to give in to public desire to keep him permanently in the presidency, stepping down at the end of his second term.
 But Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who has seen his approval ratings soar since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, opted for a another kind of response this week when he proposed extending his term in office by at least three months. 
 While the three candidates to succeed him as mayor scrambled to find a politically palatable response to the announcement, experts on American history, election law and New York City politics debated the merits of such a move and searched for historical precedents. An informal sounding of scholarly opinion yesterday revealed an academic community divided over whether the mayor's proposal, which was approved by two of the three mayoral candidates, amounted to an unacceptable breach of democratic tradition or a welcome, even necessary, response to a difficult time for the city.
"Though historians are very reluctant to say never, I can't think of a single historical precedent," said Eric Foner, a professor of history at Columbia University. "In times of crisis, we have always had transitions from one elected leader to another one and from one party to another." Mr. Foner cited several examples from American political history, including the presidential elections of 1864, during the Civil War, in which Lincoln was re-elected; of 1952, during the Korean War, in which Dwight D. Eisenhower was elected to succeed Harry S. Truman.
"I can't think of any time at which an outgoing official suggested he ought to stay on because he's indispensable," Mr. Foner said. "Our political system has gone through many political shocks and survived them." Ester Fuchs, a professor of political science and public policy at Barnard College and Columbia University and the author of "Mayors and Money: Fiscal Policy in New York and Chicago," agreed, arguing that New York City has weathered extraordinary circumstances in the past without tampering with its electoral laws or extending the terms of its political leaders.
In 1932 during the Depression and again in 1975, Ms. Fuchs said, the city faced debilitating fiscal crises, and in both cases, elected officials carried out their duties normally. The 1975 case, she said, was particularly instructive. Mayor Abraham Beame, she said, "restructured the city's debt and governance." Moreover, she stressed that unlike Mr. Giuliani, who has been able to rely on support from the federal government to pay for rescue and recovery operations at the World Trade Center, Mr. Beame was largely on his own. (Remember the front page of The Daily News summing up the White House's response: "Ford to City: Drop Dead." The government eventually did offer a loan guarantee.)
"People were satisfied with how Mr. Beame handled the crisis, no question," Ms. Fuchs said. But that did not mean they wanted to keep him on as mayor: he lost the 1977 election to Edward I. Koch. "Today we have the support of the nation and the state," Ms. Fuchs said. "We have a much broader resource network to get us through this than we did either in 1975 or in 1932."
But that network of financial resources is precisely what makes Mayor Giuliani indispensable to the city right now, said Fred Siegel, a professor of urban history at Cooper Union in Manhattan. "For our recovery, we need federal money, and the key to getting it and using it expeditiously is Giuliani," Mr. Siegel said. "We have many businesses on the verge of failure, not just in lower Manhattan but across the city. It's in our interests as a city to get those sluice gates open and get the money flowing, and Giuliani has those mechanisms at his disposal. There's no learning curve."
Even if a majority of New Yorkers supported such a move, extending Mayor Giuliani's term would require new legislation. Some scholars, including Laurence H. Tribe, an expert in constitutional law at Harvard University, said that there were no insurmountable legal obstacles to keep Mr. Giuliani from staying on. "Democracy has some play in its joints," Mr. Tribe said. "If he were looking for some underhanded or tricky way of extending his term, that would be disturbing. It's a matter of taking advantage of and acting in light of the fact that he is so widely valued in maintaining calm and order in the city in a time of terror."
But other scholars said the legal precedents were not encouraging. Some cited the unsuccessful attempt by President Franklin Delano Roosevelt to stack a hostile Supreme Court with justices favorable to his New Deal policies. In 1937, at the beginning of his second term, he proposed legislation to add as many as six justices to the court. The proposal, labeled court-packing by opponents, was even denounced by Roosevelt's supporters.
"The main point is that it was defeated," Mr. Foner said. "And this was right after F. D. R. won re-election. He was, like Giuliani, at the height of his popularity. Congress didn't pass the law for the basic reason that you don't change democratic process to accommodate a particular view or outcome."
Richard Briffault, a law professor at Columbia University and an expert on election law and local government, offered another analogy. Until the Depression, he said, the official start of term for the president of the United States was March 4. But after Roosevelt's election in November 1932, a Constitutional amendment was passed, making the date Jan. 20, partly, Mr. Briffault said, because "people were troubled by the fact that Hoover remained in office five months after being soundly defeated." But the amendment did not go into effect until after Roosevelt's re-election four years later.
"In general, people are critical of rewriting the rules in the middle of a process," Mr. Briffault said. "You're usually able to write rules for the future, not for the present."
Sean Wilentz, a professor of history at Princeton University, said that he was not in principle opposed to the idea of Mr. Giuliani's remaining in office for a few months, but he joked that he had a better idea for how to use the mayor's time. "Giuliani should step down and they should make him ruler of Afghanistan," Mr. Wilentz said. "He'll need a job, and, God willing, the job will soon be open. He'll bring law and order to the people. If he can make it happen in New York, he can make it happen anywhere."

HEADLINE: China Frees U.S. Citizen Held Since April on Spy Charges 

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL

DATELINE: BEIJING, Sept. 28 

 BODY:
China has released a Chinese-born American citizen who has been detained for almost six months on charges of spying for Taiwan, a United States Embassy official here said tonight. 
 Wu Jianmin, a freelance journalist with a United States passport, was released in the southern city of Guangzhou this morning and has already left China, the official said. Mr. Wu was detained on April 8 at a border crossing between Hong Kong and the mainland. 
 Mr. Wu is one of a handful of American citizens and permanent residents detained earlier this year by China's security forces. The detentions prompted the State Department to issue a highly unusual announcement, warning Chinese-born Americans that they could be at risk of arrest if they traveled to China.
But these high-profile detention cases have become a liability in the last few months as President Bush and his Chinese counterpart, Jiang Zemin, have sought to promote friendlier relations. 
One by one the cases have been resolved by the Chinese. Two academics, Li Shaomin and Gao Zhan, were sent home this summer after being convicted on espionage charges that both have since adamantly denied.
With Mr. Bush scheduled to meet Mr. Jiang for the first time three weeks from now, at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation group's summit meeting in Shanghai, lawyers and diplomats had been expecting more releases.
"I think this is because of the forthcoming presidential visit -- and we just had a visit to Washington by the Chinese foreign minister," said Jerome Cohen, a New York-based lawyer who has served as a consultant on several of the cases. "The State Department has made clear to the Chinese that there are these remaining cases that ought to be resolved."
Although United States Embassy officials here said they were unclear about the terms of Mr. Wu's release, others familiar with the case said he had been expelled from China after he had supposedly "confessed" to improper activities, but was never indicted or convicted. 
Mr. Wu, 46, a former journalist and instructor at the Communist Party School, left China in 1988 and wrote a book about the 1989 prodemocracy student protests in Tiananmen Square. 
Information about him is scant because his family has not mounted a public campaign for his release. Human rights groups have said he lives in New York, although the American Embassy here has previously identified him as "based in Hong Kong."
Several cases involving American citizens or permanent residents remain. 
Fuming Fong, a 66-year-old naturalized citizen from West Orange, N.J., has been held for 18 months by China's security apparatus on suspicion of gathering state secrets, although he has never been formally charged, in violation of China's legal code. Mr. Fong, who for most of his detention has been denied access to his glasses and hearing aid as well as medicine they have sent him, is accused of gathering technical documents about Chinese power projects.
A second American resident, Liu Yaping from Connecticut, has been detained since early March in Hohhut, the capital of Inner Mongolia. Charged only with minor economic crimes, Mr. Liu was held for months at a military detention center. 
While in prison, he developed symptoms of a previously undiagnosed brain aneurysm. Seven weeks ago, he was transferred to a local hospital with the understanding that he would soon be released. But since then he has received no treatment for what doctors say is a potentially life-threatening condition and is effectively a prisoner in the hospital under 24 hours police guard, said his wife.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: NEW YORK OVERVIEW; 
City to Sell Debt as It Waits For Promised Federal Billions

BYLINE:  By LESLIE EATON

 BODY:
As Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said it could take a year to clear the site of the World Trade Center, the city prepared yesterday to sell $1 billion of debt on Tuesday to tide it over until the promised federal aid for the cleanup materializes.
 The need for the money was underscored by a daunting series of statistics reeled off by the mayor at his morning news conference: 1,131 families of the victims visited the city's aid center on Wednesday; 4,620 missing people are listed at the center and 5,960 are listed at the Police Department, which is checking its roster for duplications; 565 applications for death certificates have been filed; 133,024 tons of rubble and debris have so far been removed in 8,977 truckloads. 
 Traffic seemed to be moving fairly smoothly yesterday, the first regular workday morning on which new regulations forbade lone-occupant cars from entering Manhattan below 62nd Street. The new rules, in effect from 6 a.m. to noon, were imposed Tuesday when city streets and river crossings were clogged, before the relative quiet of the Yom Kippur holiday Thursday. Subways and buses were not overwhelmed by car-deprived commuters. 
Across the city, however, government officials, economists, labor unions, business people and other New Yorkers continued to grapple with the the Sept. 11 disaster. Several bomb scares were reported, including one that forced the evacuation of the Empire State Building. 
On the economic front, a labor group forecast that workers whose jobs were affected by the collapse could lose annual wages totaling $6.7 billion, while their employers' lost revenue could total almost $17 billion over the course of a year.
The report, prepared by the Fiscal Policy Institute for the Central Labor Council of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., is one of the first efforts to quantify the economic effects of the attack. On Tuesday, government officials said that about 112,500 people were likely to apply for unemployment benefits because of the disaster.
The Fiscal Policy Institute report estimates that 65,000 jobs were directly affected by the collapse and 43,000 were affected by its spillover. Though some of these jobs simply moved out of the city, some may be gone for good, said James Parrot, the group's chief economist.
The job losses reach from Wall Street (12,200), to stores (12,200), to restaurants (11,900), to Broadway (7,800). About 5,300 of the city's 54,000 air transport jobs and 2,700 jobs in advertising may disappear.
Despite the uncertainty of the city's economic future, the note issue to finance the recovery effort "is expected to be very well received in the market," said Adam L. Barsky, director of the city's Office of Management and Budget. The money will be used to pay for things like overtime for city workers and lump-sum death benefits. 
Details of the note issue will be advertised over the weekend, he said, and individual investors will be able to place orders on Monday. The sale will be conducted by the New York City Transitional Finance Authority, which has permission from the State Legislature to raise as much as $2.5 billion for the trade center effort.
Standard & Poor's said that while the city would not update its budget plan until November, the notes were not risky investments. If the federal aid does not appear within a year, the city can refinance the notes with long-term bonds, which would be backed by income tax receipts.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE PACIFIC; 
Indonesia Radicals Issue Threats of Holy War

BYLINE:  By SETH MYDANS

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 28 

 BODY:
Holy war against America could be tough for Usmady Arafat, one of the angry young would-be warriors who marched through the rain here today with masks and headbands chanting, "Go to hell America."
 His girlfriend is an American who lives in New York. 
 "I was so sad when I heard from her about the attack on the World Trade Center," Mr. Arafat, 28, an unemployed tour guide, said. "My heart goes: 'Oh my God, who attacked that building? If I knew who did it, I would kill him.' " 
A young man named Rahmat, who went to high school in Oklahoma and rather liked the place, was also of two minds about holy war. "America is not bad," he said as he filled out a recruiting form in a small office here. "It's pretty nice."
Since the attacks on Sept. 11, radical Islamic fringe groups here among the 210 million people of largely Muslim Indonesia have been threatening holy war against the United States and against Americans who live here. Their appeals to Muslim solidarity have fired hundreds of young men with a passion to fight to defend Afghanistan, many of them unemployed and aimless in the broken economy.
The United States Embassy said today that gangs of young men had begun carrying out what they call sweeps in several cities, looking for Americans to expel. The embassy said Americans and American interests had been threatened. 
It is also true that Indonesia and the United States are connected by a web of personal and professional ties and that many Indonesians seem to feel affection for America.
Mr. Rahmat, an unemployed college dropout at 26, in fact asked a reporter to take him to America. "I want to see Michael Jordan," he said. In the next breath, he voiced readiness to die to defend his Muslim brothers in Afghanistan. Next, it was back to the good America as he said, "I hope America continues to be a superpower and maintain good relations with other countries in the world."
Organizers here at the main office of a radical group, the Islamic Youth Movement, conceded that they needed to do extensive weeding of applicants before anyone really became a holy warrior. Many of the volunteers sign up on the spur of the moment and quickly lose enthusiasm, said Muhammad Iqbal Siregar, leader of the Jakarta branch of the movement.
Some Islamic scholars here question whether anyone at all will end up going to Afghanistan. Al Chaidar, a researcher at the University of Indonesia and a member of a militant Islamic group, said thousands of Indonesians did join the war against Russia in Afghanistan a decade ago. He said some groups here were in contact with the organization of Osama bin Laden, cited by the United States for the attacks this month.
The Islamic Youth Movement office was decorated with portraits of Mr. bin Laden, and when Mr. Siregar passed by there were whispers, "He has actually met bin Laden." His organization says it has registered hundreds of volunteers, but there was no way to verify the numbers.
Despite the naivete of some recruits, the older men at the headquarters seemed hard and serious.
"As human beings, we are very, very sad about the deaths at the World Trade Center," said Mr. Siregar. "But we must take the analysis farther. Whatever happened was the result of American policy that oppresses Muslims. This shows that arrogance will be punished wherever it is. Now America is confused, panicked, broken inside."
Muhammad Naufal Dunggio, a researcher at an Islamic university who leads an allied radical group, said he, too, had studied in the United States and had not liked it.
"I lived in Virginia," he said as recruits listened, "and I'm telling you, the American people, they do not like Muslims." 
Mr. Dunggio said the mission of his group, the Hezbollah Front, was to conduct "sweeps" against Indonesians closely allied with the United States. The first target, he said, would be James T. Riady, the businessman who pleaded guilty to American campaign finance violations with contributions to President Bill Clinton. "We went to his office last week," Mr. Dunggio said, "and told the guard, 'We'll be back again if and when America attacks Afghanistan.' "
If his group is going to sweep up Indonesians, he was asked, who is going to sweep for Americans. "Ah," he said, "that's another organization. We've divided up our responsibilities."

HEADLINE: Deal to Add $25 Billion To Budget 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 

 BODY:
The White House and leaders of both parties in Congress have agreed to provide the full $18.4 billion increase President Bush sought for military spending and to allocate more money to education, in a deal that could avoid a partisan fight over government spending for 2002, officials said today.
 The bipartisan deal would mean that spending for the coming fiscal year would be $25 billion more than what Mr. Bush requested in his budget proposal last spring. 
 Aides on Capitol Hill and Bush administration officials said they were nearing final agreement on a package of spending bills that would increase financing of programs beyond Social Security and Medicare to $686 billion for the next fiscal year, which begins on Monday. 
Both the White House and Congress hope the deal can eliminate the battles over spending that typically erupt at the end of each fiscal year.
An agreement could lead to speedy passage of 13 appropriations bills that pay for normal government operations. It would not address added spending for the campaign against terrorism or the cost of any stimulus package Congress might adopt to strengthen the economy, which would be dealt with separately.
But in a sign that partisan politics continues to play a role in policy decisions, the deal is being held up by Democrats' insistence that Mr. Bush make a formal new budget request for the additional money. 
Democrats said they feared that without such a request, the administration would criticize them in next year's mid-term election as having busted the budget.
Budget politics, which have revolved for the past few years around pledges to apply the Social Security surplus toward reducing the national debt, have been turned upside down by the costs associated with the terrorist attacks. Now lawmakers have judged the need to pay for the military response and to stimulate the weakened economy to be more important than the pledge not to touch the Social Security surplus.
The federal surplus for the current fiscal year, which ends on Sunday, is expected to be around $121 billion, $32 billion less than expected just a month ago.
The outlook for next year remains murky because of uncertainties about the antiterrorism campaign and the economy, but initial estimates by Congressional budget analysts suggest that the government might run a deficit.
Senior Democrats and Republicans have tentatively agreed on the basic outlines of a deal for the 13 appropriations bills for next year.
Mr. Bush would get the full amount of extra Pentagon spending he had requested; Democrats would get another $4 billion for education, the sum requested by House Democrats -- but $4 billion less than what Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts and other Senate Democrats had sought.
The agreement is also expected to include $2.2 billion in more spending for emergencies, including $1.2 billion that Representative Tom DeLay, Republican of Texas, sought for the Federal Emergency Management Agency. Congressional aides said the White House had raised objections to Mr. DeLay's request.
In seeking a deal, President Bush has walked a fine line between accommodating Democrats and not angering conservatives in his own party. Conservatives in the House in particular have resisted more spending beyond the $18.4 billion for the military, saying that to yield to Democratic calls for more money for education and other domestic programs would undercut their efforts to check the growth of government. 
But Democrats said they would block any deal until Mr. Bush embraced the full spending package as his own. 
Otherwise, "the historical record will reflect that Congress spent more than the president requested," one Democratic aide on Capitol Hill said. "We need to move forward together holding hands."
Any deal reached by the White House and Congressional leaders could be altered as the appropriations bills come up for votes in the House and Senate. Mr. Kennedy, for example, will push for further increases in education spending, his spokesman said. 
The $4 billion increase under discussion would be in addition to a $2 billion increase proposed by Mr. Bush and would bring total federal spending on education to $48.6 billion. Mr. Kennedy would like to raise that figure to around $52 billion.

HEADLINE: Journal; 
The End of the Beginning

BYLINE:  By FRANK RICH

 BODY:
Rudy Giuliani is being mercurial again. Nostradamus is falling off the best-seller list. CNN's ratings have dropped 70 percent from their post-attack peak. Jay Leno delivers a joke linking Osama bin Laden to Anna Nicole Smith. (Had it been funny, I'd repeat it.) Scattered among the bulletins of widespread layoffs are austere TV commercials in slo-mo black-and-white in which corporations pledge their solidarity with the American spirit. 
 Nothing has changed. 
 Then you pass by a fire station, and you see the snapshots of the dead, the flowers, the candles, the crayon drawings in which earnest young minds try to parse the irrational. This is grief served up raw, unmediated by artful "Band of Brothers" cinematography. No matter where you are in New York, a city where people like to think of themselves as being in control, the vertigo of Ground Zero still seems only a block or two away. 
Everything has changed.
As we straddle this incredible moment, poised between a glimpse of Armageddon and a future only a fool would predict, there is rampant hunger for certainty -- a precious commodity far harder to track down than anti-anthrax antibiotics. In truth we don't know where we are -- or where all our enemies are. We're in limbo. The best we can do is try to differentiate between what has not changed and what has, and, most important, to figure out what hasn't changed but should. If we can't have certainty, maybe we can have clarity.
Terrorists can't alter the fundamental human equation. People are still capable of being both angels and pigs. Countless Americans have given untold millions to help families maimed by the attacks. Other Americans ignored Warren Buffett, Jack Welch, the Treasury secretary and other optimists by betting against a "patriotic rally" on Wall Street and short-selling stocks when the markets reopened in a swoon. Countless Americans raised a flag to show their love of country and their solidarity with the thousands lost on Sept. 11. Other Americans wrapped themselves in the flag to engage in patriotic one-upmanship, with some news stars (though, commendably, ABC News soon forbade this) sporting lapel effusions large enough to dwarf that of the country's commander in chief. NBC now affixes every frame of sitcom swill like "Emeril" with its promotional peacock logo outfitted in the stars and stripes -- maybe the first good argument for a constitutional amendment banning flag desecration.
But some things have changed, and they are not small. A country that during its boom became addicted to instant gratification -- and to a post-gulf-war military policy predicated on the idea of a silver bullet fired safely (and often indiscriminately) from on high -- is so far willing to let its government take its time and choose its means of battle. Of all the statements from Americans since Sept. 11, few have been more reassuring than a representative opinion voiced by Ryan Clark, a 19-year-old firefighter in Lewiston, Idaho, to a New York Times/CBS News pollster: "I would like to see quick justice, but if you jump the gun and attack the wrong person, it's not going to accomplish anything."
The country's patient mood has matched that of its president. In a matter of days, George W. Bush moved from rhetoric drawn from a Steve McQueen TV western of his adolescence, "Wanted: Dead or Alive," to an exquisitely calibrated, adult speech that drew the essential distinctions between "Islamic extremism" and Islam, between the Taliban and "Afghanistan's people," between a TV-ready war of "instant retaliation and isolated strikes" and "a lengthy campaign" whose clandestine operations may be "secret even in success." 
But since that address, Mr. Bush is being given both less credit than he deserves from some quarters -- and too much from others. Liberals -- who, let's face it, assumed that the president would go off on a half-cocked, unilateral cowboy bombing spree -- must concede that he has put on the brakes. And in doing so, he stood up to a considerable chorus within his own constituency urging otherwise. 
Such was the hysteria on the right after Sept. 11 that National Review's Web edition disseminated a call from the TV commentator Ann Coulter to "invade the hijackers' countries, kill their leaders and convert them to Christianity." Presumably her targets include Saudi Arabia and Egypt, the home states of most of the 19 identified hijackers. Then came the "open letter" signed by William Bennett, Richard Perle, Gary Bauer and editors of The New Republic and The Weekly Standard threatening to brand Mr. Bush as a wimp -- guilty of "surrender in the war on international terrorism" -- if he bucked their demand to attack Iraq. Mr. Bush has to date blown off these influential armchair generals, coming down in favor of the more incremental, less unilateral strategy of an actual general, Colin Powell. 
Mr. Bush has so far turned aside other wish lists from the right as well, including The Wall Street Journal editorial page's patriotic call for the president to use his high poll ratings in the aftermath of a mass murder to push divisive judicial appointments through the Senate. Mr. Bush's quick condemnation of Jerry Falwell's and Pat Robertson's effort to blame America first, notably its gays and lesbians, for the attacks not only forced the TV blowhards to a hasty retreat, but also hammered in, perhaps for years to come, how Taliban-like America's own homegrown mixture of fundamentalism and politics can be. As the president jettisoned these former allies, so he nimbly embraced a former bete noire, big government, to pump up the economy and airport safety -- even to the point of creating a new federal agency, the Office of Homeland Security, whose name, though presumably not its mission, has an almost Stalinist ring to it. 
But the fact remains that, as far as the war goes, the Bush administration hasn't acted yet. The president's policies are a work in progress, subject to further about-faces. All sweeping judgments and bestowals of carte blanche on his leadership are laughably premature. Only in a foreshortened Hollywood scenario can an unproven leader change in an instant, with one speech, into a giant. Washington's rush to canonize Mr. Bush -- he's already been likened to Lincoln by the capital's dean, David Broder -- is gaseous complacency of the sort that got us where we are today. 
This is a time for more skepticism, not less, especially from news organizations tempted to blur the line between jingoism and journalism. Until CBS News and The Associated Press blew the whistle this week, the White House's excuse for the president's elusiveness on Sept. 11 -- a phoned-in threat to Air Force One -- was widely reported as fact, not the spin it was. The administration, whose efforts to restrict civil liberties have even brought Bob Barr and Maxine Waters together in opposition, is so eager to stifle dissent in the media that its press secretary publicly denounced a smart-aleck as benign as a late-night comic -- in this case Bill Maher -- for a tasteless wisecrack. 
In this atmosphere, boosterism can drive out information, especially at a time when we prepare to bond with regimes that abuse human rights and wink at terrorists in their own midst. From our flag-decorated TV screens you would hardly know that the Taliban's internal opposition and our would-be fellow freedom fighters, the ragtag Northern Alliance, is anathema to Pakistan, our other frail new ally. Or that Pakistan and its military, with its dozens of nuclear weapons, are riddled with bin Laden sympathizers. (USA Today, which has been aggressive on this story, reports that "12,000 Pakistani parents named their newborn sons Osama last year," with 5,700 others opting for Jihad.) 
Maybe it's now time to resuscitate irony from the deathbed to which it was recently consigned as well. Certainly it's an irony worth contemplating that, as the columnist Geneva Overholser has pointed out, the press largely ignored public Senate testimony a mere seven months ago in which the C.I.A. director, George Tenet, said that Mr. bin Laden's "global network" was the "most immediate and serious" terrorist threat to America.
The more we know now, the better, because knowledge is an antidote to the anxiety of change, and more change is the only certainty ahead. We can go back to watching all the late-night comedy we want, hopping on planes and rooting for Barry Bonds. But still the reality remains that another shoe will drop and that we have no idea whose, or when, or where.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home; 
Progress And Problems

BYLINE:  By ANTHONY LEWIS

 BODY:
Where do we stand, two and one-half weeks after the terrorist attacks? How effective has the Bush administration been? I think the record is good, but with some serious shortfalls.
 After early miscues, President Bush has set exactly the right tone: firm but measured. And he has made the difficult, essential decision not to rush into military action. 
 That we have not yet retaliated with force is frustrating to many, but wise. There was a real danger that we would strike back in anger, heedless of civilian casualties and their consequences for our cause. The president and his people now plainly understand the cost of getting it wrong. 
The sense of deliberateness in our decision-making carries its own power in the world. So does the administration's recognition that the terrorist problem cannot be solved by force alone but will be a long struggle involving diplomacy, finance, politics. Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld, always reckoned a hawk, made just that point on the Op-Ed page of The New York Times the other day. 
The administration's diplomatic performance has been first-class. Secretary of State Colin Powell successfully pressed Saudi Arabia to break relations with the Taliban regime in Afghanistan, and pressed Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel to let his foreign minister talk with Yasir Arafat. At U.S. urging, Russia, Pakistan and others have agreed to join, in different ways, the alliance against terrorism.
But wise rhetoric and skillful diplomacy will not be enough to defeat what is an apocalyptic movement. If we want to do that, rather than just hold terrorism at bay with improved security, we will have to use military force at some stage.
There's the rub. Do we really have good evidence linking Osama bin Laden to the Sept. 11 attacks? If we do, how do we attack him? President Clinton had cruise missiles strike a camp where he was -- and missed him by an hour. If anything, he will be harder to locate and hit now. Americans may have to develop a tolerance for failure.
There is one other plus in the record: not the administration's but the country's. Attorney General John Ashcroft quickly produced a legislative package -- surveillance, detention of immigrants -- that would have done real harm to civil liberties. But both Democrats and Republicans in Congress resisted, and Mr. Ashcroft is negotiating. Democracy has worked better on civil liberties this time than it worked in the Civil War and World Wars I and II.
A critical need is to strangle terrorist finances. The administration has taken steps, but I doubt that they are anywhere near tough enough. We have to make banks abroad tell us who is moving the money around. We pressed the Saudis to break diplomatically with the Taliban; will we press them to give us the names of money manipulators?
Finance is generally a weakness of the Bush administration. Secretary of the Treasury Paul O'Neill does not have the respect needed, abroad or at home. Tellingly, Congress has turned to Robert Rubin, President Clinton's Treasury secretary, for economic advice in this crisis. 
The terrorists aimed to injure us economically, and their attack has intensified a developing recession. The belief is widespread that we need Keynesian measures: a large-scale infusion of money into the economy. But President Bush has no one on his economic team strong enough to put that case together.
The president's greatest achievement, I think, has been to hold the country together behind a careful, patient policy. There has been an extraordinary absence of partisan ideology. Two large exceptions, in their egregious character, prove that rule. 
Andrew Sullivan, a right-wing figure, wrote in The Sunday Times of London five days after the attacks: "The middle part of the country -- the great red zone that voted for Bush -- is clearly ready for war. The decadent left in its enclaves on the coasts is not dead -- and may well mount a fifth column." The disgusting diatribe condemns itself.
Then William Kristol, a leading conservative voice, used the op-ed page of The Washington Post to attack Secretary Powell as soft and disloyal to the president. To the contrary, as almost everyone else in the country has seen over these weeks, Colin Powell has been a strong, reassuring figure, giving crucial support to George W. Bush as he has grown into the presidency.

HEADLINE: NYC; 
Politics That Fray Civic Unity

BYLINE:  By CLYDE HABERMAN 

 BODY:
THE 20th Amendment to the United States Constitution seemed worth rereading yesterday.
 This is the amendment, adopted in 1933, that changed the dates when new presidents, vice presidents and members of Congress take office. Instead of March 4, which had been standard since the earliest days of the republic, Jan. 20 was fixed for the transfer of power at the White House, and Jan. 3 for Congress. 
 The reasoning was simple, said Michael Beschloss, the presidential historian. The four-month gap between Election Day and Inauguration Day, unavoidable in the horse-and-carriage age, had become as antiquated as a buggy whip. By the 1930's, Mr. Beschloss said, "there was no justification" for such a drawn-out transition period. 
"The feeling was that having a lame duck for that long would be a problem for the country," he said. "Foreign leaders won't make deals with him, and Congress obviously won't."
Mind you, the shift to a substantially shorter interregnum came while the country was mired in an enormous crisis, the greatest economic depression in its history.
All this is mentioned because New Yorkers are now caught in another tough time, the aftermath of the World Trade Center disaster. But we are told by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani that what was correct for the flat-on-its-back America of the 30's is wrong for the saddened-but-sturdy New York of today. We must have, Mr. Giuliani says, a longer transition period between mayors -- up to five months, instead of the present two months.
Hanging on to him now, he essentially says, is more important than hanging on to processes that have served the city for many decades. Clearly, many New Yorkers agree. To show that he means business, his lieutenants hint at gun-at-your-head alternatives, including doing everything possible to nullify the term-limits law that will force Mr. Giuliani out of office on Dec. 31, and then running for another four years. In short, apres moi, moi.
The very thought of four more years has some fervently anti-Giuliani New Yorkers in a cold sweat. Unsolicited, Richard D. Emery, a civil rights lawyer, phoned yesterday to say that the term-extension deal had to be accepted because it was "the least havoc-creating choice."
"Havoc" may sound a tad strong to some ears. There is no question, though, that Mr. Giuliani has managed again to do what he so often does: make himself the issue, no matter what the subject may be. In the end, it always seems to be about him. He is such a polarizing figure -- how many New Yorkers do you know who don't either love him or hate him? -- that this politicking for a term extension is already fraying the civic unity that he says he wants to preserve.
In the last few days, the mayor has begun saying that he always favored a longer transition period. He could have used one himself when he took office in 1994, he said. If that is so, he somehow never noticeably shared this recipe for good government with the public -- not until now, when he has a little more than three months to go.
MOTIVES aside, the proposal to stretch his term until April 2002 raises some questions.
For instance, who gets to prepare the direction-setting budget message that is due in January: Mr. Giuliani or the mayor-elect who should have taken office on Jan. 1 and who may have different priorities?
Would a longer term apply only to the mayor? Or should it also go to the city comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi, guardian of pension funds and the city's chief investor while the stock market does stomach-churning loop the loops? Mr. Hevesi, who remains a mayoral candidate on the Liberal Party line, did not return calls yesterday to see if he had any thoughts on what would seem an important matter.
And why should the next mayor settle for a term lasting only three years and nine months? Doesn't he deserve a full four years? If so, the effect would be to create a permanent April 1 Inauguration Day and a transition period that drags on for an exhausting five months. That is hardly in the spirit of the 20th Amendment.
There is one more point, mentioned in case Mr. Giuliani persuades Albany's power brokers to unravel the term-limits law that city voters have twice approved.
The mayor says he has been boning up lately on Winston Churchill and his brave leadership during Britain's darkest hours of World War II. It is not clear if his reading has taken him up to July 1945, when Britain had national elections, a mere two months after the war ended in Europe.
For the record, Churchill lost.

HEADLINE: Again, Democrats Find Giuliani at Center of the Race 

BYLINE:  By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
Just a few days ago, Mark Green was preparing for a runoff campaign in which he would stress unity -- a contrast with Fernando Ferrer's advocacy for "the other New York" -- while offering a sober discussion of how to rebuild the city. Mr. Ferrer was preparing to cite his work rebuilding dilapidated housing as Bronx borough president, while urging that New York, in its rush to recover, not neglect problems with housing, health care and education.
 But as Mr. Ferrer and Mr. Green began the third day of their runoff contest yesterday, they found themselves talking about the same thing: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. Fittingly for a campaign in which the most prominent player has, from Day 1, been someone who is not even on the ballot, Mr. Giuliani has moved swiftly to the center of the Democratic runoff. 
 In a mayoral campaign with relatively few distinctions among the candidates, Mr. Giuliani helped create one by urging the contenders to bow to his demand for a term extension of several months, or face the threat of him trying to persuade the State Legislature to allow him to run for a third term. Mr. Green acceded to Mr. Giuliani's request. Mr. Ferrer, who is Mr. Green's opponent in the Oct. 11 runoff, did not.
These contrasting positions, in a year when all the candidates have struggled to balance criticism of Mr. Giuliani with praise of his tenure, caught the eye of many Democrats yesterday, among them Green supporters who were not happy with the turn of events. Some suggested that Mr. Ferrer, who waited for Mr. Green to issue a news release backing Mr. Giuliani before announcing his opposition, had seized the higher ground, at least from the perspective of Democrats who tend to vote in a primary.
Mr. Ferrer said that although the mayor had performed admirably since the attack, his handling of the crisis did not justify changing the law to allow him to linger in City Hall. Mr. Green, who is the public advocate, said he was trying to ensure that the city had an orderly transition during a difficult time. 
Nonetheless, he has acquiesced to Mr. Giuliani while the mayor's popularity is at its highest. And although Mr. Green said political factors did not enter into his consideration, the public advocate, understandably, has not been looking to alienate Democrats who have been applauding Mr. Giuliani's performance over the past two weeks.
Howard Wolfson, who was the communications director for Hillary Rodham Clinton when she ran for Senate last year, said Democratic primary voters might be wary of the extension that Mr. Giuliani has proposed, and to which Mr. Green has agreed, regardless of the extraordinary circumstances. "Many Democrats may be suspicious of this kind of arrangement," Mr. Wolfson said. He added: "Freddy looks big. He looks principled."
These events over the past two days served as a reminder of how often Mr. Giuliani has been the sun around which the Democratic candidates have revolved. If there has been one constant in this mayoral campaign, it has been the struggle of all the candidates to figure out how to deal with Mr. Giuliani. Many Democrats believe that this was one of the main forces that accounted for the collapse of the candidacy of Alan G. Hevesi, the city comptroller.
New York's outsized mayor seems certain to play a dominant role in the Democratic runoff, no matter what happens with his effort to extend his tenure. And by design or not -- and when it comes to Mr. Giuliani these days, politicians have given up trying to figure that one out -- the mayor's actions are creating all kinds of complications for the Democrats seeking to succeed him.
For example, the Black and Puerto Rican Legislative Caucus in Albany, which includes a number of Mr. Green's supporters, has come out firmly against any extension for Mr. Giuliani. As Mr. Ferrer has showed success at building a coalition of black and Latino supporters, the last thing Mr. Green wants is any erosion in his support among blacks who might be put off by the perception that he is trying to help Mr. Giuliani prolong his tenure.
In addition, some of Mr. Green's supporters have expressed concern that an impression among voters that Mr. Giuliani would be on the November ballot would discourage Green supporters from voting in the runoff. That could be a problem for Mr. Green because most politicians believe that Mr. Ferrer's supporters are more likely to turn out.
"Freddy wins if we don't get the white vote out," said one state legislator who supports Mr. Green. "If whites think Mr. Giuliani is running in November, they are not going to vote in great numbers."
Mr. Green's advisers contended yesterday that Mr. Giuliani's actions were causing problems for Mr. Ferrer as well. They said Mr. Ferrer risked a backlash by standing as a roadblock to an extended term for Mr. Giuliani.
"There are signs that more conservative Democrats are looking at how people respond to this tragedy, to see who acts responsibly," one of Mr. Green's advisers said.
Still, the concern among Mr. Green's normally sanguine advisers was clear yesterday. They acknowledged that they received a swell of protest from some liberal supporters. Mr. Green sent an e-mail message to Democrats yesterday offering an explanation of his actions, which veered from the praise he has offered for the mayor in recent days.
"As you know, no public official has taken on Mayor Giuliani on important issues more than I have over the last seven and a half years," he said.
Mr. Green said yesterday that while his decision was a "close call," he was trying to work with Mr. Giuliani to ensure the smoothest possible transition in City Hall. 
Asked what role political considerations had played in his decision, he responded, "Next to none."
