HEADLINE: L.I. @ WORK; 
Displaced Companies Call, but Few Sign Leases

BYLINE:  By WARREN STRUGATCH

 BODY:
AFTER fielding a flurry of phone calls from displaced New York City companies frantically searching for office space in the wake of the World Trade Center disaster, Long Island landlords and the brokers who represent them have largely been unable to come to terms. Instead, the companies have mostly found temporary (and possibly permanent)space elsewhere in the metropolitan region.
 Since the disaster, the uprooted companies have contracted for nearly five million square feet of office space around Manhattan and another 2.5 million square feet in New Jersey, Westchester and Connecticut, according to industry reports. Brokers and landlords on Long Island said that while several New York companies are temporarily housing some of their employees at branch offices in Nassau and Suffolk, no new leases had been signed, even for temporary space. 
 An estimated 30 million square feet of office space was destroyed or is no longer usable in Manhattan because of the terrorist attacks. Some of the displaced companies may still be in the market for space, so relocation deals may yet be made on Long Island. But the two county economic development agencies that routinely sweeten relocation packages by offering financial incentives have bowed out, and despite the professed optimism of some local brokers, the possibility of corporate relocations diminishes with every passing day. 
Fred Trump III, the managing director of the Long Island office of Insignia/ESG, said: "So far on Long Island, we see people looking, and there are a number of letters of intent out there. However, no deals have been secured as of yet."
In one instance, Benjamin Development offered to waive the rent on up to 120,000 square feet of new Class A space near the federal courthouse in Central Islip for up to three months for any displaced companies, but there were no takers. "I really have no idea why nobody took us up on the offer," said Russell Mohr, the director of sales at Benjamin, which built the Courthouse Corporate Center on Carleton Avenue. "You read that companies want to go where the talented employees are, and Long Island has a talented work force."
In another outreach effort, a Long Island coalition of professionals and executives have created www.libusinessrelief.com, a Web site to assist those providing emergency office space and supplies. 
Brokers, developers and others who work in the real estate industry offer various explanations of why Manhattan companies seem to have shunned Long Island. The reasons include the usual suspects: lack of mass transit, Manhattan decision makers' unfamiliarity with Long Island as a place to do business, and their perception that no space would be immediately available. 
David Pennetta, a vice president of Oxford & Simpson, a real estate brokerage company in Jericho, attributed the region's failure to attract its share of the displaced companies directly to mass transit. "Most of the people working in New York City aren't driving to work," he said. "Long Island does not have a great infrastructure in terms of mass transportation. Because it's so difficult for people to get to work without cars, it becomes very difficult for companies to relocate quickly out here. Executives don't want to tell 4,000 employees, 'O.K., go out and buy a car to get to work Monday.' "
In contrast, he said, companies found sites in New Jersey that were near PATH stations and new locations in New York City that were accessible by subway. Taking space in those markets, he added, allowed executives and their employees to make relatively few changes in their daily schedules. 
"They also aren't familiar with Long Island as a business environment," said Mr. Pennetta, a former president of the Commercial and Industry Brokers Society of Long Island. He suggested that the region's insularity can be mysterious and off-putting to the outsider. "Long Island can be difficult to figure out if you're seeing it for the first time and you have to make an immediate decision," he said. 
Mitchell Rechler, a co-president of Reckson Associates, the largest developer of office space on the Island, said that in the days following the attacks, many New York companies telephoned to ask about space availability but ended up leasing elsewhere. "It's just not going on," he said, referring to the lack of relocation deals. "I think it was a question of space. There were large blocks of space available in Jersey City, for example, which is just a quick train ride across the river from where they had been."
Nevertheless, nearly 11 percent of Long Island office space is currently vacant, up from nearly 10 percent last fall, according to Insignia/ESG. Available office space includes blocks of modern space in the former Sperry headquarters in Lake Success and in the former Grumman test hangar in Great River that has been rebuilt as the Long Island Technology Center. 
David Leviton, the senior director at the Long Island office of Cushman & Wakefield, the commercial real estate company, said Manhattan executives had expressed substantial interest in the 1.4 million square feet of office and technology space at the former Sperry headquarters, now known as i.park. Most of that space, which is 16 miles from Midtown and just over the Queens border, is still available, Mr. Leviton said. Although the office park's proximity to New York City and the fact that it is served by several bus lines should heighten its appeal, he said, so far no one has signed a contract.
Arthur Stern, the chief executive of the Cogswell Realty Group, which represents the Long Island Technology Center, said he had found many lookers but no takers. "We've had a number of inquiries, and we are close on a number of deals," he said. "One thing I've noticed consistently is that companies want to stay in Manhattan. They are being told they will be able to come back in six months, in some cases, and they are not abandoning the city."
The financial incentives that have sweetened the pot in the past have been absent. Alice Amrhein, the commissioner of the Suffolk County Industrial Development Agency, said the county was not offering incentives to companies displaced by the World Trade Center attacks. "Out of deference to New York City, we're not actively recruiting those companies," she said. "New York City wants to keep them in the city."
In Nassau County, the post of commissioner of the Department of Commerce and Industry, which has traditionally provided relocation incentives, has been vacant since Stephen Latham retired last year. Patrick Zagarino, the executive director of the county's Industrial Development Agency, which can provide low-cost loans to relocating companies, did not return two phone calls seeking comment. 
Mr. Pennetta, the broker, said he was not particularly surprised that most of the corporate relocation activity had gone elsewhere. Historically, not many companies from New York City have ever relocated to the Island, and in turn, Long Island has never depended on them.
"The market here is the big companies like Computer Associates and Symbol Technologies that started out here small and stayed here as they grew," Mr. Pennetta said. "There haven't been a lot of companies relocating here from somewhere else."

HEADLINE: 'Shop Till You Drop' Survives, but Economists Remain Wary 

BYLINE:  By JOHN RATHER

 BODY:
RECOVERING from the shock that nearly paralyzed the region after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, Long Island residents turned off their television sets last week to venture out in search of what remained of life the way it used to be.
 For many people, that meant shopping, dining out, family gatherings, taking a Sunday drive and being with friends and strangers in an atmosphere that was strangely more civil than usual but still filled with apprehension about what might come next. 
 How close to normal life had become nearly three weeks since the attack may become clear only in retrospect, when figures for key economic indicators are posted. But even with the threat of recession and more disruption, early signs suggested a powerful rebound toward normalcy.
From Roosevelt Field in Garden City to the Tanger Factory Outlet Center in Riverhead, the parking lots at major malls and shopping centers filled up again last weekend, almost to levels seen before "shop till you drop" became a patriotic admonition. 
"We had a good weekend, not a great weekend," said Janine Nevons, the general manager of the Tanger mall, one of the largest outlet centers in the country. She said store traffic was up 6 percent over a year ago. Ms. Nevons said that shoppers were buying practical household items and apparel on sale but were staying away from fashion and high-end items. "People are buying the basics," she said.
The Simon Property Group of Indianapolis, the owner of Roosevelt Field, Walt Whitman Mall in Huntington Station, Smith Haven in Lake Grove and the Mall at the Source in Westbury, does not discuss mall attendance figures. But Irwin Kellner, a professor of economics at Hofstra University and the chief economist for North Fork Bank and CBS MarketWatch, said he had cruised the lots at Roosevelt Field and the upscale Americana at Manhasset over the weekend and found them full.
"People were out in numbers, and they were carrying shopping bags," Dr. Kellner said. "I think shopping here on Long Island has already recovered."
Another economist, Thomas Conoscenti of the Center for Regional Policy Studies at the State University at Stony Brook, said he also saw signs of recovery.
"Just because people didn't feel like shopping in that week or so of depression following the attack doesn't mean demand has fallen off," Dr. Conoscenti said. "We may now have some pent-up shopping demand, and we may end up with some strong retail activity." He said he found Smith Haven Mall "fairly packed" during a recent visit.
Dr. Conoscenti said that the economic impact of the terrorist attacks would be greater in Nassau, which he said was "a much more formalized community with white-collar ties to the city and down in Wall Street" than in more self-contained Suffolk.
High-tech companies on the Island could see an increase in sales as the government issues contracts for equipment for a war on terrorism. Francis M. Scricco, the president and chief executive of Arrow Electronics in Melville, acknowledged that his distribution company might be one of them.
Pat Iannucci, the vice president for communications at the Pall Corporation, an East Hills company specializing in highly sophisticated filtration, separation and purification equipment, said that Pall was "ready and prepared to do whatever our country asks." Pall supplies filters for military jets, helicopters and armored vehicles; one product protects helicopter engines from desert sand.
Lee E. Koppelman, the executive director of the Long Island Regional Planning Board and chief planner during the region's transition from a defense economy in the 1980's to a small-business and service economy in the 1990's, said that sales-tax revenues would be the most accurate measure of recovery on Long Island. "The real test is going to come when we see those sales-tax receipt numbers," he said. 
In Suffolk, a $1.5 billion budget for 2002 proposed by the county executive earlier this month relies on sales taxes for $780 million in revenues, more than half the total. By contrast, far more predictable property taxes account for just $51 million in revenues. 
In Nassau, a four-year financial plan submitted by the county executive took a conservative approach on increases in sales-tax revenues. Frederick E. Parola, the county comptroller, said that even though shopping activity had "literally fallen off the cliff" after the attacks, "the good news is that sales-tax revenues were so strong prior to Sept. 11 that they were running ahead of predictions." 
But he said that the county could now fall short of even the modest increases forecasted in the four-year plan, throwing off all its financial assumptions. "Whether and when things will get back to normal we don't know," he said. 
Frederick B. Pollert, the director of the Suffolk County Legislature Budget Review Office, said the attacks and their aftermath added even more uncertainty than usual to predicting sales-tax revenues. "Under the best of circumstances it is difficult to forecast," he said. "At a national level, we know that right after the World Trade Center disaster, durable purchases decreased dramatically. The question is to what extent is that going to come back."
Some activities, like dining out, seemed to have rebounded sharply last week. Mr. Parola said that he couldn't watch any more television last week, so he took his family to Le Nook on Sunrise Highway in Wantagh for dinner, expecting to find empty tables. "It was packed," he said. "Everybody must have wanted to get out." Last weekend patrons also filled the Wantagh Inn, a nearby bar and restaurant, an employee there said. 
At Pumpernickels, a German seafood restaurant with a bar in Northport, Arthur Glad, the owner, said that his regulars had returned. "When this hit, the first couple of days were horrible," he reported. "I don't think anybody did anything but stay home and watch television. Then it started to pick up pretty good, and now it's pretty busy."
Jane Baxter Lynn, the executive director of the Long Island Wine Council, said the number of visits to tasting rooms at East End wineries had been about the same as a year ago.
What has changed dramatically, she said, was the ambience. "The mood has been very different," she said, "with people saying they needed to get out into the fresh air and open spaces, away from their televisions."
Farm stands also seemed to be relatively active last weekend. Joseph Gergela, the executive director of the Long Island Farm Bureau, said a looming question was how crowded the East End would be next weekend, the Columbus Day holiday at the conclusion of the harvest, traditionally farm stands' busiest weekend of the year. 
Judy Desiderio, a vice president of Cook Pony Farm, the Hamptons real estate company, said that demand for winter rentals was up sharply. "It seems that people who only summer out here are thinking they would like to be here as much as possible and only go into the city when they have to," she said. 
Others talked of a spirit not felt since Pearl Harbor. "It's really remarkable, " Dr. Koppelman said. "I have had people telling me they are going back into the stock market even if it's going down just to show the terrorists they can't win." He said he also sensed "an overwhelming desire to return to normalcy and sanity."
Dr. Koppelman said he anticipated that retail sales during the Christmas shopping season would be normal to strong, reflecting a consumer determination to spend despite uncertainties. "I think by Thanksgiving time this horror will have receded to a great extent from people's minds," he said.
This week the Long Island Association will begin an employment assistance program for families of attack victims and for displaced workers at 14,000 affected New York City businesses. "Unfortunately, it's likely that a significant portion of the people who perished will have come from Long Island," said Matthew T. Crosson, the association's president. 
Mr. Crosson said it was too early to gauge wider economic impacts on the region. "Long Island is certainly ground zero for retail, but it still remains to be seen how shoppers will respond," he said. "There are going to be people whose financial ability was directly affected and some who harbor fears. And I suspect the general economic conditions may cause some people to cut their spending."
"But a good deal of that may be offset by a need to collectively demonstrate that we are not going to be adversely affected by this terrorist attack, and people may indeed spend," he said. 
Dr. Kellner went further, predicting that the regional economy would emerge stronger than before. "I don't want to use the word 'benefit,' " he said, "but there are trends that will give us a boost." 
The slump in the stock market and job losses at dot-com companies, he said, had already softened the high-end real estate market in New York. Now with personal safety a concern, interest in Long Island addresses will mount, he contends.
Dorothy Herman, the president of Prudential Long Island Realty, which has 37 branch offices, said that by last week sales activity was resuming after a post-attack week in which "everyone was traumatized, and there was not a whole lot of anything." She said that open houses held last weekend were "for the most part active."
"I think we're going to be O.K., but nobody 100 percent knows because it's kind of early," she said. "I think people are going to feel a little safer living here on Long Island in case we have another terrorist attack." 
John M. Kennedy, the president of the Building and Construction Trades Council of Nassau and Suffolk, said that rebuilding in Manhattan would mean jobs for the 60,000 unionized construction workers who live on the Island. 
"Whenever New York City gets busy and we have any unemployment at all, our sister locals have always called on us for manpower," he said. "They will certainly reach out, and we will respond. We will be right there to fill that void."

OVER the last two weeks, classrooms throughout the Island have been forums for students to express their emotions about the World Trade Center disaster.

HEADLINE: An Economy on the Edge 

BYLINE:  By SUSAN WARNER

DATELINE: TRENTON 

 BODY:
FOR New Jersey, the turn of the new century was rich. Wall Street was riding high, and a good share of its wealth filtered across the Hudson River. Telecommunications and computer companies were expanding, fed by the New Economy investment wave. Developers were building starter mansions and shopping centers on any cornfield they could rezone.
 Even in the past year -- as the national economy began to slow -- the state was able to defy decline. But by the end of the summer, New Jersey, too, had begun to lose jobs. Income growth had slowed, and the economy was growing only slightly. 
 That was before terrorists ripped through the World Trade Center towers, killing more than 6,000 people. 
Today, the state's economy is as fragile as at any time since the Gulf War.
"The short-term effect on the region is going to be negative," said Joseph J. Seneca, a professor of economics at Rutgers University who is also chairman of the state's nonpartisan Council of Economic Advisors. "We were hit directly."
Mr. Seneca said that the loss of business activity, consumer confidence and jobs as a result of the Sept. 11 attacks would constrict the state's economic growth -- even more than the nation's as a whole -- this quarter.
Yet despite the complications, the state's economic prospects in the longer term -- sad but true -- could benefit from the enormous loss.
"Over time," Mr. Seneca said, "the relocation of activities out of downtown Manhattan and the stimulus of rebuilding may actually benefit New Jersey."
In addition, jittery Manhattanites are giving serious thought to what was once the almost unthinkable: moving to New Jersey.
When speaking about the state's economy these days, experts are careful about using the word slowdown, since it may be months before it meets the technical definition of a recession -- two consecutive quarters of economic contraction.
Even before the trade center disaster, the state's overall output of goods and services was expected to grow an estimated 4.8 percent in 2001, to $372.7 billion, slower than the rate of 7.8 percent the previous year.
In the economic expansion from May 1992 to February 2001 -- the longest peacetime expansion in New Jersey's history -- the state added 585,000 jobs bringing total employment to more than four million. But from February to July this year, the employment figures changed direction and the state recorded a net loss of 15,000 jobs, according to a New Jersey Economic Review and Outlook prepared by Rutgers.
"February seems to be the critical month," said James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers. "That's when we seemingly hit the economic bridge abutment."
Yet as Mr. Hughes and Mr. Seneca were presenting their economic outlook in Trenton, life was being rearranged in ways they could never have imagined. They presented their data on Sept. 11 as the catastrophic events were unfolding in Lower Manhattan and at the Pentagon.
"The world has changed so much since then," Mr. Seneca said in an interview days afterward.
One example is the airline industry, which crashed along with the planes that sliced into the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. In New Jersey alone, there were 46,000 people employed by the airline industry as of July.
Continental Airlines, which has one of its three major hubs at Newark International Airport, has announced its intention to lay off as many as 12,000 employees.
"We're going to get a major hit from the layoffs at Continental," Mr. Hughes said.
Unemployment had begun creeping up even before Sept. 11. The state's unemployment figures for August showed the rate rising to 4.3 percent, up from 4.0 in July, but still not as high as the national rate of 4.9 percent.
Shirley Goetz, director of labor market and demographic research for the state Department of Labor, said the unemployment rate, while on the rise, remained at historically low levels.
Ms. Goetz said many economists considered 5 percent unemployment to be what they called the natural rate of joblessness after taking into account the number of people searching for jobs because of changes in their own lives rather than economic cycles.
On the other hand, Nancy Mantell, director of the Rutgers Economic Advisory Service, a forecasting service run by the university for private clients, was not optimistic, at least for the short term.
Ms. Mantell said she expected new job creation to shrink to an annual rate of 13,000 by the end of next year before beginning to grow by 42,000 each year from 2003 through 2006.
The state's economy as a whole is expected to grow at a rate of 1.6 percent next year, before rising to 2.8 percent a year through 2006, according to Ms. Mantell's forecast.
"We do have very serious short-term cyclical worries," said Mr. Hughes, "but they need to be seen in the context of an optimistic long term."
Even before events rearranged the economic landscape, Mr. Hughes said New Jersey was in the process of a major change similar to the one that occurred more than 100 years ago -- when the state emerged as an industrial giant with large urban centers. Now, he said, the state had embraced the information-based economy and was undergoing a second great transformation in the form of a tidal wave of suburbanization.
Moreover, in the aftermath of the assault on the Trade Center, moving to the suburbs and the exurbs is more appealing.
Paul Kuchinski, a sales associate at Prudential New Jersey Properties in Millburn, said that since the attacks city residents had made up about 70 percent of inquiries as against about 40 percent only six months ago.
"Maybe before they were on the fence," Mr. Kuchinski said, "and now they have come to the realization that it is time to do something about it."
In Watchung, Bob Rose, president of Prudential Rose Realtors, said business had begun to slow down before Sept. 11.
But now, Mr. Rose said, his firm has noticed a renewed interest on the part of city residents who had been contemplating a move.
"I think we'll probably hear from more of them," he said. "We'll know more in a month or two whether they are really ready to relocate."
New Jersey, to some extent unwittingly, had been preparing for a downturn. Joel Naroff, chief economist at the Commerce Bank of Cherry Hill, said the state had developed a more diverse economic base.
"In the past," Mr. Naroff said, "New Jersey felt the pain earlier and harder. While the state's economy is not ripping along, based on traditional patterns, we wouldn't have expected New Jersey to be doing as relatively well."
Getting down to specifics, state economic development officials have identified six industry clusters they expect to continue to outperform the rest of the economy: warehousing and logistics; pharmaceuticals and health care; science and technology; casinos and entertainment; and information technology and finance.
These six sectors employed 1.2 million people, or about 30 percent of the state's work force, at the end of 2000, and employment in these sectors was growing at a rate of 2.5 percent compared with 1.6 percent for the entire state.
Manufacturing makes up about 12 percent of the state's economic output, with heavy concentrations in chemicals and pharmaceuticals, electronics, computers, publishing and machinery, according to the Council of Economic Advisors.
Mr. Hughes said the state and the nation had undergone a two-phase manufacturing recession. The first phase, beginning in the first half of 2000, hit old-line manufacturers. The second phase, beginning this year, hit technology companies and business service firms related to the computer industry.
"New Jersey had been fairly resistant to the national slowdown," he said. "But the aftershocks of the New Economy retreat have fully engulfed the state."
Mr. Seneca said he found it ironic that the computer industry, which produced the means to manage business inventory, now finds itself overstocked and out of work.
Then there is the drug industry, the crown jewel of the state's economy and one that is largely recession-proof. New Jersey is home to 19 large pharmaceutical companies, more than any other in the nation, including several that have consolidated operations from other parts of the country and the world.
"When you talk about New Jersey, you're talking about pharmaceuticals," said Mr. Naroff.
Aventis Pharma AG and Novartis Pharmaceutical Corporation, which both have their corporate headquarters in Europe, have made New Jersey their base for their operations in the United States, the world's largest drug market.
Aventis has more than 2,000 employees spread between two major locations and is building a new campus at Bridgewater Crossing that is expected to house 1,200 workers by the middle of next year.
Novartis, in East Hanover, evolved out of the 1996 merger of Sandoz and Ciba-Geigy, which both had operations in the state. It employs 4,100 workers in New Jersey.
"It was not by design, but now we all feel very comfortable here," said Paulo Costa, the chief executive of Novartis. "The costs may be slightly higher than in the Midwest or somewhere else, but the talent pool that's available from all the metropolitan areas around New Jersey, New York and Philadelphia makes it very easy for us to recruit high-level scientists, marketers and so on."
One potential threat to the industry appears to be receding. In the 2000 election camp, presidential and congressional candidates campaigned on the promise of a prescription-drug benefit for Medicare recipients. While industry executives supported the move in general, they were concerned about how the benefit would be structured. They feared that having one huge buyer would result in de facto price controls that could cut deeply into profits.
But a shrinking federal surplus was already dampening this debate before the government was faced with the prospect of financing the rebuilding of Lower Manhattan and waging a global war against terrorism.
While the pharmaceutical industry remains healthy, the telecommunications and computer industries, which also experienced strong growth in the state in late 1990's, are now suffering from the overcapacity that has struck the technology sector worldwide.
New Jersey did not have a big bubble of dot-com business, but it did provide the research and manufacturing for much of the equipment used to build the Internet and wireless communication systems. In the past year, the work force at Lucent Technologies, which develops and manufactures telecommunications equipment, has been scaled back to 11,000 from 17,000. Of those workers, 2,500 took voluntary severance packages.
William Price, a spokesman for Lucent, said that most of the staff cuts in New Jersey were over, and that the company was now closing smaller offices around the state to consolidate at its four main locations in Whippany, Holmdel, Warren and its corporate headquarters in Murray Hill.
"The thing with the Lucent situation is that those are management jobs, engineering jobs, relatively high-paid people," said Gus Faucher, a senior economist at Economy.com a forecasting firm in West Chester, Pa., that specializes in regional economics. "We see the slowdown is now having an impact on manufacturing workers, and also higher-paid professionals."
Another key sector, finance, was also showing signs of distress even before Sept. 11.
"Whether it's back offices, bonuses or stock options, these are things that affect residents as well as companies in New Jersey, and it's spread pretty far," said Mr. Naroff of Commerce Bank.
While the financial industry overall was stagnant before the attacks, a migration of jobs from New York to offices on the riverfront and in Newark was taking place.
Since the devastation of the World Trade Center -- in which 10 million square feet of office space was wiped out -- the trickle has turned into a land rush. On the waterfront, particularly, companies have lined up for large properties.
Thomas Reilly, vice president of the CB Richard Ellis agency, said a recent report by his firm calculated northern New Jersey's office vacancy rate at 13.8 percent, and 2.6 percent for the waterfront. Much has changed.
"Property available for sublease that we had a tough time even giving away two weeks ago is gone now," Mr. Reilly said more than a week ago.
He added, "The vacancy rate in Jersey City will be zero."
Since the trade center attack, Lehman Brothers has subleased space at the Colgate Center building in Jersey City. In addition, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey subleased 180,000 square feet at Gateway Center in Newark. Also in Newark, a dinosaur known as the Tin Can, which has been all but vacant since 1986, was leased to a dislocated government office the day after the disaster.
Dudley Ryan, a broker for CB Richard Ellis, said that all the available space his company had listed in Newark could have been "leased 10 times over."
Even before the trade center disaster, J. P. Morgan Chase & Company had plans to move 2,500 employees to a new office tower in Jersey City. And Goldman Sachs & Company, which was forced to relocate some employees from Lower Manhattan to its existing space in Jersey City, is currently building a 1.4-million-square-foot office tower on the waterfront there that would house more than 6,000 employees.
Life was fat in New Jersey during the 1990's, Mr. Naroff said, also because of an increase in global trade stimulated by the growth of the Internet and because of liberalized trade rules around the world.
Foreign exports from New Jersey rose 35 percent, to $30.6 billion from the second quarter of 1999 to the same period in 2000. Nationally, exports grew, on average, only 12.6 percent, in the same period. This year, the rate of increase in New Jersey has been only 5.79 percent. Chemicals, including pharmaceuticals, and computers and electronics make up half of New Jersey's exports, according to the Rutgers economic overview.
The burst of activity in 1999 and 2000, Mr. Seneca, was due in large part to capital spending by businesses as well as spending in preparation for 2000 that has now dropped off sharply.
Through it all, New Jersey remained rich.
Indeed, New Jersey ranks first among the states in household income and third in per capita income, behind Connecticut and Massachusetts. New Jersey's per capita income was $36,983, compared with $37,992 in Massachusetts and $40,640 in Connecticut.
State officials have tried to measure how big a role the stock market's fluctuations play in New Jersey, mainly for calculating expected capital gains taxes, but have yet to find a way to break it out reliably. The state Treasury Department does project an increase in personal income tax to $7.97 billion for the fiscal year ending in June 2001 from $7.2 billion the previous year.
Mr. Naroff and Mr. Faucher said that wealthier people tend to be more heavily invested in equities, making individual net worth in New Jersey more likely to swing with the stock market than in other states.
With businesses still working off an inventory and investment glut, economists continue to look to the consumer to keep a recession at bay.
So far, the consumer has spent heroically, especially in New Jersey.
Retail sales in the state are expected to grow 4.2 percent this year, to $106.2 billion, according to the Council of Economic Advisors. While that is down from an increase of 8.9 percent in 2000 and 9.3 percent in 1999, it is comparable to increases of 4.3 percent in 1997 and 1998.
There are worrisome signs as well. Another leading indicator of consumer sentiment in New Jersey, new vehicle registrations, is down. Last year they were up 8.1 percent. But for 2001, the Council of Economic Advisors estimates new vehicle registrations will decline 5.2 percent.
In addition, Mr. Seneca said that after several years of frenzied construction of what he called starter castles, building permits in the state were expected to drop 25 percent this year, to 25,661.
In recent years, residential construction was limited by the availability of open land. There had been constraints on the supply side, he said, though with a slowing economy there will also be some constraints on the demand side.
When the Rutgers study was compiled, there was no way to anticipate the seismic events to come, of course. With the scope of the military response unknown, consumers and manufacturers alike will be constrained.
"We haven't invented what's going to happen on the global scene," Mr. Hughes said. "If it causes major shocks to the system, then all bets are off."

HEADLINE: RESTAURANTS; 
Bistro Basics

BYLINE:  By DAVID CORCORAN

DATELINE: BERGENFIELD 

 BODY:
ONE thing you will never do is stumble across Chez Dominique by accident. It sits on a sad-eyed side street in this blue-collar borough in Bergen County's midsection, in a faded downtown dreaming of urban renewal. Its next-door neighbor is a pool hall.
 But for some reason this forlorn address has been home to fine French bistros for more than a decade. First there was Chez Madeleine, which built a faithful base of customers on a dependable menu of well-turned standards. When its owners, Gaspard and Madeleine Caloz, decamped last year for grander quarters up the road in Northvale, Dominique Peyraudeau moved right in. 
 Mr. Peyraudeau, 49, grew up near Limoges, in central France, and learned the trade at Maxim's of Paris. He spent 11 years at the three-star La Reserve, in Midtown Manhattan, rising to executive chef. But he lives in Ramsey, and he wanted his own place in Bergen County. With minimal changes in name, decor and menu, he has managed to make 4 Bedford Avenue very much his own address.
The ambience will not dazzle you. Chez Dominique doesn't have checked tablecloths, but it has the look and feel of heavy-beamed, timeworn French bistros everywhere from the French countryside to the theater district. The room is tiny and crowded, with 12 tables in a space the size of a studio apartment. Squeeze-box music from the Moulin Rouge era deedle-deedles through the sound system. The staff is an eclectic mix of seasoned, charming veterans and jittery, overeager newcomers. The menu is a chalkboard, propped on an empty chair. 
Places like this -- there are not many in New Jersey anymore -- can get stuck in their own time warp, with retro recipes made from second-rate ingredients mired in gloopy sauces. Fortunately, this fate does not befall the cooking at Chez Dominique. Mr. Peyraudeau (pronounced pay-roe-DOE) works in the mold of chefs who came of age in the 1960's and 70's, like Jacques Pepin and Julia Child. Like them, he respects his ingredients and is comfortably grounded in classic technique; like them, he has the energy and skill to break out of the mold, to simplify and improvise when the mood takes him. This adds up to solid, crowd-pleasing cooking with just enough surprises to keep things interesting.
One recent Saturday night, for instance, we ordered an entree of skate. This is a fish that seldom swims through New Jersey restaurant waters; I can't recall seeing it on a menu in years. If I do, I'll order it again, but I'll be amazed if I like it as much as Chez Dominique's version, a flat, sprawling beauty that covered most of its large plate. It was flaky and not at all rubbery, its faintly nutty flavor enlivened but not drowned out by browned butter redolent of capers.
Another night, grilled jumbo shrimp in an appetizer were a bit overdone but drew great vivid flavor from their marinade of herbs and garlic and their basil-lemon infusion. On the side, for contrast, was a delicious little heap of eggplant caviar.
Salmon is my nominee for fish most in need of a vacation. For some reason, many chefs insist on preparing it in ways that overemphasize its natural fattiness -- with maple-syrup glaze, for example. Mr. Peyraudeau's salmon entree won me over. He served it in a bowl, in a fish broth with Mediterranean scents of cumin, coriander and anise. His smoked salmon appetizer, with creme fraiche and capers, was pleasingly mild.
Terrine of foie gras is worth its $15.50 price tag, about double that of the other appetizers -- a sensationally buttery slab of liver, generous enough to be shared by two. "I hope you have a healthy heart," our waiter remarked with a wicked grin.
Easy for him to say. Your cardiologist would probably advise you to go for the vegetable terrine, with layers of eggplant, fennel, carrots and red peppers bound by just enough goat cheese and given a sharp, welcome flavor jolt by whole cumin seeds. 
Mr. Peyraudeau does classic, too. Those blackboard menus change regularly, but they offer a representative selection of appetizers and entrees that could have appeared in any French bistro from the time Snoopy was shot down by the Red Baron. There's not much to say about them other than that they deliver good value. Prices are fairly high: you'll spend at least $50 a person for three courses, tax and tip, plus whatever wine you carry in. But appetizers like snails in a fragrant garlic butter or a rich crab tart bound with Gruyere cheese, and main courses like sole amandine and duck a l'orange, are about as good as those dishes get.
I was more taken with a Provencal seafood pasta -- scallops, shrimp and chunks of lobster over linguine in a tomato sauce scented with saffron and Pernod. Veal chop forestiere was terrific, meaty and tender, with generous side offerings of portobello mushroom and a shoestring-potato galette. Lamb shank, the quintessential autumn dish, drew abundant flavor from a spice chest of ingredients and from long cooking in a deep, rich broth with a mirepoix of vegetables. Another fall dish, rabbit, was dry in spots, but its accompaniments of gratin potatoes, spinach crepe and a bacon-endive compote made it a fine four-course meal in itself.
Not surprisingly, Mr. Peyraudeau has a way with comfort-food desserts like chocolate souffle (it does not need to be ordered hours in advance) and a rich, eggy, almost cheeselike clafoutis with fresh berries. But his fresh sorbets and pear glace parfait -- authentically grainy pear sorbet with a deep purple layer of black-currant sorbet -- make anapt, light ending to a rich and satisfying meal. Chez Dominique may be a hard place to find, but it's even harder to leave.

Chez Dominique
4 Bedford Avenue, Bergenfield
(201) 384-7637

VERY GOOD

ATMOSPHERE Tiny, convivial, slightly faded storefront bistro.
SERVICE Mainly calm and professional.
SMOKING None.
WINE LIST B.Y.O.
RECOMMENDED DISHES Grilled shrimp, crab tart, foie gras terrine, vegetable terrine, smoked salmon; lamb shank, veal chop forestiere, sauteed skate, salmon, rabbit, seafood pasta; berry clafoutis, chocolate souffle, pear glace parfait, sorbets.
PRICE RANGE Lunch: appetizers, $4.50; entrees, $9.50 to $12.50. Dinner: appetizers, $5 to $15.50; entrees, $22.50 to $32.50; desserts, $6.50 to $7.
HOURS Closed Sundays and Mondays. Lunch: Wednesday through Fridays, noon to 2:30 p.m. Dinner: Tuesdays through Thursdays, 6 to 10 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, 6 to 10:30 p.m.
CREDIT CARDS MasterCard, Visa.
RESERVATIONS Recommended.

HEADLINE: Atlantic City's Striving Airport Is a Victim 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT STRAUSS

 BODY:
Things had been ramping up nicely at Atlantic City Airport. Plans were afoot for more than $20 million in improvements.
 Spirit had begun flights to Chicago, Los Angeles and Florida. Continental Airlines had established a route to Cleveland. A new parking garage was being designed. 
 Then planes slammed into the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, delivering their own kind of sucker punch to Atlantic City Airport. Continental, threatened with deep financial losses even before the terrorist attacks, pulled out of Atlantic City altogether, discontinuing its flights and furloughing its staff. Spirit halted its daily excursions to Los Angeles by way of Chicago and cut back on its Florida flights. And US Airways Express, the third commercial airline at the airport, cut back -- perhaps temporarily -- on flights to Baltimore and Philadelphia.
"It wasn't good news," said James A. Crawford, executive director of the South Jersey Transportation Authority, which runs the airport. "It's not going to be great for the airline industry for at least three months. But we have to move forward and we will."
To that end, the authority recently approved $9.7 million to put up a maintenance building, primarily to house snow-clearing and sweeping equipment, as well as to install a new lighting system for runways and taxiways. Even before the attacks, the authority had planned to spend $1.6 million to upgrade security with new fencing, camera equipment and gates.
"Altogether this year, we will have spent or planned to spend $20 million in improvements," said Mr. Crawford. "Obviously, one of the big issues for us is restoring confidence in air travel. It is particularly important in a tourism-based economy that people feel comfortable to travel."
All along it has been an uphill task trying to get major airlines to come to Atlantic City Airport, which is actually in Pomona, about nine miles inland from the city. Major airlines have tended to steer Atlantic City-bound passengers to Philadelphia or Newark, where they can feed into hubs that the airlines have already established.
The arrival of Spirit, especially with its flights to Los Angeles by way of Chicago this summer, seemed to indicate a resurgence of interest in Atlantic City as a destination. But with the demise of the Continental flights and layoffs and cutbacks at US Airways, prospects for that resurgence have considerably dimmed.
Nonetheless, Mr. Crawford said that the authority was committed to bringing another commercial carrier into the airport. Earlier this year the State Legislature had appropriated $2 million for the authority to market air travel. As a result, the authority had earmarked some of those funds to help Continental Airlines establish itself in Atlantic City.
Continental officials declined to say if they would try to use some of the $2 million to defray the costs of its Cleveland flights. If not, Mr. Crawford said, he would try to use the money to attract new commercial business.
In any case, by November there will be plenty of parking space for customers to take advantage of whatever flights there may be. A 1,700-car surface parking lot will be completed by then; there had been about 1,000 spaces, some of which were on grass lots near the terminal.
Although the big commercial business was falling off significantly, Mr. Crawford said, other types of flights were on the rise.
For instance, he said that shared charter jets had become popular. Raytheon Corporation, which has a complex nearby, sells fractional ownership in its jet to other companies that may need it from time to time. In addition, charters operated by the casino hotels were thriving despite the terrorist attacks, he said.
"In each case, if you are sending four people, say, first-class on a commercial jet to Newark, you might feel better off leasing or buying a fractional share on a private jet," Mr. Crawford said. "Right now, with security slowing down flights and more flights being canceled in major airports, you can be assured at least of getting here."
Moreover, Atlantic City Airport serves as a base for the Air National Guard, the Coast Guard and the Federal Aviation Administration, all of which have been active during the current crisis.
"We've even had extra landings from McGuire and Dover Air Force bases," said Mr. Crawford. "All of these people have been extremely organized, with a lot of touch-and-go landings."
But, ultimately, Mr. Crawford said, he wanted to see Atlantic City become a thriving commercial airport.
"We're not necessarily a rival to Philadelphia and Newark, but more like an alternative," he said. "To the extent that, in the future, people will have problems with the delays caused by extra security and crowding there, we hope to build on being a lesser-hassle place.
"Give this crisis three months and have patience," he said, "and we think we'll be back."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Despite cutbacks by the airlines, Atlantic City Airport will make costly improvements. (Chris Polk for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Hundreds of Keys To Nowhere 

BYLINE:  By GEORGE JAMES

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY 

 BODY:
KELLY BADILLO has nightmares.
 Mr. Badillowho was operating an elevator just before the first plane hit the north tower of the World Trade Center -- had made his last run. He was not scheduled to relieve another operator until 9:45 a.m., and was about to go upstairs to talk to a man about a used car when he heard "all these noises" and the building shook. 
 Then he heard the sound of something falling -- elevators.
"You could hear them: ssshhhhhhh-BOOM -- as they fell," he said. "The fire and all melted the weights or something and they came flying down." 
The elevator doors blew out and flames licked out into the lobby.
"The lights flickered first," he said. "And then rmmm-BOOM, all hell broke loose. Glass started breaking, the glass on the mezzanine. And the marble and all that started coming off from the vibration. 'Evacuate the building!' " a voice on his two-way radio squawked.
People ran toward the escalator to get to the doors leading to the plaza, where they saw charred bodies amid falling debris. Desperately, he and many others fled through a side door.
On a rainy morning last week, a jumble of keys took up most of Mr. Badillo's hand as he relived the scene. There were maybe a hundred keys in all -- to supply rooms, slop sinks, bathrooms and other places in the World Trade Center where for nearly 20 years he made his living.
The keys, covered with a fine layer of dust, represented a job he no longer had in a place that no longer existed, and they sat heavy in his hand and his heart.
"The worst part is not seeing the World Trade Center anymore every morning," said Mr. Badillo, a stocky man of 40. "And you know, I guess just losing the people. A lot of people. And losing the job."
Twenty-six service employees are among the missing. About 1,200 like him -- amid the brokers, traders and lawyers in the towers -- had the less glamorous occupations of cleaners, elevator operators, porters, security guards, food service workers and tour guides. They, along with about 600 workers in buildings in downtown Manhattan that have been destroyed or closed, are out of work.
"Our members don't have the same kind of money and assets and benefits that the higher-paid people who worked there have," said Mike Fishman, president of Local 32BJ of the Service Employees International Union, who supplied those figures. "But I would add they all have the same thing in common. Those that didn't make it out no longer have their lives. And all those who did are suffering -- whether they were cleaners or investment bankers."
Mr. Badillo, like many who survived the trauma of death and collapse around him, suffers recurring nightmares. Added to that is the economic suffering for workers like him whose savings, if any, tend to be minimal, and whose job opportunities are uncertain since their counterparts in hotels and restaurants are being laid off as the tourism and entertainment industries constrict in the aftermath of the attacks.
Members of Local 32BJ include immigrants from 60 countries, primarily Central and South Americans and Eastern Europeans. "Unfortunately for our people, most live from paycheck to paycheck," said Mr. Fishman. "So while they had to live with the terror of the attack, they also have to worry where the next paycheck is coming from."
Mr. Badillo, who was born in New York City and made $17 an hour -- taking home $474 a week -- for a 40-hour week at the twin towers, said his wife, Debra, 42, an administrative assistant at the American National Standards Institute in Midtown Manhattan. They have two grown daughters, one of whom is a pre-med student at Rutgers, and they live in a three-bedroom apartment in a two-family house they bought in downtown Jersey City four years ago. 
"I had just paid my mortgage for the month," Mr. Badillo said as he sipped iced tea and smoked cigarettes at the dining room table. "That's really my concern. "Then, once I pay the mortgage, you know, a little food on the table."
His longer-range concern is getting a job.
His and his colleagues' immediate plight, however, has been eased by an industrywide agreement reached recently between Local 32BJ and the Realty Advisory Board, an association of owners, operators and employers in the real estate field, to provide health and supplemental unemployment benefits -- in addition to government unemployment compensation payments -- to members for six months and to put displaced workers on a preferential hiring list for jobs as they become available.
"The supplemental benefit will bring take-home pay closer to what they were taking home prior to the attack," said Mr. Fishman.
In addition, workers close to retiring will have five years added to their years of service and age, he said.
"The union, they're doing a good job," said Mr. Badillo. "And I believe the companies have been pretty good with us."
Yet for all of this, the sense of displacement goes beyond the loss of a job to something less tangible, Mr. Fishman said.
"For our workers, the buildings had a special significance," he said. "Many worked in the World Trade Center for years. Their lives and benefits are tied with that building, so this is quite shattering. To people who worked there, it was their whole community."
He told the story of a woman who each night cleaned the offices of a major company after all the employees had gone home. The company lost a great number of employees in the attack, and although she never met any of them, she felt she knew them from the pictures of their families on their desks.
"That kind of connection has made their loss almost as devastating to her as if she had known them personally," Mr. Fishman said.
So too for Mr. Badillo. Long before he worked there, he knew the place through his father, Henry, who emigrated from Puerto Rico and began work as a porter on the observation deck on the 107th floor of the south tower. Twenty-five years later, he retired as an elevator starter in the lobby of the north tower.
"Even when I was in high school," Mr. Badillo recalled, "I used to go there on weekends and help him out."
He began as a porter on the observation deck and worked on the concourse. For the last five years he has been an elevator operator. For five years, he and his father worked overlapping shifts.
"Every time I would go out, I would bring back coffee for him and hang out for a while," he said.
His brother, Henry Jr., 43, also worked at the World Trade Center as a manager in the aviation department of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey on the 65th floor of the north tower. He arrived for work just as the first plane sliced into the tower and never went upstairs. 
Mr. Badillo, who had been trapped in an elevator in the 1993 bombing -- but managed to free himself and lead others to safety -- was one of 350 service employees at work at the time of the Sept. 11 attack. He had arrived at 6 a.m. and had been operating an elevator to the 108th floor of the north tower until his break came.
It was a break that would never end.
Today, Kelly Badillo is haunted by the missing, his friends and the friends of his father, Sonia Ortiz among them. Miss Ortiz -- a 58-year old woman who had come from Colombia and bought a house in Queens and raised two children -- was the operator of Car 99. He was to relieve her later that morning.
He dreams about them when sleep finally comes. He dreams of the buildings falling down and that he is running again for his life. And he dreams he meets them and they say to each other, "Oh where have you been? We've been looking for you."
Mr. Badillo, who has been meeting with fellow workers "just to comfort each other," walked out onto his front porch. The rain had stopped. He looked out at the gloomy sky and beyond the turnpike overpass to where he used to be able to see the twin towers. The heavy key ring on the dining room table, his two-way radio and his dusty work boots were all that was left.
"It was home," he said. "It was a home. It was another home."

HEADLINE: ON CAMPUS; 
At a University That's Flush, No One Anted Up

BYLINE:  By ANNE RUDERMAN

DATELINE: PRINCETON 

 BODY:
It isn't often that upperclassmen at Princeton University are at a loss for words. Nor is it any more frequent that alumni are at a loss for money.
 This is an exception. 
 Three years ago, construction was completed on Princeton's new $45 million football stadium -- generally judged to be an uncommonly good piece of campus architecture -- replacing the crumbling Palmer Stadium. When orange and black tarps had to be hung to catch the falling concrete from the 1914 relic, the arrival of yet more construction cranes on this ever-sprawling campus was inevitable.
These days when the leaves turn orange and thoughts turn to cheering the Tiger 11, attention turns to . . . um . . . the stadium. 
"I don't know if the stadium has a name anymore," admitted Jason Houck, a junior from Arizona, who has gone to at least a dozen football games here.
Caitlin Fitz, a senior who is majoring in history, was stumped too.
"I have no idea," said Ms. Fitz. "They were going to say whoever donated enough money to support its cost could name it."
When the 27,000-seat stadium was in the planning stages, the overall cost was put at $45 million. And as always, the opportunity to name the complex after a generous alumnus was there for the taking: just kick in a little over half of the price tag.
In the meantime, the university borrowed money to pay for construction, getting low rates under tax-exempt privileges for university facilities. Then Princeton officials waited for a wealthy alumnus -- about as difficult a task as finding a copy of "This Side of Paradise" in the campus bookstore -- to come forward with check in hand.
They're still waiting.
Richard Spies, vice president for finance and administration, who oversaw the stadium project, thinks he knows why.
Mr. Spies said the fund-raising process usually worked the other way: a donor comes into the picture early on and finances a building or program that otherwise would not be possible.
"Most projects that are not able to attract a donor do not happen," he said. "But here we had an athletic stadium beyond repair and had to replace it."
And so the $25 million question, as the campus newspaper once put it, was born.
Alan S. Blinder, an economics professor here and a former vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, who knows his way around a dollar bill, said: "I was amazed that finding a donor was so difficult. At the time, my brother was working in the development office. I told him, 'This is going to be the easiest thing you've ever raised money for.' "
It wasn't.
While Princeton did manage to amass nearly $23 million in smaller gifts, and find a naming donor for the adjacent track, no one wanted to sign on to the biggest one of all.
Jotham Johnson, director of leadership gifts, said the university approached about a half-dozen potential donors over about four years, including at least one former football player.
Some of the alumni who were courted for the stadium project had other campus facilities named after them, Mr. Johnson said,
As Mr. Spies put it, "A lot of it is serendipity in terms of making a connection between the project and the donor, and we just didn't hit it right."
Not that everyone thinks that is a bad thing.
"I really, really do not want somebody's name on that stadium," said Stanislaw Maliszewki, the president of the Princeton Football Association.
Mr. Maliszewki, who was an all-American for Princeton in 1965, said he did not think a naming gift would be appropriate for the football program.
"All of the great stadiums in this country are named after the institutions they represent," he said.
That may be true for great football stadiums, but at Princeton, buildings have families behind them: Firestone Library; the Frist Campus Center; the Lewis-Sigler Institute for Integrative Genomics. The list goes on.
After all, Palmer Memorial Stadium was originally the gift of Edgar Palmer, class of 1903, who commissioned and donated the money for the complex in memory of his father. The Palmer family also donated the money for the Palmer Physics Laboratory, which is now part of the Frist Campus Center, the Cottage Club and later the Palmer House, an off-campus guest house.
According to the university's development office, the last major building not to attract a naming donor was the Computer Science building, completed in 1985.
To hear Van Zandt Williams, the vice president for development, tell it, the stadium did not have a major donor because the university changed its mind.
Mr. Willams explained: "It's like if you bought a Christmas gift for a friend, but decided you liked it so much that you kept it for yourself. Basically we built a stadium, which we were so proud of that we felt we'd like to keep Princeton's name associated with it in perpetuity."
Mr. Williams noted that the university had spent nearly a billion dollars on such renovations as cogeneration plants and parking garages without any donor recognition.
"For a huge amount of what the university does in the way of construction, there's no possible donor interest," he said.
But parking garages are hardly on a par with football stadiums as far as monumentality or pizazz. Princeton's new stadium, designed by Rafael Vinoly, has been warmly praised, as has the architect himself.
Gary Walters, director of athletics, said the stadium had been a boon to the football program and clearly helped recruitment. Not that it has helped the team's record. Last year it went 3-7, and it has not won an Ivy championship since 1995. 
Nonetheless, as one alumnus said, "It's a great place to spend a Saturday afternoon."
The question of the elusive $25 million donation for the stadium, the only major effort to go unnamed under Harold T. Shapiro, the former university president, brings up the larger issue of athletics and alumni giving at elite universities.
"It's an awful lot of money, and it has something to do with the fact that football doesn't really occupy the place in the university's heart that it did 50 or 60 years ago," said Mark F. Bernstein, a Princeton alumnus who recently completed a book on intercollegiate football. 
James L. Shulman, who wrote a book on college athletics, "The Game of Life: College Sports and Educational Values" (Princeton University Press, $27.95) said major contributors who donated an astounding sum of money were not particularly enthusiastic about sports.
Dr. Shulman's book, written with William G. Bowen, a former Princeton president, said that primary donors cared much more about other issues, like academics, residential life and culture on campus.
After the first year, said Mr. Walters, the athletic director, many people thought that Princeton Stadium would be a good name. "I think the name really resonates," he said.
So in 1999, the trustees decided to call it just that -- though neither they nor the development office publicized the fact that the naming was a done deal. That has led many on campus to think that it might not be the last word.
"My perception is that they'll keep looking until they find someone who wants their name on Princeton Stadium," said Harvey S. Rosen, an economics professor here. "They'll find someone sooner or later. It's a matter of being patient. There must be some alum out there who has fond memories of his football days."
For now, according to Mr. Johnson, the development office has moved on to other priorities.
Mr. Williams went so far as to say: "We're not looking."
Even if a donor surfaced, he added, Princeton would not accept the gift now. But with Princeton repaying about $2 million a year on the stadium loan, Mr. Blinder is more than a little skeptical of such bravado.
"I'd be shocked if they wouldn't accept it," he said. "I don't think they ever envisioned not being able to find someone."
Or as one campus, tour guide, tongue firmly in cheek, said: "I always tell my tours that Princeton stadium costs $45 million, but if you have $25 million just lying around in your living room, they'll consider naming it after you."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Three years ago, construction was completed on Princeton's new $45 million football stadium, top, but a major donor proved to be illusive. It replaced Palmer Stadium, which was completed in 1914 and had begun to crumble. (Laura Pedrick for The New York Times and, inset, G. Paul Burnett/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: GOOD EATING; 
In Terror's Aftermath

 BODY:
The economic impact of the World Trade Center attack has been deeply felt in the city's restaurant industry. Tourism is down and many New Yorkers have been too upset to dine out.
 As a result, several restaurants have had to lay off employees. But many other New York restaurants have gone to extraordinary measures to help feed the rescue workers by delivering food to the trade center site, and some have even set up on-site cooking facilities. 
 Here are some restaurants that are offering specials to entice diners back:

AVENUE
(212) 579-3194; 520 Columbus Avenue (85th Street); $$; $25 and Under: 7/29/98.
Avenue offers a French-American hybrid menu and with crisp, efficient service. On Monday nights, Avenue is giving a 50 percent discount on any bottle of wine with dinner.

CAPSOUTO FRERES
(212) 966-4900; 451 Washington Street (Watts Street); $$$; Review: 3/21/97.
Capsouto Freres was a TriBeCa pioneer, moving into a fine old 1891 landmark building long before the area became chic. Capsouto is one of several restaurants offering a special $29.95 "I Love New York" menu. Menu selections include terrine Provencal; roasted duck with cassis and ginger; and banana profiterole with butterscotch sauce.

FLEUR DE SEL **
Rating: two stars
(212) 460-9100; 5 East 20th Street (near Fifth Avenue); $$$$; Review: 12/13/00.
Who doesn't pine for that little neighborhood restaurant, tucked away on a side street, where the lighting is subdued, the chef is French and the food is terrific? Well, here it is. Cyril Renaud, the chef and owner, is offering a special three-course lunch menu for $20.

LENOX ROOM **
Rating: two stars
(212) 772-0404; 1278 Third Avenue (near 73rd Street); $$$; Review: 6/16/95.
On Saturday nights the Lenox Room is offering any two courses for $30, which includes a glass of wine.

MEDI *
Rating: one star
(212) 399-8888; 45 Rockefeller Plaza (50th Street); $$$$; Review: 9/19/01.
Medi, a collaboration between the legendary Roger Verge, the chef and owner of Moulin des Mougins in Provence, and Roberto Ruggeri, the president of the Bice chain, is offering an "I Love New York" dinner menu for $29.95. Among the dishes featured are minestrone, roasted king salmon and caramelized cheesecake with strawberry sauce.

WALLSE **
Rating: two stars
(212) 352-2300; 344 West 11th Street (Washington Street); $$$; Review: 9/6/00.
Kurt Gutenbrunner's appealing little Austrian restaurant, named to honor his hometown, has a relaxed neighborhood feeling and a menu devoted mostly to comfortable favorites like goulash. A four-course dinner menu of some of these favorites is offered for $35.

HEADLINE: Personal Business; 
Traumatized Workers Look for Healing on the Job

BYLINE:  By ABBY ELLIN

 BODY:
SHERYL HICKS was never the sort of person to call a doctor. If she had a major ache, she usually suffered in silence. And she most certainly would never have called her company's employee assistance program, the mechanism for receiving emotional and psychological support in the workplace, even if she did have a worry on her mind.
 "They say it's confidential, but who really knows?" asked Ms. Hicks, 55, an administrative assistant at the Atlantic Mutual Insurance Company, whose offices had been at 130 Broadway and Liberty Street, near the World Trade Center. "I wasn't going to tell them my business." 
 But then, she had never experienced anything like the terror attacks on Sept. 11. "I watched the whole thing from my 33rd-floor office window," Ms. Hicks said. 
She had never seen bodies fall from the 110-story twin towers, or planes slam into the buildings and cause them to crumble. She had never been covered with jet fuel, as she was when she fled the area, or been plagued by what she called "Technicolor flashbacks."
"Every time I talked to people they wanted details, which made it worse for me," said Ms. Hicks, who lives on Staten Island and now commutes to a temporary office in Madison, N.J. "I had so much anger about what had happened to my life and the lives of so many people and the city where I've worked for 36 years."
So when her company's human resources department referred her to Sharon Dougherty, a licensed clinical social worker, Ms. Hicks said, "I went to meet her as soon as I could."
"I was in so much pain," she added, "I'd do anything to get out of it." 
Ms. Dougherty is president of Priority Consulting, a Glen Ridge, N.J., company that helps run employee assistance programs, or E.A.P.'s, for companies. 
Ms. Hicks is one of many people who would have shunned E.A.P.'s in the past but are now taking advantage of them -- and seeing them in a new light. Typically, only 4 percent to 8 percent of eligible workers use them, according to industry data. Employees like Ms. Hicks were not only concerned about confidentiality (conversations between employees and counselors are, in fact, intended to be confidential) but also reluctant to discuss their problems with strangers.
Participation, though, is growing and it is expected to increase in the next few months, and perhaps for years to come. Many employers are depending on E.A.P. counselors to address workplace fears after the attacks, which have hurt morale, and in some cases, productivity. Past studies have also shown that E.A.P.'s have helped contain costs for workers' compensation.
E.A.P.'s were started in the early 1970's to help employees and their families deal with substance abuse and marital, family and workplace issues. The programs are now available to about 62 million Americans, through internal departments or outside consultants on contract. Dr. Richard A. Chaifetz, the chairman and chief executive of the ComPsych Corporation, an employee assistance provider based in Chicago, said that nearly all Fortune 500 companies and more than half of midsize companies had E.A.P.'s.
Within hours of the Sept. 11 attacks, telephones at E.A.P.'s across the country rang nonstop with questions from human resource managers about how to handle employee concerns. Corporate managers began bringing in counselors and organizing staff meetings and counseling sessions. While exact figures were hard to come by, the Society for Human Resource Management said that about half of the members it surveyed last week offered E.A.P. services after the attack and that nearly one in five brought counselors on site.
All employees at ESPN offices in the New York metropolitan area, for example, were given contact numbers for counselors for group or individual sessions two days after the attacks. Within 24 hours, the human resources division of PricewaterhouseCoopers received 17 requests from client companies about what their E.A.P.'s should be doing to help. The Walt Disney Company added crisis counselors to its cruise ship, Disney Magic. At Claremont Partners, a consortium of E.A.P.'s that is based in Alameda, Calif., call volume has risen 40 percent nationwide since the attacks; at ComPsych, which deployed 80 full-time counselors to New York area companies, it is up "1,000 percent," Dr. Chaifetz said.
PROFESSIONAL organizations are also offering help. The American Management Association is holding free workshops for managers and human resources professionals to address emotional reactions. The Association of Flight Attendants has started a hot line on which an E.A.P. representative provides information to members, families and friends about mental health professionals in their areas.
Other examples of assistance abound. Cigna HealthCare is making its E.A.P. services available to anyone, and the Caron Foundation, a drug and alcohol rehabilitation center in Wernersville, Pa., is contacting businesses affected most by the attacks and offering free workshops on grief management and substance abuse.
"Individuals with a history of drug and alcohol abuse are particularly vulnerable during this time, as many suffer from post-traumatic stress disorder, and this will re-stimulate it," said Wendy Caplan, a clinical social worker at the Caron Foundation. "I think we'll see a lot of relapsing; the tendency to self-medicate is strong."
Experts warn that chronic conditions, like sleeplessness, phobias and drug and alcohol addiction, will rear their heads. "People are afraid to get on elevators, go into garages, to enter tall buildings, to get out of bed and go to work," said Dr. Suzanne Gelber, the manager in charge of Claremont Partners. "Children don't want their parents to go to work. Neither do a lot of spouses. Many East Coast transplants to the West Coast feel helpless; they want to be back home.
"If people don't address their anxieties in the immediate wake of the trauma there are long-term repercussions, like loss of concentration or post-traumatic stress disorder," she added. "Companies are realizing this and are really trying to help employees cope. They had no idea the E.A.P. could serve the purpose we do."
In many instances, the programs reassure employees and managers that their feelings of anger, despair, fear and guilt are normal, that they should not feel badly if they are having difficulty functioning.
"Managers need to know what to expect," said Ms. Dougherty, who counseled a number of people in New York and New Jersey. "Many want to know when they can expect things to go back to normal, but we don't have one-size-fits-all grieving.
"People are still grieving," she added. "They're sad, anxious. Managers have to be very steady and compassionate with them, give their people a little bit of room now. You've got to let people grieve and be sad and get over it in their own way."
Joe Cohen knows what Ms. Dougherty is talking about. Mr. Cohen, 24, an account executive at the MWW Group, a public relations firm in East Rutherford, N.J., says he watched the horror unfold from his chief executive's picture window, which had a clear view of the Manhattan skyline.
"Everyone was shellshocked," he said. "When the building went down, people were screaming, crying, hugging, frantically dialing their cellphones, and trying to reach friends." Although he had never been in any kind of therapy -- "I never thought I needed to," he said -- he and 50 colleagues attended grief counseling seminars offered at MWW through Magellan Behavioral Health of Columbia, Md., which runs its E.A.P. 
"I thought I was over it, but then every so often I would hear stories about the event and I would just break down," he said. "As soon as everyone started speaking, I realized I did have issues. I talked, too, and understood the whole thing had more of an impact than I'd thought. It's a big part of my life, and it's going to be, whether I like it or not." 
In addition to offering the crisis counseling, his company has adopted more lenient policies. Donald McIver, vice president for human resources at MWW, said its bereavement policy was changed to include the deaths of friends, as well as those of family members, and the company allowed employees to take take time off to volunteer at relief organizations. They are also allowed to post volunteer information and other resources on the company e-mail system.
"We are here for our employees however they need us to be," Mr. McIver said. 
Ms. Hicks said her sessions with Ms. Dougherty were valuable. "I didn't want someone to tell me it was going to be O.K., because it's not," she said. "People who saw it on TV have a different view; we lived it. Don't tell me you understand. But Sharon listened to me and gave me some helpful pointers, like not to watch TV or listen to the radio. I still get scared when I hear loud noises -- I can't stand the sound of airplanes -- so she suggested I put on headphones and listen to music to block out unpleasant sounds. It's helped.
"I wish everyone would call any hot line," she added. "A lot of people I know are taking pills to help them cope and all they are doing is crying. But the E.A.P. is excellent."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Michael W. Kempner, chief executive of the MWW Group, a public relations firm, talked to employees about the terrorist attacks. (Frances Roberts for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
Mourn TheDead, But Not New York

BYLINE:  By TOM REDBURN

 BODY:
FROM headlines long forgotten: "New York's Last Gasp?" "Living Dangerously in New York," "Bankrupt New York: No Funds for Fun City," "Is New York City Worth Saving?"
 New York has been through tough times before. And with the blow that the terrorist attacks have delivered to an already shaky local and national economy, it is about to go through them again. 
 But amid the mourning for the dead at the World Trade Center, elegies for New York as a vital business center -- and for skyscrapers, for dense concentrations of people, for urban life in general -- are no more likely to be right this time than they were in the past. 
The city will never be the same, of course. But nothing is ever the same in a city like New York. Companies, as they have before, will re-examine where they put their headquarters. Many Wall Street offices will continue to spread beyond Lower Manhattan into other parts of the city and the surrounding region.
For the next year or so, too, the local economy is bound to shrink, jobs will be lost and government budgets will be under increasing strain.
Yet none of that should extinguish the aspiration, enterprise and hard work that truly stirs the New York urban economy. Indeed, the disaster has revealed unexpected qualities of grit, sacrifice and cooperation that, even as they fade into memory, will serve as a foundation for the rebuilding and renewal to come.
The new mood is visible everywhere. "In the subways and on streets," Julie Talen, a filmmaker who lives in SoHo, wrote in an e-mail message to friends and family, "strangers, instead of looking away in the millisecond glance that defines the New Yorker -- we hold each other's gazes, and sort of search our faces, for what we have lost, for reassurance, for simple connection."
"On the West Side Highway, spontaneous groups of New Yorkers cheer and clap and wave flags and posters -- cheering the soot-covered weary firefighters and rescuers coming out and the fresh ones going in," she continued. "It's all a new kind of New York; we're all transformed."
New York is not unique in its ability to bounce back. Following the 1992 riots in Los Angeles, which came as Southern California was reeling from an economic malaise tied largely to the shrinkage of its military contractors after the cold war, even many local boosters threw in the towel. Running for mayor, Richard Riordan described Los Angeles as a "dysfunctional city." And a Time magazine cover article asked: "Is the City of Angels Going to Hell?"
But the Northridge earthquake of 1994, instead of knocking the city out for the count, was a catalyst for the broad-based revival that was already under way. Economic growth surged throughout the late 1990's, and the city resumed its traditional role as a magnet for migrants from elsewhere in the United States and abroad.
"Racked by riots and then a devastating earthquake, many predicted that our city would become something of a modern-day Carthage," said Joel Kotkin, a Los Angeles-based author. "Yet in less than five years, we have rebounded from our nadir to a new era of metropolitan growth and self-confidence."
Miami, also torn by racial polarization, was condemned as America's most dangerous city in the 1980's and early 1990's. Yet after being hit by the most costly hurricane in history, it, too, has made a remarkable comeback.
What gives all these urban centers their resilience is their diversity and their openness to strangers. New York, Los Angeles and Miami -- like few other cities in the country -- draw their strength from outsiders. As long as new people, particularly adventurous and ambitious young people, dream of coming to places like New York, their economies will prosper.
That, of course, is what makes the World Trade Center attack such a nightmare. We ache over the absence of the twin towers, not because of the buildings that were destroyed (something much better can be built in their place), but because of the thousands of lives lost. Many of those people were just beginning their careers and their families.
New York's most recent boom would not have been so stunning without the sharp reduction in crime that occurred throughout much of the 1990's. That was true in other big cities as well. Restoring a sense of security -- this time from the threat of further terror attacks -- is therefore essential to maintaining the urban revival of recent years.
Once fear eases, though, the pull that New York has long exerted on newcomers should reassert itself. And with that, the city will rise from the ashes -- again.
