HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends; 
In Every Mind the Memory, In Every Building, a Threat

BYLINE:  By TOM ZELLER

 BODY:
MAJ. MICHAEL GEORGE is an instructor at the United States Military Academy in West Point. On what has become that Tuesday morning, shortly after 9 a.m., a fellow instructor stopped by his classroom to suggest that Major George and his students -- like the rising tide of other Americans who were snapping on televisions to find Manhattan ablaze -- take a look at CNN. 
 "Nobody said a word for the first five minutes," Major George recalled of his dozen or so cadets. "Our reaction was not too different from that of most Americans, I guess. There was a lot of shock, anger, emotions." 
 Unlike most Americans, however, Major George switched off the TV after 10 minutes, and the class returned to the topic it had discussed twice a week since the beginning of the semester: national security. 
 Nearly three weeks after the terrorist attack that took thousands of lives and destroyed an unflagging sense of safeness from such things, most Americans have joined the discussion on national security, or its freshly minted variant, homeland security. From subway platforms to schoolyard parking lots; in building lobbies and on the long, now so obviously suspended spans of bridges; from economy class to the cockpit, the free world is contemplating just where it wants to be on the freedom-fear continuum. The tilt is now toward fear. 
 Consider that although a poll conducted by the Pew Research Center in the days following the attack found that 57 percent of Americans "clearly reject the establishment of internment camps to round up legal immigrants from hostile nations," a full 29 percent said it wasn't such a bad idea. The poll also indicated that 70 percent of Americans wouldn't mind being required to "carry a national identity card at all times to show to a police officer on request."
 Armed marshals are quietly boarding commercial flights, the Professional Gun Retailers Association has reported a jump in handgun sales and government buildings around the nation have thrown up barricades. 
 But how long can such a heightened state of alert be maintained? And how far can it go? 
 "Anything can be done and it can get very, very expensive," said James Russell, a writer and architect specializing in security design. "But in the end, you're always just responding to the last technique, not the next one." So, for instance, the nation's airport security guards became adept at recognizing the shadow of a gun in the geometric thicket of an X-ray screen, but they weren't even looking for box cutters. Knives and other sharp objects are now being filtered out of the air, but what about ?
 "The nation is stunned partly because it's built on the belief that perfectibility is possible -- that with every dollar spent on security, we can get closer to realizing a kind of perfection, Mr. Russell said. But the idea that airplanes could be hijacked and flown into the World Trade Center expands the possibilities to the infinite, and how can we prepare for that?"
 Which may well be the question that, according to the Pew poll, is keeping so many Americans up at night, distracted from their jobs and supportive of the national scramble to keep one step ahead of the next attack -- and the next.

GRAPHIC: Chart/Diagrams: "Finding Insecurity in Every Walk of Life"National ID cards can keep track of your whereabouts. Digital cameras can take a scan of your face and compare it with a database of known troublemakers. Your pilot may be carrying a gun. Some of it is fantasy. Some of it is already real. All of it is being discussed. An overview: PLANESIdeas for making aircraft less vulnerable to hijackers --and less deadly when they crash -- were on the table long before the attacks of Sept. 11. But recent events have given old ideas new life. The Craft ItselfThe terrorist attacks were particularly deadly because of the enormous amount of jet fuel on board the hijacked aircraft. This may call for various levels of redesign for commercial planes. The CockpitMany analysts have suggested sealing the cockpit and arming pilots. Issues of pressure differentials between the cabin and the cockpit will need to be overcome, but some change in cockpit access is likely. AIRPORTSThere may be limited access to curbside check-ins for some time. It remains banned at many airports. National Guard troops are likely to be visible both inside and outside the facility. Some passengers may be profiled based on how they bought their ticket, where they are going and how often they tend to fly. Some have argued for greater consideration of body lift planes, which make use of the craft's body to help generate lift, permitting use of smaller engines and less fuel. The CabinA new generation of well-armed air marshals will be quietly slipping onto flights. And passengers might no longer be permitted to change seats freely, making identification of troublemakers easier. The FuelHigh flashpoint fuels may be explored, because they burn less readily in crashes. SCHOOLS AND HOSPITALSSchools and hospitals may become terrorist targets. Schools may need to develop new drills that will take into consideration the special circumstances of a terrorist attack, and develop tighter access controls with identity cards. Both hospitals and schools may need to consider redesigns that limit the proximity of vehicles to the main buildings. HIGH-SECURITY BUILDINGSEmbassies have long been a favorite target for attack and may need to be further retrofitted for future attacks. SECURE-ACCESSPASSES COULD TRACK EMPLOYEES AND BE LINKED TO SPECIFIC PIECES OF EQUIPMENT AND VEHICLES OFFICE BUILDINGSOffice workers are already experiencing a level of security they may not be accustomed to and things may become more restricted as technology improves and the threat of biological and chemical attacks looms. Overhauled systemsAir intakes and exhausts are often accessible from outside and are prone to tampering. Some vents may need to be relocated, and others may need to be fitted with motion detectors to prevent tampering. STADIUMS, LARGE EVENT VENUESPublic entertainment facilities are likely to become heavily restricted. Elimination of bags and backpacks has already been put in place in some stadiums. Police barricades may be used to keep traffic from getting near the facility, and the number of entry points may be reduced. Flyover advertising planes and other aircraft may be permanently restricted, and digital cameras may scan the crowd for faces of known suspects. HIGHWAYS AND ROADSLarge cities have already implemented more restrictive traffic controls. Random searches and police checkpoints may be used not just for special events, but as a means of monitoring vehicle movements in and out of vulnerable areas. SMALL PLANESCrop dusters might be used to spread harmful agents and have been grounded. In the long term, access to small airfields will be more heavily restricted. NUCLEAR FACILITIESWatchdog groups have called for deployment of military troops and antiaircraft defenses to guard the nation's nuclear power plants. PUBLIC TRANSITHigh vulnerability to chemical and biological attack may call for tighter screening of employees, more surveillance cameras and greater police presence. HEADLINE: A Monument to the Towers of Pain and Might; 
Low-Income Workers

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 In a Sept. 23 editorial, you correctly point out that the terrorist attacks have stolen or threatened the jobs of thousands of low-income workers in New York City and that helping them should be a top priority. 
 A redevelopment strategy should encompass workers' needs and focus on creating a diverse and vibrant local economy, wherein industries provide good jobs that offer living wages and health benefits to every worker. 
Redevelopment should also prioritize access to mass transit and affordable housing for everyone who works in Lower Manhattan.
Your Sept. 24 editorial presented a redevelopment strategy that won't help workers. Giving tax credits and other subsidies to companies without requiring that they create good jobs will only drain precious resources from the city coffers.

HEATHER BOUSHEY
Washington, Sept. 28, 2001

The writer is an economist at the Economic Policy Institute.

HEADLINE: A Monument to the Towers of Pain and Might; 
Rethinking Transit

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 As New York City requires cars to carry more than one passenger (front page, Sept. 26), transportation is becoming more difficult. But there is one solution that will make transportation easier in the city. 
This is to increase the number of cabs. If the city issued more medallions, transportation would be easier, and commuters would be more willing to use mass transit. 
 As many in the city suffer from the tragedy and its aftermath, it is appropriate to ask the owners of taxi medallions to bear their share. The burden of a reduced-value medallion could be lessened if the new medallions were issued to those already owning medallions, but in any event, an increase in the number of medallions could reduce the costs of more difficult transportation.

PAUL H. RUBIN
Atlanta, Sept. 27, 2001

The writer is an economics professor at Emory University.

HEADLINE: Investing; 
Forecasters Try to Assess the Terror Factor

BYLINE:  By JOANNE LEGOMSKY

 BODY:
SENDHIL MULLAINATHAN, an economics professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, has spent the last two weeks plugging worst-case possibilities into his economic and market forecasts.
 Even if there are no further terrorist incidents, he is concerned that just a minor change in the outlook of consumers and investors could wreak havoc with the economy and drive down the price of stocks. 
 "Two hundred fifty million people are going through the same grieving process," he said. "How long does it take the human mind to get back to normal?"
Economists, market strategists and money managers are struggling to revise their forecasts of stock market returns in the wake of the Sept. 11 attacks. Most are trying to analyze not only the likelihood of protracted disruptions of financial markets, but also the chance that the trauma has caused huge changes in investor attitudes. As a result, current forecasts are even fuzzier than usual, ranging from a quick return to robust economic and stock market growth to a fundamental scaling back of long-term expectations. At the same time, market analysts are aiming to identify sectors that are likely to prosper despite the turmoil. 
Edward Yardeni, the chief investment strategist at Deutsche Banc Alex. Brown, said that he normally expects the stock market to anticipate economic shifts, but that may not be the case this time. Investors have probably not grasped how badly the attacks will hurt corporate profits, he said. Once companies report earnings for the third quarter, he said, investors may grow more skittish.
Although he expects the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index to end the year at roughly its current level, he said that there was a chance it could fall an additional 15 percent this year if investors were frightened by the coming earnings decline.
He has lowered his 2001 forecast for operating earnings for the S.& P. 500 to $40 a share from $45 before the attack. But he left his 2002 estimate unchanged, at $55. In his view, the market is likely to bottom around March 2002 and then rebound significantly. He expects a 20 percent gain for the S.& P. 500 next year.
Mr. Yardeni is telling clients to put relatively little money into technology shares, believing that businesses will restrict capital spending for technology improvements.
"We're reassessing our outlook, asking ourselves 'What do we know for sure?' " he said. "We know, for example, that aging baby boomers will drive long-term demand for health care services and equipment." So he is emphasizing health care stocks.
Hugh A. Johnson, the chief investment officer at the First Albany Corporation, expects subpar stock returns through 2005. He said he believes that stocks will return an average of 8 percent a year in the period, more than two percentage points above his forecast for 10-year Treasuries. By contrast, Mr. Johnson said, stocks outperformed bonds by an average of 17 percentage points a year from 1995 through 1999.
His outlook reflects his expectation of "uninspiring growth for the economy" in the next several years, he said, adding that all forecasts warrant some skepticism because of the current uncertainties.
After long bull markets in the 1980's and 1990's, Kevin A. Hassett and James K. Glassman, co-authors of "Dow 36,000," argued in 1999 that investors had become so comfortable with owning stocks and so convinced that stocks would outperform bonds that investors would bid up their price. At the time, they expected the Dow to go as high as 36,000.
Mr. Hassett remains bullish on stocks. "When things return to normal," he said, "investors will be rewarded for holding stocks, especially on an after-tax basis." He added that although bonds might outperform stocks in the near term, stocks were likely to more than offset any shortfall in one good year.
Jeremy J. Siegel of the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania, who described the superior long-term performance of stocks in "Stocks for the Long Run," says he does not expect stocks to outpace bonds by much in the future. Stocks will return five to seven percentage points a year above inflation over the next 20 to 30 years, versus a spread of two to three percentage points for 10-year Treasuries, he said. 
"Before, people realized that stocks were undervalued assets over long periods of time," he said. "Now they're recognizing that long-term returns may not be as good."
Mr. Siegel expects bond returns over the same period, adjusted for inflation, to be higher than in the past, noting that bondholders were penalized by the unanticipated high inflation of the 1970's.
Some strategists say short-term expectations for stocks are so uncertain that additional investments may not be justified now. "Investors should have lower return objectives for stocks than prevailed in the late 1990's," said Thomas C. Van Leuven, an equity market strategist at J. P. Morgan Chase. 
While he said he still viewed the stock market as a good long-term investment, he urged caution.
Recent history may provide insight into short-term market conditions. Joseph J. Mezrich, quantitative strategist at Morgan Stanley, said that in previous crises -- the onset of World War II, the Cuban missile crisis, the oil shocks of the 1970's and the Persian Gulf war -- the upheaval initially left investors more risk-averse.
Historically, he said, stock valuations rose when the government resolved a problem decisively; they remained low during longer crises, like the Arab oil embargo of 1973-74.
Steve Galbraith, United States equity strategist at Morgan Stanley, saw a bright spot amid the turmoil. He said that in a period of low earnings, companies were more inclined to improve profit margins and capital efficiency, which should eventually bolster returns.
Mr. Galbraith advises investors to emphasize sectors and companies with predictable earnings prospects. He recommends health care stocks like Abbott Laboratories, Bristol-Myers Squibb, Schering-Plough, Merck and Guidant; cable companies like Charter Communications and Cox Communications; regional telephone companies like Verizon Communications and SBC Communications; and financial stocks that are less sensitive to capital markets, like Fannie Mae and Fifth Third Bancorp.
SOME analysts and money managers are wagering that a strong recovery is imminent. "Now is the time to be adding to equity positions," said Thomas M. Galvin, chief investment officer at Credit Suisse First Boston. "It's too late to be bearish."
Mr. Galvin says he thinks that the S.& P. 500 will finish the year 10 to 15 percent higher, at 1,100 to 1,150, and rise to 1,375 in 2002. He recommends that investors gradually put some money into growth areas such as health care; among his favorites are Amgen and King Pharmaceuticals. He particularly favors consumer-oriented companies like Reebok International and Walt Disney and basic materials companies like Nucor, the specialty steel maker. Other choices are Ensco International and Varco International, energy service companies; and Nokia and Veritas Software, in the technology sector.
S. Basu Mullick, manager of the $1.9 billion Neuberger Berman Partners, a value-oriented fund, said he was "very optimistic about the speed and quality of the recovery." He recommended Carnival, the cruise line company, as well as Hilton Hotels and Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide. On a longer-term basis, he likes Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, Merrill Lynch and the Williams Companies, an energy business.
Still, Mr. Mullainathan, of M.I.T., said the market was grossly overvalued before the attacks. A behavioral economist who thinks investors' decisions reflect emotional factors as well as rational ones, he said investors had propped up share prices with their optimism. Based on corporate profits, he said, stocks should have been much lower.
Robert J. Shiller, a Yale behavioral economist argued in his bleak, admonitory book, "Irrational Exuberance," that the 1990's stock market boom was a bubble that would inevitably burst. The collapse of stocks last year, combined with the recent attacks, may be enough, in his view, to change investor attitudes for a generation.
"It could be the beginning of a downward spiral or a negative bubble," he said. By way of perspective, Mr. Shiller said that the price-to-earnings ratio of the S.& P. 500, now 28, is roughly double its historical average. If it reverted to traditional levels, prices would be cut in half.
One thing seems clear. The chaos has had a humbling effect on many market prognosticators.
Richard H. Thaler, a professor of economics and behavioral science at the University of Chicago Graduate School of Business, said he had no clue what consumers would do in the current environment. "It's certainly possible, however, that the market will go into a prolonged funk," he said. "The biggest thing is not to overstate the importance of what happened."

SECTION: Section 3; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 9

LENGTH: 727 words

HEADLINE: Investing; 
Focused on Basics, Dollar Stores May Show Strength

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH KELLEHER

 BODY:
MOST retailers fear that consumers are now unwilling to spend freely, but dollar stores, which sell household staples like toothpaste and laundry detergent, appear well positioned for a difficult economy.
 Usually found in small towns and urban neighborhoods, dollar stores cater to low-income consumers. Some chains put the same price on all products -- $1 or 99 cents -- while others use varying, though still low, prices throughout the store. They stock products that need frequent replenishment. 
 "There's a change in consumers' attitudes," said Mark Miller, an analyst at William Blair & Company, an investment firm in Chicago. "They're saying, 'Maybe I'll focus on necessities, buy the basics.' " 
Michael Niemira, an economist at Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi Ltd. in New York, said, "Cheap stuff is where the demand is now."
The major publicly traded companies -- Family Dollar Stores, Dollar General, Dollar Tree Stores, Fred's Inc. and 99 Cents Only Stores -- have built small stores close to lower-income neighborhoods in rural areas and small cities far from New York and Washington. 
By relying on manufacturers' close outs, dollar stores can offer prices that are competitive with those of big chains. A survey last year by Blair shows prices at Dollar General and Family Dollar hovering just below Wal-Mart's and significantly below those of grocery stores and drugstores. A 175-count box of Kleenex tissues cost $1 at Dollar General and Family Dollar, $1.16 at Wal-Mart, $1.25 at Jewel-Osco and $1.49 at Walgreens, the survey said.
"When you've got small-store convenience combined with sharp pricing, you've got an attractive position," Mr. Miller said.
Dan Barry, an analyst at Merrill Lynch, said the 20 percent growth pace of 99 Cents Only Stores, based in Commerce, Calif., made it a good bet. The chain is starting from a small base -- 114 stores in California, Arizona and Nevada.
Other chains in the sector are also growing at double-digit rates, Mr. Barry said. "They're growing like an ink spot, opening stores in nearby markets," he added.
For 1999 and 2000, Family Dollar Stores, based in Charlotte, N.C., and Dollar General, in Goodlettsville, Tenn., each had an average return on capital of 15.4 percent, with Fred's Inc., of Memphis, at 9.3 percent, Mr. Miller said. In that period, a dozen major department stores averaged 7.5 percent. 
The combination of that high return on capital and earnings growth of 10 percent in the last 12 months makes Family Dollar's stock attractive, Mr. Miller said. It now trades at $27.52.
Dollar General's stock is a story of high risk and potential high return. After the company announced accounting irregularities in April, the shares plunged to $17 from $23. On Sept. 21, the firm announced that it was firing its auditor, Deloitte & Touche, and the stock plunged again, to $11.25 from $14.77. It closed on Friday at $11.70.
But Mark Mandel, an analyst at SunTrust Robinson Humphrey in New York, said the business is sound. Same-store sales, those for stores open at least a year, rose 8.4 percent in June, 6.6 percent in July and 6.7 percent in August. Mr. Mandel recommended buying Dollar General shares in stages.
"If it jumps, you bought some, and if it takes a hit, you didn't put all your money into it," he said.
Dollar Tree, based in Chesapeake, Va., has 1,900 stores, blanketing the coasts, and sells all products for $1. Because 20 percent of its stores are in malls, where sales have been sluggish, and because it stocks nonessential products, like party goods, Dollar Tree's sales have been weak, analysts say. 
Erica Robb, a spokeswoman for the company, says it is shifting its focus to consumer staples and leaving malls as leases come up for renewal.
Mr. Barry said that when the economy rebounds, Dollar Tree may well have large increases in sales and a substantial increase in its stock value. 
Fred's, with about 400 stores in the Southeast, offers full-service pharmacies. It earned 98 cents a share in the year ended Jan. 29; the forecast for this fiscal year is $1.15 a share. The stock now trades at $26.20.
Jerry Shore, the chief financial officer of Fred's, declined to comment on the company's stock, but said, "We are very confident on the future of our industry."
As Eric Schiffer, president of 99 Cents Only, put it, "If there's any store format that is recession-resistant, ours is."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE STREETS; 
Streets of Huge Pakistan City Seethe With Hatred of U.S.

BYLINE:  By RICK BRAGG

DATELINE: KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 29 

 BODY:
In a giant city of whirling contradictions, of donkey carts that share choking traffic with gleaming S.U.V.'s, of emaciated one-legged beggars and billboards for running shoes, a three-story banner fluttered from a building in the Azizabad neighborhood, calling for peace, for an end to terrorism, for calm. It is the government's position, the moderate one, and it vanishes from Karachi almost around the corner. 
 In every direction in this city of 12 million people, the largest city in a nation that has become a crucial but brittle ally in the United States' war on terrorism, there are cries and signs for Osama bin Laden, for the Taliban, for holy war. 
 In the downtown, not far from a KFC restaurant, a young man stood in traffic to sell color copies of Mr. bin Laden's picture. Near the teeming port on the Arabian Sea, someone had used a paintbrush to crudely spell out "CRUSH AMERICA" in foot-high black letters. 
Outside the largest Islamic seminary in Pakistan, Jamiat-tul-Islamia, boys shouted "Death to America" and laughed, as though it were a game, and mechanics warned that they would put down their wrenches and hammers and answer their mullahs' calls for jihad when the first American bomb hits the first grain of Afghan sand.
This is one of the world's largest cities, but the language people use to discuss the current confrontation is as old as the desert. "Fourteen hundred years ago, infidels threw stones and garbage on our prophet," said Mustafa Kamal Uddin, 32, a body-and-fender man. Yet Allah, he said, was merciful and did not strike at those who offended him. Holy wars, he said, come about only when Allah has no other way to maintain justice, times like now. "That is why Allah took out his sword."
Karachi, with a history of political turmoil and corruption that goes back to the founding of modern Pakistan in 1947, has long been considered one of the world's most dangerous cities, before most people had ever heard of Osama bin Laden. Now, there is a feeling of dread in some and seething anger in others. In Karachi, the economic heart of Pakistan, with its many, many Dunkin' Donuts and McDonald's, religion may rule the future.
There are many wealthy and middle-class Pakistanis here, people who support the alliance with the United States, who fear a rise in fundamentalist religion that, they say, could transform their country.
But there seem to be many more in Karachi who would welcome it, who in choosing sides would choose Mr. bin Laden in a heartbeat, because they see him as a hero of Islam.
"We don't want to become Afghanistan, and we think Pakistan will become like Afghanistan," said Nasreen Jalil, a former senator who lives in Karachi and is a member of the powerful Muttahida Qaumi Movement. 
Politics here has been an often bloody process. But the standoff between the United States and the Taliban could have a far more drastic influence than any assassination or bombing in the past.
Even Ms. Jalil opposes American military action because of what could happen here if it is bungled. 
"From the mosques, they are saying that this is a war on Islam," she said. "They think bin Laden is a symbol of Islam. It's mostly just talk, but peoples' emotions are heightened, and it could take a different turn. The people are not thinking. In the name of religion, they become oblivious to everything else." 
With many high-ranking officers in the military aligned with the fundamentalists in this city -- and in the country that stretches northward from its port -- there seems little doubt who would win if a majority of the population adopts the fundamentalists' argument that this is a war between Islam and Christianity. "I don't know who would be able to control it," Ms. Jalil said. "We mustn't go back to the Stone Age."
Newspapers in Karachi have promised yet more "Death to America," and warned that the attacks in New York and Washington were a trick by the Jews to plunge the United States and Islam into war.
Some on the streets said they were sorry for the Americans, but said the United States would only cause more tragedy by killing or arresting Mr. bin Laden without proof. Few people here believe that the United States has any proof and few would believe any proof submitted, anyway.
Mention dead firemen, and they counter with dead teenagers shot to death in Palestine. Mention dead civilians in the World Trade Center, and they speak of children killed by American bombs in air strikes on Afghanistan and Iraq. 
"They are terrified, and we are also terrified," said Dr. Abdurrazzak Sikander, principal of the Jamiat-tul-Islamia seminary in the Binori Town section, which draws students from many Islamic countries but especially from Pakistan and Afghanistan. 
The United States has demonized Islam, Dr. Sikander said. "We give respect to Jesus, to Moses -- we even name our daughters after Mary," he said. But after the World Trade Center disaster, the United States has persecuted many followers of Islam, for no other reason than their facial hair, he said. "Everyone with a beard is called a terrorist," he said.
Like others here, he believes that the United States has not produced proof of guilt in the attacks. 
If the mastermind behind the attacks is Mr. bin Laden, the United States must share the blame, people here said. It was the United States' presence in Saudi Arabia, they argue, that created Mr. bin Laden.
"But he didn't do anything," said Muhammad Khalid, who was praying at the seminary. Like many here, he reduces the confrontation to a political move by the United States to justify attacking Islam. "Bin Laden is Islam," said Mr. Khalid. "He represents Islam. Muslims are not in fear. They are all over the world."
Inside the quiet grounds of the seminary, Mufti Imdad Ullah said there were only two ways to deal with an enemy.
"Dialogue, or eliminate your opponent," he said. But even if you kill your enemy, he warned, "his race will remain, his people will remain."
At the headquarters of the Muttahida Qaumi Movement, Ms. Jalil, the former senator, contemplated a Karachi under a Taliban-like rule, where women have no rights.
She carefully covered her head before she was photographed. "Or they will say I am not a good Muslim," she said.
Everyone here seems to have a strong opinion about the United States, Pakistan, Afghanistan, the Taliban, Mr. bin Laden, all of it -- all, it seems, except a young man named Shahid who is selling color copies of Mr. bin Laden's photograph. He is asked if he is a follower of the man. 
"No," he said, "I'm just selling him."

HEADLINE: The 90's Wars 

BYLINE:  By Jane Perlez; Jane Perlez is the chief diplomatic correspondent of The Times.

 BODY:
 WAR IN A TIME OF PEACE
Bush, Clinton, and the Generals.
By David Halberstam.
543 pp. New York:
Scribner. $28.
 In "War in a Time of Peace," David Halberstam carves out an ambitious agenda: to describe how former President Bill Clinton and, to a lesser extent, the first President George Bush dealt with the foreign policy challenges of the 1990's. Halberstam's central thesis is damning. In an era when Americans were feeling fat and happy at home, he says, the United States at the zenith of its power was reluctant to commit itself abroad. Halberstam shrewdly writes that for Clinton, the brilliant politician with his finger always on the people's pulse, foreign policy was "an inconvenience, something that might pull him away from his primary job at hand -- domestic issues, above all the economy."
It is almost 30 years since Halberstam demystified another foreign policy establishment in "The Best and the Brightest," explaining how the hubris of those men got the United States into the Vietnam War, the most bitter of conflicts. His latest work, a sprawling tapestry of exquisite bottom-up reporting and powerful vignettes, is conceived as a bookend to that earlier volume. Many of the people at the White House, State Department and Pentagon who dealt with Bosnia, Somalia, Rwanda, Haiti and finally Kosovo were personally touched one way or another by the Vietnam War, Halberstam explains. Some, like Clinton, avoided the draft. Others, like two of his major foreign policy spokesmen, Anthony Lake and Richard C. Holbrooke, were young diplomats in Saigon. Still others, like Colin L. Powell and Wesley K. Clark, served in the military. By the 1990's these were the people on top of the heap, conducting policy and mindful always of that earlier disaster. Still, Halberstam is smart enough to avoid concluding that the memory of Vietnam drove the major military decisions of the Clinton administration or, as it turned out in some cases, the nondecisions.
Halberstam's narrative opens with what many Americans considered the successful outcome of the Persian Gulf war. He points out that President Bush got little electoral bounce from that first high-tech, low-casualty victory, and that this was a lesson Clinton never forgot. Halberstam quickly moves on to Bosnia, a different kind of conflict. That war, he says, tested the United States' commitment to moral goals in its foreign policy rather than simply to considerations of national security. Bosnia, Halberstam writes, created a new political constituency in America, one "driven by a memory that connected these events to the atrocities of the Nazis and therefore demanded that other nations ask themselves what their larger purpose was."
Halberstam then proceeds to show that Washington preferred not to think about larger purposes, and that the new political constituency he describes lacked clout. In one chilling example, he recounts how Richard Johnson, the State Department desk officer for the Balkans in the spring of 1992, went to a special interagency briefing where he saw satellite pictures of Serbian artillery and antiaircraft emplacements above Sarajevo. The briefing officer, who had been through the gulf war, expressed surprise at how brazen the gun positions were. When Johnson asked how difficult it would be to take them out, the answer was simple: a day and a half of American air attacks. Johnson, Halberstam reports, dutifully wrote a one-page memo to a superior two ranks above him. He heard nothing. And when he finally did get a response, he was rapped on the knuckles for daring to send the memo on high, and for venturing into territory that belonged to the military. 
Similarly, Halberstam says, the senior echelons of the State Department did not want to know about Serbian atrocities: the systematic execution of Muslim leaders, the detention of Muslim men in concentration camps, the wholesale rape of Muslim women. As Washington dithered over the definition of genocide, Slobodan Milosevic, the Serbian president, was allowed to proceed apace in a war that killed more than 200,000 people. 
And it was not just the American government that didn't want to know. In a fitting digression on a subject he well understands from writing "The Powers That Be," his book on the media barons, Halberstam illustrates how the Clinton administration was abetted by the television networks in its hear-no-evil, see-no-evil foreign policy. Just as newspapers were exposing the Serbian atrocities, and an upstart (but not widely watched) television outfit, CNN, was covering them, experienced network war correspondents languished in their expensive European bureaus, unable to get pocket change from their superiors to travel to Bosnia. All this was of a piece with Clinton's recognition that the American people were not eager to know about the persecution of minorities abroad. 
While the main foreign policy event of the book is the violent disintegration of the former Yugoslavia, Halberstam also covers Somalia, Rwanda and Haiti. Of these three, he is best on Somalia, appreciating that the idea of turning a swath of desert inhabited by proud warrior nomads into an emerging democracy with the help of American troops was a lost cause from the start. Ambassador Robert Oakley, dispatched to Somalia as a sort of proconsul by Bush during the famine and then on hand later for a clean-up operation under Clinton, knew from his Vietnam experience that "nation-building imposed in the third world at gunpoint" made no sense. Halberstam agrees. The main proponent for the democracy project in Somalia was Madeleine K. Albright, then the United States representative at the United Nations and one of the senior officials without Vietnam experience. 
In his final chapters Halberstam turns to Kosovo, the immaculate air war conducted from altitudes of 15,000 feet. Here, he expands on one of his important themes: the military's aversion to intervening in smaller wars and ethnic conflicts that posed little threat to American power. Compounding the difficulties presented by the Pentagon was the fact that Clinton was ill at ease with his senior military officers, and they with him. Halberstam notes that Powell, who was chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff for the first nine months of Clinton's tenure and the most resistant of military interventionists, intimidated the new president. (Did Powell play a subtle game with Clinton? Halberstam reports that it was Powell who gave Clinton "Balkan Ghosts," by Robert Kaplan, the book that Clinton often cited as a persuasive reason for not intervening in Bosnia.) 
Halberstam skillfully covers the already well-reported clashes between Secretary of Defense William Cohen and the commander of NATO forces, General Clark, over the use of ground troops in Kosovo. But he underplays a result of not using those troops: that Milosevic was emboldened to send some 40,000 Serbian forces into Kosovo for ethnic cleansing, leading to the expulsion of nearly a million Albanians. 
Halberstam is never a strident writer, but he does tend to overwrite, sometimes to the point of repetition. And the purr of his narrative while describing bureaucratic disputes in Washington sometimes masks the devastating effects of those squabbles in the field. The insider gossip, obviously garnered from gold-plated sources (but not from Clinton, who even out of office declined to see him), is always entertaining. Picture Vernon Jordan, brought in by President-elect Clinton to sharpen up the 1992 transition, using locker room language to tell the ineffably polite Warren Christopher, who wants to be secretary of state but is too timid to ask, that he has one last chance to put his name forward. At the same time, Halberstam can be maddeningly generous. He tends to balance the motives and actions of people in power rather than daring to hold them accountable. He agrees, for example, with Albright's contention that she was never fully accepted by her peers in the Clinton administration because she was a woman. Who knows the truth, but surely there were other factors as well. And he tosses a big bouquet to Holbrooke (with whom he acknowledges in his notes a "warm friendship"), saying that after Holbrooke's stint as United Nations representative he "emerged as something of a star, and the role was becoming to him."
In a way, "War in a Time of Peace" will be an interesting test case for Americans. Over the past decade Americans were absorbed in themselves. Now that foreign affairs have come home to the United States in the most crushing of ways, are they ready to read an account of foreign policy and its makers by one of the most astute writers in the trade? If they want to learn from the past decade, they should. If they want to think seriously about the future, they must.

HEADLINE: OFF OFF FIFTH; 
Nothing Chapeau Is Alien to Her

BYLINE:  By RUTH LA FERLA

 BODY:
FUR trappers, tulle-swathed toques, floppy J-Lo fedoras -- hats of every ilk and shape beguile Eugenia Kim. On Wednesday afternoon Ms. Kim, a hat designer, prowled Archangel Antiques, a purveyor of vintage clothing and accessories at 334 East Ninth Street in Manhattan, poking into nooks and alcoves in search of the whimsical shapes that inspire her designs.
 Like a toddler in a candy shop, Ms. Kim, who makes and sells hats at her store on East Fourth Street, careered from shelf to shelf, sampling and slipping on her own eccentric favorites. Within minutes, she had tried and discarded a brocade turban, a rabbit felt tricorn, a straw sailor hat and a taupe felt beret, finally settling on a black lacquered straw cocktail hat of 1940's provenance, to which she attached a Bakelite cherry brooch. 
 "So much black, you need a little touch of color," Ms. Kim said, alluding less to the hat than to the fall fashion collections, which she found somber and badly in need of the whimsy that only a hat can provide.
It's a hat year, as Ms. Kim well knows. There's no better time to scour New York's vintage stores for ideas and inspiration, and she is not the first to have done so. Style-setting celebrities like Jennifer Lopez and Nicole Kidman have been quick to make hats a raffish fashion insignia, wearing them everywhere and feeding a frenzy for floppy fedoras, uptight pillboxes and insouciant Dorothy Parker cloches, a favorite also of Ms. Kim. 
Variations on vintage themes proliferate these days on runways, in fashion ads and on store counters. Come next month, they will also be showcased in a raft of glossy magazines, like Vibe and Vogue, arriving not a moment to soon, as far as Ms. Kim is concerned.
"I was thinking that hats used to be an extraneous part of fashion," she said. No longer. "With fashion changing so little from season to season, kind of moving along on a continuum," hats, she noted, inject a welcome dose of novelty.
"In a recession," she added, "you could say hats are essential. You might not buy a lot of clothes, so a hat or two makes an instant and affordable wardrobe pick-me-up." 
"They can also be a political statement," she said, only half in jest, fingering a daisy trim from the 60's embroidered in red, white and blue. "You could use this as a headband," Ms. Kim suggested, promptly winding a length around her crown. "To me this says peace, love and patriotism." 
Moreover, hats can be infinitely flattering. "They're like shoes," she said. "You might not be able to fit into Kate Moss's dresses, but you can fit into her hats."
Ms. Kim, whose personal signature lately is a pink leather newsboy cap she wears six days a week, thinks of hats as a cosmetic. 
"I have no cheekbones, and I never learned to use eyeliner," she said. "A hat accents things that I don't have."
To make her point she put on a feathered cocktail hat -- the sort Grace Kelly might have worn -- and voila, instant contours. Next she slid on a fedora, tilted at a rakish angle. "I like showcasing one eye, like a monocle," Ms. Kim said with a laugh. 
Exhausting Archangel's quirky stock, she moved on to Anna, another vintage fashion and accessories shop, at 150 East Third. Her mission was to find designs she considers almost universally flattering. She was instantly smitten by a patchwork rabbit fur hat, a 60's relic that brought Julie Christie to mind. 
"This hat is really gorgeous," Ms. Kim exclaimed. "It has a little bit of height, it brings your face upward and makes almost everyone look like Audrey Hepburn." 
Fur hats, the romantic Zhivago types prevalent on the runways last spring, are staples in Ms. Kim's winter line. But other looks attract her, too. No hat, in fact, is too outrageous or perverse to escape her radar. Updating vintage style is mostly a matter of details, she said, emphasizing the point by placing a prim pillbox on her head. It was just the sort of thing she renders witty in her collection by adding feline features to the crown.
When wearing a hat, Ms. Kim advised, always consider the context. Never be literal, as in accenting a cocktail dress with a Schiaparelli toque. Wear the hat instead, she suggested, with a rock concert T-shirt, a pair of jeans and high-heeled boots. "You'll be the downtown version of a lady."
Articles in the Off Off Fifth series focus on stores and shopping expeditions that are out of the ordinary.

HEADLINE: FIVE QUESTIONS for MARILYN CARLSON NELSON; 
Now Make the Traveler Want to Travel

BYLINE:  By JULIE FLAHERTY

 BODY:
MARILYN CARLSON NELSON, the chairwoman and chief executive of the Carlson Companies, parent of the Radisson hotel chain and the Carlson Wagonlit travel agency chain, was among a group of travel executives who met last week with Donald L. Evans, the commerce secretary, to seek relief from the travel crisis caused by the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.
 Though the airline industry has won a multibillion-dollar rescue package from Congress, the travel and tourism industry has its own relief request that includes tax incentives for travelers and expanded loans for small businesses like travel agencies. Mrs. Nelson spoke in a telephone interview on Thursday. JULIE FLAHERTY 

Q. How will financial inducements help if people fear terrorism?

A. The federal government is moving very quickly on safety and security issues. The very fact that the government will give incentives to people to travel has the next step of assuring them that it is O.K. to travel. We have Transportation Secretary Norman Y. Mineta and others traveling on commercial airlines to demonstrate their confidence in the safety of air travel. Then we need the shot, the boost, the short-term, one-time incentive that says Americans can take a trip and save a job. We have two wars going on, a war on terrorism and an economic war.

Q. Was the decision to provide emergency aid to the airlines a dangerous precedent?

A. It was a legitimate move to save an absolutely essential industry that was on the brink of bankruptcy. We just believe that it was a short-term fix. With the package we are proposing, it is also clearly short term. We're asking for the federal government to jump-start consumer demand. The industry will compete for those dollars. The industry will start advertising again. No one is talking to the traveler about traveling. Instead, people are looking at how to reduce their costs. We've got to stop that before we have all those people on unemployment.

Q. If the government doesn't provide the kind of help you seek, what will the travel industry do on its own to survive?

A. You can still do promotions, but it doesn't give you the stimulus you need to get back at full force. There isn't any question that all of us will do what we can to create pricing that provides incentives. It could put a few heads in beds, which is great, but it really isn't enough and it's not soon enough. But if we were to do this tax incentive, it allows corporations to use some of the money they might use to create cash flow, to create advertising, to do the packaging and to keep the employees on the payroll.

Q. How long do you think it will take the travel industry to recover from this crisis?

A. If we could get the stimulus so that by Thanksgiving we have Americans getting back together for family reunions, certainly we could be back pretty close to normal by the end of 2002. If we could get the stimulus soon so that people can see that they should be investing their money in advertising and incentives, it could be back as early as the first or second quarter of next year. If there is military reaction or some further retaliation, that could dramatically impact things. But we cannot afford to sit back and wait. If we do, the fundamental fabric of our society will be put at risk. So many people in this industry will lose their jobs.

Q. The travel industry has survived for decades despite wars and other disasters. What's different now?

A. The industry has survived, but the industry has never been as significant a part of the global economy as it is now. Travel and tourism on a global basis generated $3.5 trillion in activity in 2000. That represented 12 percent of the global economic activity of the world. In the United States, we used to be an agrarian economy and then we were an industrial economy, and of course people traveled, but they didn't travel far; we didn't have the investment in infrastructure for travel. Travel and tourism has emerged as America's third-largest retail sales industry. Never in history has travel, tourism, hospitality or lodging accounted for such an enormous impact.

HEADLINE: After the Fall, A Tech Star Stays Scrappy 

BYLINE:  By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
SCOTT G. McNEALY came to New York last week for a product announcement, not a memorial service. 
 Yet before the audience of customers, industry analysts and journalists was told of Sun Microsystems' new computers on Tuesday, Mr. McNealy -- Sun's chairman and chief executive -- spoke briefly of Philip Rosenzweig. A software senior engineer and manager, Mr. Rosenzweig, 47, had worked for Sun for more than a decade. His only mistake, Mr. McNealy said, was that "he got on the wrong airplane," American Airlines Flight 11 from Boston on the morning of Sept. 11. As Mr. McNealy mentioned Mr. Rosenzweig's surviving wife and two children by name, his voice broke and he turned aside and sobbed. "I know thousands of people are lost," he said, "but it's so personal." 
 Mr. McNealy recovered quickly, and after a moment's silence in honor of Mr. Rosenzweig, he returned to computers once more. As Sun's president, Edward J. Zander, who next took the stage, explained, "We need to get back to business." 
For Sun and companies across the nation, that promises to be a struggle economically as well as emotionally. In the vast, diverse $10 trillion economy of the United States, there is no such thing as a truly representative company. But Sun, an innovative stalwart of the computer industry, was one of the companies that fueled the technology-led economic boom of the 1990's, and this year Sun has been leading the way again -- downward, as its business eroded abruptly and alarmingly while the economy veered toward recession, even before Sept. 11.
Sun's experience in the last few weeks, and the challenges it is now facing, are shared by much of corporate America. The landscape of business has been shaken, as if by an earthquake, though one of uncertain force. Consumer confidence and business investment have fallen sharply, but the outlook depends much on what political and military -- and possibly terrorist -- actions lie ahead. The virtual halt of business activity in the week immediately after the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon has passed, and companies and workers are indeed getting back to business. Still, it is by no means business as usual.
Like many companies, Sun has been hurt, even touched, by the tragedy, but not devastated. Its New York offices, far from the corporate headquarters in Silicon Valley, occupied the 25th and 26th floors of the south tower of the World Trade Center, and all of its 346 New York employees got out safely. Sun is also a major supplier of technology to the financial industry, including firms like Lehman Brothers, Merrill Lynch and Citigroup's Salomon Smith Barney, all of whom had offices that were destroyed or damaged.
So Sun's suddenly displaced workers dusted themselves off, then scrambled to get Wall Street up and trading again. At times, the company's sales and technical managers even drove trucks filled with replacement computers to clients trying to relocate and revive their operations. In the immediate aftermath of Sept. 11, the New York product introduction -- eventually held last week at the Hudson Theater in Midtown Manhattan -- had been scrapped. Sun had arranged to move the event to San Francisco. But after reflection, and prodded by Mr. Zander, a Brooklyn native, the Sun marketing team was persuaded to go to New York after all -- partly by leasing three private jets so that the staff, fearful for its security, would not have to fly on commercial airlines.
NOW, as the business climate worsens, Sun's executives must rethink their plans and probably retool the company, yet still try to maintain the loyalty and enthusiasm of the work force. Leadership, more than ever, is a delicate balancing act -- attending to the new worries of traumatized employees but also preparing them for the harsh business realities ahead.
Mr. McNealy did both in an afternoon meeting last Tuesday with Sun's work force in New York. At 46, he is known as a combative, outspoken executive given to glib insults aimed at rivals and their products (he calls Microsoft's Windows a "hairball" of software) and spirited declarations of his libertarian conservative views that extol the virtues of Darwinian capitalism. Friends and colleagues say that to understand Mr. McNealy's personality, it helps to note that his preferred recreation is hockey and, they add, to watch the way he plays. He just keeps shooting at the goal, always on the attack. He's tough, relentless and single-minded.
It was a different Mr. McNealy, though, who began the employees' gathering by observing that some of them had seen and lived through things that no one should have to experience. "Don't be hard on yourselves," he told them. "Give yourself time to heal, and understand that some these wounds may never heal.
"Remember, there are 40,000 people around the company who are dying to help in some way." Mr. McNealy continued. "Send an e-mail, reach out for help either professionally or personally. And include Eddie and me," he said, referring to Mr. Zander.
Mr. McNealy, who in 1982 helped to found Sun, spoke of the company as a "family" in a way that seemed heartfelt. "You're all my heroes," he told them. "I'm so relieved that you're all here and safe."
"This all makes an economic recession not so much to deal with," he said. "It sort of puts everything in perspective, huh?"
Later, Mr. McNealy shifted gears, addressing the effect of Sept. 11 on Sun's business. Things were bad before, and they were now certain to become worse.
Sun has weathered downturns in the past without shedding workers. Throughout this year, as one technology company after another announced layoffs and downsizing programs, Sun resisted. It held on to its 43,000 employees worldwide and maintained its research and development spending, the corporate seed corn for the future. Instead, Sun cut down on travel, off-site meetings and eliminated the free bagels and doughnuts on Wednesday mornings, a company tradition. It has pared its real estate expenses by consolidating offices and setting up thousands of employees to work mainly from home. It urged Sun workers to take extra, unpaid vacation.
Previously, Sun executives thought the steep fall in the business had bottomed out. Those hopes have been dashed. "That's one of the reasons I'm so mad about what's happened," Mr. McNealy told the employees.
"My last resort is taking people out of their jobs," he said. "It's not about the stock options anymore. It's about the medical coverage, the dental coverage, the salary, the self-respect and knowing that you're contributing."
After the quarter ends today, Mr. McNealy, Mr. Zander and Sun's other top executives will go over the financial results -- numbers that will certainly make grim reading. The executive team, Mr. McNealy explained, will then try to assess the outlook for the next three to six months. And, he said, they will make some "very, very tough calls."
"There is no policy at Sun that says no layoffs," Mr. McNealy said. "So go work hard. There are still a few days left in the quarter. Make some sales and ship it."
YET a flurry of orders in the last few days of the current quarter will not help Sun, or other companies, very much. The day after Mr. McNealy spoke, Laura Conigliaro of Goldman, Sachs sharply scaled back her estimates of Sun's financial results for the July-September quarter to levels that "even in my wildest nightmare I never would have imagined" a short time ago.
In the last few months, Ms. Conigliaro, a leading computer analyst who has followed Sun for years, had reduced her estimates of the company's sales for the quarter to less than $3.3 billion from $3.7 billion. Last Wednesday, she reduced her sales figure to $2.8 billion, and she now estimates that Sun will lose $210 million in the quarter. For comparison, Sun reported profits of $510 million on sales of more than $5 billion in the same quarter a year ago. On Sept. 28, 2000, Sun's stock closed at $61.81 a share. On Friday, a year later to the day, it closed at $8.27.
Layoffs, Ms. Conigliaro said, now appear inevitable. She does not expect Sun to return to profitability until the first quarter of 2002. Still, she sounds optimistic about Sun's long-term prospects. The company, she noted, supplies the computers and software that help power corporate computer networks and the Internet. Sun has emerged from recessions in the past, typically stronger than ever. Sun, she said, is a sound company, strategically, managerially and technologically. "This is an important company," she said, "and it will come back."
In the last few weeks, business all but came to a halt for Sun, as it did for so many companies.
Mr. Zander is the president, but also one of the company's most effective salesmen. In a sense, Mr. Zander and Mr. McNealy personify the aggressive sales culture at Sun, while Bill Joy, a founder and the chief scientist, represents the research culture at the company, which has delivered a steady stream of innovations, including Java, the Internet programming language.
Never in his career, the 53-year-old Mr. Zander recalled, had he experienced anything quite like the week after Sept. 11. "It was scary," he said. He returned from work one day and told his wife, Mona, "I don't think anybody on the planet is buying a computer." His calendar was totally clean, all executive-level appointments canceled by mutual consent. "It would have been bad taste to knock on doors and ask if they wanted to buy computers," he said.
In the last 10 days, however, Mr. Zander began making sales calls again, on the West Coast and in New York. In the first 15 to 30 minutes of each meeting, he said, each side would tell its story, how the business and its people had been affected by Sept. 11. But then, Mr. Zander said, the talks turned to how the big retailer, manufacturer, media company or government agency planned to deploy information technology in the future and what role Sun might play.
The days are gone when established companies invested in technology at a furious, if not thoughtless, pace out of fear that some Internet start-up might soon put them out of business. "People thought the Internet was a business, but it's not -- it's a technology," said Mr. Zander, whose company benefited enormously from the misconception. These days, the conversations with corporate executives are about how to use computing to streamline supply channels, tighten relationships with customers, cut costs and improve productivity.
In a recession, Mr. Zander said, companies will stretch out their spending plans. "But I am encouraged because what I don't hear is companies saying they are going to turn away from information technology and computers as a crucial tool of business," he said.
There will be a few difficult quarters ahead, he said, and perhaps it will be a year before strong growth returns. "But I still think this is a great industry that is going to grow faster than others," Mr. Zander said. "Nothing that has happened, not even this disaster, has changed that."
The one place where there was a sudden surge of business after Sept. 11 was on Wall Street. Sun's computers and software animate the stock and bond trading desks of many of the big brokerage houses and investment banks. Sun and its employees played a big role in getting Wall Street up and trading again within days of the attacks, from alternate sites after operations in Lower Manhattan were destroyed.
Merrill Lynch, a big Sun customer, had to have its replacement trading floor in Jersey City ready by Sunday morning, Sept. 16 -- for scheduled testing to ensure that trading on the New York Stock Exchange and Nasdaq could resume the next morning. The Sun account team scrambled to arrange for $15 million of equipment to be shipped in from around the country. To speed the deliveries from the West Coast, Sun put two drivers in each tractor-trailer, so that they could drive without stopping.
Some 40 desktop computers were pulled out of a Sun sales and engineering office in Burlington, Mass. With drivers in short supply and time running out, two people in the New York office, Leslie Maher, a sales manager, and Michael Yenke, a technical specialist, went to Massachusetts and drove the computer-filled truck to New Jersey themselves. They arrived in Jersey City at 5:30 a.m. Saturday.
Another Sun customer, Lehman Brothers, had its offices in the World Trade Center and its data center nearby. Lehman also had to set up a new data center in Jersey City, and Chris Wojie, a Sun manager, led a team of 15 people that, working with a reseller, delivered and installed $14 million worth of equipment -- more than 130 data-serving computers. At Salomon Smith Barney, a Sun team of 25, led by Irwin Morrisey and Steve Nichols, arranged for more than 100 Sun server computers to be shipped in and installed.
"There were no purchase orders or anything for those shipments," said Raymond Tellalian, a vice president in New York who is in charge of Sun's financial services unit. "Our people just went out and got it done. The billing and the paperwork could wait."
IN a crisis, the Sun employees were practicing an often-repeated credo at Sun: Better to ask forgiveness than seek denial. Occasionally, Mr. McNealy, a Harvard graduate with a Stanford M.B.A., has denied saying it. Yet anyone who has been at Sun a while regards it as an implicit tenet of its irreverent, entrepreneurial culture -- one nurtured by and reflected in Mr. McNealy, who, incidentally, named his son Maverick.
Last Thursday, Mr. McNealy ventured to the tip of Manhattan to call on a few customers. Mostly, he heard words of appreciation. "I can't say enough about what your people did," Don Alecci, a managing director of Citigroup's technology group, told him, "when you consider that they narrowly escaped a collapsing building themselves, and then worked around the clock to get our trading operations up and running again."
While walking through the financial district, Mr. McNealy offered his thoughts on what lies ahead. "It's going to be tough, personally, for a lot of people," he said. "And we're facing a tough couple of quarters, our company and the economy. But you've got to keep the faith. This economy is going to come back, and so is Sun. And every day that something bad doesn't happen, people are getting back to business -- dealing with life."
Later, Mr. McNealy went up to the barricades a short distance from the ruins of the trade center. The site was still smoldering, and an acrid smell hung in the air. Gazing at the devastation, he said: "Geez, that used to be our offices. Unbelievable. Makes you mad, doesn't it?"

HEADLINE: An Act Of Terror Reshapes The Globe 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL WINES

DATELINE: MOSCOW 

 BODY:
EN route to Spain to marry Prince Pedro of Castille in 1348, England's Princess Joan foolishly paused in plague-ridden Bordeaux, fell ill and died, dooming an English-Spanish alliance that could have remade Europe. A Serbian madman murdered an Austrian archduke in 1914, and the echoes of that deed -- World War I, an imperial carving-up of the Middle East, totalitarianism's rise -- still resound nine decades later.
 Tragedy is history's pivot. The question now, as a single breathtaking act of horror cracks old alliances and snaps together unlikely new ones in their place, is whether a modern madman has swung history onto a new axis, with ramifications far from his own intentions. 
 Underscore "whether," for this is, literally, history in the making. 
But to grasp how profound these tectonics are -- and how unpredictable -- look first at Moscow. It is no exaggeration to say that the events of Sept. 11 may be delivering what Peter the Great, the empress Catherine and President Boris N. Yeltsin could not: a Russian state anchored solidly in the West, for the first time in a millennium. By shattering the notion of a sole American superpower that could single-handedly build global stability and prosperity, those events may have removed the biggest obstacle to Russia's final integration with the West.
President Vladimir V. Putin, until now everyone's friend and no one's ally, jumped decisively off the fence last week with a string of offers to assist the Western-led campaign against terrorism. Most striking, he dropped Russian objections to the deployment of American and other NATO counterterrorism forces in Tajikistan, Uzbekistan and elsewhere in Russia's Central Asian sphere of influence.
A month ago, the notion of allowing American troops on former Soviet soil would have been politically suicidal; even after the Sept. 11 attacks, Mr. Putin's own defense minister declared it unthinkable.
Mr. Putin not only did it, but hinted that Russians might eventually join the battle, depending on how relations with the West develop. "Nobody has asked us," he told German journalists. "We can't be more Catholic than the Pope."
Mr. Putin, of course, was not being munificent. His commitments sprang from a calculation that suppressing terrorism furthers Russia's own interests -- particularly in Chechnya, where Islamic extremists lead a guerrilla revolt, but also along the nation's Muslim southern border, where extremism threatens to take root.
But that is exactly the point. Students of history who call themselves realists say that commitments based on vital interests, despite differences about ideals, can be the most profound.
And the Sept. 11 attack opened opportunities for Mr. Bush too. He and his advisers have long derided nation-building and the advancement of human rights abroad. Under President Clinton, those goals hurt relations with Russia, China and other less than democratic countries whose support the Bush administration now wants. Since Sept. 11, the logic of war has freed Mr. Bush to make those missions expendable as he pursues something the Russians can truly understand: a no-holds-barred fight against enemies.
Indeed, President Putin extracted a fee for Russia's support. Within days, the United States and Germany lined up behind a Kremlin demand that rebels in Chechnya lay down their arms, pointedly omitting the West's standard criticism of human-rights abuses there by Russian troops. The United States also hopes to accelerate Russia's admission to the World Trade Organization, the American trade representative, Robert O. Zoellick, said here on Friday.
Most of all, Mr. Putin himself has begun pushing publicly for a Western unthinkable: Russian admission to NATO. And while that seems unlikely any time soon, some other formal security arrangement between the West and Moscow seems likely -- and given the developing campaign against terrorism, desirable.
"I don't want to overstate it, to make it too poetic," Robert Legvold, a Columbia University historian and Russia scholar, said. "But this is the first time since Dec. 7, 1941, in which the United States and Russia have in fact had potentially a common enemy, which allows us to band together and overlook those things that divide us. In those days, very fundamental things divided us, and in the end we couldn't sustain the relationship. This may be the first case in which we have what might be called a transcendent common enemy." 
And, he might have added, no deep ideological fight over how to organize the human race.
The enemy has opened the way for reassessments in other alliances and rivalries around the world. Consider Pakistan, the American ally that essentially engineered the Taliban's rise to power in Afghanistan and now finds itself in an excruciating bind. Before Sept. 11, American policy there focused on one goal: averting nuclear war between India and Pakistan.
Since Sept. 11, nothing has been the same. India has come out forcefully against terrorism in Afghanistan. Pakistan, its military and intelligence ranks riddled with Taliban sympathizers, struggles to maintain its American alliance without triggering a coup or popular revolt. In Washington, economic sanctions stemming from the nuclear competition have been lifted, and even part of Pakistan's foreign debt burden eased. But how the new partnerships with Washington will complicate -- or perhaps clarify -- the long-range goal of pacifying the subcontinent is anybody's guess.
Or consider Iran. Long branded by Washington as the world's leading state sponsor of terrorism, Tehran turns out to have a redeeming quality: it despises Osama bin Laden and the Taliban's extreme fundamentalism almost as much as the United States does.
NOW, American policy makers have been debating whether to try once more to thaw relations with Iran. And Iran's theocratic rulers, for all their stinging words about America, have not ruled out joining an antiterrorist coalition, provided the United States does not lead it.
Or consider the former Soviet states that border Afghanistan -- Uzbekistan, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan and others -- many of which are racked by their own pro-Taliban insurgencies. Last July, a State Department official warned that their aid could be in jeopardy because many are led by autocrats. Since Sept. 11, Turkmenistan has opened its airspace to American humanitarian assistance to Afghanistan, and Uzbekistan, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan and Tajikistan have agreed to open airfields to Western military forces. 
Finally, consider the common element in these equations, the United States. Before Sept. 11, the White House had unilaterally abandoned or rejected a string of international accords and placed dues payment to the United Nations on a back burner.
Since Sept. 11, Congress has suddenly ratified the long-delayed nominee for ambassador to the United Nations and moved to pay arrears to the United Nations. Secretary of State Colin Powell, who stands out in this administration as a multilateralist, has swept past go-it-aloners to the forefront of American foreign policy. Missile defense seems to have lost its center-stage position at the White House.
In one way or another, the depth and permanence of these changes depend to a large extent on the United States and Russia. Mr. Putin appears to see Europe as Russia's eventual home, but Europe looks to the United States for guidance.
American-Russian relations have been adrift for at least eight years, plagued by Washington's deep mistrust of the Russian commitment to democracy and Moscow's bottomless suspicion that America seeks, in its heart, to rule the world.
That suspicion still runs deep in the Kremlin and in Russian society at large, and there is no guarantee that Mr. Putin can tame it. And Russia's alliance with the West could yet prove a feint.
On Washington's part, there is no guarantee that the White House can navigate a foreign-policy minefield in which too much prudence renders its war on terrorism impotent, and too little unleashes a backlash from Moscow and others against American hegemony.
Still, it is a moment to stand in awe before the potential for change. It is possible that a shared commitment to eradicating terrorism could override mistrusts and salve a host of other irritants -- including with China, which has its own problems with Islamic separatists and is a potential ally in any international campaign against terror.
Dmitri Trenin, a Carnegie Endowment scholar whose recent book, "The End of Eurasia," examines Russia's prospects for a westward turn, likens Russia's position now to Britain's after World War II.
The British came late to the realization that they were no longer an empire and could not conduct a global policy without American help. The events of Sept. 11, Mr. Trenin said, give Russia a unique opportunity to gracefully put aside its own superpower legacy and assume its new logical role: as an important, if junior, partner in a Western alliance stretching from Vancouver to Vladivostok.
"It's really a godsend situation, in which the Russians could turn to the West on an issue on which the West, Russia and China basically have the same position," he said. "This was a tragedy out of all proportion imaginable in the post-cold-war era. But if it leads us to take a more realistic view of ourselves and the world around us, then it would be truly historic."

HEADLINE: Under Siege, Chirac Gets Political Lift From Crisis 

BYLINE:  By SUZANNE DALEY

DATELINE: PARIS, Sept. 29 

 BODY:
Just weeks ago, President Jacques Chirac was looking beleaguered, heading into a re-election campaign with a pack of corruption-busting judges nipping at his heels.
 But all that seems like history, at least for now. The terror attacks in the United States have swiftly altered the political landscape here, sweeping scandal stories off the front pages and giving Mr. Chirac a political lift. 
 Rushing to Washington to meet with President Bush and then to New York to grieve with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, Mr. Chirac has been able to reinvigorate his presidential image and drive home his experience as an international player.
One national poll last week found that his popularity ratings had soared 17 points. Nearly 75 percent of those surveyed said they had confidence in his ability to handle the problems France might face. And political strategists say that the outcome of elections next March may be profoundly changed by the events of Sept. 11.
Members of Mr. Chirac's conservative Rally for the Republic party who have struggled in recent months to defend their leader in the face of mounting evidence of corruption when he was mayor of Paris were virtually gloating this week, saying that voters would be sure to notice that Mr. Chirac's likely opponent, the Socialist prime minister Lionel Jospin, has had little experience on the world stage.
"The game has completely changed," said Jean-Louis Debre , the leader of the R.P.R. in the National Assembly. "The French are going to be looking for a head of state now, not just a gang leader." 
Several newspapers here even carried articles saying that members of Mr. Chirac's entourage were now so sure of a big victory next year that they even had begun squabbling over which posts they wanted in the new government. "On the question of morale," one party official told the daily Liberation, "we no longer need to pump it up. "
The Socialists, on the other hand, are muttering to columnists that there is not much they can do right now. Criticizing the president in a time of crisis is unlikely to score them points in the eyes of the electorate. "It is just not our week," one of Mr. Jospin's advisers told Le Monde.
France holds presidential elections in March and parliamentary elections later in the year. If the same party is in charge of the presidency and Parliament, the president is a powerful figure. But if, as now, they are controlled by different parties, the prime minister has considerable sway, for instance over the economy. So Mr. Chirac and Mr. Jospin would aim to win the presidency and carry their party to control of Parliament. 
Mr. Chirac is not the only European leader to appear to be benefiting from the crisis. Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain and Chancellor Gerhard Schroder of Germany have both improved their political standing in recent weeks. 
But Mr. Chirac may be in the best position to benefit. Mr. Jospin has other problems, too, including an ever-worsening economic outlook, a messy internal fight in the French Green Party and what looks like the unraveling of his efforts to bring peace to Corsica. 
Mr. Chirac could still face new trouble on the scandal front. Investigators would like to question him about illicit party financing schemes, fake jobs for party officials and how he got some $400,000 in cash to pay for luxury trips for himself and his entourage in the early 1990's. A court is supposed to rule on his immunity from questioning next week. 
Mr. Jospin remains popular, though he now trails the president in most polls by 5 to 10 points. But the road ahead looks harder and harder for Mr. Jospin, who six months ago looked as if he might roll to victory on the strength of the government's successful management of the economy since 1997.
Since then, unemployment has started to rise again, and prospects of rosy economic growth have been clouded by a global economic slowdown.
The Green Party, a member of Mr. Jospin's governing coalition, is in turmoil, having chosen a presidential candidate, Alain Lipietz, who sinks further in the polls by the day. 
This week, party officials made it clear that they were trying to figure out a way to get rid of Mr. Lipietz, a former Maoist, but it was unclear who might replace him. The most likely candidate, Noel Mamere, who had hoped to be chosen as the candidate but lost to Mr. Lipietz, has said he is no longer interested.
Mr. Jospin's bold effort to 25 years of violence in Corsica began to look like it was falling apart this week. The nationalist parties, to protest recent arrests of militants, withdrew support for a plan that would have given the island limited autonomy in return for peace.
